PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Leonid Yakovich Lubman
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned shows:
1. Leonid Yakovich Lubman, electronics engineer, was born on 5 March 1936 in the Soviet Union.

2. He is believed to have been arrested on or about 29 August 1977 and to have been charged under Article 64 (a) of the RSFSR Criminal Code with Treason and Slander of the USSR and to have been sentenced to 13 years strict regime.
3. He is presently believed to be in Prison Camp 35, and it is believed that he is due to be released on 29 August 1990.

4. He has, whilst in prison, undergone extreme suffering and is in poor health and is grossly undernourished. He is believed, inter alia, to be suffering from stomach, lung and liver pain; intensive headaches and blackouts; hunger pains and partial paralysis.

Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should make a formal request to the diplomatic representatives of the USSR in Australia on behalf of the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia on humanitarian grounds for the immediate release of Leonid Yakovich Lubman.
And the petitioners, as is duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care for the Elderly
PETITION.PARA: Honourable the President and members of the Senate Assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Australia's population is ageing and most people require more health services as they grow older.
If open not-for-profit Health Funds are to be able to meet the costs of providing benefits to their older members at affordable rates, those costs need to be shared equitably.
Some Health Insurance organisations are being allowed to avoid meeting the health costs of sick and elderly people.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to take the necessary action to reverse rising cost trends and provide positive incentives to encourage all Health Funds to share the cost of health care for sick and elderly Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth that:

This petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the Senate to the continued Government interference in the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which has severely affected the viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide the quality and quantity of services to which we Australians have as a right.

Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to guarantee the provision of our adequately funded Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which ensures the availability of Pharmaceutical Benefits through local community Pharmacies.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Home Ownership
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Recent huge rises in mortgage interest rates have pushed the cost of buying their own home beyond the reach of most Australian families.

Those Australians already paying off home mortgages are now suffering severely and unfairly through increased mortgage payments or longer repayment times so that many will never pay off their mortgage and go further and further into debt unless interest rates fall substantially.

Now, therefore, your petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled require the Hawke-Keating government to cease its excessive reliance on high interest rates as its major economic policy weapon and instead to use other measures which would allow interest rates to return to levels that do not force most Australian home-seekers out of the housing market-and many Australians out of their homes-so that the traditional right of home ownership is returned to average Australian families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Economy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia calls upon Parliament to:
(1) Re-establish control over interest rates-and in particular those affecting housing, farming, and small business.
(2) Take action which enables the repatriation of our resources and heritage in the long-term.
(3) Ban the export of profits deriving from Australian-owned businesses and companies.
(4) Develop programmes to limit the vulnerability of the Australian economy to overseas influences.
(5) Enact the monetary means to develop and sustain an equitable internal economy, which properly reflects the natural wealth of our Nation.

(6) In the spirit of the above, generally guide our Nation towards a sustainable, humanitarian future-by evolving the regulatory means to deal with encroaching environmental problems, and social break-down. For example: the greenhouse effect, homelessness and drug-dependency.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Maintaining VHF Television Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The Petition of the undersigned residents of Tasmania respectfully showeth:
That the mountainous terrain and geography of Tasmania makes VHF television transmissions the most suitable for the State;
The more than 30,000 Tasmanians will have to purchase new television receivers and new antennae if commercial television in the State is forced to change from the VHF to the UHF band;

Your petitioners therefore request that the requirement by the Department of Transport and Communications to force Tasmania's two commercial television stations to change from the VHF to the UHF band by 1993 be immediately rescinded.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON HEALTH LEGISLATION AND HEALTH INSURANCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a select committee, to be known as the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance, be appointed to inquire into and report upon:
(a) the meaning of clause 10 of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989, (hereafter referred to as ``the Bill'');
(b) the implications of clause 10 of the Bill for the medical profession in general, general practitioners in particular, and various categories of patients;
(c) whether the Senate should approve of clause 10 of the Bill, or whether the clause should be amended, and if so, in what respects it should be amended;
(d) the effectiveness of the current health insurance industry structure, and in particular-
(i) the ability of Hospital Medicare to meet its two main objectives, namely accessibility and equity, and the type of restructuring which may be necessary to assist in this regard;
(ii) the role of the private sector in providing hospital care and whether the current health insurance industry structure supports that role;
(iii) the relevance of community rating in a system which has Hospital Medicare as an alternative to health insurance;
(iv) whether the Federal Government has a role in supporting a health insurance industry based on community rating and how it can provide such support;
(v) what kinds and levels of benefits should be provided by health insurance organizations and the extent to which benefits should cover hospital costs;

(vi) the level of contribution rates required to be set by funds having regard to their own administrative costs, benefits payable and the willingness of people to contribute to private insurance funds;
(vii) the rules governing benefit payments and portability of fund membership;

(viii) the expenses incurred by funds in administration and management, including the payment of benefits and the level of reserved needed to ensure the funds' ability to meet their liabilities to contributors;
(ix) the investment policies, overall management, administration and financial operations of funds in relation to their reserves and other contribution moneys;
(x) the extent of effective contributor representation in the administration and policy making of the funds;
(xi) current recruiting activities employed by the funds and the extent and form of competition between them that is desirable; and
(xii) whether the interests of contributors would be better served if there were a greater or lesser number of registered organizations.
(2) That the Committee consist of six members, to be nominated as follows:
(a) three to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(b) two to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate;
(c) one to be nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats.
(3) That the Committee may proceed to the dispatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(4) That the Chairman of the Committee be appointed by and from the members of the Committee.

(5) That the Chairman of the Committee may, from time to time, appoint another member of the Committee who is a non-government Senator, to be the Deputy-Chairman of the Committee, and that the member so appointed act as Chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.
(6) That, in the event of the votes on any question before the Committee being equally divided, the Chairman, or the Deputy-Chairman when acting as Chairman, have a casting vote.
(7) That the quorum of the Committee be three members.

(8) That the Committee and any sub-committee have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives, and the Committee have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations it may deem fit.

(9) That the Committee have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of three of more of its members, and to refer to any such sub-committee any of the matters which the Committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a sub-committee be a majority of the Senators appointed to the sub-committee.

(10) That the Committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the Committee with the approval of the President.
(11) That the Committee be empowered to print from day to day such papers and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.
(12) That the Committee report to the Senate on or before the first sitting day in September 1989.

(13) That, if the Senate be not sitting when the Committee has completed its report, the Committee may provide the report to the President, or, if the President is unable to act, to the Deputy President, and, in that event-
(a) the report shall be deemed to have been presented to the Senate,
(b) the publication of the report is authorized by this Resolution,
(c) the President or the Deputy President, as the case may be, may give directions for the printing and circulation of the report, and
(d) the President or the Deputy President, as the case may be, shall lay the report upon the Table at the next sitting of the Senate.
(14) That the foregoing provisions of this Resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.

SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of Senator Evans, I ask that Government Business notice of motion No. 1 be taken as formal.
—Is there any objection to this notice of motion being taken as formal?
—Not formal.
—It is not formal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Evans, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) condemns the massive and indiscriminate slaughter of thousands of unarmed Chinese pro-democracy demonstrators and bystanders by units of the Chinese People's Liberation Army in Beijing since Saturday, 3 June 1989;

(b) calls on the Chinese Government to cease this brutality and commence a process of open and democratic consultation with the Chinese people in order to avoid further bloodshed and violations of fundamental human rights;

(c) notes that the recent processes of economic liberalisation in the People's Republic of China, and the attendant benefit to the peoples of China and the region of those processes, cannot succeed in the face of the systematic repression of legitimate democratic aspirations; and

(d) recognises the work of diplomats and their staff who at times of trauma and difficulty are prepared to risk their personal safety to ensure that the lives of Australian citizens are not endangered.

I do not intend to speak to the motion at any great length because I think that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, has made the position of the Australian Government completely clear on the events that have occurred in China. I have very little doubt that at the end of this debate the chamber will carry the motion unanimously and, as such, indicate to the Chinese Government the attitude of all Australians to the events that have occurred in China. Over the last eight or 10 years we have all been very encouraged by the extent to which reform was occurring and the degree of openness that was occurring in China. I think we all anticipated that long term, the events would lead, inevitably, to the establishment of a democratic regime-an open society, a society with respect for the law.

The events of the last few days are a massive setback to the direction of the last eight to 10 years. It is an absolute tragedy when a government feels it necessary to use its armed forces to shoot innocent, unarmed demonstrators in the way that has occurred. The Australian Government has made very clear to the Ambassador of China, and by its statements, its absolute abhorrence of the events that have occurred in China and calls on the Chinese Government to abstain from these activities. We hope that, long term, not only will stability be restored but also the march towards democracy and freedom in China will continue, and that China will take its place very proudly among the rest of the nations of the world. The events of the last few days certainly give it a lot to be ashamed about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the motion. In fact, we had said that we would be prepared to have it called `formal' and simply vote upon it because, needless to say, we have been appalled by the bloodshed and the indiscriminate slaughter that have occurred in China in the last week or so. Recognising the economic reforms that have occurred in China over a period, we have been concerned as to whether they would stand the test of time without corresponding social and political reforms. That is a debate that perhaps we could have another day-a debate about whether Western powers, including Australia, have correctly read the evolving changes in China or perhaps have overestimated the extent of change and in some ways attributed a Western assessment, invalidly and prematurely, to those changes and formed a view that they were more significant, in our terms of moral behaviour-to use a rather emotive expression-than what was in fact occurring. As I said, that is certainly a debate for another day.

SPEECH.PARA: The extent to which the Government has been correctly advised in its assessment of these events in China is also a debate for another day. There is the question of whether the West generally, including Australia, has adopted the right policies to encourage sufficiently the evolvement of the forms of democracy which we believe are so important. We believe those forms of democracy and basic freedoms are important. We now find that the people of China also believe them to be important, but they have not had the opportunity to exercise them under the communist regime. These are important debates for another day.

We indicate our support, as part of the Parliament of this country, for this motion to condemn the massive and indiscriminate slaughter that has occurred and which calls upon the Chinese Government to cease this brutality and to enter into negotiations. As we said in our motion the other day, those negotiations should be with students, those who have been fighting and the representatives of those who have been prepared to give their lives for the sorts of values that we regard as so important for basic freedoms, such as freedom of speech. This motion notes that the processes of economic liberalisation that have occurred are important, but that they are only half the recipe. As we have noted, they will not stand without changes of a much more substantial nature in attitudes.

We support the motion. In doing so, we recognise the work that our diplomats do, not only in China, as in this instance, but in so many places throughout the world, in risking their lives to protect the interests and the lives of Australians. At times like this it is important that we note that because at other times they are taken for granted. For the reasons we have indicated, we support the motion, leaving to another day what is a much more complex debate as to the role Australia has played, could have played and could play in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make no apology for calling the motion not formal. It delayed the introduction of the motion by exactly 45 seconds. It is too important a matter to be dealt with simply by formal notice of motion-a motion is called formal when there is no debate-particularly as the motion was drawn up certainly not in consultation with me. I have seen the motion and, as motions go, it is a reasonable one, although one could quibble about whether the slaughter was indiscriminate. I would have thought that premeditated and very discriminate slaughter was undertaken by the 27th Army of the People's Liberation Army. It was quite deliberate, quite discriminate, and ordered by the power brokers in Beijing.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the main reasons that I asked for the motion to be declared formal was so that I could express some of the concerns I have that the lessons of this action may not even be heard by the Government, the Parliament or the democracies of the world. That is so, given their attitudes over the last 10 years since the fall of the democracy wall, given their attitudes to the Chinese leadership and given their failure to draw attention, time after time, to the violation of human rights in China. The euphoria that has swept the Western world over the so-called democratisation of trade in China has stifled the attempts of people to raise civil rights issues and the violation of human rights in China. I have felt the odd one out in this regard for the last 10 years. I have pointed out, on a number of occasions, the violations of civil rights and the undermining of respect for human life in China. That respect is the basis for a true recognition of all human rights and, of course, all civil and political rights, no matter which country we are talking about.

We should reflect upon the fact that this most recent manifestation of imperial leadership in China in respect of its citizens comes about 10 years after the democracy wall incident. The democracy wall incident occurred in 1979, and had a long lead period. I speak as one who has an interest in China and personal contacts who presumably are able to give me far more detailed information than the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) is able to get. The democracy wall incident in 1979 was, apparently, used by Deng Xiaoping as a means of consolidating his position vis-a-vis Hua. It involved, as we all know, criticism of the Gang of Four. We know that Deng Xiaoping had spent a period of time in the wilderness prior to that. As the campaign progressed it appeared to Deng that the demands of those protesting were broadening to include criticism of the state and of the communist rule of the state, including the violation of human, civil and political rights. It was at that stage that Deng ordered a crackdown and the movement was crushed. The crackdown was accompanied by widespread purges and imprisonment. Indeed, a report in 1983-I think it was-by Amnesty International adverted to a number of violations of human rights in China.

One has to ask what has happened in those 10 years. How many people have been executed in China during those last 10 years? Has that issue ever been raised in an effective manner with the Chinese authorities-raised on every possible occasion? These are the questions we have to ask ourselves. When the blood has been cleaned up in Tiananmen Square the problem will still be with us. It is up to the governments of free democratic countries to continually raise the violations of human rights in China, instead of constantly considering how much money they can get from this enormous source of trade. It is a very strange circumstance when many people are carried away by that sort of euphoria.
About two months ago there was an advertisement from Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) in the House Magazine. I understand that it was also in the daily press. It was headed:
When we were capitalist running dogs and the world was better dead than red, we saw future partnerships, not rhetoric.

I am convinced that Arvi Parbo, who is now Chairman of BHP, would not have seen that advertisement before it went in. He would have been rather more understanding of what that meant. The message that comes through is: do not raise human rights issues; let us get in and make a quid no matter what happens to the Chinese people; it is an internal affair of the Chinese. That attitude has even been stated here when I have raised matters such as the use of RU-486, the drug which was mainly developed for the Chinese Family Planning Commission. There was no international ethical evaluation of that. The Australian Government pays money to the program. I asked whether there was any international ethical evaluation of the program. The answer was no, because it was responding to the needs of the particular government-the Chinese Government in this particular regard. The Government funds the United Nations Fund for Population Activities (UNFPA) and financially supports the program in China. USAID said in its official declaration:
UNFPA participates in the management of a program of coercive abortion and involuntary sterilisation in the People's Republic of China.

We are paying money to the UNFPA. We have to consider these essential human rights issues before we willy-nilly accept the slogan that these are internal Chinese affairs. We have a large number of lessons to learn from this. I believe that unless we learn those lessons, democracy will not be inevitable in China. Violations of human rights in China will not stop.

I feel very strongly about this question, as I believe all honourable senators do. It has come to us very strongly in recent days but I believe that on every possible occasion we should raise these matters with dictatorship governments. Even though trade is flowing and there is a free-flow of people and a greater understanding of problems, we should never forget our responsibility as free democratic nations to raise not only issues of civil and political rights but also issues of fundamental human rights. Those rights will never ultimately be established unless there is a recognition of and respect for human life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not intended entering this debate. On behalf of my Party I express our wholehearted support for the motion moved by Senator Robert Ray for Senator Gareth Evans. I was moved to enter the debate by some of the remarks of Senator Harradine which I find quite extraordinary. The suggestion is wrong that he is the only one who has in fact raised human rights issues. I can see in the chamber, for example, Senator Puplick who I know on many occasions has raised these issues personally and has worked tirelessly in this matter. I know also of people on the Government benches who have done likewise. In fact, four weeks ago I was in China and on behalf of Amnesty International I raised issues about people who are imprisoned in China. Members of all political parties of every delegation that I have been with to China have raised those issues each time. I find it a most distressing thing that in a debate recognising the slaughter that is taking place we should have descended to a petty political exercise amongst ourselves in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have hoped that we could have joined together unanimously in a formal motion expressing-all members when they are in China and when they are speaking with the representatives of that country in Australia time and time again have expressed this view-our concern for human rights.

There is no other group of people from whatever party with whom I would prefer to be on this particular issue. I have seen no divisions whatsoever at any time in the strong support shown by everybody in every political party in this nation for human rights and at outrage at the violations that have occurred in China to date. These matters have been raised with the hosts on every occasion that I have been there. I hope that we will have unanimous support for this motion to express our concern, our profound distaste for and our condemnation of what has been the most extraordinarily massive and indiscriminate slaughter of those people fighting for one thing only and that is the right to have their country run by their own people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will support the motion. But I make the point that since the motion was moved yesterday things have moved on at speed. The Army has been mobilised and has split, and the slaughter is going on. Senator Harradine raised some important points. He is not the only one to have raised them over some years. I have had the good fortune to visit China twice, once in 1974 on a private trip with the Australian Institute of International Affairs and once with a delegation led, Mr President, by your predecessor, Senator Douglas McClelland. There were vast changes in China between the visits. It has gone from having the world's poorest and most struggling people to a society that has a chance of getting on in the world.

SPEECH.PARA: China had its original revolution in 1949 when Mao Zedong took over. In 10 years the country was on its beam end. It had the Great Leap Forward. In another 10 years the Great Leap Forward had not got off the ground, so China had the Cultural Revolution; but that did not cause any prosperity for it. So it had a campaign of persecution against Lin Biao and Confucius. That did not help and so China had a campaign of persecution against the Gang of Four. And so it has gone on.

The significant thing about all these putsches to reinstate the fervour of the socialist revolution is that the time between them has become less and less. It was quite obvious that at some time the people were going to revolt against the oppression. This motion calls for the Government of Red China to stop what it is doing. The Government in China is fighting for its life. The fact that the Army is split in the way in which it is shows the desperation of the struggle. The people, of course, are struggling for their freedom. It will not stop.

Honourable senators will be aware from history that nearly every country that has fought for democracy has had to go through a monumental revolution. Even Britain had to do that. Brother fought brother, father fought son and the king wound up getting beheaded. The United States had a civil war where the same thing happened; the French had a revolution; and China looks as if it is destined for that. Certainly we can support the sentiments of the motion. I think the split in China goes a lot deeper than we realise at the moment.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented by Senator Macklin. I had no intention of reflecting on the actions that have been taken by members of parliament. What I was referring to-I hope I am sustained by what I thought I was referring to-was that, given the euphoria of trade and the acceptance by the community of what was happening in China, one felt somewhat embarrassed in raising these human rights issues in the public arena in Australia. I certainly did not want to reflect-I hope that honourable senators did not take it as a reflection-on anybody in the chamber.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Robert Ray)-by leave-proposed:
That for the remaining stages of the Senate's consideration of the following Bills, the Bills be taken together:

Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1989, Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989, Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1989, Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1989, Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1989, Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1989, Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 and Bounty (Ships) Bill 1989.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion, if passed, may result in these Bills being hastened through the chamber. But then again, this may not be the case. I will speak to this formal motion in order to lay something on the table. As I understand it, there may be a move to bring back before the Senate the superannuation tax package of Bills after the Customs package of Bills has been dealt with. I feel that that would not be appropriate. I for one do not know what amendments we will be faced with in the superannuation package. I have read in the press of arrangements that have been made between the Australian Democrats and the Government. I do not know what those arrangements are. The Table Office does not have a copy of the amendments; I do not have a copy of the amendments; no-one seems to have a copy of the amendments other than the Minister and the Democrats. I think it would be unfair-I hope the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) understands this-for us to have to consider in detail any amendment without having sufficient time to have a look at it prior to the debate coming on.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1989CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL 1989CUSTOMS TARIFF (COAL EXPORT DUTY) AMENDMENT BILL 1989CUSTOMS TARIFF (URANIUM CONCENTRATE EXPORT DUTY) AMENDMENT BILL 1989CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1989SUBSIDY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1989BOUNTY (SHIPS) BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 and 6 April and 3, 5, 25 and 26 May, on motions by Senators Robert Ray and Button:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has agreed to debate a package of six Bills-in reality there are eight Bills-as a block in a cognate debate. The Opposition did not vote against that. First of all, we do not have the numbers to turn the Senate around and, secondly, we recognise the mess that the Government has got the legislative program into and the need to finish in time.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to put on record that the motion really abuses the whole concept of a cognate debate because we agree to a cognate debate where Bills are similar. We have before us eight Bills which have no similarity at all. They range from a diesel fuel rebate Bill to a customs tariff amendment Bill dealing with shipping containers and top crude oils, another customs tariff Bill on beer and liquefied petroleum gas, a coal export levy Bill, a sugar Bill, a uranium concentrate Bill, a subsidy Bill for farm equipment and a bounty Bill on ships. There is nothing linking any of those Bills together. It is an abuse of the cognate system, an abuse of the Senate and an abuse of the Parliament.

Four of those Bills are of significant political importance to the Australian community. The diesel fuel rebate Bill, the coal export levy Bill, the uranium concentrate Bill and the sugar Bill, which is the sequence to the abolition of the embargo, all have great political significance not only for the Liberal and National parties but also for the Australian Labor Party. The Parliament is entitled to have some time to debate them. Instead, we have an hour, which works out roughly to a little over three minutes to cope with each of these Bills. Being the shadow Minister for Customs, the person responsible for the Liberal and National parties' approach to the Bills, I want to put on record the total inadequacy of the system we are faced with.

Let us deal with the Bills in series. The first is the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1989. The Opposition will not be opposing this Bill. The Bill proposes amendments to the Customs Act 1901, the Excise Act 1901 and the Customs Administration Act 1985. The principal amendments in the Bill relate to the diesel fuel rebate scheme which was announced on 3 March 1989. The proposal to alter the diesel fuel rebate scheme contained in this Bill includes amendments to improve its administration and to correct anomalies in the coverage of activities eligible for rebate. The diesel fuel rebate provides rebate on either customs or excise duty at varying rates for diesel fuel purchased for specified categories of off-road use-namely, in mining and primary production, residential premises and medical institutions.

This Bill reverts to the situation which existed prior to 2 October 1987. A whole host of rebate claims were made prior to October 1987. These will now be able to be claimed after the announcement on 3 March 1989. But in between there is a veritable no-man's-land where no claims can be made. The Opposition would very much like to know in the committee stage how the Government can justify the discriminatory action of inflicting different requirements on the industry at different points in time. I am advised that some of the mining companies miss out to the extent of up to $800,000 in some cases because of this illogicality, this gap in the payment of rebates. I look forward to the explanation from the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in due course in the committee stage.

The second Bill before the Senate is the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989. Again, the Opposition supports this Bill. The principal amendments in this Bill relate to the treatment of transport containers and topped crude oil. The Bill also contains some minor amendments which relate to the introduction of harmonised tariff classification and makes a complementary amendment in line with changes to the Excise Tariff Act, which is part of this debate also, concerning the beer provisions in the next Bill.

The tariff amendments in this Bill are a consequence of a number of factors, including Budget decisions, consideration of various Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) reports and Government policy. In the case of top crude oil the amendments reflect the Government's desire not to let an estimated $14m slip from the revenue pool. This $14m is the amount which the Government has estimated it could lose if steps are not taken to tighten the position of revenue gained from the tariff on crude. Presently, all crude oil is not subject to tariff. A tariff is payable on the refined products. The potential revenue effect arising from crude oil not being sent to local refiners but instead being used for other purposes, such as fuel oil, means that it would be possible for the Treasury to miss out on excise payments which the Government estimates could reach up to $14m a year.

The other major amendment in this Bill relates to the tariff on shipping containers. At present containers attract a tariff loading of 30 per cent. Following the IAC report on transport containers which was released in February 1988, the Government has accepted that the 30 per cent tariff be removed. The IAC concluded that the current rate of duty was distorting the allocation of resources and was resulting in Australian customers for containers paying a higher price than necessary. This situation is further complicated by the containers convention, which places restrictions on the use of international containers in domestic trade. The Australian National shipping line is one of the major sources of containers and it has estimated that the amendment to the Act will save it about $1m a year. There are other industry estimates which suggest that the removal of this tariff will provide, collectively, benefits up to a value of about $9m a year.

The other amendments to this Bill are basically in line with the harmonisation of tariffs, and they range from the removal of a high rate of duty on embroidery sewing kits-a reduction to 15 per cent-and the introduction of a new tariff barrier of up to 15 per cent on the production of Australian manufactured large hand-held sprays. There are a few minor areas which deal with carpets and hand-held machinery.

The Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1989 deals with amendments to enable customs duty on certain imported goods to be collected at the time of importation, to alter the excise duty on naturally occurring liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), and to impose excise duty on top petroleum crudes as a consequence of the preceding Bill. Again, the Opposition will not be opposing this Bill. Three proposals of note are the excise changes in relation to low-alcohol beer, liquefied petroleum gas, and top crude.

The Opposition supports very much the reduction of excise duty on low-alcohol beer. One of the distortions that have taken place in Australian drinking habits has been a preference for spirits because beer, quite simply, has been inflated out of its normal price range. If people are going to drink, particularly people who are starting to drink such as adolescents in the 16- to 20-year-old bracket, I argue very strongly, as I have in the past in this chamber, that the Government should provide an incentive in the form of reduced excise loading on beer to people to drink beer rather than spirits. I am very alarmed about the way we have, in the last 15 to 20 years, seen very sophisticated television inciting and inviting young and immature drinkers, because of the high glamour depicted on television, to drink things such as Bacardi and Tia Maria, which contain very high levels of alcohol. They are drinks which, by their very nature, are mixed with tonic water, soda water, orange juice, and so on, which disguise their true flavour.

I am concerned at the way the importers of these spirits are leading young people to believe that it is smart and desirable to drink these very high alcohol content drinks. My objection is that inexperienced drinkers simply do not know the alcohol content of what they are drinking, and that beer is to be preferred because it is the drink of moderation. Most people, particularly with the introduction of the new low-alcohol beers, reach satisfaction before they reach inebriation. Given the enormous cost and devastation that alcohol in excess does to this society, the Government has a public duty to provide an incentive in the form of a lower duty rate on beer. I say again that, whatever people might think of beer, beer is the drink of moderation in the alcoholic regime.

This Bill will provide for a lower rate of duty on the low-alcohol beers, which are now making big inroads into the beer-drinking market. But I am not sure that in the competition from wines and spirits, the beer-drinking market is recovering the place that it enjoyed 20 or 30 years ago.

In passing, I note that the cost of alcohol abuse in Australia is about $1.5 billion a year. About 40 per cent of road deaths are associated with alcohol consumption. In 1987 alone, Australians spent $7,098m on alcohol-almost as much as we spend on our defence budget. It is comparable with our education budget at the Federal level. It is a huge amount of money.

The next amendment in this Bill deals with changes in excise in relation to LPG. That is basically a technical matter. The Opposition welcomes the change but we believe that complete deregulation of the liquefied petroleum gas market would be a greater industry incentive to increase availability of supply, to prolong the availability of the gas beyond the next decade and to ensure its efficient allocation. We would move for more deregulation in that field.

The next Bill, the Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1989, deals with the blending of low grade coals with higher grade coals to satisfy market requirements. In 1984 the Government provided an exemption from export duty for high quality coking coal, which was blended with underground and open-cut coal, providing that on average there was at least 15 per cent of the underground coal in the blended coal and all of the resulting blend was produced from the same mine. The exemption also applied to high quality coking coal produced at the same mine where at least 15 per cent of the total production of exported coal on average had been produced from underground mines. The effect of these provisions was that in the Bowen Basin in Queensland, at Moura and South Blackwater high quality coking coal blends were exempt from export duty if exported as a single blend. They lost that exemption if further blended with coals from other mines before export. This Bill will extend the existing exemption from export duty where high quality coking coal is blended with coal from other mines before export.

The origins of the Coal Export Bill go back to 1975 and the infamous Rex Connor when the Australian coal market was expanding very rapidly. There were some very big profits to be made, particularly from the Queensland fields with their efficient, low cost production. Those days are long past. The coal market is now intensely competitive and the imposition of excessive freight rates as a taxing vehicle, as occurs in some of the States, particularly in Queensland, and the imposition of a customs tariff coal export duty severely operate against the national interests of our export sales. On this side of the Parliament we would like to see these coal export levies abolished in the interests of the coal industry and in the interests of Australia's export trade. We certainly support this Bill, which is extending the entitlement to exemption for coal export duties to those mines.

The next Bill is the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1989. On behalf of the Opposition, I have an amendment in relation to the motion for the second reading, which reads:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate is of the opinion that the Government should be condemned for:

(a) imposing a discriminatory levy upon one operation alone at a time when Australia's uranium exporters are struggling to remain competitive in the international market and are already overburdened by excessive taxes and charges; and
(b) its ideological approach to the development of Australia's uranium industry which has resulted in an economically absurd `three mine policy' ''.

The Uranium Concentrate Export Duty Bill imposes an increased duty on exported uranium mined in the Alligator Rivers region from $1.02 per kilogram to $1.15 per kilogram. I noted that on page 311 of Budget Paper No. 1 a further increase is proposed. It covers the increase we are discussing here and then talks about an increase to $1.30 per kilogram from 1 July 1989.

A duty was imposed on the exported uranium concentrate mined in the Alligator Rivers area by the Customs (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Act 1980. Funds raised through the duty are used to finance the operation of the Office of the Supervising Scientist, which is responsible for monitoring, controlling and conducting research into the environmental effects of uranium mining in the area. As a sideline, it is interesting that at the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd operation at Coronation Hill, which is also covered by the Supervising Scientist, BHP makes no contribution at all. The sole producer in the region, Ranger, has to pay for the environmental supervision of the Coronation Hill gold prospect in its exploratory stages under this legislation. The duty is quite significant; it is about 5 per cent of the operating costs for Energy Resources of Australia Ltd which is the operator of Ranger. This is not an inconsiderable impost on an industry which is struggling against the great fratricidal warfare going on in the Australian Labor Party which is having a most detrimental effect on Australia's uranium export industry.

We live in a very polluted world. One of the huge pollutants of this world is the burning of fossil fuels. No matter how many scrubbers we put on the exhaust chimneys of thermal power stations burning coal, we still end up with carbon dioxide; we end up with a considerable amount of nitrous oxides; and, to some degree, depending on the nature of the product and the efficiency of the scrubbers, we end up with sulphur dioxide. Millions of tonnes of pollutants go into the atmosphere from the combustion of coal. Inevitably, the world will have to move to a cleaner and safer form of production. That form of production, given present technology, must be atomic power stations. There is no alternative.

It is interesting to note in the technical literature at present the development of a second generation of atomic power stations. We have been through the first phase during the last 30 to 40 years, where we have dealt with very big units at very high costs. In the Western democracies, they have had a predictable and safe performance. This has not been so in the Soviet economies, but it has certainly been the case in the West. We have been free from great accidents such as that which occurred at Chernobyl. Now technology has advanced into the phase two stage and we are looking at power units which can be at least a third, and possibly a tenth, of the size of the huge mega-stations which were once required to be built for the nuclear generation of electricity. Not only has there been a great shrinkage in the size of stations, but also there has been a commensurate reduction in capital costs. There have been great increases in safety because passive safety measures have been developed in the light of the engineering experiences of the last 30 to 40 years.

The world is on the brink of a huge expansion into the nuclear generation of power which will be safe and cheaper than coal-fired stations. That, in itself, has implications for Australia with respect to its coal exports. But we have the greatest proven deposits of uranium in the world at the lowest cost of extraction. There is an enormous market for Australia if we get into that market now. We do not have a monopoly. Other countries can come in. Yet this Government is at war within itself-the Left versus the Right versus the Centre and the unity factions and all the other factions the Labor Party has manufactured. We have a very bad reputation internationally. When one makes an investment in nuclear power houses, with the amount of money that is involved, one has to be able to look not only 10 years ahead, but also 20, 30, 40 years ahead. One has to know that supplies are going to be delivered on time and on price. This Government's behaviour over the last six years-with members fighting amongst themselves and with the Party not being able to resolve a simple, fundamental, management issue, namely the production of a fuel that the world needs-is working very much against Australia's national interest.

The next Bill we are debating is the Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill 1989, which is designed to terminate the Subsidy (Cultivation Machines and Equipment) Act 1986 and the Subsidy (Grain Harvesters and Equipment) Act 1985. This Bill has its origins in the April economic statement. The termination of these assistance schemes will result in a saving to the Government of $19m during 1989 and $10.4m during 1990-91. Whilst the Bill is obviously favourable for the Government, it does not do much for the industry operating in an environment of total unpredictability. The industry was told some time ago that this bounty would stay on grain harvesters and farm equipment. In the April statement the ground was cut from under its feet. The Bill contains an amendment to provide a transitional period. Again, the Opposition does not oppose the legislation.
I seek leave to move two amendments together.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1989:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate is of the opinion that the Government should be condemned for:

(a) imposing a discriminatory levy upon one operation alone at a time when Australia's uranium exporters are struggling to remain competitive in the international market and are already overburdened by excessive taxes and charges; and
(b) its ideological approach to the development of Australia's uranium industry which has resulted in an economically absurd `three mine policy' ''.
In respect of the Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill 1989: At end of motion, add `` , but the Senate condemns the Government for:
(a) its pre-emptory action in terminating the bounties without notice; and
(b) its disregard of the need for certainty and predictability in industry policy; and
calls on the Government to introduce as quickly as possible the proposed new policy initiatives promised in the April statement''.

The next Bill we are considering is the Bounty (Ships) Bill 1989. The Government has notified the industry that the bounty will be phased out and it has given it a forward termination date. The Opposition will support this Bill but we will move an amendment in the committee stage which is aimed at changing clause 17, which deals with the registration criteria. This Bill is very much a compromise. The Bounty (Ships) Bill is not a new Bill, but it is effectively a successor to the Bounty (Ships) Act 1980, which is soon to expire.

The purpose of the Bill is to provide bounty assistance to the shipbuilding industry for the period 1 July 1989 to 30 June 1995, with the bounty being phased down in that time. It reflects the Government's policy announced in November 1988 following the consideration of the IAC report entitled Ships, Boats and Other Vessels. Under the provisions of this Bill it is proposed that shipbuilders who meet the registration criteria and who construct or modify bountiable vessels in Australia will be eligible to claim bounty for their eligible costs, with rate of bounty paid at that cost dependent on which cost was incurred by the shipbuilder. That sounds very complicated, but it happens to be what the legislation provides.

A bounty has been paid to the ship building industry for almost 40 years. The current scheme has applied since 1980. In 1988 the IAC undertook a review of the industry, and this Bill is based on its recommendations. It recommended that the removal of import restrictions be undertaken; that the continuation of bounty assistance for ship construction and modification for domestic sale be phased down from 19 per cent to 15 per cent by 1992 for prescribed vessels, and continuing at 15 per cent for other than prescribed vessels, with certain provisions; the continuation of bounty until 1993; and payment of bounty only on completion of the vessel. The Government has not accepted all of those recommendations. In the face of the IAC recommendations, the Government proposed to phase out bounty on all eligible construction and modification for the export and domestic markets over a six-year period. However, it has agreed to remove import restrictions.

A major concern is the Government's proposals concerning registration, which have become more restrictive. I will continue my remarks on this topic in the committee stage. A major provision of the Bill is an interpretation section-clause 4. Clause 5 specifies which costs incurred by a shipbuilder in the construction or modification of a bountiable vessel are eligible to receive bounty. Clause 6 relates to the determination of costs of construction and modification. Part 2 of the Bill concerns the bounty itself, and prescribes the eligibility conditions, circumstances where bounty is not payable, and the rate of the bounty. The rate of the bounty is 15 per cent from July 1989 to June 1991, 10 per cent from July 1991 to June 1993 and 5 per cent from July 1993 to June 1995, when it will be terminated.

Part 3 of the Bill concerns the payment of bounty and part 4, which is entitled `Administration', concerns the registration of crown securities and so on. Currently, registration criteria are prescribed by regulation. However, the criteria have been included in the body of the Bounty (Ships) Bill. There are three newer, modified registration criteria which set out that at least 75 per cent of the applicants' activities will be devoted to the construction or modification of vessels which are bountiable; that applicants must employ at least 40 persons, in contrast to the current specified requirement of a minimum of 20 persons; and that applicants will have to submit a business plan. Part 5 of the Bill permits the making of regulations as required by the Act.

The final Bill we are considering is a very important one-the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1989. In a way, it is the end of a saga of mismanagement by this Government. It is particularly important to all Queensland senators. I would like to quote the statement of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin. On 12 May 1989-within the last four weeks-he said:
I am pleased to announce that after a year of grandstanding and political opportunism, often by people who would not know sugar from salt, the new arrangements have been completed.

If there is one person who should not have made that statement it is the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The sugar embargo-the prohibition on the importation of sugar into this country-which has been so important to such a large industry, was handled by Mr Kerin and this Government in an absolutely scandalous manner. The announcement came out of the blue. The industry has always recognised that the prohibition of sugar imports had to expire at some stage. But the Government, without warning and consultation, dropped this decision on a very big and important industry. There is no way that can be justified. At the time Mr Kerin said that he was too busy to talk with this industry-one of the biggest industries in Australia, but the Minister simply did not have time to talk with its members. If anyone has grandstanded or operated in an opportunistic way, it has been Mr Kerin, on behalf of the Labor Party. The price for that negligence, arrogance and incompetence will be exacted at the next Federal election in the sugar seats in Queensland currently held by the Labor Party.

The abolition of the sugar embargo was accompanied by a statement that certain tariff protection would be provided. That tariff protection operated in a way that gave no defence to the industry when it was most vulnerable. The Opposition, in this chamber, referred the matter of the form of protection the industry should have to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology for inquiry. The Committee made its recommendations. It advanced the case of the sugar industry considerably. But at the end of the day, the Senate Committee's recommendations were not practical because they compromised the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and could not be implemented. Building on the Senate Committee's recommendations, the Government and the Opposition have now come up with a specific rate of duty for sugar which is acceptable to the industry and which will be beneficial.

The legislation before us proposes to terminate the Sugar Agreement Act 1985 and to lift the sugar import embargo. It places a fixed tariff on most sugar products of 11.5c a kilogram, phasing to 7c a kilogram protection by 1 July 1992. The Bill provides for a 5 per cent tariff discount for developing countries: Papua New Guinea and the Forum island countries. The sugar trade between Australia and New Zealand will be free of any tariff. The Bill would expose the Australian refined sugar industry to competition from this source because sugar could be imported by New Zealand duty free-there is no tariff on it there-could be refined and then sold on the Australian market. The protection for the Australian market is the incompetence of this Government in handling the Waterside Workers Federation and the Seamen's Union of Australia. The freight costs across the Tasman are so high they form a natural protective barrier for the Australian industry. However, because of the very high costs of transport in Australia we will be in the ridiculous position that it will be cheaper for Western Australians to import sugar from Mauritius or Thailand than to buy it from Queensland, where it is produced.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The package of Bills we are dealing with is quite extensive. I intend to address only three of those Bills-the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1989, the Bounty (Ships) Bill 1989 and the Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator MacGibbon drew out several important features in his remarks which underlie consideration of two of these matters; namely, the use and export of coal and the use and export of uranium. He argued in a somewhat illogical way that we should not increase the tariff on uranium because the industry was in dire straits. Yet, at the same time, he seemed to be arguing that we should be expanding that industry because somewhere down the track it will become extremely profitable for Australia. The Australian Democrats do not accept that view. We point to, and we underscore, the lack of profitability of the uranium industry at the present time. I understand there is an announcement in today's press that, following a public referendum in California, a further nuclear power station has been closed down because of the very high costs of that form of energy.

I will pick up that point for a moment. Senator MacGibbon and others in the Opposition repeatedly seem to emphasise that nuclear energy will be the fuel which will address the important environmental problems which we face, such as the greenhouse effect. They do not seem to have read the very extensive literature which gives very good reasons why that is simply not the case. Those arguments bear on both coal exports from Australia-which is the subject of one of the Bills we are dealing with-and the uranium concentrate customs tariff. When the increase in the price of oil occurred throughout the world in the early 1970s, one would have expected that if nuclear energy was a suitable substitute for fossil fuels, the demand for nuclear electricity would have increased. But what did we observe? Not only was there a downturn in the consumption of fossil fuels, as we learnt to use them more efficiently, but also there was a very considerable downturn in the building and ordering of nuclear power stations. Since that time there have been no new orders for nuclear power stations in the United States of America. The stations which have been coming on-line were ordered and have been under construction since the mid-1970s.

In an economy which is directed towards perpetual growth, there is a positive and not a negative link between the consumption of fossil fuels and the perceived need to build nuclear power stations. In other words, the consumption of fossil fuels increases as we move towards building more nuclear power stations, and there are very good reasons for that. If there is a demand in the economy for more electricity and that is met by nuclear sources, those industries which use the electricity and those industries which serve both the electricity industry and the other industries which will use the electricity, are largely dependent upon fossil fuels. For instance, the mining of the uranium ore itself is normally carried out with devices which use fossil fuels. Fossil fuels are used to transport the ore. The industries in the major centres which use the electricity which is generated will use fossil fuels to transport their raw materials to factories. While they may use nuclear generated electricity within the factory, the transport of those goods away from the factory also involves the use of fossil fuels.

This subject was very closely explored as long ago as the mid-1970s by the so-called Flowers Commission, which published the sixth report on the environment in the United Kingdom and which dealt specifically with nuclear power. It posed the question in a somewhat different form and asked: what is the likelihood of the advent of nuclear power and the use of nuclear power in advanced industrialised countries releasing fossil fuel for less developed countries? It came to the clear conclusion that that was extremely unlikely, that the need for very large up-front capital expenses for the building of nuclear power stations would place such a demand on the economies in these countries that their consumption of fossil fuel would in fact increase. It pointed to the need for a political will to reverse both the demand for fossil fuel and the demand for energy generally if less developed countries were going to get greater access to fossil fuel at a lower cost.

I do not know whether Senator MacGibbon is aware of a quite extensive paper produced by two American researchers, Keepin and Katz, who have looked at the relative costs of developing technologies which would use the available energy far more efficiently. They compared those costs with the costs of going down the nuclear road as a way of addressing problems like the greenhouse effect. The figures come out something like this: the efficiency road is about seven times more cost effective, dollar for dollar, than going down the nuclear road. According to their estimate, for every $100 spent on building nuclear power stations rather than on increasing the efficiency with which conventional fuels are used, approximately one tonne extra of carbon dioxide goes into the atmosphere. So building nuclear power stations directly contributes to the addition of carbon dioxide to the atmosphere and increases the greenhouse effect for a variety of reasons.

What we derive from these analyses is that we need to be moving very firmly towards greater efficiency in the use of energy, and there are considerable technologies available to do that. But what do we find in these Bills, particularly the coal Bill? We find the Government looking backwards and attempting to keep the levy on coal low in a desperate attempt to export more coal. The Government clearly has no ability to look to the future and allow the longer term considerations to be fed into determining policy with respect to fossil fuels or to modify policy to develop those technologies which in the future will be of economic benefit to Australia. For instance, if the world recognises that there is a severe problem with greenhouse warming, with the addition of carbon dioxide to the atmosphere, and moves towards greater fuel efficiency, then clearly the demand for coal, including Australian coal, will fall still further.

What do we do then with those industries which we have artificially supported for longer than they needed to be supported? It leaves our coal industry and Australia in an even worse plight. Rather than further subsidise an industry which clearly is not able to compete while it pays the full levy, I suggest that the Government and Australia, as a nation, would be far better advised to put that money into developing more efficient ways of utilising energy. They are the technologies which will be demanded within the next one or two decades. Not only would we get advantages in terms of increased fuel efficiency, lower costs, decreased emissions of greenhouse gases, which benefit everybody, but also we would put ourselves in the forefront of new technological developments which the world will be needing and demanding.

Unfortunately, this Government is looking backwards. In looking at the coal legislation, it is interesting to note that the Government seems to recognise that in a competitive market situation the price of our coal needs to be kept lower so that we can maintain our exports. Coal is also being exported by a number of less developed countries, so by doing that we are directly competing with those countries and putting them in a less viable situation at a time when we should be providing more help in an attempt to increase equity in this world.

The Australian Democrats are very concerned about the Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Amendment Bill, which seeks to extend further the alleviation of the coal levy with respect to certain coals-in effect, to subsidise coal, although the Government would deny the use of that term. I am reminded that just the other day the Opposition asked a question about the gold tax and the Government was careful to point out that it was putting a similar tax on gold producers to that applying in other industries; it was simply bringing the gold production industry into line with other industries. In this case the Government clearly is moving in the other direction and, I believe, for the wrong reasons.

In relation to the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill, I note that the Government has accepted the logic of the argument which I used last year when the levy was increased and has now further increased the levy, making it much closer to covering the total cost of the Supervising Scientist in the Northern Territory. This is completely justified, strongly supported and long overdue. The levy should have been made to cover the environmental consequences of uranium mining in that environmentally sensitive area. The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) referred in his second reading speech to the environmentally sensitive nature of Kakadu National Park.

Senator MacGibbon asserted that nuclear energy is safer than fossil fuel. He is apparently unaware of the work of Pohl, an American health physicist, who calculated the long term health consequences of uranium mining, arising from the release of radon gas from tailings. His calculations show that the number of deaths from cancer arising from that radon gas is essentially the same as the number which would arise from mining coal to provide an equivalent amount of energy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that an open-cut or underground mine?

—This was an open-cut mine: it was from the open tailings on the surface. The difference is that the effect of radon releases extends for hundreds of thousands of years into the future and the resultant deaths are spread out over a long time, whereas those who are killed in coal mines belong to the generation which enjoys the benefit of the electricity. Some people would argue that we can discount future deaths. That is not a position taken by the Democrats. We would argue that it does not matter whether a death occurs in this generation or 10 or 100 years hence; it is still a death which is attributable to an activity in this generation, and we have a moral responsibility to take the integrated death toll into account. Of course, the levy relates to immediate environmental consequences and in no sense takes that into account. We say that we do not have a right to shift onto later generations the penalties from activities which produce a benefit in this generation. We believe it is a significant reason why we should not proceed with uranium mining.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bounty (Ships) Bill provides for a continuation of the bounty on ships of between 150 and 10,000 tonnes built in Australia up to 1995 and under certain conditions. The conditions have been mentioned by Senator MacGibbon and the bounty applies to yards which employ at least 40 people on such an activity and yards which are 75 per cent involved in shipbuilding. The bounty scales down over time. It will be 15 per cent of eligible costs up to 1991 and will go down to 10 per cent between 1991 and 30 June 1993. It will then be reduced to 5 per cent and will run out completely in June 1995. The Minister has made a convincing case that this restructured bounty has already had a significant effect on the building of ships in Australia, and particularly on exports. He points in his second reading speech to current export orders amounting to $300m and goes on to outline some of the details of those successes. It seems that the Government's action has been successful in establishing a viable shipbuilding industry and helping it to get and maintain export orders.

Strong representations have been made to the Democrats by one shipbuilder in particular, who maintains that his operation may at times fall below the 75 per cent requirements in the legislation. The Democrats accept that, whatever criteria are set to determine whether an operation is in or outside the registrable category, those criteria will be arbitrary to some extent. In this case we accept the Government's criteria and, therefore do not support the Opposition's amendment. We believe that, should the criteria be modified, as has been suggested, some company or companies will be sitting right on the borderline and there will be further claims to extend the bounty criteria and make them much wider. It is for that reason that we believe that the criteria set by the Government, while arbitrary, are appropriate. They seem to be working, and therefore we support the legislation in the form in which the Government has presented it.

In conclusion, I make the point again that two of the Bills before us deal very much with the development of a long term energy policy by Australia but do not properly reflect the development of such a policy. Indeed, the Energy 2000 statement by the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) earlier this year did not deal with questions such as the greenhouse effect and improved energy efficiency. We are, therefore, disappointed with the way in which this lack of policy development comes through in things such as the coal Bill. We enjoin the Government to look again at the development of a longer term energy policy and how that policy would mesh in with the development and establishment of desirable forward-looking industries in Australia directed towards improved energy efficiency. Those sorts of industries would be of benefit in terms of their environmental impact and they would also be cost effective. In being forward-looking they would put Australia in a very advantaged position in terms of our industries being able to compete on future markets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak to just one of the Bills before the Senate, the Bounty (Ships) Bill. This Bill extends bounty assistance for some Australian shipbuilding from 1 July this year to 30 June 1995. The reason for the Bill is that the current Bounty (Ships) Act provides for a cash limited bounty to shipbuilders who commenced construction of vessels prior to 30 June 1989, that is, the end of this month. This new Bill will continue bounty assistance after this month at rates which will be gradually phased down until June 1995 when the bounty assistance will cease. There is no doubt that in recent times the bounty assistance for shipbuilding has increased our export orders. At the moment our export orders for ships amount to $300m. Recent orders include two high-speed catamaran car and passenger ferries, 10 fishing trawlers and two luxury motor yachts, all for export. Over half the vessels completed in 1989 so far have been for export, compared to only one ship exported from Australia in the whole of 1984-85.

SPEECH.PARA: If the shipbuilding industry is becoming more vibrant, why do we need to retain the bounty? The Government argues-and I agree-that we need it because the cost from entry to the international market resulted in trading losses for a number of firms in their early years. I agree with the Government that the most appropriate form of assistance is a bounty, which is very much preferable to a tariff because a tariff is likely to distort consumption costs and reduce the local demand for ships. I also strongly agree with the proposal in this Bill to phase down the rates of assistance gradually and for the bounty to cease altogether on the designated date, June 1995. The trouble with protection in Australia in the past has been that we have never known when to end it. We have protected so-called infant industries and have kept protecting them long past infancy until they have become senile and inefficient, and very costly to Australia. The car industry is one example of this, and we are still trying to clean up that mess. If we are to protect our newly emerging shipbuilding industry, we must ensure that protection ceases at a predictable and reasonable date. I believe that this Bill does just that.

Why do we want a shipbuilding industry at all? In 1979 a combined Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) and Tariff Board inquiry looked into the shipbuilding industry and concluded that it was essential for defence reasons and for maintaining and developing shipbuilding skills in Australia. At the beginning of the 1980s the prospects for the shipbuilding industry were certainly not very bright. The introduction of the 38-hour week increased costs and wages in shipbuilding. The imposition of a sales tax on pleasure craft had a detrimental effect on shipbuilding. As a result there were no new sales. In addition, the high costs of protected materials in Australia added to the other high costs for shipbuilders.

The result was that in the early 1980s few new ships were built here and second-hand ships were imported instead. Even the Government was not a particularly good customer for our shipbuilding industry. Two mine hunters were built for the Navy, but the first four FFGs were built in America, rather than being built here. The two follow-on FFGs were built at Williamstown, which is an improvement. The only reason that program has had any degree of success is that the Government has sold off Williamstown. It is now privatised and is working apparently quite efficiently, although one still has to see a detailed run-down of the costs of building these ships at Williamstown. What was done there-I wish it had also been done elsewhere-was to reduce the number of unions involved in shipbuilding. The number of unions at Williamstown is now down to three. We will not really succeed until it is down to one.

I wish more action had been taken in regard to the other major shipbuilding projects in Australia: the submarines in South Australia, and the proposed 12 frigates to be built in eastern Australia-the exact position where they will be built is still not decided. We must use the shipbuilding programs for the Navy to revolutionise and clean up our shipbuilding industry. It is absolutely essential that we have only one union in each work place if we are to have efficiency. The workers in each shipyard must have some interest, some involvement, in the success of their enterprise, rather than regarding it as an enormous cow which they can milk interminably with unreasonable wage and condition demands. Until we achieve that, we will not be competitive on an international scale.

We can build very good ships, but at the moment they are extremely expensive and their delivery dates are extremely unreliable. That is for the Navy. I mention that only in passing because this bounty Bill does not deal with ships built for the Navy. So, coming back to the types of ships with which the Bill is concerned, I repeat the remarks I was making about naval shipbuilding. The importance of proper industrial relations, the involvement of the work force and the productivity of the enterprise are essential if we are to have a long-term success in building other ships.

Coming back to the Bill, though, since the introduction of bounties to assist the shipbuilding industry there has been some improvement and the beginnings of an export market. However, there are still a number of problems. The Government boasts that 45 new companies have registered since the extension of the bounty scheme in 1984. However, of these 45 new companies, only 13 have maintained continual registration during the last five years. Our shipbuilding industry now is very small by world standards, following the closing of the shipyards in Whyalla and Newcastle. As a result of their closure, we no longer have the capability to produce large international trading vessels. We are still able to build steel-hulled vessels up to 10,000 tonnes-fishing vessels, support vessels for off-shore installations, tugs, dredgers, small naval vessels, barges and passenger ferries.

What are the problems facing existing and potential shipbuilders in Australia? The fundamental problem is that we are between 10 per cent and 20 per cent dearer than an overseas competing firm. We should not be, but we are. The reasons are essentially the appalling system of industrial relations and restrictive work practices. If we want to be competitive in this and all other areas, we must tackle those problems. In addition, finance for shipbuilding is very difficult to obtain in Australia. Even the bounty is not easy to come by under the present Act. To receive the bounty a shipbuilder has to be registered by the Minister, who acts on the advice of the Shipbuilding Consultative Group. This group advises the Minister whether a shipbuilder meets the registration criteria and whether the builder will `contribute to the orderly development of the industry'. The result is the bounties are restricted to a select group of shipbuilders, determined by bureaucrats rather than the market. However, imperfect as the system might be, for the moment contribution of the bounty seems to offer the best hope for the shipbuilding industry in Australia. Otherwise I fear that the resources will just move out of the industry as the current orders are completed within the next year or so.
