This bounty Bill, I make quite clear, applies to ship construction or modification. The ship repair industry, though related, is a different industry. One has only to look at that industry to see the problems. Just over two years ago the Government provided bounty assistance for the ship repair industry, but it is still very uncompetitive. Last month I was at a meeting of the Institute of Marine Engineers, at which the leading shipowner told us that he still preferred to have his ships repaired overseas. His reasons were cost and time taken. Time out of service is a cost for the shipowner. This particular shipowner said-I agree with him from my experience-that Australia does high quality work very well, but that routine ship repairs are just too expensive because of the high wages and poor performance in terms of output per person of the employees in the Ship Painters and Dockers Union and other relevant unions. The result is that shipowners would prefer to have their ships repaired overseas rather than in Australia.

On the shipbuilding side there is some hope for us with the world shipbuilding outlook. The latest Drewry Shipping survey indicates that the shipbuilding industry worldwide is now entering a period of relative stability, with replacement being the prime requirement. We have only to recall that the average age of the Australian National Line fleet is now over nine years to realise that the replacement requirement is also very strong here in Australia.

The shipbuilding industry in 1989 is an entirely different industry from 10 years ago. In 1979-I am talking about the world-wide situation-most of the top shipbuilders were located in western Europe. Ten years later the shipbuilding industry has gravitated to the Far East with the South Koreans challenging the Japanese for world supremacy in shipbuilding. All shipbuilders have incurred losses in recent years and government subsidies have declined. As a result, the prices of new ships are bound to rise and the shipyards will be unwilling and, of course, unable to offer loss making contracts. This expected rise in the prices of new ships has resulted in more owners upgrading or converting existing tonnage, and it is important that we, here in Australia, are in a position to take advantage of the increasing market for ship modifications.

What worries me, as I mentioned briefly before, is our lack of productivity and the high costs of our ship repair and shipbuilding industries, which may prevent us taking advantage of the chances offered. For instance, Australia takes three times as long as Holland to build a dead-weight 4,000-tonne ship. In Australia we take at least a year to build one of these vessels while Holland builds three ships in the same period. Put another way, Holland has a 300 per cent productivity rate over Australia. This is because Holland has a longer working week than we do, its people take fewer days off work and it has a lead over us in innovative design. Here, we do less work, we subsidise inefficient industries, and frankly, we just cannot afford to go on as we have been doing.

One of the great crimes of this Government is that during its six years in office industrial productivity has not risen at all. At a time when we desperately need a rise in productivity to overcome our very serious economic problems, our productivity has not risen. We can see why, from the debate we had yesterday on shipping and the waterfront. The Labor Government is an extension of the trade union movement, and is not prepared to take the necessary tough measures because the consequence would be a revolt from their trade union colleagues. I was going to say `masters'. I think they are masters rather than colleagues. The problem is, if the Government is not prepared to tackle industrial problems, we are doomed to sinking further and further down in international comparisons. Coming back to the ships, they are essential, of course, and we have an urgent need to replace the ageing fleet of Australian flag ships. If we are to do it here in Australia, and be economically competitive with our shipping afterwards, we must be able to build them economically.

This Bill reflects some of the recommendations of the IAC report on Ships, Boats and Other Vessels, and is designed to preserve the small amount of shipbuilding this country still has. The IAC recommended the removal of import restrictions on ships, the gradual phasing-down of tariffs on boats, the continuation of bounty assistance for ship construction and modification for domestic sale, the phasing out of bounty assistance for export sale and the payment of bounty only on completion of vessels. The Government has implemented some, but not all, of these recommendations. For instance, this Bill will phase out the bounty for all eligible ship construction and modification for the domestic as well as the export market over a six-year period. This Bill does not put any upper limit on the total amount of bounty which is calculated as a percentage of the costs at the time the costs were incurred, plus 20 per cent of overheads.

On the other hand, the registration criteria in the Bill have become more restrictive than the IAC recommended. In the committee stage Senator MacGibbon, I understand, will be moving an amendment relating to these registration criteria. It is these registration criteria which concern the Opposition. The Opposition is concerned that the Bill requires, firstly, that at least 75 per cent of the activities of the applicants must be devoted to the construction or modification of vessels which are bountiable. That excludes ship repair activities which are neither construction nor modifications. The second requirement is that the applicant must, at all times, employ at least 40 persons in ship modifications or construction, compared to the present requirement of 20 under the existing regulations. Thirdly, applicants will have to submit a business plan whereas, at present, this is not necessary.

The IAC is strongly opposed to these registration criteria. The amendment to be moved by Senator MacGibbon would delete the 75 per cent requirement. The reason the Government included this requirement is to stop the proliferation of bounty hunters. I accept that that is a reason for doing it, but these sorts of decisions are very rarely black and white but various shades of grey. In this case the balance, I believe, looking at all the favours, suggests that the 75 per cent rule should be removed. The 75 per cent has to be engaged in ship construction or modification. There are very great advantages in the same shipyard being also involved in ship repair. We are building very few ships in Australia, but if ship constructors are exposed to repairing foreign built ships which have new technologies and new design features, it will keep our shipbuilders and, of course, the work force involved up to date in new techniques. Without that, our ship construction industry will, I believe, lag behind international technology.

Also, when a firm builds ships for export, there is an increasing trend that the firm is also required to service the ships it has built. If the firm is limited to how much ship repair it can do, it cannot offer the sort of contract that people looking for export orders would require. The other problem is that, inevitably, shipbuilding is very variable in demand. What a firm could do, is employ its work force sometimes on ship repairs and sometimes on ship building. If it has no shipbuilding orders it can go flat out to get more ship repair orders, but this Bill would prevent that sort of flexible management. Probably firms would get around this problem by setting up a subsidy company within the main one to do ship construction, but that would be very clumsy and, I suspect, uneconomical. I suppose they would have to do that, if faced with this variable pattern, but it is a very untidy way, and for that reason a very uncompetitive way, in which to run a business.

We understand, from the remarks made by the Australian Democrats-in so far as they were comprehensible-that they will not be supporting this amendment to be moved by the Opposition and, therefore, the Government will have its way. The Opposition will be looking very carefully at how these registration criteria will work. We do not want to see efficient producers discouraged. Some of the criteria are entirely acceptable to us and very sensible, such as that the builders must be financially sound, they must have access to waterfront premises and they must employ one apprentice for every eight tradesmen. These criteria, I think, are very reasonable. If the registration is rejected or withdrawn the applicants have a right to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal which will look at the case on its merits. That also is very reasonable. The registration is to last for a period of one year. Those criteria are all reasonable.

Our two objections are, first of all, to the 75 per cent requirement for shipbuilding and ship construction, which we think will make for an inefficient industry. It is an undesirable requirement, although we can see the reasons for the Government's proposing it. But even more importantly-and this is not directly a part of this bounty Bill-in the shipbuilding and ship repair industry and right across the rest of our secondary industry we have to tackle our deplorable industrial relations and productivity problems. Without that we are doomed to future mediocrity. The Opposition supports the general thrust of this Bill. I and, I think, all of us hope that the Australian shipbuilding industry will survive in the short term and expand and prosper in the long term.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The package of Bills before us today relates to an extensive series of changes to various customs tariffs. The ones that I would like to turn my attention to relate to the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1989. Madam Acting Deputy President, as you will appreciate, this has a major import and bearing on the productivity of uranium in the Northern Territory. The duty, which has been imposed since 1980, is in recognition of the special costs incurred by the Commonwealth for environmental monitoring and research activity related to uranium mining in the Alligator Rivers Region of the Northern Territory. The increase which is now proposed to the rate of duty reflects the Government's position that the costs associated with protecting the environment from the potentially adverse effects of uranium mining should be borne, as far as practical, by the industry carrying out that mining activity and not by the ordinary taxpayer.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to address a number of issues relating to this matter, particularly as it affects the operation of the office of the Supervising Scientist (OSS). Whilst it is the Government's intention to raise more funds to offset the costs of the Office of the Supervising Scientist, we need at all times to be sure that the operations of that very office are being carried out in an efficient, accountable manner that does not require an undue extra subsidy by the Government. Today in the Senate my colleague the shadow Minister for customs, Senator MacGibbon, has moved an amendment in the following terms:
. . . but the Senate is of the opinion that the Government should be condemned for:

(a) imposing a discriminatory levy upon one operation alone at a time when Australia's uranium exporters are struggling to remain competitive in the international market and are already overburdened by excessive taxes and charges; and
(b) its ideological approach to the development of Australia's uranium industry which has resulted in an economically absurd `three mine policy'.

Both tenets of that amendment moved by Senator MacGibbon have great value. They need to be addressed particularly by this Senate and in the broader context of the debate that, naturally, at all times goes on with regard to the expansion of uranium mining in Australia.

Many issues arise from the international marketplace. It is our responsibility to ensure that we are a proper partner in providing an environmentally safe nuclear fuel cycle. This Government is imposing excessive taxes and charges on that industry because it sees it as one in which there is an opportunity to seize and to grab easy, large dollops of money. The Labor Government is also constrained by the Labor Conference, which has imposed upon it the absurd three-mine policy, which does not allow for the expansion of that industry in a manner that would be controlled by environmental guidelines and by the marketplace itself.

When this Bill was originally introduced in the House of Representatives in early March-and it is interesting to note that it has taken some two months to surface in this chamber-the shadow Minister for science and energy, Peter McGauran, drew attention to a lot of the issues regarding the current state of the international marketing of uranium. At that time Mr McGauran drew particular attention to the fact that 5 per cent of the operating costs of Energy Resources of Australia Ltd (ERA), the operators of Ranger uranium mine, were now being allocated for this duty and how it was to be imposed for environmental monitoring and research activities related to the Alligator Rivers Region. I commend to the Senate Mr McGauran's speech on 4 April. He goes into great detail with regard to the marketing of uranium and how this duty is disproportionate in that the levy is imposed on one company alone. Mr McGauran stressed that the policy of the Government at the moment makes no good economic sense-it is a policy which expresses the interests of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) ahead of and above those of the nation as a whole.

The previous coalition Government imposed this levy in 1980 as part of the principal Act, which is now being amended, but I remind the Senate that the duty that was initially put in place stood at 11c a kilogram. It is now proposed that that be increased to a whopping $1.15 a kilogram. That is a tenfold increase since its introduction some nine years ago. By and large, the levy falls on the shoulders of one company-Energy Resources of Australia, the operators of the Ranger uranium mine.

It is often argued that the funding of OSS at its present exorbitant levels is vital and necessary to what is going on in the area. But I think we need to turn to and address the annual report to this Parliament of the Supervising Scientist. Throughout the report there are glowing accounts of the practices at Ranger, which are environmentally sound. Of course, no mention is made of the fact that Ranger itself is expending some $10m in this whole area of monitoring and the environment. Looking in particular at the report there is reference to the fact that, to date, there is only minimal environmental detriment. Let me draw from page 6 of the report, where it states:

Over the seven or eight years that the Ranger and Nabarlek projects have been operating in the Region, the work of the OSS, in co-operation with other Commonwealth and Northern Territory agencies, has been essential not only in understanding and ensuring protection of the environment, but also in giving credibility to the claims made by the mining companies and the regulatory authorities that the mining operations have resulted in minimal environmental detriment to date.
We find on page 8 of the report:
Overall, a high standard of environment protection, commensurate with the unique natural and cultural values of the Region, has been achieved.

I believe that this has been achieved largely as a result of the practices of the Ranger mine and the Northern Territory Government in their approach to the peculiar problems of Kakadu. We find on page 60 of the report:

Ranger has fulfilled its regulatory requirements, under the terms of its authorisation, in respect of environmental protection during 1987-88. Review and assessment by OSS of monitoring reports and other information indicate that requirements to minimise the environmental impact of the mining operations are being met.

As I have said, Ranger itself has engaged in extensive environmental operations at costs that far exceed those of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. We need to look very carefully at the costs that arise and at the reasons why the OSS is carrying out so much of the research that goes on in particular areas.

This issue was raised in the House of Representatives in early March. It was probably not coincidental that at that time there was also a reporting of incidents that had arisen with regard to releases from the tailings at restricted zones at Ranger. I remind the Senate that on 8 March I gave in this place a notice of a motion, which says:
That the Senate-

(a) condemns the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) for misleading the Senate in his answer to a put-up Question without Notice by Senator Collins on 3 March 1989 and his failure to present a comprehensive and adequate account to the Senate regarding recent alleged breaches of environmental guidelines at the Ranger Uranium Mine and notes that he failed to:
(i) acknowledge the view expressed by the Office of the Supervising Scientist that the dumping of waste rock did not constitute `any immediate or even demonstrable risk to the environment',
(ii) acknowledge that uranium levels in the pond receiving run-off from the waste rock dump have actually fallen during the current wet season,
(iii) acknowledge the steps taken by the Northern Territory Government to act promptly to ensure adherence to approved environmental guidelines, and
(iv) accurately advise the Senate of the date of the granting of original approvals covering the most recent discharge of water from RP4; and

(b) calls on Senator Richardson to make a comprehensive statement to the Senate which can be debated fully and to refrain from making statements which are inflammatory and misleading and designed for no other purpose than to attempt to restore his shattered political credibility with the ill-informed but noisy elements of the environmental movement.

To date that motion has not been brought on in the Senate. Senator Richardson has not responded to any of the calls made in that notice of motion and has certainly not given this Senate the opportunity to debate the incidents that arose at that particular time. There always seems to be a coincidence between the incidents that happen at Ranger and the times at which the Government is proposing to address policy matters within the Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President: I have let Senator Tambling read into the record the notice of motion that he gave, but I believe that he is now taking advantage of the debate on this Bill to embark on a series of justifications and comments that would be more appropriate to the debate on the motion of which he gave notice. I would ask you to call him to order and ask him to confine his remarks to the material relevant to the Bill rather than to his notice of motion.
—On that point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President: Senator Tambling is involved in the second reading debate on a Bill and the matter that he has put before the Chair is quite relevant.
—I ask Senator Tambling to address his remarks directly to the Bill.

—I believe that the remarks I am making are directly relevant in that we are looking at the Budget allocations or the raising of levy funds that provide for the conduct of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. The very conduct of that office was very much the matter of the notice of motion that I gave here in March. So there is a direct parallel and there are direct issues that relate both to this Bill and to the motion that I gave in March. The issues arising with regard to the Office of the Supervising Scientist are such that they require urgent and, always, comprehensive attention by this Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting that Ranger itself has undertaken a comprehensive study of all these particular areas and has released a report that it made available to Senator Richardson on the very matter of the operations between Ranger and the Office of the Supervising Scientist. The Ranger report alleged that the Office of the Supervising Scientist had spent about $40m but had failed to produce any standards, practices and procedures of value to environment protection at Ranger; that it was insufficient and duplicated the functions of other organisations; that it did not effectively carry out the work that it was required to do; that the average cost per employee in the Office of the Supervising Scientist was approximately 50 per cent higher than in the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation, 20 per cent higher than the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation's Natural Resources Division and 28 per cent higher than the Alligator Rivers Region Unit, the Northern Territory's uranium unit. The report also stated that in the 10 years from 1978 to 1988 the research work of the Office of the Supervising Scientist had produced no standards, practices or procedures that Ranger could use to protect the environment; that on average roughly $4m a year was being spent on research but almost nothing of any real practical value for protection of the environment from uranium mining had resulted; and that in 10 years the Office of the Supervising Scientist had grown into an organisation far from the original concept proposed by Commissioner Fox in the second report of the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry. Of course, we must be mindful of the fact that about 75 per cent of the funds required by the Office of the Supervising Scientist comes from ERA, Ranger's operators in this particular area.

On a number of occasions Senator Richardson has sought to discredit Ranger in order to influence the ALP's committee which is currently looking at the uranium policy of the Government. Senator Richardson supports the three-mine policy that is currently under way. We need to be aware, of course, that Ranger's operations have at all times been clean and straightforward. Senator Richardson has ignored the Northern Territory's strong record in administering procedures and safeguards as well as the evidence from the Office of the Supervising Scientist which supports Ranger. That was patently obvious from the last annual report of the Office of the Supervising Scientist which I quoted earlier. Ranger is practising wetlands filtration, which is far more efficient and environmentally safer than any pipeline release. The issues relating to that March incident of the RP4 ponds bring this out.

I take a few moments to look at the review of the Government's uranium policy that is currently under way. We are all aware that the Labor Party has instituted a uranium policy review which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has now announced will not report until 1991. This will put off any decisions with regard to the expansion of uranium mining in Australia until well after the next Federal election and will seriously affect our economic production as a country. It is obvious that the Labor Party is unable to decide, whether through its review committee or by action of government, where it really stands on this very important matter. There seems to be a number of conflicting views within the Labor Party as to where the three-mine policy or the whole uranium debate ought to go. We are well aware that Senator Collins has taken, to his credit, a very positive stance with regard to the liberalisation of the three-mine policy and has been very active in that area. The honourable member for the Northern Territory, Mr Snowdon, has not come as clean as Senator Collins as to where he stands on this particular issue. For example, in a recent radio interview, when he was asked about this particular area, he commented, `I have got a view, I am not going to tell you what that view is'. Of course, he has equivocated in relation to the review that is under way with regard to the three-mine policy, so we do not know exactly where he stands. In 1988, Senator Richardson stated:
I have considerable sympathy with those people who have been seeking a change, but while the arguments are there the numbers are not.
As usual, Senator Richardson seems to understand numbers very well but he is not prepared to get out and muster them with regard to liberalising the policies that are so necessary in uranium mining.

The Leader of the Opposition in the Northern Territory Parliament, Mr Terry Smith, has come down with a very different view. He obviously now understands, as a result of a recent world fact finding trip looking at the nuclear fuel industry, that there must be some very important changes. Mr Smith's conclusion now is that nuclear power will become an integral and growing factor in the world's future energy needs and that the environmental consequences of non-nuclear energy alternatives are beginning to dawn even upon the troglodytes of the greenie industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are the Democrats?

—Where are the Democrats? The troglodytes are not here to participate in this debate. Having listened to Senator Coulter earlier, it is no wonder. The Northern Territory Leader of the Opposition, Mr Smith, now supports the development of new uranium mines on the basis that there is a significant uncommitted demand for uranium and a lack of low cost uranium reserves. His conclusion that Australia, with the world's largest low cost reserves, could capture a significant proportion of the uncommitted demand is in agreement with the Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy report on the nuclear fuel cycle industry. I commend that report to the Senate. The fact that the report now has the endorsement of the Labor Leader of the Opposition in the Northern Territory is, I believe, most important and significant.

SPEECH.PARA: We have reached a point where the uranium industry is now well accepted as being environmentally safe and environmentally clean. If Australia is to develop and benefit from the economic advantages, it is important that this industry not be constrained. The provisions of the legislation before us today impose, in a very discriminatory manner, additional taxes on the principal operator of a uranium mine in the Northern Territory. It is important that we should note that. I think it is also important that this Senate should very carefully address the issues that were properly raised in Senator MacGibbon's amendment. We are imposing a discriminatory level upon one operation alone at a time when Australia's uranium exporters are struggling to remain competitive in the international marketplace and are already overburdened by excessive taxes and charges. We should be challenging the Labor Party at all times to review thoroughly, properly and promptly the absurd three-mine policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in this debate on the Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 mainly because of the disruption that this sudden removal of bounty paid to Australian manufacturers of certain products has caused. To be more precise, the Bill amends the Subsidy (Cultivation Machines and Equipment) Act 1986 and the Subsidy (Grain Harvesters and Equipment) Act 1985. The situation concerning cultivation machines is probably more important, though I will briefly comment on grain harvesters as well.

SPEECH.PARA: In his second reading speech Senator Button said:

As outlined by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the April economic statement the Government is determined to ensure that fiscal policy is kept tight in order to maintain downward pressure on Australia's trade deficit.
After telling us that savings would be used to offset the cost of measures announced in the economic statement, which would assist families and pensioners, Senator Button went on to tell us:

In view of these strong budgetary pressures, the Government considers it would be inappropriate to exempt outlays associated with industry assistance and development. In the Government's view the most appropriate means of effecting the necessary savings in this area is to terminate the grain harvesting and cultivation equipment assistance schemes.

As I see it, the Government has once again seen fit to harvest an efficient rural industry to fulfil its ever-growing social welfare account, which is out of control. The Minister made a contradictory point when he said that the Government is determined to maintain downward pressure on Australia's trade deficit. I was under the impression that the best way to take off that pressure is to encourage Australians to buy Australian products and so lessen demand-in this case, demand for imported machines.

What better way is there to lessen that demand than to encourage Australian manufacturers of machinery which could be competitive in price, which is suited to Australian conditions and which is accepted already by Australian primary producers? I would like Senator Button to tell us exactly what he means and which way he wants to go. Does he want downward pressure on imports or does he want upward pressure by causing Australian products to rise in price? Surely, if the price of Australian machinery is kept down, we would be able to compete against overseas products. This would help the balance of payments and employment situations and the benefit would flow on to the factory workers and the suppliers of materials and components.

The Bill will result in savings to the Government of $19m in 1989-90 and $10.4m in 1990-91. In my opinion, the total savings do not justify the disruption to the supply of farm machinery and the employment losses in the manufacturing and distribution fields. In these days of micro-economic reform, I do not believe that bounties should continue forever. The cessation of these bounties was due by 30 June 1990. In view of the expected amount of savings and the disruption that this legislation will cause, I cannot see why the phase-out of bounties should not have been left to run its course.

I believe that there is a difference between a bounty for harvesters and a bounty for cultivation gear. These two products differ. The harvester bounty came into being because of a government bungle. There used to be no tariff on imported machines of a certain size-to be more exact, harvesting machines with a threshing drum greater than 48 inches. In the early 1980s Massey-Ferguson (Aust.) Ltd experimented with a power take-off harvester or header with a drum size greater than 48 inches-namely, about 60 inches. The company went to the Tariff Board and applied for a tariff. To my dismay and that of other Australian farmers, it was successful. Even though it had a machine that was suitable, Massey-Ferguson could not have hoped to supply all Australia's wheat farmers with harvesting machinery. The Government at the time should have looked at a bounty rather than a tariff. That tariff added up to $30,000 to the price of an imported good-sized rotary or conventional machine with a drum size of 60 inches. After lobbying took place between 1983 and 1985, that tariff was removed and a bounty was put on. This is what should have been done in the first place. When the tariff was removed, not all importers returned to the consumer the gain that was made. I welcome the end of the bounty on harvesting machines. But as I have said, the tariff should never have been imposed in the first place.

Let me turn to the amendment to the Subsidy (Cultivation Machines and Equipment) Act. A vastly different set of circumstances apply in respect of this legislation. Let me refer to the question of John Shearer (Holdings) Ltd in Adelaide, a matter which has been in the news in the last few weeks. As I have always said, and I know from first hand experience, Australian harvesting machines are far behind those manufactured in other parts of the world. But, on the other side of the coin, I believe that Australian cultivating machines far exceed any other product in the world. This is especially true when working soils in the medium to low rainfall wheatbelts around Australia. We should take into consideration that a lot of those lands have been cleared for upwards of 150 years, yet are still new in comparison to many parts of the world.

We had the case of John Shearer Ltd, a manufacturer of what I consider to be the best tillage machinery in the world, and certainly the best available in Australia. It outshines any imported gear. The Government cut the bounty on cultivation gear right in midstream. The bounty was to continue to 31 December 1990. The Government then announced in its mini-statement that this bounty would finish on 12 April 1989. We then had the Shearer debacle over the last couple of months. I suppose in one respect there has been good come out of legislation by press release in that it allows one to have a good look at it before it ever comes to this place. Honourable senators should know that rural producers did not operate in a good climate from the year 1985 through to 1988. This climate was not caused by any lack of rainfall but rather the economic climate around the world. Farm commodities were at a low ebb. We then had a turnaround at the beginning of 1988 which was mainly caused by the great improvement in the price of wheat and wool.

In those years to which I have referred, farmers, mainly wheat farmers, did not reinvest in new machinery. Hence, second-hand machinery was sought after and this lifted its price. In 1989 with a good crop behind us, a good wool crop as well, expectations of better prices for wheat in 1990-hopefully at around $A225 or better-and the encouragement from this Government, of which you, Madam Acting Deputy President, are a part, to grow more wheat in the season to come there was an upturn in demand for new tillage gear to sow the crop that is now going in despite the excessive wet weather around Australia. These manufacturers-this includes Shearers-had through their dealers full order books with contracts at a fixed price from the manufacturer to the dealer and a fixed price under contract between the dealer and the farmer. In most cases the dealer had taken machines off the farmers as trade-ins and again in most cases the dealer had sold them to someone else. In the middle of this-we should bear in mind that 12 April is the time the Australian wheat crop is being planned and farmers, in order to start sowing the crop, are waiting for the rains-the Government dropped a bombshell by removing the bounty. As I have already said, farmers had held off buying new plant for the past three years and the Government came in and removed this bounty at what one would call, in secondary industry, the re-tooling stage. It was very convenient for the Government to bring in extra income to itself.

In the case of Shearers and in the case of other manufacturers, they had to go back to the dealers and ask them for more money. The dealers in turn had to go back to the farmers and ask them for more money. I would say that the contracts were at a fixed price between the farmer and the dealer but not necessarily at a fixed price between the dealer and the manufacturer. Of course, a farmer, or a dealer for that matter, to add to the double confusion could have walked away from the whole contract. But with the wet season coming on the farmer, especially the farmer who had had his trade-in taken away and sold, would have to put up the money and shut up, to put it in plain terms. That changed after the Shearer fiasco. There was a case with enough problems already. The Amalgamated Metal Workers Union decided to have a strike-I am not exactly sure of the length of it-over nothing but compulsory unionism. The company then was returned to past practice; that is, compulsory unionism. Even the Adelaide Advertiser on 21 May 1989 made a mockery in its editorial of the plight of Shearer and its customers. I have a copy of that editorial and I will quote a section of it:

The Industrial Relations Commission yesterday ordered the company to resume past practices while the issue was negotiated-a basic move in any dispute. Whatever may be felt about closed shops, Mr White-
that is, the Chairman and Director, I believe, of Shearers-
should recognise that the unions behaved properly in resuming work.
What this editorial did not point out was that the unions misbehaved by being on strike for two weeks. The editorial continued:
As for the bounty, Shearer has known for four years that it would be removed.

This was because the Act came down in 1986 and contained a sunset clause. The company knew but it worked and budgeted for it to come off in June 1990 not 12 April 1989. Now, after negotiations, the bounty will remain until 10 June 1989. I believe that the Adelaide Advertiser gave a very cynical view of the whole show. As I mentioned briefly, a fall out occurred. It concerned Shearer. Things were brought to a head. Under this amended Bill the bounty, as I understand it, is to continue to 10 June 1989. Manufacturers will have to apply for their bounty by 10 July of the same year, that is this year. Three hundred jobs have been saved and Shearers is without compulsory unionism, at least for the present.

That means that the bounty on cultivation gear would have had only 12 months to go after 15 June. I consider that the Government, for what it will save, could have let it go to the dates set by the sunset clause. The Government could have let that subsidy continue until 30 June 1990 and would have recouped the cost many times over in the increased production which would have been gained by the new machinery which would have been available and which was so badly needed on the farms. Honourable senators should bear in mind what I have already told them: very little retooling and replacement of machinery by investment in new machinery was done in those three years. Once again the Government has regard to all except primary industry when it comes to cost cutting measures and it will probably never change.

In conclusion, I reiterate my disappointment at the decision of this Government to remove this bounty at such short notice when in fact the legislation was already due to run out on 30 June 1990. In such times of economic restraint I believe that the load should be shared around to all the sectors of the voting public and not only to the ones of our persuasion or to the ones with little voting strength, that is, the rural areas. This is the section of the population, as I have said many times in this chamber, that accounts for 85 per cent of Australia's export income. That figure will be rising with a downward pressure on manufacturing exports. This section of the population has only 10 per cent of Australia's voting strength.

Bearing in mind Australia's total export and import deficit, I thought that the Government would have kept any incentive for Australian manufacturers in place, for the time being anyhow. What are the alternatives? John Shearer is an Australian manufacturer making machinery that is suited to Australia, not a multinational manufacturing in Australia. We have had many multinationals manufacturing in Australia, such as New Holland, Massey Ferguson and a few others. Australia is only a minor cog in the whole system for them. When the multinationals withdrew from manufacturing in Australia and exported their farm machinery to this country from overseas, this was of no great concern to us, especially in relation to cultivation gear, because, as I have always maintained, their gear does not stand up to Australian conditions. John Shearer is probably the only real Australian manufacturer left, but the accent should be on keeping such companies manufacturing in Australia. I believe that there is a vast difference between how an Australian manufacturer should be treated and how a multinational manufacturer in Australia should be treated. The only alternative for Australian manufacturers-I have used John Shearer as an example-is to go overseas, manufacture under contract and export back into Australia. They would be away from compulsory trade unionism and disruptions. They would be taking detailed drawings and specialised jigs to manufacture in various parts of the world under contract and would then export back at a lower cost than they pay in Australia at present. No special personnel would be taken overseas, so the result would be a lessening of the demand for personnel of specialised machinery in Australia. Hence, their future is not so great.

I will not delay the Senate any longer. I will be supporting the amendments moved during the second reading debate by my colleague, Senator MacGibbon, and will support any amendments moved by the Opposition in the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon I wish to speak on the sixth Bill in the parcel of Bills that are being debated today, the Bounty (Ships) Bill 1989. As my colleague Senator Hamer said earlier, it is not the intention of the Opposition to oppose these Bills, but we do intend to move an amendment in the committee stage which will remove the requirement that 75 per cent of a shipbuilder's business be devoted to activities which are subject to a bounty. As Senator Hamer quite rightly said, this restrictive requirement tends to lessen the likelihood of shipbuilding companies keeping up to date with modern technology and using new techniques that are available overseas, because fewer shipyards will be devoted to repairing ships in our country.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a matter of some disappointment that as an island continent Australia does not have a more vibrant shipbuilding industry. Indeed, given the restrictive work practices which have flourished in this country for so long under the present Government, it is a great credit to those in the shipbuilding industry that they have survived at all under the restrictions that abound in the climate in this country at the moment, with massive wage increases, interest rates and all such things that work against business. Under the existing Bounty (Ships) Act 1980, a bounty is payable on the construction and/or modification in Australia of vessels which exceed 150 gross construction tonnes and commercial vessels exceeding 150 gross construction tonnes or 21 metres in length. The bounty is based upon the cost of construction or modification of a vessel. For tugs, bulk carriers, rig servicing and fishing vessels which fit the pre-requisites commenced after 1 January 1988, the bounty is 20 per cent of the cost of construction. For other vessels the bounty is 15 per cent. To be eligible for a bounty in relation to modifications, the cost of these modifications must exceed $400,000.

In July 1986 a limit of $144m was placed on the total funds available under the Bounty (Ships) Act 1980 in respect of vessels completed before 1 July 1989. However, at the end of March 1988 all of that $144m had either been distributed or reserved. The new scheme will begin on 1 July 1989 and will phase out the bounty over six years so that by July 1995 the industry will operate without any bounty assistance at all. It is estimated that over the six-year period the scheme will cost $145m with an initial outlay of some $24m in 1989-90, rising to $33m in 1990-91. To be eligible for the bounty, shipbuilders must meet what are known as orderly development provisions, along with registration criteria. It emerges that 45 shipbuilders have received registration during the period from 1984 to April 1989 while, disappointingly, only 13 firms have managed to maintain their registration during that period.

The decision to phase out the bounty over the next six years is something which the Opposition is prepared to live with, as Senator Hamer said earlier, but we certainly see it as an acceptable compromise between those people who wanted the bounty to remain at its present rate and those who wanted it scrapped altogether. However, it provides a clear path for the future for those in the community who wish to remain involved. As I said earlier, they are becoming fewer and fewer because of the restrictive provisions that have been forced upon them by this Federal Government with work practices, high interest rates and all the other things that make it so difficult for them to make their businesses profitable.

I spoke earlier of the success which has been achieved by a number of operators in the industry despite the difficult economic circumstances under which they must presently operate. I want to refer particularly to two highly successful operations in my own State of Tasmania. I believe that they deserve the commendation of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are building catamarans.

—Yes, that is right. As honourable senators would realise, because of Tasmania's dependence on the sea, it has always made quite a significant contribution to Australia's shipbuilding industry. During the early whaling years Tasmania was noted for its wonderful wooden construction of vessels that plied around the world in pursuit of whales. In fact, I learnt when I was in Japan some five years ago that one of the first contacts the people there made with Europeans involved a whaling ship that was wrecked on the shores on Mabiro Beach in Japan in 1826. That ship was built and registered in Hobart, so our shipbuilding industry goes back many years. Former Senator Ken Wriedt, now a member of the Tasmanian House of Assembly, tried to get dry dock facilities in Hobart for Russian vessels some 10 years ago. I know of efforts being made at present by Mr Gunther Shultz, of whom the Minister opposite would have heard. He was the Polar part of P & O Polar. He is currently trying to get the Government to support Hobart becoming a stopping off point for Russian research vessels as a repair providoring port for vessels that are plying to Antarctica. I believe that the port of Hobart is certainly well able to cater, as a supply depot at least, for Antarctic vessels from all over the world. It seems unusual that the Government can support the Chinese working out of Hobart whilst the Russian ships do not seem to be receiving the support they should. My own State Premier has had varying views on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier, we have skilled craftsmen and the facilities in Hobart to produce world class vessels. Tasmanians have made many famous yachts and fishing vessels. At present, on the banks of Prince of Wales Bay at Glenorchy, International Catamarans is a company which is flourishing. It is run by a friend of mine, Bob Clifford, who came about this enterprise after one of the most unfortunate incidents that ever happened to my State. That was when the Tasman Bridge collapsed when the Lake Illawarra collided with it on a foggy night and caused a lot of disruption to the eastern shore of Hobart. He, along with quite a few others, used the unfortunate circumstances as an opportunity to ply ferries between Rosny Park and Hobart. In the early days he was responsible for the construction of a couple of well known vessels-the James McCabe and the Matthew Brady. They are all named after bushrangers; I can assure honourable senators that Bob Clifford is no bushranger. He adapted the technique of using catamarans as ferries. The first catamaran he used to cross the river was the Lawrence Cavanagh. That was the beginning of his success. He could see that eventually the ferry services would melt away with the relocation of the Tasman Bridge.

This company has gone from strength to strength. At present it is undertaking the construction of three wave-piercing 71-metre catamarans, the first two of which have been sold to British Sea-Link for service in Europe. The first sea trials of those vessels are expected in March. The third vessel, which is being promoted by Tasmanian Ferry Services, will be used to ply between George Town in Tasmania and Port Welshpool in Victoria. It will enable a fast daylight service to transport 350 passengers and some 80 cars across Bass Strait. I believe that this particular service will certainly have a great effect on Tasmania. Unfortunately, even though the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the early days was averse to having this particular company exempted from the payment of diesel fuel excise, which would have saved the travelling public some $26 on the trip, that has not come to pass. Paying passengers going both ways will now have to pay an extra $26 because of this unwarranted diesel fuel excise. Given the fact that this new service will be paying all wharfage fees and other docking fees at both ends, I cannot see why it should be paying diesel fuel tax when it does not use any roads at all. It is very unlikely that any of the funds it pays in the form of this diesel fuel excise will find their way to our crumbling road network around Australia. The efforts of International Catamarans will generate 760 new jobs in Tasmania and inject an estimated $35m into the Tasmanian economy.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., pursuant to sessional order the Senate will now proceed to a discussion of matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few brief remarks regarding the situation in China and, in particular, respond to some remarks made by Senator Harradine today during the debate on the motion moved by Senator Robert Ray, on behalf of Senator Gareth Evans. I did not have a chance to speak in that debate because of time constraints due to the amount of government business to be dealt with. Senator Harradine, although he made a personal explanation at the end of the debate, I think left an unfortunate impression that the Australian Government has been soft in its attitude to the Chinese Government in recent years over the issue of human rights because of our interest in trade matters. I completely refute that. I believe that if one studies the records of any international forum, one will find that over the last six years this Government has been a supporter of human rights wherever the issue has arisen, without fear or favour. I believe our record is one that is recognised by other democratic countries as being exemplary. I believe it is unfortunate that Senator Harradine left that impression. Certainly, in his personal explanation, he said he was not implying that individual members of parliament were not concerned about human rights in China, but he did leave the impression that the Government was soft on the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: I mention to the Senate that in April 1987 I was invited to visit China as a guest of the international liaison section of the Chinese Communist Party. It has an extensive program under which people from Australia and other countries are invited to visit China. Senator Teague-I think 1988 was the most recent occasion-represented the Liberal Party under a similar program. So the program does not just invite people from particular parties. The Chinese Communist Party uses it to invite a whole range of people. During my two-week visit, I had discussions with senior members of the international liaison section of the Communist Party of China over six hours spread across two days. The major points that I raised, in accordance with Australian Labor Party policy-I was not then a senator but I was, and still am, a member of the international committee of the Labor Party-were the issue of human rights, the issue of democracy, and the extent to which China intended to develop its system to take account of the right of people to dissent, to form free trade unions-and, if they so choose, to strike, to withdraw their labour-and the right of people to have access to a free press.

I had meetings with senior editors of the People's Daily, the official newspaper, and again raised those issues. I do not believe that I did anything remarkable, compared to what many other Australians have done, but I think it is wrong to suggest that the Australian Labor Party Government has been soft on China. Certainly, members of the Chinese Communist Party at times felt uncomfortable, when I had discussions with them, about the issues we were raising. I think it is a pity that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) could not be here-at the moment he is overseas on Government business-to give a detailed response to what Senator Harradine said. I am sure that when he returns that detailed response will be given and it will prove conclusively that Australia's role in supporting human rights in China is one of which the Australian community can be proud.

I conclude by referring to activities in Australia at the moment. I gave notice of a motion yesterday in which I reminded the Senate that at 1 o'clock tomorrow in the Great Hall of Parliament House a memorial service will be held for the people killed in China in the last few days. I hope that as it will occur during the lunch break, as many senators as possible will attend that function. Protest rallies will be held in various places in Australia tomorrow. I am sure that many more will be held in coming weeks. I certainly look forward, in view of Senator Harradine's great interest in these issues, to seeing whether he attends those rallies. I believe that it is one way in which we can demonstrate our support to the Chinese people.

Yesterday I raised an issue about Radio Australia. I requested the Managing Director of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation to permit Radio Australia to extend its Chinese language broadcasts to China so that there is more opportunity for Chinese people to hear on the short wave band what is actually happening in their own country, having regard to the fact that the official press is not reporting those events. Above all, it would show the Chinese people that there is strong support from people elsewhere in the world for their struggle for democracy.

There is another way in which we can show our support. Last night on television an American commentator said that many Chinese students living in America at the moment are sending random fax and telex messages to China, explaining what is going on in the Western press, and giving expressions of support. I am making arrangements to obtain a copy of the fax and telex directory for the People's Republic of China and will arrange its distribution amongst protest groups in Australia-and among members of the Senate, if they wish to get a copy-and will encourage people to make their contribution to the support of democracy in China by also sending faxes and telexes to random numbers in China so that people in China are aware that they are not alone in their struggle.

Next week it will probably be necessary for us again to place on the agenda another notice of motion. I note the remarks of Senator Hill earlier today regarding the need for there to be a more extensive debate. I think that is necessary and I hope it can be arranged without affecting the Government's legislative program. I agree with Senator Hill; these are momentous events in China and they should be debated in the Parliament in a bipartisan way. I do not think it does our cause for the support of democracy any good to start criticising each other and what our role has been, or whether we have been strong enough in the past. I believe that the record of the Parliament and the Australian Government over the last few years on human rights in China has been good and does not need to be criticised. I think we need to put on the record continually our concern about what is happening.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't think China is being judged by different standards compared to some other places in the world?
—That may be the case.
—Like South Africa, for example, with your lot.

—If we are concerned about human rights, as I certainly am, we will know that there may be 60, 70, or 100 countries that have human rights abuses that we find intolerable. They occur sometimes under regimes of the totalitarian Left; sometimes under regimes of the totalitarian Right. I do not think we can afford to be self-serving and try to pick and choose where we think human rights abuses are less abusive because they may occur under regimes of the Right or the Left.

SPEECH.PARA: I think this Parliament and the Australian Government have been quite correct in taking up the question of human rights under various regimes, irrespective of where they occur. I, like many other senators, have a particular interest in some countries. I am interested in human rights violations in Burma. Four thousand students and civilians were killed last year in Burma by the army when they demonstrated for democracy. They did not get coverage in the West because of the lack of access by television and the news media to Burma. But those events were just as horrific as what has been occurring in China in the last week. I do not criticise other members of the Senate by saying they are soft on human rights in Burma because they have not been there or they have not seen the information. I was fortunate to visit Burma earlier this year for a week and met students who had been tortured or beaten up. I met people who had been arrested and detained for years without trial. I deplore that. I do not criticise other members of the Senate or the Australian Government for being supposedly less active in Burma, because there is a lack of information. Before people say we are selective or give more emphasis to one country than another, they should realise that on many occasions it is a matter of available information. We have quite rightly taken up the matter of South Africa, about which Senator MacGibbon interjected. South Africa is a country that hangs more people per year than practically any other country. Most of the people it hangs, if not all of them, are black.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nowhere near the number that get executed in China, though.
—Senator Hill is right, certainly not the number that have been shot down in the streets in China.
—No, I mean legally, for the commission of offences. The death penalty in China is used more extensively than practically anywhere else.

—Yes. When I was in China in 1987 I raised with Chinese authorities the system during 1985-86, when it is estimated that maybe 20,000, 30,000 or 40,000 people had been, in my view, summarily executed for supposed criminal activities. That is something that I find quite abhorrent, just as I find it abhorrent that in the mid-1980s in Indonesia similar activities were carried out by the Government to get rid of so-called criminal elements. The point I am making is that one cannot be selective; one should not make a judgment that one country is worse than another on human rights abuses. We must be active in promoting human rights wherever abuses occur, without fear or favour. I believe that this Government and this Parliament have been as effective on these matters as any in the world in acting without fear or favour-at times to our cost and to the irritation of other countries, including China.

SPEECH.PARA: I visited Vietnam and Indonesia in January. In both of those places I raised, along with other members of the delegation, human rights abuses. It was embarrassing to our hosts when we raised the matters, but we did raise them because they were issues about which we felt strongly. I conclude by saying I hope that before the Senate rises, subject to the Government's legislative programs, we can have a debate on events in China, which I think would be worth while.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 May 1989 I wrote to the Editor-in-Chief of the Australian newspaper in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: I have today lodged the attached Question on Notice seeking information about the living conditions of Aboriginal people at Brunette Downs.
Mr Anthony Hoy, who produced several recent articles for The Australian, might have done well to check the facts before going into print.

If, as I suspect will be the case, the Minister's reply to my question reveals that the situation at Brunette Downs differs from that represented in your columns, one would have to ask why both Mr Hoy and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs omitted to mention several significant aspects of the story.
In the interests of balanced media presentation, I suggest you take some interest in securing the information which the Minister's reply to my question may be expected to provide.

Subsequently, on 23 May 1989, I tabled in the Senate a document which set out the negotiations between the Northern Territory Cattlemen's Association and the Commonwealth Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs during the period 1984-89. There has been a further response to this matter by the Northern Territory Cattlemen's Association. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short statement entitled `Brunette Downs-The Facts'.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
BRUNETTE DOWNS-THE FACTS
What the Government claims

On 19 May 1989, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Gerry Hand, wrote to The Australian to congratulate the paper on its front-page story about living conditions of Aboriginal people at the Northern Territory cattle station known as Brunette Downs.
The Minister wrote:

``The story focused on the living conditions of the Brunette Downs' Aboriginal stockmen and their families. The shocking conditions they endured are directly related to the fact that they have no title to the area of land on which they live.

It is a problem which unfortunately is not confined to the Aboriginal people living on Brunette Downs. There are other Aboriginal communities who, because their traditional living areas happen to be part of pastoral leases, have no title or security to their land.
In most cases this means the Government cannot do anything about proper housing or infrastructure requirements.''
The facts
These assertions, and the matters represented in The Australian as the factual basis for Mr Hand's implied criticism of Brunette Downs, require closer examination.
The facts show that:
the Aboriginal people at Brunette Downs have had title to land there for several years;
the site of that land was chosen by the people and title transferred to them at no cost;

the people later decided they wanted a different site. The company has agreed in principle to a second excision. Title will pass as soon as Mr Hand honours the Government's promise to exclude stock routes/reserves from land claim.
What The Australian says
On 5 and 16 May 1989, The Australian gave prominent coverage to a ``photographic essay'' entitled Brunette Downs: a showpiece property for whites, a squalid camp for Aborigines.

The article drew a sharp distinction between the living conditions for station owners and Aboriginal families nearby. It implies that the pastoral company is content with the present situation and has done nothing to improve matters.

It is stated that the Human Rights Commission has investigated the whole matter. Yet the Commission established that the complaint submitted on behalf of the community by the Northern Land Council did not warrant investigation.

The article conveniently neglects to mention, until just near the end, that, at the instigation of the company, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs has agreed to provide temporary housing improvements at the existing camp site.

There is not one word in the article explaining that, if the Federal Minister had delivered his Government's promises on stock routes/reserves, the company would by now have signed a new second lease with the community where they would be able to make any accommodation arrangements which suited them.
History of the negotiations

In 1980, Brunette Downs management and the Aboriginal Community agreed on an area of 4104ha south of the Tablelands Highway and north of Barkly Stock Route (the ``Corella Creek'' site) as suitable for excision from Brunette Downs.
The Aboriginal community leader, Mr Jack Cotton, signed an acceptance note on 5 October 1980. (Document A).
A sub-lease was drawn up and signed in September 1982. Again, Mr Cotton signed on behalf of the Jarnba-Gadarlangi Aboriginal Corporation. (Document C).

Between 1982 and 1987, it became clear that the community members had changed their minds. On 24 November 1987, the Northern Territory Department of Lands and Housing informed the leaseholders that ``the people do not wish to live at Corella Creek on the eastern side of the Tablelands Highway''. The letter also said ``that the Aboriginal community wishes to pursue an interest in an excision at the Two Mile Waterhole on Brunette Creek.'' (Document D).

The leaseholders replied on 27 May 1987 indicating that they would offer an alternative site. (Document E). The letter said the Company would ``seriously consider the excision of an area, for living site . . . adjacent to the Two Mile Waterhole of one square kilometre . . .'' There were a number of conditions attached to this offer. The most important was that the Federal Government should comply with its earlier undertaking to protect stock routes and reserves from claim as Aboriginal land. Such a requirement was quite reasonable, since the Government had publicly promised to pass this legislation. The former Minister had kept his word but the present Minister decided not to proclaim the amendment.

Since then, however, it would seem that the community have changed their minds again. Now it is said on their behalf that they wish to stay at the present site, which is within 500m of the Brunette Downs homestead. However, no official indication of this further change in preference has been given to the leaseholders.

Although this proposal has always been unacceptable to the leaseholders, they remain concerned to improve the living conditions of the Aboriginal community-now camping near the homestead. A meeting was held in Darwin on 16 November 1988 involving all parties. This meeting was called by the leaseholders themselves.

A later consequence of this meeting was that the Department of Aboriginal Affairs eventually accepted the company's proposal and agreed to fund certain improvements at the homestead site. The work included 8 new housing units, even though the community will have to move from there when permanent arrangements are agreed on. That work is now in progress and that fact would have been known to the Minister when he wrote to The Australian on 19 May 1989.
Alleged Human Rights Commission ``investigation''
The Australian article of 5 May stated that the Aboriginal settlement at Brunette Downs was ``the embarrassing subject of a Human Rights Commission investigation into living conditions''.

The truth is that, in October last year, the Northern Land Council Chairman said that the Human Rights Commission ``is to be asked to act on a dispute in which a Pastoral Company is asking the Northern Territory Aboriginal community to shift off their traditional home''.
It is not known whether the NLC or the community did make a complaint to the Commission. But, if a complaint was made, it was never taken to investigation or hearing.
It is by no means clear whether the NLC has any power or responsibility under the Act establishing it, to make any complaint or otherwise act for this community.

It is, however, quite clear that the Human Rights Commission took no investigative action in this case. There is no doubt that the Commission has power to investigate matters which may involve ``unlawful'' acts as defined in the statute. The fact that they did not act shows that there was not even a prima facie case of breach of human rights involved in this instance.
Breach of faith by Commonwealth Minister

The situation at Brunette Downs would have long since been resolved if the Commonwealth Minister had honoured the understanding of his predecessor and amended the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act so that stock routes and reserves were excluded from claim. In return, the cattlemen had agreed to hasten negotiation of excisions for Aboriginal living areas from their leaseholdings.

The Government's failure to proclaim the legislation it promised meant that the pastoral leaseholders could not continue negotiations. The Commonwealth Government must accept full responsibility for this delay. It could advance matters immediately by proclaiming the legislation without further prevarication.
The Evidence
Copies of the following documents are tabled showing the facts of this matter:

a. ``Brunette Downs Sub-lease to Aboriginals''. This document, signed on behalf of the Aboriginal community by their leader, Mr Jack Cotton, accepts an offer to sub-lease ``16 square miles more or less'' in an area to the north-east of the North Barkly Stock route.

b. Copy of letter dated 3 September 1981 from the DAA area office to the Company. The letter states that the Northern Territory Government had indicated a willingness to upgrade the water reticulation etc. at their expense ``provided some sort of land tenure can be negotiated''. As already noted, such tenure had in fact been already agreed to.
c. Copy of sub-lease of September 1982.

d. Copy of letter dated 24 November 1987 from Northern Territory Department of Lands and Housing to the Company stating that ``the people do not wish to live at Corella Creek on the eastern side of the Tablelands Highway'' (ie, the 16 square mile site). The letter also stated ``that the Aboriginal community wishes to pursue an interest in an excision at the Two Mile Waterhole on Brunette Creek''.
e. Copy of company's letter to the Department of Lands and Housing dated 27 May 1988, agreeing in principle to a second sub-lease ``north of the Brunette Creek adjacent to the Two Mile Waterhole''.

f. Copy of letter dated 6 May 1989 from DAA to the Company stating that ``Jurnkurakurr Aboriginal Resource Centre will commence work next week on the construction of shelters at Brunette Downs Aboriginal Community''.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I seek leave to table, for the interest of honourable senators, a series of six documents referred to in the statement I have just incorporated.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make only two brief points with regard to these incorporated and tabled documents. I stress that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . they-
the people at Brunette Downs-
have no title to the area of land on which they live.

He must have known that that statement was incorrect. I draw attention to the cunning use of words in that particular statement and also to the fact that the so-called human rights investigation that was drummed up by the Northern Land Council did not take place because in fact there was nothing to investigate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I return briefly to the theme of banking which, as I am sure honourable senators are aware, I have been exploring for weeks. Since I first raised the question of allegations of banking malpractice in November 1988, quite obviously the profile of the banking issue generally in the community has increased quite dramatically. The focus recently, of course, has been on questions of bank charges-specifically, bank interest charges. The question of charges generally has captured the interest of the public, as have the extraordinary profits-I think the banks referred to them as super profits-announced by all major banks in Australia in recent times.

SPEECH.PARA: On previous occasions, I have tabled 39 affidavits relating to allegations of serious banking malpractice. Indeed, I proposed to the Senate that the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs address these serious allegations. I have undertaken on behalf of constituents to table, for the consideration of honourable senators, further examples of these allegations of malpractice. I seek leave to table two further affidavits today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister had a chance to have a look at those?
—I presume that the usual courtesies would have been entered into, knowing Senator McLean's reputation.

—I thank the Senate. I have circulated copies of those two affidavits to the Minister who was previously at the table and to the shadow Minister on duty. They refer to the cases-I will cite them now, but not in detail-of Michael Patek, who has a dispute with the Westpac Banking Corporation, and Kenneth Whitbread, who has a dispute with the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group. I will not take up the time of the Senate by elaborating the details of these cases, but I have spent some considerable time examining them. They are of a nature that I believe warrant the attention of those senators who are pursuing with some interest this growing issue of banking and, specifically, allegations of malpractice and corruption.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to one further matter which touches on the issue of bank charges and the attitude of banks to those charges. I have received a letter from a Mr D. G. Quinton who is a public accountant and who, like many of us, has a bank mortgage-in his case with the Royal Bank-and who sought an explanation of some of the charges which were being made on his account. He was either unable to follow the explanation or not satisfied by it and he pursued the matter; in fact, he has been doing so over some considerable period. He is obviously a very diligent and fastidious person who keeps very close records, is persistent and does not give in. He was dissatisfied with the responses from the Royal Bank. He approached the Australian Bankers Association concerning this dissatisfaction. He took issue with a press release which it had put out on 3 July 1988. I quote from that press release of the Australian Bankers Association:

Banks will undertake to provide the above information in such a way as to enable any customer who so wishes to calculate independently charges made by the bank and to verify their accuracy. Details of methodology employed will be available on request.

Mr Quinton took that assurance from the Australian Bankers Association on its merits. He sought an explanation for some of the charges. As I say, he was dissatisfied with, or unable completely to comprehend, the explanations that were given to him. However, more recently, in following up these matters, he has received a reply from the Royal Bank which, among other things says:

Please note that further correspondence, unless it is to do with refinancing, will be directed to our solicitors for reply. The costs of their attending to that work will be debited to your loan account without further notice to you.

So this bank has taken the attitude that if one is not satisfied with its answers, one cannot comprehend its answers, or one believes they are inadequate, once it has offered what it considers to be satisfactory explanations, any queries thereafter will be referred to its solicitors and one will be required to cover the costs thereof. Those costs, without further notice, will be debited automatically to one's bank account. That strikes me as a very potent way of truncating the process of open inquiry which had been assured by the Bankers Association in its press release of 3 July 1988.

Mr Quinton, being, as I say, persistent, took the matter up quite recently with the Australian Bankers Association. On 28 April this year he wrote seeking its intervention. He received the following reply. This is the entire text of the letter:

I refer to your letter of 28th April 1989 and advise that this Association is not a governing body for the member banks and it is not within our charter to become involved in individual bank-customer disputes.

That is probably a fairly reasonable position for the Australian Bankers Association to take, but it contradicts its press release of 3 July 1988 and it certainly does not resolve the sorts of difficulties in which Mr Quinton and others find themselves. There has been inadequate explanation of bank charges, and they face what could be substantial legal expenses incurred by banks to respond to requests for explanation. This attitude stands in marked contrast to that which has been espoused by the Australian Bankers Association in the recent suggestions that it will voluntarily set up an ombudsman process. The Australian Bankers Association, as you know, Madam Acting Deputy President, has undertaken to sponsor the process of a bank ombudsman. I think that is quite a positive first step, provided that we can assume the process encompasses a little more than banks looking at banks. We hope that the Australian public will get more satisfaction from this process than they received, for instance, from the process of police looking at police over the last decade or so.

I cite the Quinton case simply to illustrate what I have attempted to illustrate previously, and to demonstrate to the Senate that the ethos of banking and the attitude of banks stand in contradiction to their fundamental fiduciary relationship to the client which requires that they consider the interests of their client as being equal to their own interests. The Australian community has every reason to be dissatisfied with the posture of banks in the Australian community today. On future occasions I will continue to bring before the Senate serious matters in relation to banking.

This morning I had a protracted discussion in my office with a gentleman who is making most extraordinary allegations about the way in which he has been treated by banks in the last two weeks. I am investigating those matters further. Last Saturday I had several hours of discussion with a gentleman who, once again, has given me examples of very serious difficulties with banks which he believes have been inadequately investigated by the Australian Federal Police, the Victorian fraud squad and the Trade Practices Commission. I will pursue that issue further. If I believe it is responsible to do so, I will bring it to the attention of the Senate at a later time. However, on this occasion I seek leave to table Mr Quinton's letters and the correspondence he has had with the Royal Bank and the Australian Bankers Association.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate once again for its tolerance in this matter. I am quite sure that all honourable senators are aware of the fact that the issue of banking is one of primary concern to the Australian community. I am convinced that as time goes by, as we move towards an election, the Australian community will reinforce my requests that I have placed before the Parliament to regard the whole question of banking as one which warrants the attention not only of Government but of Parliament. I will at a later date again put before the Senate the proposal for a Senate inquiry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the past two years I have been helping a constituent to investigate the use of epidural injections for the treatment of lower back pain and other pain resulting from injuries such as whiplash injuries sustained in motor vehicle accidents. This research has revealed what I regard as a totally scandalous situation in my home State of Western Australia and I suspect that a similar situation may also exist in other States. My basic concern is that doctors in Western Australia-mainly anaesthetists who specialise in pain relief-are routinely giving a dangerous and sometimes damaging form of treatment to a very large number of people.
