Many individuals are experiencing severe adverse reactions to this treatment. Honourable senators may be surprised to know that when a patient experiences a serious adverse reaction to a drug or a form of therapy, it is not mandatory for a doctor to make a report to the adverse drug reaction committee. Forms are available to doctors to make such a report, but they are not obliged to use them. I understand that in Britain and the United States the reporting of adverse reactions to drugs and therapies is mandatory.

SPEECH.PARA: The particular form of treatment that I am concerned about is the epidural administration of the drug methylprednisolone acetate. It is a form of cortisone. The trade name under which it is commonly marketed in Australia is Depo-Medrol. This drug is intended for use in the treatment of inflamed and painful joints. A typical injury for which it is suitable is an injury to the knee joint. As far as I am aware, the drug is efficacious in this particular application. I have no reports of problems with it in that respect, although I understand that the drug has been banned from use with horses. Depo-Medrol is not intended for use in the joints of the spinal column. The notes supplied by the manufacturer specifically warn against its use in the joints of the spine. Under the heading `adverse reactions' there is reference to reports of developments of a condition known as arachnoiditis if the drug is administered in the spinal column.

Attempts were made, beginning in about 1960, to treat both disc diseases and multiple sclerosis by intrathecal injections of Depo-Medrol-that is, injections into the fluid of the membrane of the spine. There were some initial promising reports as a result of clinical trials, but these were rapidly followed by a mass of contradictory results and warnings of many serious complications, such as the development of sterile meningitis, arachnoiditis or pachymeningitis. By 1979 intrathecal use of the drug had almost ceased because of a number of studies which showed conclusively that horrendous and frequent complications ensued. At this time, in about 1979, there developed renewed interest in the epidural use of Depo-Medrol for the treatment of severe and persistent back pain. A number of reports announced its efficacy and safety.

An epidural injection is one in which a presumed therapeutic substance is injected close to, but external to, the membranes which protect the spinal column. The theory was that depomedrol administered outside the membranes would not be able to cross this barrier and contaminate the spinal fluid. Once again, however, within quite a short time other specialists began to question the efficacy of this form of treatment and to report adverse reactions. There were reports that the treatment was completely ineffective. There were other reports of serious complications and adverse reactions, including arachnoiditis and meningitis, which I mentioned previously. The epidural use of Depo-Medrol for the control of back pain and other spinal conditions has been highly controversial ever since.

There are three possible dangers connected with the use of Depo-Medrol for epidural injections. In the first case, a planned epidural injection may, by mechanical misadventure, become an intrathecal injection, that is, the anaesthetist making the injection inadvertently pierces the membranes and injects the drug directly into the spinal column, where it is conclusively proven to be capable of doing enormous damage. This happens, on average, with between 0.5 and 2.5 per cent of injections. The patients who receive these injections by misadventure are highly likely to experience very serious adverse reactions.

In the second case, the needle may enter the interspinous ligaments as a result of inaccurate placement. This has been proven to occur in up to 42.5 per cent of injections. In the third case, Depo-Medrol injected epidurally as intended may very well cross the blood brain barrier and contaminate the spinal fluid, again with potentially catastrophic results for the patients. My concern is that in my State of Western Australia this form of therapy continues to be widely practised by a number of anaesthetists. I seek leave to table 17 statutory declarations from constituents in Western Australia which detail the dreadful impact this treatment has had on their lives.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —These people all had spinal problems, some as a result of work-related injuries, and others as a result of traffic accidents. In the great majority of cases their medical treatment was being paid for under workers compensation or by the Motor Vehicle Insurance Trust. In a number of cases they had experienced pain for a long period of time and had had other unsuccessful treatments for that pain, but they were still functioning effectively as human beings and they were still able to work as productive members of our society. Following the treatment, they have experienced a great range of serious adverse effects and a number of them have been rendered incapable of working and turned into pain-ridden invalid pensioners. They regard themselves as a burden on their families, a burden on society and, in fact, a burden to themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to stress this aspect of the problem because it is the most distressing aspect of it. This form of treatment is routinely being given by qualified specialists. It takes full functioning individuals, suffering from distressing and manageable pain, and converts them into physical wrecks. Some of the reactions reported in these statutory declarations include: vastly increased pain; severe headaches; intracranial pressure; confusion and poor memory; paralysis of the arms and legs; abdominal distension; blurred vision; involuntary spasms; sweating; rashes; muscle weakness; loss of muscle mass; skin discoloration; total loss of sexual function; quick temper and nervousness; bleeding from the rectum; dizziness; chronic dermatitis; peptic ulcer; kidney pain; limitation of movement; weight gain; photosensitivity; numbness; bowel problems; fluid retention, and chronic adhesive arachnoiditis. The list goes on and on. The Senate will begin to understand why I expressed concern at the commencement of my remarks about the non-reporting of adverse reaction to drugs.

I have no means of knowing how many people have been affected, but I do know that a considerable number of people in Western Australia have been receiving this treatment. On the basis of limited publicity-a small advertisement placed by one of my constituents in a local suburban paper and a couple of follow-up radio interviews-my office is now in touch with almost 100 people who have experienced problems with this treatment. I suspect that the numbers may be many more.

Surprisingly, I have not been contacted by anybody who has defended the treatment and claimed that he or she has experienced beneficial effects as a result of it. We are dealing with a therapy which does not appear to help anyone and certainly causes great damage to a number of those on whom it is practised.

Another aspect greatly concerns me. I have pointed out that the manufacturer who supplies the drug in question specifically provides a warning in the accompanying notes about its unsuitability for injection into the joints of the spine. I have detailed a large number of the adverse reactions which have been reported to me by people and which are contained in their statutory declarations. It is therefore clear that the specialists who administer this treatment cannot but be very much aware both of the warning and of the adverse reactions. The principle of informed consent requires that a practitioner proposing to embark upon a course of treatment must advise the patient of the nature of the treatment, of any attendant risks and of any adverse reactions which may be experienced. The patient is then in a position to decide whether he or she is prepared to accept any risks which may be involved in return for any prospect of relief.

A constant refrain throughout these stat- utory declarations is that the patients were not told what drug was being used. They were not told that there was a warning from the manufacturer against its use in the spinal joints. They were not told anything about the procedure involved. They were not warned of the possibility of any debilitating reactions. I believe that steps must be taken to ensure that doctors genuinely respect the principle of informed consent. Indeed, I suggest that they should be liable to powerful sanctions if they engage in risky or controversial forms of treatment without adequately informing the patients concerned.

By raising this matter in the Senate I hope to achieve the following: I believe that it is imperative that the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) place an interim ban on the use of Depo-Medrol by the epidural route while a detailed investigation is conducted by the Department of Health and Community Services into the efficacy and safety of this form of treatment. This would be with a view to the imposition of a permanent ban on this form of treatment if the investigation reveals, as indeed it may well do, that this treatment offers benefits to few and disastrous consequences to many. It is imperative that the Government move to make the reporting of adverse drug reactions mandatory and to provide for the use of powerful sanctions against doctors who fail to make such reports. It is imperative that the Government further review the application in Australian medicine of the principle of informed consent and take steps to make doctors liable to serious professional and financial consequences if they neglect adequately to inform patients before engaging in forms of treatment. I believe that these steps will stop the damage which is currently being done to people's lives and may also bring an end to serious abuses which they may not even be aware of in the initial stages.

The human and financial costs of the situation which I have just described are absolutely horrendous. Some of the people affected have described their experiences as a `lingering, living death' which, in one case at least, has continued for more than 10 years. The treatment itself is expensive and involves a half-day in hospital for each injection, with minor theatre costs. These costs are in one way or another borne by the community. They contribute to the high level of workers compensation, insurance premiums and also motor vehicle insurance premiums. The loss from the work force of those permanently incapacitated is also enormously expensive to the community.

Honourable senators may ask why doctors persist with this form of treatment when they can see with their own eyes what damage it does to people's lives. I cannot answer that question. I have covered only the medical aspects of this problem. There are other aspects to it, such as the way workers compensation insurance works in Australia, the involvement of the legal profession and the unions and the role of the State Government. The overall picture is ugly. I hope to develop it further in another speech at a later time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it the Motor Vehicle Standards Bill 1989. The Opposition will be supporting the legislation. The Bill is comprehensive and proposes to give effect to a series of Inter-State Commission recommendations concerning a common, Australia-wide standard for the importation of motor vehicles and components into Australia. The Bill will establish and apply a national uniform standard for motor vehicle safety and environmental quality which will apply at the time of first sale in Australia, irrespective of where the vehicle has come from.

SPEECH.PARA: The standards will be declared by ministerial order. They will apply to vehicles offered for sale in Australia prior to their first registration. Once the vehicles are in Australia, the laws that exist within each State with respect to maintenance and operation will apply. So the responsibilities of the States are not diminished in that sense, except that now we will have an overriding national safety standard in place.

The Bill will require that identification is on the vehicles showing that they comply with the Australian Design Rules. The Bill comprehensively goes into the monitoring, manufacturing and testing processes for the production of vehicles and spare parts. It also provides appropriate sanctions for breaches of the Act. The Bill applies both to new vehicles imported into this country for sale and to the second-hand market.

Over the last 20 years we have had in this country a certification system for motor vehicles. It has been developed between the various States, the Federal authorities and the vehicle industry. It has been managed out of the Federal Office of Road Safety. In the early 1970s, the Australian Design Standards were introduced to provide minimum standards. They covered a variety of features: safety requirements, vehicle exhaust emission, noise, and anti-theft requirements. The design standards, where possible, were harmonised with international standards. To date, Australia achieves about 60 per cent harmonisation with international safety standards.

Whilst it is not covered in this Bill, I think it is important that we move towards an agreed international standard with respect to design rules for motor vehicles because it costs the consumer if we have our own rules. Whether the consumer is in Australia is not the chief point. Consumers all around the world are affected in some way or other by the cost of meeting these standards. The more varied they are, the more the cost of the vehicles necessarily must be. There is no reason why vehicles produced in Australia should have different safety standards and different emission requirements from standards required of vehicles produced in the centre of Germany or in North America. It is the same environment, essentially, in which they are operating. The provision of agreed standards would be of benefit to all of us.

Australia needs to be more conscious of international standards. I give as an example the certification standards relating to the importation of aircraft. Ludicrously, the Federal authority designated with the responsibility for the certification of aircraft, the Civil Aviation Authority, sets the assessment criteria and certifies passenger aircraft imported into this country that have been rigorously tested in their country of manufacture. The last aircraft we brought in was the 737/300 series. It cost Australian Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia $1m to reinvent the wheel, to prove that the aeroplane was safe. In all the years that the Australian authorities have examined imported passenger aircraft, costing Australian users millions of dollars, not one modification has arisen. In other words, the certifying processes in the United States, Britain and Europe, where our passenger aircraft come from, are more than adequate for our requirements.

There is a real need for Australia to grow up and to recognise that standards can be set internationally and that we do not need to stand out in an uncompromising way. I would hope that particularly in the car market-a far more important market with respect to the volume of production than the aviation market-we move rapidly to an agreed international standard for all matters covered by the Design Rules.

Under the old legislation, because the responsibility was divided between the various States and the Federal Government, a vehicle manufacturer or a vehicle importer had to deal with at least eight different authorities. Whilst a base level was set by the Federal authorities for vehicle standards, various States had differences. Again, delays and cost, inevitably, were involved in this program. The other point is that the Commonwealth had no legal capacity to intervene to enforce the standards.

This Bill will overcome the different standards within the country. It is hard to put a numerical value on the benefit it will be to the industry, but it certainly will contain costs to some degree. It is particularly important in regard to one facet, that is, the importation of used vehicles. There has been a flourishing trade in imported cars as Australian cars have become more expensive-as a consequence of the failed Button car plan. It has been very attractive to pick up vehicles around Asia, particularly in Japan. The Japanese certification requirements are so tight that five years after the purchase of a car it does not become economic for the Japanese to keep that car on the road. The renewal of registration becomes so expensive that the Japanese sell them. One often wonders whether that does not have an influence on Japanese design practices; that the Japanese build vehicles that basically satisfy the five-year rule. It means that a large number of vehicles have been available at a very low price in Japan and they have been imported into Australia. Because of the variation in State standards it has been most attractive to import them through Western Australia. This legislation will prevent that happening by imposing a standard that imported vehicles have to meet. It is important that, if we do have standards, we do not have loopholes in them.

I was talking earlier this morning about the cost of alcohol to Australia and its social consequences. It is also true that road accidents are a big cost to the economy. It is estimated that the cost of road accidents is in excess of $5 billion a year. That is an enormous amount of money. It not only involves property damage; there are also some very severe human consequences. The mortality rate is devastating. About 3,000 people a year are routinely killed on Australian roads. If we were losing 3,000 people a year in aviation accidents, in Army training or in a sporting activity, the country would be in uproar. The fact is that a ritual process which kills 3,000 of our fellow citizens on average a year passes without comment in this country. I find that quite terrible.

Apart from those who are killed, there is the morbidity side of it-the people who are injured in road accidents: the quadriplegics and paraplegics, and the human distress it causes their families and the society supporting these people. The whole purpose of the Design Rules with respect to safety standards is to ensure, firstly, that vehicles licensed for sale in Australia have safe handling qualities and, secondly, that when accidents occur, the passengers within the vehicles get the maximum amount of protection possible.

So the Opposition supports this proposal. We take particular interest in the denial of the loophole in regard to the importation of vehicles. It is important that those importers who acted in good faith and within the correct letter of the law as it stood, those who had made forward orders at the time this legislation was announced, have the right to import those vehicles into the country. Clearly, they were operating within the law as it stood at the time. I believe that the Bill will allow that to take place.

I think it is worth making some comment about the way the Government has mismanaged the manufacturing side of passenger vehicles in this country. The latest plan-the Button car manufacturing plan-has been in place for four or five years and we have nothing to show for it. Australians now have the privilege of paying, both for locally produced cars and for imported cars, at least twice what they would pay for the same vehicle in the United States. Under the Button plan, Australian manufacturers have increased the price of their products to a level which enables them, when imported cars are brought in and heavy duty is paid on them, just to undercut the price of imported cars and thereby maintain their market share. In short, the plan has not succeeded; it has been a failure. It does not matter how much Senator Button rabbits on about what great changes and rationalisations have taken place in the industry, the fact is that, after a fair trial, we are still paying twice what we should be paying for vehicles-vehicles which, by and large, do not meet quality control standards that are attained by the Japanese, the American or the European producers and which are often a year or two, or five or six years, behind with respect to component design refinements. In conclusion, the Opposition supports this legislation and wishes it a speedy passage through the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats applaud the Government for its action in bringing in the Motor Vehicle Standards Bill-action in which we have taken a particular interest throughout this year. While this legislation has a broad ambit-that is, to enable the Federal Government to establish and apply nationally uniform standards for motor vehicle safety, gaseous and noise emissions and anti-theft devices-the specific area of interest with which I, on behalf of the Democrats in my capacity as consumer affairs spokesperson, have been involved during this year has related to concerns which arose out of the enormous increase in imports of substandard second-hand vehicles, particularly from Japan, and especially-as Senator MacGibbon has mentioned-through Western Australia. This has occurred as a result of the lack of a national set of standards. Western Australia has been the most favoured State for this practice.

SPEECH.PARA: In February of this year I made a public statement by way of a press release expressing our concern about the road safety issue, and I put the position of Australian consumers on this matter. We were very concerned that a large and increasing number of cars without standard safety features, such as side intrusion bars, seat belt anchoring points, anti-burst door locks, and so on, were coming into the country, being registered and finding their way out of Western Australia as well as remaining in large numbers in Western Australia. We were also concerned about the safety of people purchasing these vehicles, their inability to have the vehicles serviced, to get spare parts, and so on.

We pursued the issue. I asked a question on 8 March of the Minister for Consumer Affairs, Senator Bolkus, raising the issue of the danger of these cars on our roads and consumer issues. I referred to insurance companies not wanting to insure these cars, to the unavailability of spare parts and also to the position of consumers with regard to litigation which might follow any accident involving cars of this nature. On 15 March, the Minister sought the views of the Trade Practices Commission on the importation of commercial quantities of used passenger vehicles said not to conform with the Australian Design Rules, and which in some cases might pose safety hazards for consumers.
We received a report from the Trade Practices Commission in May. I note that at that time Senator McKiernan, in the West Australian, expressed his concern.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you.

—I note that because I happened to come across a press clipping. I am not claiming to be the only person around here who is concerned. That is really what I am saying. The officer of the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Brown) pursued the issue with us.

SPEECH.PARA: We are, as I say, extremely pleased to see that this legislation has come before us. It does, of course, go beyond the importation issue. The Government has taken the opportunity to address the important question of national standards. The Australian Democrats have urged the implementation of a range of national standards in a number of other areas, particularly from the consumer angle. As Senator MacGibbon has pointed out, there are enormous economic disadvantages to this country because of the disparities that we so often find in so many areas from State to State.

So in general terms we support the concept of national standards in this area, particularly in view of the fact that this legislation addresses the issue of the importation of large numbers of vehicles. They have been largely Japanese vehicles, because the system of motor car registration in Japan makes it virtually impossible for Japanese consumers to keep a car much beyond five years unless they are prepared to spend a great deal of money going through the incredible hoops they have to go through to continue to register cars of that age. So there is an enormous market of barely used second-hand vehicles in that country. I have been told stories of whole fields of vehicles just sitting in Japan waiting to be exported around the world.

The implications for our indigenous industry are enormous. It is a fact of international economic life, I suppose, but it is a cunning market practice of the Japanese industry. An extraordinarily high proportion of Japanese motor vehicles are sold in New Zealand-more than 50 per cent, I believe. I suppose that while this is a free country, with a free market to a large extent, we simply have to accept that this is likely to happen. However, what the Democrats have said all along is that if motor vehicles are going to come into this country and be registered here they must meet the same standards as the motor vehicles which are produced in this country have to meet. Further, we have said that those standards should be the same throughout the country.

Therefore, we commend the Government for this legislation and, in particular, for the speed with which this legislation has appeared subsequent to the concern that was expressed publicly by us and others on the issue of the importation of substandard vehicles. I understand that the Government has been working towards this sort of legislation for some time. The industry felt a need for it and expressed that need. A conjunction of events has brought us this legislation today, which the Democrats endorse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator MacGibbon, speaking on behalf of the Opposition, and Senator Powell, speaking on behalf of the Australian Democrats, have both indicated their support for the Motor Vehicle Standards Bill 1989, produced by the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown). I do not need to go through an exposition of what the Bill contains because that has been well and adequately done by Senators MacGibbon and Powell. I thank them for their support.

SPEECH.PARA: They made a number of comments-some helpful and some critical-which I will draw to the attention of the relevant Ministers. Senator MacGibbon made some comments about the Button car plan. I do not endorse those comments. I am sure that Senator MacGibbon is not shocked by that admission by me. Senator MacGibbon concluded by wishing this Bill a speedy passage. I join him in that sentiment.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to part 2 of the Bill, `National Standards', could I have an explanation from the Minister of clause 9, which says that the Minister `may make arrangements, in accordance with the regulations', for a series of functions. Why is the word `may' used, rather than a firmer obligation on the Minister compelling him to set up the various testing standards?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the form in which those words appear is the modern drafting style for this type of provision. It means that the Minister can set up the testing standards. I am advised that the Minister will be doing so and that it will be in the regulations.

—Thank you. I just felt that, given the whole nature of the Bill, which is to enforce standards, the clause should have had a firmer direction. Over the page, under `nonstandard vehicles not to be used by manufacturers', paragraph 15 (1) (b) states that a corporation that manufactured a new vehicle that does not have a compliance plate `must not knowingly or recklessly use the vehicle in transport in Australia'. Could I have a definition of what `in transport' means? Does it mean that it is okay if someone uses the vehicle for personal use or does it actually prohibit any use of the vehicle at all? In other words, it is one thing to sell the vehicle, but is one permitted to use the vehicle for one's own purposes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources)

TALK.START.PARA: —I turn to page 3 of the Bill, `Interpretation', clause 5. Line 34 defines `use in transport' as part of the Bill's interpretation. I do not propose to read it.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Cook) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN FEDERAL POLICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 May, on motion by Senator Cook:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Federal Police Legislation Amendment Bill is supported by the Opposition. A number of matters have been subject to negotiation, but those negotiations have been concluded and allow our support at this time without our having to propose amendments. I will mention those in a minute. There are four principal issues contained in the legislation. The first is in relation to the loss of superannuation benefits because of corruption. The Bill cancels the superannuation benefits of members of the Australian Federal Police (AFP) who are convicted of a corruption offence and sentenced to imprisonment for life or a term longer than 12 months. A corruption offence is defined as an offence involving an abuse of office, one which is committed for a corrupt purpose, or perverting or attempting to pervert the course of justice. Therefore, after conviction and sentence, the AFP member runs the risk of having his or her superannuation benefits cancelled. That order is made by the court which heard the original charge. If the court order is made, the member loses the Commonwealth contribution but is repaid the employee's contribution and accrued interest.

SPEECH.PARA: The provision applies to present and former members convicted after commencement of the Act. Equivalent provisions apply in relation to members convicted of declared disciplinary offences under the AFP discipline regulations and also apply separately to the Commissioner and Deputy Commissioner. As I understand it, under the structure of the legislation a separate provision is needed in relation to such officers. There is, as you are well aware, Madam Acting Deputy President, widespread public concern that police officers who have been guilty of corruption might be able to leave the police force with large superannuation payouts. We support the Commonwealth in its efforts through this legislation to ensure that the public contribution to those payments is not made.

We have been concerned about a couple of aspects of this part of the Bill. The first was in relation to the disciplinary regulations. We were a bit worried that the disciplinary offences should not be of such a minor nature that it would seem to be unjust that such provisions would apply. We moved an amendment in the other place in order that the Parliament could have some input by making such provisions disallowable. I understand that there have been some negotiations between my colleague the shadow Attorney-General, Mr N. A. Brown, and the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, that enable me not to need to move that amendment in this place.

The other aspect that has caused us concern is in relation to members of the AFP who have taken a superannuation payout and have disposed of that payout in some way. Our belief is that, according to the normal principles of justice, the public should be able to recover the public contribution to such a payout where such officers are subsequently found guilty of a serious offence relating to official corruption. We moved amendments to that effect in the other place. We do not move them here because we have accepted an undertaking from the Government that it intends to introduce similar legislation that will cover the Australian Public Service generally, other government employees, and statutory office holders-and I think it will cover parliamentarians as well. In such circumstances we have indicated that we would be satisfied if the amendments that we moved in the other place to widen the scope of the Bill were included within that intended piece of legislation. The Government has indicated by letter to us that it will move accordingly. On that basis we are not seeking to amend this Bill. I look forward to the Minister's confirmation of that agreement when he responds today.

The second area covered by the Bill has to do with redeployment and retirement. The Bill contains streamlined provisions on redeployment and retirement which provide that if the Commissioner is satisfied that a member's services cannot be reasonably used in a particular position in his present rank, the member may be appointed to a specified position in a lower rank, or retired. That is subject to appeal under the Merit Protection Act. We think that that greater flexibility is worth while, and therefore we support it.

The third area covered by the Bill is witness protection. The Bill provides that the Commissioner may make arrangements with State and Territory police forces, the National Crime Authority and other authorities for the provision of services needed for a witness protection program. We have indicated in this chamber our support for a witness protection program under the auspices of the AFP, which has had a good record in relation to witness protection so far, and we therefore support these provisions. I should say that they represent only a start in dealing with the problems of witness protection. There are still major issues, such as the cost of such programs at the moment, which are going to have to be streamlined, and also the fact that there has been very little done so far to enable the establishment of a witness-after his services are no longer required-in a new identity. As you might imagine, Madam Acting Deputy President, that requires not only Commonwealth but State legislation in order that everything from motor vehicle licences to social security numbers and the like can be adequately varied. We urge the Government to lift its pace in relation to those necessary reforms.

The fourth and last area covered by the Bill is in relation to fixed term appointments. The Bill enables fixed term appointments to be made to prescribed or senior executive ranks. We understand that the Australian Federal Police Association supports that provision. We support it. Again, we think that fixed term appointments will provide greater flexibility and therefore is a reform that is worth while. As was indicated in the other place, and as I have indicated today, we therefore support the fourth of those reforms. On that basis I indicate our support for the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for its support.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, who has indicated that he will try to provide an answer. I ask: What is the Government's assessment of the current situation in China? Has the Government been conferring with other Western countries? Is there, in the opinion of the Government, anything Australia can do in cooperation with other nations to limit the bloodshed and chaos? What is the assessment of the Government as to whether other so-called counter-revolutionary centres outside the People's Republic of China, such as Hong Kong and Taiwan, are threatened by conflict? Finally, can the Government now account for the safety of all Australians still remaining in the country and, if not, what is it doing to ensure that all are safe?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot give a detailed answer to the last part of the question. All I can say is that I know efforts have been made to contact Australians in various parts of China. But there may be some more detailed and up to date information available than I have on that issue. Quite apart from any tourists in China, I am unable to say whether Australians working in various projects, in universities and so on throughout the country at the present time, have been accounted for.
—But is an effort being made by the Government to contact all those people?

—I understand so. But that effort may be very much curtailed or inhibited by a breakdown in communication systems. That comes back to the first part of Senator Lewis's question about the current assessment. It is fair to say that there is increasingly less hard news coming out of China and that newspaper headlines speculating about divisions within the military and so on are probably exaggerated.

ANSWER.PARA: In so far as conferring with other Western countries is concerned, intelligence assessments are made on behalf of the Australian Government and other Western countries. There is some liaison in comparing those intelligence assessments. However, I am not in a position to answer the question in further detail for obvious reasons.

The other point I should make-which is very much my own point-is that the machinery of government in China is currently totally preoccupied with its own problems and is not highly susceptible to what the outside world is saying or thinking about those issues. While countries might engage in a fair degree of competition to make statements about the issues, I am not sure that those signals from the outside world will be heeded or that they will be of a great deal of interest to the Chinese Government or whoever is in control at the present time. In answer to the question as to what Australia can do to limit the broadening of current problems in China, the realistic assessment is: not very much.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer to a grant of $1m recently allocated by the Federal Government to assist Australian Aborigines and Islanders to teach and maintain their unique languages. Is it a fact that only 20 Aboriginal languages now survive, when in 1788 almost 250 distinct Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander languages were spoken across Australia, consisting of more than 700 dialects? Is it correct that, based on the current rate of attrition, all Aboriginal and Islander languages will be extinct within 20 years? Is the grant of $1m vital in preserving the cultural heritage of the Aboriginal people? Has the Minister's attention been drawn to criticism levelled by the Opposition Aboriginal Affairs spokesman, Mr Smith, that the $1m would have been better spent on Aboriginal housing, employment and health? Can the Minister provide details of the amount of funding currently allocated by the Federal Government to provide housing, education and health for Aboriginal and Islander people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fact that only about 20 Aboriginal languages are still in existence. It is believed that a couple of hundred years ago there were about 250, with a larger number of dialects. It is also believed generally that without some government assistance the remaining 20 languages might well die out altogether. With that in mind Mr Dawkins has already announced that more than $1m will be allocated by the Commonwealth to assist Aborigines in teaching and maintaining their languages. This year 53 grants have been offered, most of them to community groups.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of criticism levelled at the program by the shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs, Mr Smith, who said that the money would be better spent somewhere else. However, I understand that Mr Smith made those comments not as the shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs but as Chairman of the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee in some previous incarnation-I am not sure whether he is still the Chairman of that Committee. Therefore, there seems to be a bit of confusion about where the Opposition or its spokesman on this subject stands on this issue and whether Mr Smith cares at all about the survival of the remnants of Aboriginal languages and the associated culture. In view of that, it is incumbent on the Opposition leadership, and especially on Senator Chaney, who has often claimed to have a deep and genuine interest in these matters, to clarify the Opposition's position on the funding for Aboriginal languages and to clarify whether Mr Smith's comments are his own views. If so, it is incumbent upon Senator Chaney and the Opposition to dissociate themselves from Mr Smith's views. For the record, since Mr Smith also mentioned housing, education and health, the Government is currently spending some $295m on those programs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Has he seen an article in the magazine New Idea of 29 April 1989 relating to matters concerning north Queensland? Senator Richardson is quoted directly as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: There's one guy in Ravenshoe I'll do great harm to if I ever get the opportunity-and I'm sure I will.

Will the Minister be courageous enough to name the man so that he can take the necessary precautions and so that other citizens of Ravenshoe will not feel threatened? What exactly does the Minister have in mind by proposing that he will `do great harm' to this citizen? Does the Minister have any particular friends or associates in mind who are professionally qualified or skilled in doing great harm to people on the Minister's hit lists? Does he think it is proper for a Minister of the Crown, pledged presumably to uphold the rule of law, to say publicly of an Australian citizen, `I'll do great harm to him if I ever get the opportunity-and I'm sure I will.'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the article. The quote attributed to me is roughly correct. I am not certain whether every word in it is correct. I repeat it now. The person concerned was responsible for an attempt to cause grievous bodily harm not only to me but also to many members of my staff. He spent a great deal of time trying to do that harm and, as far as I am concerned--
—Tell the police. Don't take it into your own hands.
—I will get to that; do not worry. As far as I am concerned, if people seek to perpetrate violence against me or members of my staff, I shall retaliate-and why should I not?
—An eye for an eye: is that what you are saying?

—The honourable senator should wait to see what I have to say. I am asked what sorts of things I intend to do-not an unreasonable question. I am asked also whether I have associates who are professionally good at these sorts of things.
—And are they out of gaol?

—Is that the next question? As far as Senator Puplick is concerned, in this Parliament over the last six years time and again he gets up and I hear allegations about the fact that I knew Tom Domican. Apparently this is supposed to be a devastating piece of news. The reality is that that will never be a substitute for policy or a substitute for Senator Puplick ever having the guts to stand up to those in the National Party or the New South Wales Government who are routing the environment. It will never cover up his weakness.

ANSWER.PARA: I am asked what sort of harm I have in mind. What I would dearly like to do is ensure that the Queensland police are able to do their job. When I was in Ravenshoe some time back, they failed dismally. In fact, they watched while the debacle occurred. They sat back and watched while a mob took on not just me but, as I said, members of my staff and a member of the other House, John Gayler. I will be going back there. I will make sure that the Queensland police are given the name of this person. I will make sure that, if that person repeats what he has done, he will finish up in strife. He would have been in strife last time, were it not for the fact that the Queensland police were hopeless.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why haven't you done it already?

—Good question. I will answer that question. The reason I have not done anything already is that there was an inquiry into this matter, and I was given an opportunity, I suppose one could say, to defend myself. The difficulty was that the inquiry was conducted by Judge Pratt. Does anyone remember who Judge Pratt is? The reason I cannot do anything about it is that the Queensland Government and its institutions are so crook that no-one can.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Since some part of the Minister's answer goes to the question of the nature of the Queensland police authorities, I ask: Since he claims that he, as a Minister of the Crown, was threatened, intimidated or subjected to some degree of physical abuse, what steps has he taken to refer this matter to his colleague Senator Tate and to the Australian Federal Police for it to take proper action on the basis that presumably he regards it as a police force of integrity under proper ministerial control? As a matter of principle, can he explain why it is he believes that it is necessary for him to take action when there are other remedies available to him through the law?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —After the incident in Ravenshoe, which was, as I said, quite some time ago, I saw Senator Tate about this issue and he agreed to make sure that on future visits, not just for me but for other Ministers, there would be a better assessment of risk involved by the Commonwealth police, and that further Commonwealth police protection would be made available. When I went back to Queensland on many other occasions, I made sure that I made the name of this person known to the officers who were with me. It is interesting to note that time and again the same person was there leading the charge-except that on the other occasions, because of the actions I had taken, that thug found himself faced with Commonwealth police officers who were doing their job. Next time I go back the same thing will happen.

—I refer the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to recent reports that show a slump in the growth rate of international travel to Australia. I also point out to the Minister that Queensland is a major popular destination for these international travellers-even though it might not be so good for the Minister-with many flying directly to Queensland through Brisbane. Is the Minister aware of the Government's recent announcement that construction of a new international airport terminal for Brisbane will not be started for at least the next three years? In light of the fact that this industry is Australia's second largest foreign exchange earner and that, due to the economic chaos into which the Government has plunged Australia, it is imperative to continue attracting as many tourists to our shores as possible, has the Minister made any attempt to get the Government to speed up the construction of Brisbane's international airport terminal-for example, by letting the contract out to private enterprise?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that recent tourist figures show a decline. In particular, that decline exists in the markets from the United States and New Zealand. Given that they have been our first and second markets, it is a matter of great concern. There has been a fall-off also in the numbers coming from other destinations, but there is still a 25 per cent increase over the previous 12 months, which is down slightly from the 26 per cent increase in the month before. The honourable senator asks about Brisbane Airport. I am aware that the terminal just constructed at Brisbane Airport cost $650m.
—That is the domestic one.

—I know it is a domestic one; I have been there. Given that $650m has been spent at Brisbane Airport in comparatively recent times by the Commonwealth, I think Brisbane and Queensland can say that they have done very well indeed. The question of improvements to the airport in Brisbane has to be a matter of some priority with the Commonwealth, but Brisbane Airport is by no means the only airport where work will be required. The Commonwealth will have to balance up those requirements around Australia. I am sure that, just as with the domestic terminal, improvements will, in the end, be made to the international one.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. I refer to the Minister's response to a question yesterday from Senator Collins regarding coverage in the press of the possible consequences of the increase in fees by general practitioners (GPs) of some $5 from 1 August 1989. Can the Minister indicate what the consequences to the Australian public of such an increase in consultation fees might be?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I indicated in broad terms what the cost to the general public would be if the legislation were rejected. I can now indicate in some specific examples what the cost would be. The examples I have selected are the electorates of Kingston and Fairfax, and the new electorate of Pearce. I observe that, as it so happens, these are the electorates for which the Leader of the Australian Democrats is running, the Leader of the National Party of Australia is running and the Leader of the Liberal Party of Australia is running. For the first time, all the leaders of the non-Labor parties are trying to get out of this chamber and are running for lower House seats. From Senator Button's point of view, that is a Garry Ablett-like performance. The three players that have been positioned on him are trying to move themselves off him.

ANSWER.PARA: I table the detailed workings out of the costs to those electorates. For the record, I mention that the cost to the ordinary population of Kingston would be $900,000. The loss of income for GPs would be $2,250,000. The cost to the electorate of Fairfax would be $900,000. I do not have figures for GPs. We do not have a census figure for the actual population of the new electorate of Pearce, but based on electors it would be $470,000. I do not have the figures for GPs. This document shows how those sums have been worked out. An elector in any one of those three electorates would not call those three people running the `three amigos'; he or she would call them the `three stooges'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories aware of a report in today's Sydney Morning Herald that the Japanese Daishowa Paper Manufacturing Co. Ltd is considering building pulp mills in Australia, including one at Grafton in New South Wales, which will produce unbleached paper board pulp? Does this mean that Australia is now placing some of the highest environmental standards on paper production in the world? Has the Minister considered thermomechanical pulping as a means of producing finished grade paper in Australia while using no chlorine bleach and consuming fewer trees than the current norm? Finally, will the Minister now consider outlawing the building of any new pulp mill in Australia which uses the old, environmentally disastrous kraft method of pulping?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware of the report in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald about Harris-Daishowa's intention to build two pulp mills, one at Grafton and one in Tasmania, and its statement that no chlorine bleaching would be conducted here in Australia. I also note its statement that, if that is the case, it would be none of Australia's business. I am not sure I can agree with that part of the statement made by its spokesperson this morning. There would obviously be two tests that any pulp mill proposal in Australia would have to pass. First and foremost, given that it is a Foreign Investment Review Board matter, economic tests apply, one matter being whether it is considered that this proposal and its value-added nature would be of sufficient benefit to Australia to warrant approval. That matter would be for the Treasurer, Mr Keating, and for the other economic Ministers to determine. The second test to pass would be the environmental test. The Government demonstrated the strength of its resolve when it came to the Wesley Vale mill earlier in the year. When one looks at that result one sees that the answer to question No. 2 of Senator McLean's question-are we placing some of the highest environmental standards on paper production in the world?-is yes.

ANSWER.PARA: As Senator McLean is aware, early in May, the Government announced that a delegation from the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, my Department and the industry would be going to Finland, Sweden and Canada to look at what was the best possible technology. I think that delegation is due to report by the end of this month. The members returned a couple of weeks ago. In the briefing that I have had so far from one member of the delegation, it is quite clear that the technology suggested for Wesley Vale was nowhere near the best possible technology and that the Government's decision to announce its intention to apply higher environmental standards, had the consortium wished to go ahead, was certainly correct.

I am asked whether I have considered thermomechanical pulping as a means of producing paper. Senator McLean will recall that the Prime Minister did change the terms of reference for the group that was going to Europe and Canada. As a result of that change of the terms of reference, I am sure that there will be a report on that process in this report we are expecting to get in the next few weeks. I shall let Senator McLean know what those experts have to say about its possibility.

The last question asked whether I have considered outlawing the building of any new pulp mill in Australia which uses the old environmentally disastrous kraft method of pulping. I have not considered attempting to outlaw kraft mills. It is not a decision I would make; it would be a government decision. I anxiously await this report. I think it may well suggest that if the best possible technology is used, then kraft mills do not necessarily have to be environmentally disastrous. The effluent which will come out from them, at the end of the day, might be very much cleaner than that which we were talking about before. I remind honourable senators that we were talking about 13 tonnes of organochlorins being dumped into Bass Strait every day. I am hopeful that that report will give us at least the basis to answer question No. 4. Certainly, at the moment I have not considered outlawing the building of a pulp mill which includes the kraft process.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs seen an item in this morning's Canberra Times reporting certain comments of Mr Sergio Buschmann criticising the Federal Government? Is Mr Buschmann's allegation true that the Government is bowing to pressure from Australian investors in Chile? What is the Government's attitude towards Mr Buschmann's self-proclaimed credentials as an `anti-fascist freedom fighter'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see the article in this morning's Canberra Times. It is not the first time these allegations have been made by either Mr Buschmann or his supporters, although, I note for the record, that when asked the question directly in a television interview over the weekend Mr Buschmann very quickly denied that allegation. But he has resurrected it again today-I can only assume for the purpose of playing on the emotions of those who are gullible and trying to raise emotions and false issues, as has occurred all the way through. My Department is dealing with this individual and his supporters. I reiterate that the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs is acting upon two matters related to his application form for a visa. Whenever these breaches are brought to our attention they are acted upon. He has been treated no differently from any other visitor to this country. As always in these cases, he was given the opportunity to leave voluntarily, as other visitors to this country are once a breach is brought to the attention of the Government. When one does not leave voluntarily our Department proceeds with the deportation.

ANSWER.PARA: On Friday night of last week Mr Buschmann was offered passage from this country via a safe route-not a dangerous route-but he insisted on going to Adelaide to continue his political activities. Throughout this matter the Department has acted in a non-political way. But I do say this: Mr Buschmann describes himself as an `anti-fascist fighter'. I would have thought that the first step down the road to fascism was ignoring the law or treating people differently under the law. In future our Department will find it impossible to enforce deportations or visa conditions if we let a darling of one section of society get away with breaches of those laws yet prosecute everyone else. I have not made any of these decisions on the basis of politics.

I guess we have had a fair deal of criticism because Mr Buschmann is perceived as a magnificent freedom fighter. I might put the record straight on that once and for all; in my view Mr Buschmann is a left wing terrorist. That is not only my view. I can quote leader after leader of the opposition in Chile, people who have risked their lives to oppose the Pinochet regime, people who are still in Chile risking their lives, who have condemned Mr Buschmann. The ultimate statement by Mr Buschmann that disgusts me and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade is that even if the democratic road were to succeed in Chile in 1990-91, and even if there were to be a democratically elected government, he would still pursue an armed overthrow of that government. There is no way that we, as a government, would support those activities and say, `All right, Chile has gone to democracy but you can still install a left wing terrorist regime to replace a right wing totalitarian regime'. None of these political issues has been used in the consideration of my Department in its treatment of Mr Buschmann. But if Mr Buschmann wants a public fire fight on his political views, I am willing to have it because to me they are not an Australian way of doing things. He is preying on the gullibility of his supporters in this country who, I accept, to a man and woman are anti-Pinochet. However, it does not necessarily follow that, if one is anti-Pinochet, one must support Mr Buschmann.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence concerns the request made to three large corporations each to prepare tenders for the Jindalee project and to put together a consortium of firms for that purpose. Has not Kel Aerospace, an Australian firm, designed and manufactured the best and cheapest practical apparatus to carry out over the horizon radar reception? Has it sold its products in 25 countries but not in Australia? Since it should be ideal for the project, having worked on Jindalee now for 10 years, given that it wishes to be part of the project and in view of the fact that at least two of the consortia have indicated no interest in this Australian manufacturer because of commitments made to potential overseas partners, I ask the Minister: Can he seek to ensure that, in the making of the contract with whichever prime contractor is successful, the Government will insist that manufacturers like Kel Aerospace not be excluded by the demands of overseas companies seeking to reserve to themselves elements of any successful contract for the Jindalee project? Will the Minister review the government furnishing equipment-or GFE-regulations in cases where government tendering works to exclude or limit the opportunities of qualified Australian manufacturers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly, I would acknowledge that Kel Aerospace has done some very important work over the last decade on this and has certainly sold its expertise and equipment to a number of countries. I am not sure whether that number is 25, but I accept the honourable senator's word for it. The Government has asked three large corporations to tender for Jindalee. Those corporations are Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, Telecom Australia and AWA Ltd, which are all Australian companies. These companies will take into account any Australian company that hopes to contribute to Jindalee. The Government is determined that Australia will have full technical control over this vital strategic asset. In relation to that vital control, obviously we hope Kel Aerospace will be an important part of the project. But its capabilities are on a small scale. It is not as if Kel Aerospace could have been asked to fulfil the whole contract. However, contrary to the information which the honourable senator has provided, I am advised that the company would be welcomed as a sub-contractor to the three companies that are bidding for the prime contract. In its approach to the project, the Government will certainly ensure that this company is encouraged to bid.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AIR SAFETY: ONGOING MAINTENANCE OF AIRCRAFT

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications relates to air safety. Is the Minister aware that the United States Federal Aviation Administration has just scrapped the practice of relying on regular inspections of aircraft to detect cracks and other signs of metal fatigue before parts are replaced? Instead, the United States aviation authorities have ordered extensive repairs of all aircraft to occur when planes reach a certain age or specified number of flights, regardless of their condition. For example, under the new guidelines of the United States Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), a Boeing 747 jumbo jet should undergo extensive modifications and repairs after 20,000 flights, or 20 years. I ask the Minister: Is Australia also considering adopting a policy of automatically repairing and replacing the structural components of ageing aircraft at a specified life, or flight limit, rather than just when cracks appear? Will these modifications and repairs, costing an estimated $US2.3m, be made as soon as possible to Qantas 747 aircraft, given that at least one Qantas plane had chalked up 19,300 flights as at April this year, according to an answer given in the Senate on 5 May?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the United States Federal Aviation Administration is considering imposing mandatory modifications along the lines outlined by Senator Maguire. But, it is important to note that there is no proposal to scrap the regular inspections of aircraft which will continue for all aircraft. The mandatory modifications, should that decision be made, would be on top of the normal scheduled inspections. The recommendations have arisen as a result of the deliberations of a number of committees considering the problems of ageing aircraft. The United States FAA has put the recommendation in the form of a `notices of proposed rule making' circulated for industry comment in the United States.

ANSWER.PARA: At this stage, the proposals are still awaiting United States industry reaction. When the consultation has been finalised, the United States FAA will take action formally to make the requirements mandatory for United States registered aircraft. Once it is clear what the final decision is in the United States and what the United States Federal Aviation Administration requirements are, the Australian Civil Aviation Authority, I would expect-indeed, I think I could guarantee-would give any action taken by the FAA immediate consideration for implementation in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask the Minister: Was Mr Syd Hickman a member of the personal staff of the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, until last year? Is Arvin Consultancy Pty Ltd, of which Mr Hickman is the Managing Director, a consultant to Australian Marine Engineering Consolidated Ltd (AMECON), one of the two consortia which are currently competing for the new Anzac ship project? Does the Government agree that this situation has the appearance of providing inside information to one of the tenderers? Does the Government condone this situation? Is the Government aware of the situation in the United States where regulations govern this conduct and former government employees in this situation are obliged to avoid such employment for a substantial period and could be liable to a gaol sentence if they break the rules? Has the Government given any consideration to the introduction of regulations to determine the conditions under which those in government positions can take up employment in industry when they have been privy to confidential and/or classified information? If so, what action is the Government intending to take? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall Mr Syd Hickman. I recall that he was a consultant for Mr Beazley, the Minister for Defence.
—He knew all about defence contracts and their requirements. He possessed inside information.

—I would hope so. If he was a consultant to the Minister, I would hope that would be the case. I believe that he is now a consultant, although I do not know with what firm, but I accept the information contained in the question. I do not know whether he is a consultant to AMECON-I will find that out.

ANSWER.PARA: In so far as the suggestion of inside information being available to tenderers in competitive situations and so on is concerned, of course that is a potential area of conflict of interest and concern. There are, however, Public Service rules about this matter and I will obtain the necessary details of those rules for Senator Newman. I cannot say that I remember them at this precise moment. I have some knowledge of the situation which applies in the United States. I must say that whatever virtues the system in the United States has, it has not stopped very extensive corruption in relation to defence contracts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some people have gone to gaol.

—That may be so, but the point remains that it has not stopped corruption in relation to defence contracts. I do not know whether that is a desirable model to follow or not. I do not think we necessarily need to grab at any model which is available, particularly if it happens to be in the US. But I will to get a more detailed answer in relation to the Public Service rules that apply and what action is required.
—And ministerial staff.
—I think the rules apply to ministerial staff. I will also try to obtain information on what action is required under those rules.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: LOGGING IN SOUTH-EASTERN NEW SOUTH WALES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Has the Government yet received the detailed analysis and response to its proposal for logging in the south-east forests of New South Wales, for which it asked the New South Wales Government last month?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer to that question is no, we have not. I received last week, and tabled in the Senate this week, an interim reply from the Minister for Natural Resources, Mr Ian Causley, after it was reported that the New South Wales Premier, Mr Nick Greiner, had indicated in a press interview that he would direct the Minister for Natural Resources to resume discussions with the Commonwealth. I received that letter, which I take as being an interim reply from him to a quite detailed and complex submission from us to ensure protection of the industry in the south-east and to enable the Commonwealth Government to conduct over 12 months a biological survey of the environmental properties of the key areas of the south-east forests. A further dimension of our proposition was to try to encourage the industry and the New South Wales Government to develop plantations to meet future sawlog and woodchip resources from that area.

ANSWER.PARA: On Tuesday of this week I wrote to Mr Causley-the letter was faxed and he would have got it the same day-inviting him to come to Canberra, as the sittings of the Senate prevent my going to Sydney, to try to finalise what is now a long running stand-off between the Commonwealth and the State. I am surprised that Mr Causley has not responded by now. This matter is quite important and urgent. Three weeks ago I obtained the support of the employees of Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd to the proposition that I put. I have also obtained support for the proposition from shop stewards of the Timber Workers Union of Australia, who met in one central spot in the south-east to hear the proposition from me. After discussions with the Bega Shire Council, representatives of the Bombala Shire Council and representatives of the Eden Chamber of Commerce, I believe there is substantial support for my proposal.

It is unfortunate that the New South Wales Government has not finally come forward and stated its position on my proposition. The New South Wales Government has stated its position in political terms. It has attacked this Government and it has attacked me. It has made allegations, to which I have not responded because it is my intention to try to debate the issues on their merits and not to get into a political argument. I understand also that last Thursday, after the demonstration outside Parliament House in support of employment by members of the timber industry, members sent a delegation to meet the Opposition and to solicit its support. As I am now advised, there may be an answer to the question that both Senator Richardson and I have been asking of Senator Puplick: Where does the Opposition stand in terms of the New South Wales Government's attitude on the south-east forests? I understand from the industry that it could not get a clear answer either way-whether the Opposition supports the New South Wales Government, the environmentalists, the industry or this Government. There was an attempt by those in the Opposition with whom the industry met to appear invisible, to hide behind the drapes and curtains of this place and not take a position at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. In view of the obvious increase in interest in emigration by residents of Hong Kong following the brutal repression in mainland China, will the Government reintroduce the former category two eligibility for business migration to Australia? In other words, will the Government allow people who meet all of the current requirements for approval as business migrants except for the fact that they do not have $650,000 available for transfer but who have more than, say, $300,000 available, to provide the substantial benefit to Australia of their expertise and capital by coming here as business migrants?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not like Senator Chapman's question to perpetuate the myth that the majority of people coming to Australia from Hong Kong are business migrants. He did not intend it that way, but I think there is a general view that everyone coming from Hong Kong is a business migrant. Business migrants would not make up more than 10 per cent of the total applications out of Hong Kong. The level of $650,000, as I indicated at the Estimates hearings, is under review. It is under review for a number of reasons. One was the level of the Australian dollar at that time, which was US88c. That has now come down to US75c, so it is not such a strong factor. We have been looking at whether we can lower that level. One of the things we are looking at is age. We think it is harder for a younger person to accumulate that amount of assets. We may have three categories. For instance-this is not definitive-for those under 40 years of age we may require only $300,000; for those from 40 to 58 years of age we may require $500,000; and for those over 58 years of age, because of the short business span, we may require $1m. We have been looking at all of those features. A report on these matters is due to me very shortly.

ANSWER.PARA: It has also been suggested that we might like to take a country's taxation regime into account because it is a lot easier to accumulate assets in one country than another. I suspect that in the end that criterion would not be enforceable because of the capital gains tax and a number of other matters. The honourable senator's suggestion is under serious consideration, not just for Hong Kong but for countries throughout the world. We are now in a position, with a return to a bipartisan policy and with the sorts of adjustments I have mentioned, to compete very strongly with our major competitors, New Zealand and Canada, in this regard. I suspect that no matter what, even if we do not alter the current requirement, we will see a very substantial increase over the next couple of financial years in the number of business migrants coming to Australia.

The suggestion that the honourable senator makes is under strong consideration at the moment. I do not think it will be more than another five weeks before the honourable senator gets a positive answer as to government policy in this direction.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security aware that changes were made to the Western Australian Workers Compensation and Assistance Act in December 1986 which had the effect of transferring the responsibility for long term income maintenance in respect of totally and permanently disabled workers in Western Australia from the Western Australian State Government Insurance Commission and member companies of the Insurance Council of Australia Ltd onto the Department of Social Security? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether other State governments have passed similar legislative amendments which allow them to transfer their responsibility for their injured workers onto the Department of Social Security? Does the Government accept that it is appropriate for the Government of Western Australia to enable insurers thus to escape their liability to injured workers? If not, what measures does the Government propose to take to correct the situation?

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I ask you to rule as to whether a Minister could properly answer such a question. I saw the honourable senator turn the page, which means, I think, that the question went to a page and a half of typed notes. The Minister was observed not to be taking any notice of the question that was being asked, as he was having a discussion with his colleague on the side. I wonder whether you should rule the question out of order as being far too long and impossible for a Minister to answer.

—Mr President, on the point of order: I think the inference from Senator Lewis concerned whether Senator Jenkins gave notice of the question. I think it is a tradition that one gives notice of detailed questions. We do not necessarily get all these questions five hours beforehand. Sometimes they come in at five past 2 in the afternoon. I agree with Senator Lewis's criticism of Senator Bolkus in that we should always follow a question, because sometimes I have found that a question has changed halfway through. Leaving that aside, I argue that the question is not out of order, although I reinforce the point made by Senator Lewis about the length of questions and the fact that long questions waste a lot of Question Time. On that I concur.

—Order! There is no point of order. If a senator wishes to give a Minister notice that he or she is going to ask a question, there is nothing the Chair can do about it. I ask Senator Bolkus to keep his answer appropriately brief.

—Mr President, I raise a different point of order, on which I would ask you to rule. The question is clearly in the court of the Western Australian Government. It calls for an opinion about what happened in the area of workers compensation under the Western Australian Government. It has no relevance to this Parliament whatsoever.
—Mr President, on the point of order--
—Order! Does Senator Bolkus wish to speak to the point of order? Otherwise I ask him to relate his answer to that area of the question covered by his portfolio.

—Thank you, Mr President. There were six parts to the question, all of which were as indicated. I must say that I have had five minutes notice because Senator Jenkins was delayed in the air for a few hours this morning. In respect of the first three parts of the question, the answer is no; I did not know. In respect of the last three parts of the question, the answer is that the Social Security Act has always accommodated, and still does, workers compensation payments-whatever they are and whenever they are made. If I had had more notice, I do not think that I could have answered the question more fully.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. With reference to both the Treasurer's statement that personal end benefits will not be diminished by one cent under the Government's planned superannuation changes and the Minister's reply in Question Time a couple of days ago where he allowed that Senator Bishop might be able to find a handful of people who have been disadvantaged, I ask: Is the Minister aware that 75,000 Queensland public servants, from the lowest paid to the highest paid, will suffer drastic reductions in the superannuation benefits levels? For example, teachers retiring at the age of 60 on an average salary of $30,000 will have their lump sum retirement benefit slashed from $252,000--

—On a point of order, Mr President: Senator Boswell gave a notice of motion on this matter this morning. How does that relate to Senator Puplick's points of order? Not only is the legislation before us but also Senator Boswell put a notice of motion before us this morning.

—Order! It has been my policy since I have been President to allow a question if possible. There is no doubt that Senator Boswell's question anticipates debate on the Bill. I will allow the question and ask Senator Walsh whether he wishes to answer it or not. I call Senator Boswell.
