—This is a very important question for 75,000 Queensland public servants. Teachers retiring at the age of 60 on an average salary of $30,000 will have their lump sum retirement benefit slashed from $252,000 to approximately $204,000-a total of $48,000-and police officers retiring at 55 on an average salary of $30,000 will have their lump sum retirement benefit slashed from $234,000 to about $178,500, an amount of approximately $55,000. In light of the Treasurer's statement that no-one will lose a cent in benefits, what action does the Government intend to take to compensate these hardworking public servants for the loss of the benefits for which they have worked for 40 years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although Senator Maguire's interjection was not responded to, it should be put on record that it is a bit extraordinary to find somebody from the Queensland National Party purporting to have some concern for the welfare and interests of public servants, be they in Queensland or anywhere else. I do not know who compiled those figures and allegations. I suppose it was somebody in the Opposition. I will look at them afterwards when the pink comes out. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that any figure that comes from the Opposition should be regarded as suspect. On this subject in particular, figures and allegations that come from the shadow Minister-what is his name? Connolly-Mr Connolly--
—Order! I remind honourable senators again that proper titles should be used.

—I did say `Mr Connolly', Mr President, when I thought of his name. He produced a press statement a couple of days ago which contained two serious factual errors in the first three sentences. He referred to my having produced a table listing 25 companies. In fact, there were 18 in the table that I presented; not 25. I do not know whether that qualifies Mr Connolly to be a graduate of the Andrew Peacock school of accounting, but I would have thought that somebody who is an Opposition spokesman on any subject ought to be able to count up to 25. The third sentence stated:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . little or no effect on investments in the superannuation industry.

When read in context it should have stated, `investments by the superannuation industry'; not `in'. So not only can the Opposition not count, but also it cannot even accurately describe the direction of a flow of funds. I do not know who compiled the figures. I will look at them some time or other. Frankly, I would not take them very seriously unless they were corroborated by something other than assertions by the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Justice seen comments by the shadow Minister for justice, Senator Hill, relating to the death of Mr X in Sydney? In particular, can the Minister comment on Senator Hill's suggestion that the National Crime Authority or the New South Wales Internal Affairs Unit look into the death?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen facsimile copies of media reports attributing to Senator Hill a suggestion that the National Crime Authority or the Internal Affairs Unit of the New South Wales Police look into the death of Mr X. I do not think that that would be necessary for the following reasons: I am advised that the immediate investigation into the death is being carried out by Darling- hurst detectives under Inspector Alan Rugless, in whom Mr Ted Pickering, the Minister for Police in New South Wales, has the utmost confidence, as he has confirmed to me personally. In addition, the whole investigation is being oversighted by the Internal Police Security Unit of the New South Wales Police, which is composed of members of the highest integrity. Once again, Mr Pickering has great faith in that unit, especially in its knowledge of events around the Darlinghurst-Kings Cross area.

ANSWER.PARA: As late as this morning I had discussions with Mr Justice Stewart regarding the whole course of the investigations into this death and he indicated to me that he saw no need for the National Crime Authority to take any special steps to itself conduct an investigation into the death. Concerning the New South Wales Police investigation being undertaken in the manner that I have outlined, he said, `I believe they're pretty fair dinkum about it'. I believe that, with the assurances at this stage of Mr Justice Stewart and Mr Pickering as to the course of the investigation, we can rest assured that it is being undertaken with scrupulous attention to the sorts of matters to which Senator Hill alluded and which could give rise to misgivings as to an investigation into this incident by the New South Wales Police.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Minister for Justice take note of Senator Richardson's assertion that he reserved to himself the right to retaliate-my note of the words was that he said, `I shall retaliate and why not?'-against an Australian citizen and one who, apparently, at this stage has not been charged with any offence, even by the Australian Federal Police? In the light of Senator Ray's strong and proper condemnation of people for indicating their contempt for and intention to ignore the laws of Australia, will the Minister for Justice now say whether or not, as Minister responsible for law enforcement, he endorses Senator Richardson's claim that he has the right to retaliate and-these were the words used-`do great harm' against any Australian citizen?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would not for one moment cross my mind that a person of Senator Richardson's integrity, which is known to the whole nation, would contemplate the use of violence against an Australian citizen. In regard to this whole matter, my concern as Minister for Justice is to ensure the safety of Federal politicians and their families around Australia when they go about their duties. I undertake that with a sense of great concern for the safety of honourable senators and their families, who can be put in jeopardy or peril in certain situations.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the answer given by Senator Richardson, I can confirm that the incident to which he was subjected led to a loss of confidence on my part in the willingness of those Queensland police to provide the sort of protection that was required. Indeed, there was also a rather nasty incident in Queensland involving Mr Howard, the then Leader of the Opposition, and the Queensland police reports did not indicate its seriousness or the jeopardy in which Mr Howard was placed. I made sure that the Senior Private Secretary of Mr Howard, and of Senator Richardson before that, was made well aware of the procedures required-that is, to give us the fullest possible notice of trips to Queensland so that appropriate threat assessments could be undertaken and a close personal escort could be provided by the Federal Police, as it has been in the case of Senator Richardson to ensure his safety. I repeat that I cannot for one moment take the words that are attributed to Senator Richardson to have the colouring that he would in any way offer or suggest violence against a fellow Australian citizen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does that mean that the Senate should give no credence to the answers which Senator Richardson gives to questions in this chamber?

—I believe that in the use of language when one is part of a culture and a society one understands the degrees of exaggeration and colouring that creep into our conversation and our statements. No-one for one moment could think that a senator of the Australian Parliament would by use of such language have in contemplation the doing of violence to any fellow Australian.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer. What proportion of Australian taxpayers personally own company shares? Is this proportion low by the standards of comparable overseas countries? If so, why is this and what steps could the Government take to raise that proportion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The financial year 1986-87 is the latest one for which detailed taxation statistics are available. They show that in that year just over half a million Australians declared on their personal income tax returns income from dividends on company shares. As a percentage of total taxpayers, that is just over 7 per cent. Some taxpayers would own shares through partnerships and some would own non-dividend paying shares. In addition, a very much larger number would have some very indirect share ownership via superannuation funds, so the 7.2 per cent is very much the base figure. Because the figures refer to 1986-87, pre-dating the effects of the imputation system, they might well have changed since then.

ANSWER.PARA: The data does not allow for particularly reliable international comparisons, but it seems that the proportion of Australians who personally own shares-that excludes indirect ownership through superannuation funds-is not high by international standards, given that Australian per capita incomes are still about fourteenth or fifteenth in the world.

I mentioned the dividend imputation system as being a factor which ought to encourage the ownership of shares by Australians. Another factor which some surveys have picked up is that many Australians perceive our stock exchanges as casinos where rich wheeler-dealers shuffle paper. That, of course, is a negative for more widespread share ownership. It is a perception that is not helped when leading figures are seen to be deliberately flouting the rules of the game. That includes the current attempt by Mr Elliott to deprive small shareholders in Elders IXL Ltd of their right to a proper takeover bid from Harlin Pty Ltd.

The mechanism through which the take- over bid is being pursued by Harlin is that shareholders have been offered a block of Elders shares, around 18 per cent, on a pro rata basis to their present holdings. The price at which the shares are being offered is $3, which is well above the prevailing market price of around $2.70. The issue is underwritten by Harlin Pty Ltd, a company controlled by Mr Elliott. If the other shareholders decline to pay the price, which is well above market price, at which the shares have been offered to them, Harlin as the underwriter picks them up, bringing Harlin's total shareholding in Elders IXL to around 48 per cent. Any company which had a pre-existing level of shareholding of around 30 per cent, which Harlin had, would under the proper rules of the game have been required not to add more than 3 per cent in any six-month period to its shareholding or alternatively to make a proper takeover offer to all the shareholders. This particular behaviour was commented on in an article in the Australian on Monday of this week. It stated:
The equities manager at Perpetual Trustees, Mr Anton Tagliaferro, said he was `disappointed to see the paper shuffle continuing'.
A private client and institutional adviser at a Melbourne stockbroking firm, Mr Lee le Frate, echoed Mr Tagliaferro's sentiments.
Mr le Frate said he was advising clients not to support the proposal scheduled for consideration at the EGM.
He is quoted as saying:
Issuing bonus shares on shares paid to 1c (under the Elders IXL executive incentive scheme) was bad enough, but this creeping takeover is worse.

The final point I want to make is that when company executives manipulate share issues and takeovers to benefit themselves and therefore by definition diddle ordinary shareholders and are known to be doing so, that obviously discourages direct participation in share ownership by the great majority of Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! My attention has been drawn to some advertising material circulated in the chamber by the attendants. The only documents which may be circulated in the chamber are those related to the business of the Senate or parliamentary notices such as amendments, documents which have been tabled, and so on. Other material, particularly the material which was circulated today, should not be circulated.
—by leave-I realise that the document that was distributed today bears my signature. I am mindful of the remarks you have just made, Mr President, and I apologise to the Senate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Further to a question asked of me by Senator Peter Baume on the Jindalee project, I have some more information. The target of the Australian industry program in Jindalee is that the Australian and New Zealand content for the project will be at least 70 per cent of the contract price and that, together with offsets in designated work, the total Australian industry program will be in the order of 80 per cent of the contract price. Furthermore, the tender evaluation criteria in the request for tender state that it is a condition of acceptability that the Commonwealth objectives for Australian industry for the project be satisfied.

ANSWER.PARA: These objectives are stated as being to foster the establishment and maintenance of an Australian infrastructure suitable for, first, system engineering support of the Jindalee over-the-horizon radar network throughout the network life, and, secondly, the development of an environment which permits the support of evolutionary developments likely to occur over the network life, including the modification, adaptation and redesign for the network to changed needs. Within those broad industry objectives there is to be no government furnishing equipment in Jindalee, apart from COMSEC equipment. The prime contractor must be given the total responsibility to come up with the most cost effective approach to satisfying the Commonwealth needs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 31 May Senator Calvert asked me a question concerning nursing home admissions in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. An answer to that question was supplied to me by Dr Blewett. As it is a long answer, I wonder whether it would be more appropriate to incorporate it in Hansard. I seek leave to do so.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

In general, nursing homes are neither staffed nor equipped to provide care for people with psychiatric disorders. Most people with psychiatric disorders would not be helped by being admitted to a facility which is intended to provide nursing and personal care mainly for people with physical disabilities.
For these reasons I do not intend altering this section of the guidelines in response to the issues raised in the question.

The Section of the ``Guidelines for Approval of Admission to a Nursing Home'' relating to residents of State psychiatric institutions was adopted in 1986 following a large number of nursing home admission applications from such residents where the reason for admission was given as ``closure of hospital beds''. This type of application is still being received.

The Commonwealth cannot be expected to bear the cost of savings realised by State Governments when State institutions are closed down and the State fails to make appropriate alternative arrangements for their accommodation and care. It remains the responsibility of State Governments to continue to provide care for long term residents of State psychiatric institutions particularly when those residents are discharged because of closures. Alternative arrangements are the responsibility of the States not the Commonwealth.

For this reason, the Commonwealth guidelines do preclude persons who have been long term residents of State institutions from being approved for nursing home admission. However, the guidelines specifically state that exemptions may occur where the application fulfils the criteria for admission in the National Health Act section 40ab (3) and:
where the application is for admission to a special purpose home related to the person's disability; or
the applicant has been admitted to the State institution for an acute episode while still a nursing home patient, or where admission was for less than twelve months or three years in last five; and
the applicant suffers a long term physical illness, which overrides any psychiatric disorder or intellectual disability, and
the physical disability cannot be adequately managed in the State institution, and acute hospital care is not appropriate.

These exemptions would cover the case of a nursing home resident being required to have treatment for a temporary illness in a State institution and then wishing to return to a nursing home. There would therefore be nothing to prevent such a person from returning to the nursing home providing his or her physical and mental condition continued to require nursing home care.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday Senator Boswell asked me, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, a question concerning frozen banana prawns being traded to Japan. I have given a copy of the answer provided by the Minister to Senator Boswell, but as it is a three-page answer I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
Exports of prawns from Australia to Japan in 1981-82 totalled 13,168 tonnes, while in 1986-87, there were 9,257 tonnes exported
some stocks of ocean-caught prawns are being held in cold-stores in Northern Australia. This is not unusual.
Quality of the product is not the major barrier to sales of Australian prawns to Japan.
There has been a large expansion of imports of white prawns from China, Indonesia and Thailand into Japan, associated particularly with the enormous growth of aquaculture in those countries.
At the end of March there were 92,000 tonnes of prawns still held in Japanese cold storage from last year
consumption fell away during the illness of the Emperor and the mourning period which followed his death.
Japanese companies are attempting to reduce excess holdings, especially of large size prawns.
The decline in trade to Japan therefore has much less to do with inappropriate export standards
Product assessed for export is rejected if the aggregate defects exceed a total of 15% (not 37% as stated by Senator Boswell)
existing export standards for fish were brought into effect in 1985 with the promulgation of the Fish Orders (amended in 1988 as the Export Control (Fish) Orders)
a review of the export standard for frozen prawns in 1988 resulted in the tightening of the size grade tolerance from 25% defective (ie outside the declared grade) to 15%
this change was made in accordance with broad industry views.
Government policy is to place greater responsibility for compliance with regulations onto industry, and to avoid interference in matters of a strictly commercial nature

the concerns raised by the honourable senator reflect difficulties experienced by the industry to meet commercial demands, and are not relevant to product wholesomeness or truth in labelling which are the objectives of export controls administered by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service.
If the fishing industry desires a review of the current export standards, I will be happy to arrange that
however, the comments received from industry in 1987 and 1988 would suggest that the export standard meets the needs of the export industry
a tighter grade standard would very likely result in higher costs for Australian exporters and therefore a widening of the cost differential between us and our competitors.
The Government is actively encouraging the adoption of quality assurance and Total Quality Management principles by the food industry
the benefits include reduced inspection costs, greater product quality assurance and improved competitiveness
it is open to all fish exporters to pursue this approach, and AQIS officers can assist in explaining the systems and initiating Approved Quality Assurance arrangements.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the President has received the following letter, dated 8 June, from Senator Peter Baume:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64 I give notice that today I propose to move-
`That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The urgent need for Government action to strengthen Australia's Defence capability by enhancing the capacity of the reserve forces.'
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The urgent need for Government action to strengthen Australia's Defence capability by enhancing the capacity of the reserve forces.

The Australian Defence Force (ADF) has outgrown its budget and, as a result, is now in crisis. The Army, in particular, cannot survive at its present regular size without more money and, because more money may not be available, the only way to preserve structures and to maintain capabilities at an acceptable level of peacetime readiness is to make more effective use of the Army Reserve. The Reserve is that body of part time servicemen which, in time of conflict, would be the core of the rapid expansion of our military forces. It is the Reserve which gave us some of our most famous leaders-people like Monash, Morshead, Herring and Dougherty-people who are famous for their deeds in defence of this country. And the Army Reserve, if allowed to do so, could do the same again.

Are senior service officers serious about the Army Reserve and about the reserves generally? Do they fear the reserves as a threat to the permanent forces? Do they fear that a fair go to the reserves might not suit their short term agendas for personal promotion? Sadly, it seems that that might be so.

This is the background, contained in a series of facts: firstly, the defence vote has been used to accommodate capital equipment expenditure running at about 30 per cent of the total vote. Secondly, the vote itself has not risen significantly in real terms and, if there is more money for capital expenditure, there has therefore to be less for other functions. Thirdly, costs, including Australian industry participation costs and capital cost increases, have placed even more stress on the Defence budget. That again means that there will be even less for people and for day-to-day operations. Further, ADF manpower has been left behind as far as wage justice is concerned. Senator Newman has drawn attention to this on many occasions. This is significant, and is of the order of 20 per cent of the wages bill. That is to say, Defence Force personnel are underpaid, which is one reason for the high resignation rate within the forces. Even so, the cost of ADF manpower within the regular forces is about $35m for every thousand personnel. When the long-overdue pay rise is put into effect, that cost will exceed $40m for every thousand Defence Force personnel.

In addition, the Services, in order to live within their budgets, have been forced to economise to the point of real hurt in the area of operating costs. These operating costs are the essential items of fuel, rations, travel allowances, and so on which permit personnel in the ADF to undergo adequate training. Flying time, steaming time, exercise time-all the training elements-have been drastically curtailed. Further, the restrictions have not been shared equally. Certain elite units-for example, the Army's Operational Deployment Force-have properly required, and received, high resource inputs to maintain high degrees of readiness. Of course, that means that other areas get even less. One of the consequences of these economic stringencies and of the restrictions on service life which they cause has been the huge wastage by resignation and non-re-engagement. Again, this has been referred to by my colleagues on many occasions.

The only alternatives for solutions to the present training, resignation and morale problems are, on the one hand, more money for operating costs-and we know this is not likely to be forthcoming-or, on the other hand, reduced commitments either to equipment or to manpower. If there is to be no more money, the solution has to be one of those two alternatives. In the absence of any real new commitment of resources, and in the presence of a continuing commitment to equipment acquisition, the only solution will inevitably mean the shedding of regular manpower and the loss of more of our regular forces. It should make any Australian frightened, because this loss is likely to be 5 or 10 per cent of the total manpower of the Australian Defence Force. And this is where the Reserve forces should come in.

The Army has, for very sensible reasons, incorporated Reserve manpower into its regular units and formations. One would have expected the ADF to have turned increasingly to its Reserve components. This would have enabled key capabilities to be maintained, numbers to be kept up, units to be preserved and a core force to be maintained-perhaps at a lesser degree of readiness but at least as part of the force in being. Certainly, at top levels-the Chief of Defence Force, for example-this imperative is clearly recognised, but in application the policy is sadly and dangerously deficient. That is why it is a matter of urgency to bring this issue to the attention of the Senate today.

The policy is deficient in several ways. Firstly, not only are we wasting regular soldiers, not only is there an enormous rate of resignations and non-re-engagements; but also there is no effective policy whereby resigning officers, with expensive expertise provided at public cost, are required or encouraged then to perform a return of service, part time, as reservists. There is no effective encouragement or requirement for Royal Australian Air Force aircrew, Army engineers, naval technical officers or any other hi-tech personnel fleeing the Services to do Reserve service after they have left. This is a tragedy. For example, to replace the pilots we know we have lost recently will take years and cost millions or dollars-even if no more resign. Of course, we would expect that the resignations will continue. There is no effective policy to use the training and experience of the rank and file who, by not re-engaging, leave the Army at the rate of about 3,000 a year. No Reserve service is required of these persons.

But the problem is worse than that. The Reserve component itself, and the Army Reserve in particular, has been subject, over recent years, to debilitating neglect and debilitating restrictions. At this stage I wish to quote from the minutes of an Army Reserve Association contact meeting held on 3 May 1989 at Kogarah depot at which a number of concerns were expressed to Major-General Keldie, who was at the meeting, and to other senior officers. Let me select the complaint about clothing. The minutes read:

Dissatisfaction with availability of clothing was wide-spread. It appears that pieces of World War II webbing are still being issued. Slouch hats are still not available. Poly shoulder boards have not been available in the Sydney system for two years. Sleeping bags for weekend activities are difficult to obtain.
Recruits, in particular, receive a very poor impression of the Reserve when their initial kit-out issue fails to supply the majority of items to which they are entitled.

The minutes go on. This is not some document from the Opposition; it is in fact a document from the Army Reserve Association. These are the kinds of concerns that are being expressed. It is not enough for the Chief of the Defence Force and for many high-ranking officers to say that they want to see the Reserve play a greater and a necessary role. It is not enough for them to say that they want the Army Reserve to be able to assist the Australian defence forces in a time of crisis if the desire in those statements is not reflected at unit and formation level.

The Army Reserve has been subject to hurtful training day restrictions which will save literally trivial amounts of money when we look at the quantum of what is involved in, say, equipment purchases. The Army Reserve has been forced to impose strength restrictions which, in turn, is now forcing some commanders to turn away hundreds of would-be volunteers. Units are being disbanded or combined. Restrictions on operating costs are preventing adequate training or exercising. Where Reserve elements serve with regular units, the needs of the reservists tend to be overlooked or ignored. Inevitably, as a result, there is a loss of soldiers, non-commissioned officers and officers and there is a need for continuing high levels of recruiting activity. That in itself is another expense; recruiting is expensive.

In addition, reserve officer production is starved of real resources. The officer cadet training units have small intakes because few resources now go into attracting suitable candidates to undertake the training. Units are short of officers and equipment is scarce. But, even more, no real total Army or total force feeling has emerged. The reservist is frequently and unfairly criticised, as is his unit, because of deficiencies. There are low training standards. Also, there is no money to train-they cannot do much about that; high manpower wastage, which is inevitable; and low officer strength. These deficiencies have always been within the capacity of government to rectify if only it will make available the necessary resources to the forces and to the Army.

Lately we have had a new attack on the opportunity of reservists to have a career in the Reserve Army, leading to formation command or above. When I talk about `formation command', I am talking about the rank of brigadier and above. The argument, especially as espoused, I am sorry to say, by the General Officer Commanding Land Force, Major-General Neville Smethurst, goes something like this: there are too few places for brigade commanders; the reservist is not well enough qualified; we need command places for regular soldiers; readiness requirements have changed since World War II and reservists will not do. I have to say that Major-General Smethurst, applying that kind of argument and that kind of policy, has ceased to appoint Reserve officers to formation command and above and has started to replace them with regular soldiers. This is the final straw. As the Army Reserve is operating today under the promotional strategy of Major-General Smethurst, no senior commands are going to Reserve soldiers. Many qualified reservists have been passed over in favour of regular soldiers and, as a result, no Reserve officers serving today can realistically entertain hopes of holding high command.

What would have happened in the time of Monash had that policy applied? What would have happened if we had not been able to send away the Monashes and the Morsheads who became famous for the role they were able to play? Several Reserve formation commanders have been removed or not renewed by Major-General Smethurst and have been replaced by regular soldiers in recent times-I am talking about this year and last year. While this happens there can be no emergence of great citizen soldier leaders-the people who have genius and interest but who have an occupation apart from professional soldiering. Although there is supposed to be a policy against this, every indication is that this practice of not appointing Reserve soldiers will continue while ever the major-general continues to ignore the policy.

I have been informed by a former senior officer that, some time early in May, Major-General Smethurst gave a keynote address at General Fay's Army Reserve conference. In front of a large number of officers, he supported his anti-Reserve formation commander policy and he described it as his policy. So we now have a situation where this is the policy of the Land Force Commander. It is no good; it is not right. This will be another nail in a coffin already largely nailed down and it would not be to the advantage of this country.

I might support my argument by reading into the Hansard a letter from General Sir Francis Hassett, AC, KBE, CB, DSO, MVO. Those honourable senators who know General Hassett will be aware that he was the former Chief of Defence Force and, before that, Chief of the General Staff. His letter to Major-General Cullen reads as follows:
Dear Paul,
I have read your Army papers with concern.

I strongly support the principle that when an Army Reserve officer is suitable for an Army Reserve appointment then he must be preferred. Suitable, to me, means that he has adequate military knowledge for the appointment and potential in other fields, such as leadership. The last, for Army Reserve officers, also takes account of his standing in the community. The more senior the appointment, the higher the expectation.
Adequacy in military knowledge does not mean that he must be as thoroughly informed as his regular counterpart. He will learn on the job-that is part of the exercise.

The purpose of the Army Reserve is, inter alia, to train and give experience to Army Reserve officers at the various command and staff levels. This can only be done if appointments are kept open for them. We do not want to shut out potential Morsheads, Herrings, Allen and the like.
I have spoken to people in Canberra, including the acting CGS Fitzgerald-(O'Donnell is overseas). It seems to me that you have already achieved two important results.
He sets out two results which have been achieved recently. The letter continues:
(a) Re-affirmation by the Minister, the CDF and others of the important principle that if a suitable Reserve officer is available then he must be preferred.
(b) An awareness at senior levels of current feelings and the need for extreme care in future appointments.

I do not believe there is a deliberate plot to undermine the ethos and standing of the CGS. If there has been such a move, then you have stopped it. The present policy is perfectly sound. Its implementation is the problem. Perhaps there is currently, undue concentration on producing an efficient organisation today as opposed to training Reserve officers for the future. There must be a proper balance and it is the responsibility of the Advisory Committee to get it right.

Having said all of the above, we both know from long experience, that there are situations, particularly in the smaller or more remote areas, where a suitable Reserve officer is just not available. The appointment of an unsuitable officer, particularly if senior, not only affects the Army internally but drags down its reputation with the community.
I cannot comment on individuals you mention because I know little about them and none of the details.

He then said a couple of personal things. General Hassett has no doubt what the proper promotion strategy should be. If one reads General Hassett's letter, it is quite clear that he would not agree with the policy being followed today by Major-General Neville Smethurst.

My message today is that the future of Australian defence requires as an essential element the enhancement and reinvigoration of the reserve forces. These are the elements of Australian defence that gave us a number of very famous generals who came forward in a time of crisis to help defend this country-names such as Monash, Morshead, Dougherty, Herring and Allen.

If we fail to respond to the crisis now facing the Army, if we pretend that the crisis does not exist, if we fail to understand its critical elements, if we fail to take the difficult decisions which are demanded-and I have set out in this speech some of the things that need to be done; they seem to be decisions that the Labor Government has avoided for far too long-then we will betray this country: its traditions, its past, its present soldiers and its future. I believe that we can today send the following message to the bunker at Russell: What you are doing is unacceptable to the Parliament. It is not fair to the Army Reserve. It is not in the best interests of Australia. Ignore our protests if you will, but do so at your own peril.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin at the outset by trying to put this motion in some context. The first point that needs to be made is that we are not just talking about the Army Reserve. Senator Peter Baume attempted to paint a broader picture about Australia's defence capabilities and the policies of this Government relating to them. I will begin by responding in kind. I remind Senator Baume that the reserves are part of a total context, a total defence capability that Australia has put together and will need over the next decade or so. He knows very well, having been a member of this Senate for so many years, that when this Government came to office we were confronted with a backlog of defence decisions that had to be made. For example, there was no overall strategy. Procurement was haphazard and not part of an overall defence strategy. There was no overall view of defence requirements.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators opposite have made a few noises about this being an inappropriate picture. Yet some of them were members of a government which tolerated the idiocy of having three separate departments looking after the defence of Australia, putting in their bids, and often counterbids, for procurement of equipment and the setting of strategy goals. In effect, they were fighting each other, in and out of the bureaucracy, to get what they wanted. We knew when we came to government that it was absolutely necessary not only to set new structures and new goals but also to get a debate going about what we wanted for the next decade or more.

That debate was started by Minister Beazley. Minister Beazley is not only one of the first Ministers to have had the courage to force those involved in setting policy goals for defence in Australia but also the first to ask for that debate to occur and request a response from the Opposition, the community at large and current members of the forces and those who have retired. I believe that that debate has been very valuable. When I listen to Opposition senators in Estimates committees, for example, I realise that they are now able to ask questions about procurement policies in line with an understanding that this Government has long term strategy goals for defence. I wonder how they would have got on if they had sat on Estimates committees at the time when they were in government. What could they have asked then about long term goals? I am sure that those members who were on the back bench committee of the Liberal Party at the time realise how little discussion was ever undertaken in their party room about long term defence goals. I could refer to some of the issues that they raised as back bench senators and members of the House of Representatives at the time, when they were totally ignored.

I could also refer to situations in which strategy goals were written down and discussions held within the Department of Defence by civilians in consultation with permanent Army and defence personnel, at the end of which some of the discussion papers were shredded. These were discussion papers aimed primarily at giving Australia a long term strategic goal. What happened to them? They were shredded. There was no public discussion in those days about where Australia was heading in terms of its defence requirements. Did I hear a word at all from any of the backbenchers in the Liberal Government who were present at the time that occurred?

I can assure the Opposition that the idea of a full public, open debate is something that is new in the history of Australian defence requirements in this country. For all the noise that Senator MacGibbon is making on the other side, he is nodding his head, because he knows that that is the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't misrepresent me, or I'll break into your speech.

—There is a threat from Senator MacGibbon. He is a man who is obsessed with toys for the boys, who gets excited when he sees rockets and other things going up into the air. He decided to threaten me. This is typical of the approach that he has taken over the years that I have seen him on Estimates committees, particularly when he is talking about defence. He talks about toys for the boys. Boy, he was a sucker whenever those boys from the Royal Australian Navy, the Army and the Royal Australian Air Force put their Christmas card requests to him. Senator MacGibbon was the one who always nodded his head because he was infatuated with the toys that they used to talk about. That is not the only thing that defence is about. Defence is about having long term goals, restructuring to fit in with those goals and making sure that procurement policies are rationally based upon those goals. Senator MacGibbon would not even understand that.

SPEECH.PARA: Getting down to the question of the debate that Minister Beazley began, as we all know, there have been various reports-reports that have been made public by this Government. They have not been shredded and put in the wastepaper bin at Russell Hill but made public so that everyone who had something to contribute in this area was able to do so. We have never hidden from the fact that there ought to be a public debate about where defence is going in this country. Let us look at the Cross report on the capabilities of the Australian Defence Force and at the report of the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities. The former deputy director of the Joint Intelligence Organisation, Paul Dibb, was asked to look at the fundamental areas of strategic appreciation, threat assessment and force structure priorities. That report was a watershed in the setting of goals for defence policy in this country. The Government did not agree with all that Paul Dibb put down. The Government was determined that there should be a debate about the issues that he raised. As we all know, at least Paul Dibb put the settings in place so that the debate could not take place in quiet rooms around the Senate or at Russell Hill but could help us set goals for the future.

As we all know, the 1987 White Paper not only laid down the goals and the structures that should apply in the future but also referred at length to the new role that the reserves should play. Senator Baume is acutely aware of that. I understand that he was a member of the reserves at one time. He is aware of the role that the reserves played in the past. In many cases, it was a rather insignificant role. He is well aware of the morale problems that occurred when the reserve forces were not taken seriously in certain areas. As I understand it, he has talked to a sufficient number of present reservists, who have told him that the integration of the reserves into the total defence structure of Australia is something that they support. Am I not correct?

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not hear your question. I was talking to my colleague.

—I will repeat it, because I think it is important that we get that point clear. On the whole, do the reservists themselves believe that the appropriate way for them to be important, to be valuable, in the defence of Australia is to be integrated as much as possible into the permanent armed forces of this country? Is that not the approach that most of them take?
—If it's fair dinkum. That's their problem.
—At least Senator Baume has agreed, then, with the major concept behind the Government's approach to the defence of Australia and the relationship of the reserves to that defence.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us have a look at some of the actions that this Government took when it came to power. First of all, there was the new submarine project, which the recently sacked Opposition defence spokesman, Mr Peter White, wanted to scrap. That is a very important part in the defence of Australia, given our particular and peculiar geostrategic position. Other examples are the new Navy frigate program; the expanding Jindalee over the horizon radar, begun by the Whitlam Government; the airborne early warning; the Exercise Kangaroo 89, despite the Opposition's view that that should not have gone ahead. I also raise a question which might interest Senator Tambling: the studies of the Australian Defence Force (ADF) development priorities, which brought about the proposed move of an Army brigade to the Northern Territory. As Senator Tambling knows, it has been announced that 2 Cavalry Regiment is to move north. He is also very aware that the spokesman for the Opposition at the time, Peter White, opposed that idea, in addition to Kangaroo 89. Senator Tambling agrees with the view that I am putting today: that the Opposition spokesman of that period was totally out of touch with the real defence requirements of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said so in a press release.

—Senator Tambling said so at the time and he has been honest enough today to reaffirm the view that the former Opposition spokesman, the potential Minister for Defence in this country, was totally off beam in terms of his attitude towards this very important part of the restructuring of the Australian defence forces.

SPEECH.PARA: Above all else, this Government has brought a sense of sanity to the overall view about defence in this country. We have said that the defence of Australia is not about leaving a few bureaucrats and the armed forces simply to make their bids to this Parliament but that it has to be based upon a proper debate about where we are going, what our potential threats are and how we restructure ourselves to meet them. It is not a question of toys for the boys-buying the best equipment that may not be appropriate for the task it is to be used for by the Australian defence forces. The defence of Australia involves taking a calm and rational approach. It is not about being a younger child helping Daddy in the United States of America or the United Kingdom in forward defence operations, either in Vietnam or elsewhere. It is about looking first and foremost at the defence of Australia and saying, `What is the most logical way to defend Australia?', not `How do we hide under the umbrella of some ally?'. The relationship with our allies and how we integrate with their armed forces is an important part of our defence but it is not the most important part. The most important part of any long term defence strategy is to set goals for the defence of Australia first and foremost, and setting them based upon a realistic appreciation of the situation.
Turning to the reserves themselves, there have been studies, as honourable senators know, of the Reserve Force in this country. The Defence White Paper says:

Our requirements for land warfare cannot be achieved without extensive Reserve participation. Accordingly, the Army Reserve structure is being reviewed and changes will be implemented progressively. Since World War Two the Reserve has provided the expansion base for the Army. It will now-
and this is the important point-
in addition, be required to contribute to operations which might arise in the shorter term as part of the total Army, at a level commensurate with achievable degrees of training and readiness.

Implementation of this policy-and remember this is the first time we have had a clear policy on this issue in something like 20 years-has led to the addition of a significant Reserve component to 6 Brigade. Previously an all-Regular formation, 6 Brigade is acquiring 49 Battalion of the Royal Queensland Regiment to give it its third infantry battalion. The second move was to add to headquarters of 1 Division-the main Regular formation-a Reserve-manned rear divisional signals squadron. The third move was to give headquarters of 1 Division a divisional headquarters defence company from the Reserve formation 2nd Division.

It is interesting to note that in 1978 the Fraser Government's back bench committee on foreign affairs and defence proposed legislation to facilitate the call-out of the reserves in situations short of a formal declaration of war or a defence emergency. The Fraser Government took no action on that recommendation. It was left to the Hawke Labor Government to act on it. Now, as we all know, practical reserves call-out legislation is in place. Not one honourable senator on the other side of the chamber would disagree that the Hawke Government finally carried out that very sensible recommendation of the Fraser Government back bench committee on defence. It is again a situation in which, on policy matters, the Liberal Party of Australia has shown itself to be totally inadequate and unable to listen to those people who gave time, effort and thought to the question of the defence of Australia.

The Government has also identified an important role for the Reserve forces in the protection of vital installations and key points. This will be done through the creation of four brigade groups from Reserve units in north Queensland, Victoria, Western Australia, and South Australia and Tasmania. The effectiveness of the Government's determination to give the reserves a meaningful role to play is strongly demonstrated by Exercise Diamond Dollar held in 1987. General Jeffrey, who was then commander of 1 Division, said that, of the 7,000 troops who took part in that exercise, 1,000 were reservists, including an infantry battalion, a transport squadron, an armoured personnel carrier squadron, an engineer squadron, military police, a field hospital and individual support staff-in other words, pretty well the full spectrum. General Jeffrey summed up the Reserve input into that exercise. I think it is particularly important to quote him because General Jeffrey can give us here in the Senate today, through this quotation, an idea of exactly what the Government has planned for the reserves in terms of integration into the defence forces and what has been achieved so far by way of their cooperation and activity in that area. In the Australian of 7 October 1988 he said:
The Reserve performed magnificently and the exercise simply would not have happened without their contribution.
Comments like this, rather than the whines from the negative Opposition, are the true measure of the success of the Government's policies with respect to the Reserve forces.

Senator Baume, again because of his experience in this area, has rightly raised the question of the morale of the reservists. I have talked about how important it is that they be integrated into the permanent defence forces so that they have a place in the sun and their contribution is one in which they are regarded not just as boys on holidays but as people who have a very important role to play in the defence of Australia. We have talked about the appropriate legislation to allow us to call out reservists in situations short of total emergency or war. This Government has never put aside or discounted the role of the reservists. We know that their role is very important, particularly in any full scale war or emergency. But their role must be seen as one shared with the permanent defence forces. This Government is on record for, first of all, creating a defence debate; secondly, creating structures which are appropriate to the defence of this country; thirdly, creating strategies which are relevant to this country; and, fourthly, bringing together the reservists and the Army. If for nothing else, this Government can be applauded for moving in that direction.

If, as I indicated before, people like Senator MacGibbon think that the defence of Australia is all about buying toys-buying Leopard tanks, for example, which look wonderful on paper but are inappropriate for the defence of Australia-if he believes that that is appropriate, let him say so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Poor old Lance Barnard!

—I am not defending the Whitlam Government in defence areas. I am saying that all governments needed to get to the point where this Government has brought us-to set strategic goals first and foremost for the Defence Force and to create a debate about defence in which it is no longer a sacred topic but one on which all of us should exchange views and on which the Army should be free to put forward its viewpoint.

SPEECH.PARA: If nothing else, firstly, we have created that debate, secondly, we have created a sense of long term strategy and, thirdly, we have integrated the system in this country in a way which I believe will bear fruit in the future. Nothing is perfect. There are questions of morale that have to be addressed. Some of them are wider questions such as sociological questions. They apply also to the permanent defence forces. What does one do, for example, with Defence Force personnel when one is asked to send them, to make them really relevant, to places like Tindal? What does one do with their families? How does one cope, for example, with wives who want to work and who do not want to follow the traditional Army pattern of moving from town to town and from place to place? How does one make those decisions without affecting morale? These questions apply not only to reservists but also to the permanent defence forces as well.

This Parliament ought to look at the whole question of morale in a sympathetic and rational way and not just debate the issue of the reservists. The reservists are only part of the total picture of the defence forces of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats I enthusiastically support this urgency motion moved by Senator Peter Baume. It is with great pride that I look back 32 years to the beginning of my own 10 years in the Army Reserve. It was at that time, on day one, that I first met Peter Baume. I am proud of the fact that I spent 10 years in the Army Reserve although I did not spend all of those 10 years as an infantry officer. I am moved today to recall that it was in that context that Peter and I first met. It is from that that we probably share the sense of urgency about the issue that he has brought before the Senate today. After 10 years in the Army Reserve I went on to serve 10 years in the Regular Army. I specialised in training systems. Therefore I rise today to speak with enthusiasm and conviction about the predicament in which the Australian Defence Force finds itself.

SPEECH.PARA: Before moving on to discuss this predicament I would like to make reference very briefly to the matter that Senator Dunn raised in her previous explanation. Yesterday she was confused about my role. She was rather offended at the fact that she was projected onto the Beecroft Peninsula as the resister to the military exercise. Perhaps I can explain my presence there. Not only am I committed to the Army and to the services but I am also committed to the environment. I am also committed to the civil and spiritual liberties of the Australian Aborigines. I found myself in a dilemma-a trilemma, if you like-concerning the circumstances that were about to take place on the Beecroft Peninsula. As a member of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade I am frankly puzzled about how the Australian Government can create a set of circumstances where a military exercise will be involved in pounding the peninsula, a place which holds 200 sacred Aboriginal sites and which has been declared a part of our National Estate.

I make that observation and explanation in passing because I would like to emphasise in contributing on behalf of the Australian Democrats to this debate that we as a party are very pro-defence. We believe in a strong, flexible and competent Defence Force. We demand that it be a neutral defence force in terms of its alignment and that it be essentially exactly that, a defence force. It must be potent, it must be flexible and it must be competent. By virtue of those requirements it will always be built, as historically it has always been, upon the foundation of a militia or an army reserve. It goes without saying that in a nation of 16 million people-Australia has the fifth largest national land mass on earth-we must be very creative and flexible in our thinking about how we structure our Defence Force. It will inevitably be dependent upon a militia.

Senator Peter Baume has very adequately cited the historical evidence for that. In a briefing to the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Subcommittee the other day, a civilian expert, Dr Ross Babbage, drew an interesting comparison. He said that we have moved forward in the last 50 or 60 years from the days when we could see a militia being made up of the courageous and willing who would mount their own horses, bring their own rifles, march to an assembly point and within weeks be part of an effective fighting force. Looking back on the history of the Anzacs, that force was transhipped across the world and fought with gallantry, extraordinary courage and great effect. The days of that militia are long since gone. The thinking of governments about our army reserve and our citizens' military forces unfortunately is still there.

The Australian Democrats therefore put out the plea for an entirely new era, an entirely new age of the Army Reserve. We believe in a strong army reserve. We believe that it must be much bigger than it is now, that it must be much better equipped than it is now. But if it is to justify the expenditure for that, it must be much more flexible and it must be confronted with a diversity of roles which warrant the expenditure to create that sort of civil and military Defence Force.

We believe we have reached a stage where we require-I have said it over and over again in this chamber-profound lateral thinking about how we defend ourselves. I have in my hand a paper entitled Defence in the 90s: The challenge of Change, which was a paper presented at the Australian Defence Force Academy in March of this year by Mr George Younger, MP, who is the British Secretary of State for Defence. In addressing the challenges of defence in the 1990s and into the twenty-first century he emphasised the need for flexibility and lateral thinking. The Australian Democrats contend that we are locked into conventional models of thinking about our defence. They will not serve us any longer. We spend $7.6 billion a year on a defence force which at this moment sadly is extremely demoralised, which is largely impotent and which by its own admission could not render the service to which it may be called.

I do not make those comments lightly. I am not the only one who has advanced those arguments in this chamber. Indeed inherent in the Cross report entitled Personnel Wastage in the Australian Defence Force tabled in this Parliament a matter of a few mere months ago is the suggestion-it is not exactly overt but it is a covert suggestion-that our defence forces are impotent. They are impotent sadly because people are not committed to serve in them for all sorts of good reasons. I will cite just a couple of paragraphs from this vitally important report. I am reading from the introductory segment which says:
The extent and magnitude of wastage . . . in some of those areas-
the report has cited some of the areas of wastage-

is such that it will adversely affect the ADF for at least the next decade. It also shows that retention strategies must be directed at both the needs of the broader ADF and those of specific specialist groups within the Force.
It cites the effects of this wastage as being:
a. decreased organisational health;
b. dilution of experience;
c. increased costs;
d. training deficiencies;
e. diversion of manpower;
f. reactive personnel management; and
g. loss of morale.
It says:

In sum the effects of wastage adumbrated above amount to a loss of operational capability. It is manifestly obvious that the prevailing excessive level of personnel wastage is damaging the organisational health of the ADF.

It goes on in a volume of hundreds of pages to substantiate those generalisations. The management of the Defence Force had been equally substantially documented in a report entitled The Management of Australia's Defences 12 months earlier, in November 1987. I have cited the opinion of some academic experts. I referred earlier to the eminent Dr Ross Babbage from the Strategic and Defence Studies Centre of the Australian National University. In his book Rethinking Australia's Defence, which was written in 1980, he cited the problem of the Reserve as fundamental to the rethinking of Australia's Defence. He cited this at the beginning of the era to which Senator Aulich has referred. Senator Aulich has said that this has been a period of rethinking for this Government, but it has not adequately addressed the fundamental requirement that Dr Babbage cited nine years ago. He stated:

We have seen a progressive deterioration in . . . (the) reserve component to its present state, which, despite the best efforts of its members, must be regarded as unsatisfactory and in urgent need of reorganization and rehabilitation.
He was quoting the Millar Committee of Inquiry into the Citizen Military Forces in his book in 1980. Those words are just as true today as they were then.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you think we began the process of rethinking?

—The Government may have begun the process, but it certainly has not resolved the problem. Brigadier Serong is well known to those who have served in recent years in the Australian Defence Force. I will quote Brigadier Serong's opinion as it was stated in the News Weekly of 15 March 1989:

SPEECH.PARA: We do have severe manpower problems, with no sign yet that they are improving. We are undermanned. It is not a matter of trimming the fat now . . . We are cutting into the bone and into the muscle.

The fact is that our defences are in crisis. They will have to be resolved by the rebuilding of the Australian Army and military reserve forces. The Beazley model has been predominantly oriented towards equipment and we have procured-these statistics are outstanding-75 FA18 fighters at a cost of $35m each. By the time we pilot them and provide the necessary backup, about 75 times $45m will have been provided to create an air force. The senior officer who commands them says that assuming there is no wastage of pilots it will be nine years before he can put three squadrons in the sky, with inexperienced pilots. That is not good economics.

Senator Aulich is not listening to this. The Australian Democrats believe that the frigate concept is ill-conceived and the Royal Australian Navy will proceed to build at least eight, possibly 12 frigates which will just go down the same equipment path which is not directed towards the requirements of a newly conceived Australian Defence Force into the twenty-first century. Let me tell Senator Aulich about the superb Jindalee over the horizon radar as he may not know about it. We all acknowledge the fact that it is a superb Australian innovation. When it is in place 10 years from now the manning formula indicates that it will be manned between 9 a.m. and 5 p.m. It will be a part time radar system, it will have the most sophisticated equipment that one could conceive, and the enemy will know that it is manned between 9 a.m. and 5 p.m.

The realities are that the Beazley approach to defence in this country has failed; it has left us in crisis. The problem can be resolved only by profound lateral thinking about the structure of our Defence Force. That structure must be based upon a viable Army Reserve and not a Dad's Army-the image that most Australians used to laugh at and chortle over on the television. It must be a highly equipped, highly trained, sophisticated force commanded by itself. Senator Peter Baume is quite right: it is an absolute offence to the Army Reserve to say that it is not capable of training and commanding itself at the highest level. History proves that it has been and it will be again.

This Government must seriously acknowledge the fact that our defences are in crisis. The expenditure of $7.6 billion a year, when we have funded our bushfire brigades, coastal and surveillance patrols and emergency services by selling lamingtons on street corners, is just absolutely irrational. Senator Aulich claims that this is the Government of rethinking. It should do some lateral rethinking; it is thinking within traditional models. It should become imaginative and address itself to some truly profound new thinking about how we organise our defence forces around a revitalised Army Reserve.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very interesting topic to be debating now, particularly in the light of the review which is coming up as part of the defence subcommittee's program for this year, which is a total review of the reserve structure in Australia. There are two problem areas which we need to look at here. The first is the insistence of the military and their conservative political allies on maintaining the myth of the need for a large, full time, fully equipped professional military force in this country despite the absence of a military threat in the foreseeable future. Secondly, there is the refusal of this same unholy alliance to follow the example of other countries which are prepared to adapt their military force structures to peacetime and the need to cut costs for economic reasons. I totally endorse the remarks that have been made by Senator McLean on the need for lateral thinking. We do need a creative and new approach. The old model will not serve for the Australian defence forces any longer because it is an old model trying to deal with new problems. The wastage rate from the armed services is testimony to this.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact of the matter is that this country cannot afford an expensive military equipment program, decent support for personnel in the Australian Defence Force (ADF) and an adequate reserve. At the moment the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) is intent on building up the military equipment side of the armed services to the detriment of the personnel and, I would say, to the detriment of the effectiveness of the whole of the ADF because the reserves are not being utilised as much as they should be. The Government needs to take a total new look at the question of reserves as a matter of efficiency in the ADF.

Even if we could afford to service the three areas that I have mentioned-the equipment program, decent support and maintenance for the personnel, and an adequate reserve-the result would be that our neighbours would be asking themselves why Australia needed to be embarking on this extensive military build-up when there were no threats in the region. Indeed, the emphasis should be on developing non-military security such as trade, common security programs and promoting regional understanding.

Given the feeling in the majority of the Australian community that we need some kind of military defence, the obvious way forward is to look at what other countries are doing in the way of building up the reserve, and following their example where it is relevant to the Australian geostrategic situation. Countries we might look to for this kind of lead include the United States, Switzerland and West Germany. They are countries which put a lot more emphasis on their reserves at the moment and have many more part time personnel in their armed services than we do in the ADF.

The problem with Senator Peter Baume's motion is that I am not sure that the Opposition wants to build up the Reserve in addition to its desire to build up the ADF and to purchase all manner of highly sophisticated military equipment from overseas, such as nuclear submarines and possibly aircraft carriers. This is the dilemma. The Opposition never says where the extra money will come from for the increased expenditure in defence. I noticed with Senator Baume speaking that we do not have the usual defence spokespersons in this chamber having a go on this subject. It is something that I have asked before and have never got an answer from the Opposition. It cannot have it both ways. In peacetime Australia the population will not allow for a further increase in defence expenditure, so we have to look at either spending the money on personnel, which I believe would be better spent building up the reserves rather than building up the full time professional service people. It is patently obvious that that model is not working at the moment. We cannot have the military equipment and the personnel side being served with the current expenditure on defence. Somebody from the Opposition has to ask, `Where are the changes in emphasis going to occur? What is going to be the priority for defence expenditure?'.

The problem we are facing is not confined to the Australian military structure. In a number of advanced Western countries the cost of full time manpower-or more correctly, people power, if we consider the proportion of women now in the military-has risen, putting a heavy squeeze on new capital equipment, the construction of new defence facilities and other national security functions. Increasingly, countries which have spent an enormous amount on military budgets are being asked by their populations why there is all this outlay on military expenditure when there are crucial social security needs within their own countries, such as housing. The same could be said in Australia. Internationally, people are questioning the result of large outlays on military expenditure.

As President Eisenhower said, every new weapon that is tested and every new missile that is launched is a theft from the poor and oppressed in the world. We could put an environmental aspect on this as well because we have so many really urgent environmental problems which could well do with the amount of money that is being wasted on the military at the moment. I believe that these particular areas of lateral thinking that we need to explore will come up for discussion in the defence subcommittee. I know that Senator Peter Baume wants to reply so I will not go into that any further now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-There are only two minutes remaining for this debate. I want to thank Senator McLean for his support as a brother officer from the same regiment many years ago. If the choice of theme and choice of speakers is significant the choice of Senator Aulich and the choice of the speech he made is quite eloquent. The subject which we proposed was deliberately narrow. Senator Aulich chose to dwell on areas of agreement and to skate over areas of concern about the Army Reserve. That is a pity. He must have had a prepared speech or briefing and was not going to depart from it. It is a pity that in those circumstances he was selected to represent the Government in what we think is an important matter which affects the Army Reserve. It is now time to put the question and hopefully, to record the support of the Senate for this motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a personal explanation on the grounds that I have been misrepresented. Through what passed for his contribution to the debate Senator Aulich chose persistently and wilfully to misrepresent my position in this chamber. Had Senator Aulich taken any interest in the subject of defence before today he would have realised that in the 11 years I have been in this chamber I have talked consistently on the subject on a wide range of topics, from the recruitment of personnel, their training, the equipment they are issued with, their conditions of service, their morale and the command and control of the Australian defence forces to the whole strategic concept as to how they have been employed.

—I rise on a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. I am more than willing to listen to Senator MacGibbon make a personal explanation. I quite welcome the opportunity for him to put on record where he stands in terms of his personal reputation. At this stage he has not made clear where or how he has been misrepresented. We are listening to a potted history of his views about defence which is really very interesting. It is nice to know he is interested but he is not being specific at this stage about where he has been misrepresented. The time of the Senate should not be taken up with potted biographies but with specific attempts to set the record straight.
—I feel sure that Senator MacGibbon will do exactly that and make the point that he wishes to make.
—It was essential that I made that introduction, given the profoundness of Senator Aulich's ignorance about my position and my knowledge in this chamber.

—I rise on a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. Senator MacGibbon has risen to make a personal explanation. I do not know how allegations about someone's ignorance and that sort of language fit within the limits of the Standing Orders in terms of what Senator MacGibbon can say to explain where he has been misrepresented. I ask you to draw him to the point very quickly.
—Will you please come to the point of your personal explanation, Senator MacGibbon.

—I was indicating to the Senate that I have spoken over the years about a very wide range of issues-in fact, the whole ambit of defence activities in this country. To have my position presented, as Senator Aulich repeatedly did in his speech, as being concerned with only one element of defence is entirely misleading.
