SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this afternoon I was speaking about the Bounty (Ships) Bill 1989 and commenting on a company in my State of Tasmania called International Catamarans which has become a world leader in an innovative technology, using twin-hull vessels for ocean going transport. It is making a great contribution to Tasmania by injecting an estimated $35m into the Tasmanian economy. It has something like $50m to $60m worth of forward orders. It also expects to increase Tasmania's current 4 per cent share in the national shipbuilding industry quite considerably.

SPEECH.PARA: It was interesting to note the very illuminating address that Senator McLean made earlier. I hung upon a particular fact he mentioned. He said that defence in Australia was in a crisis. I do not think anybody on this side of the chamber or anyone in Australia as a whole would disagree that the economy of Australia is in a crisis, particularly with regard to our balance of payments. I believe in this day and age every assistance should be given to industries that are contributing to improving our balance of payments. Our balance of payments situation is helped immeasurably by contributions made by companies such as International Catamarans, which is exporting ocean going vessels around the world. All the way up the east coast of Australia in your own State, Madam Acting Deputy President, a considerable number of catamarans are used for the tourist industry that were made under licence as a result of the technology and design that was put together in Tasmania. This very important shipbuilding industry, which unfortunately after the next six years will receive no assistance from the Federal Government by way of bounty, will not receive any further help. Nevertheless, I believe the integrity and the professional way in which it is going about its task will enable it to continue in a very important way by contributing to our balance of payments situation.

It would be remiss of me not to mention the efforts of the Sea Management Corporation which is based in Launceston and operating as Launceston Marine. It has also been very successful. Recently it obtained a $4.5m tender to undertake work on the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation vessel, the Southern Surveyor. This will involve the provision of new accommodation sections and laboratory and scientific areas on that vessel. Work is expected to be completed by the end of November. Given the significant competition when tendering for that vessel, it speaks very highly of the company's management and shipbuilding ability that it obtained the tender. The Tamar steel boats arm of the Sea Management Corporation is involved in the construction of high quality steel passenger and work vessels of up to 75 metres in length. Currently two 25-metre vessels are also under construction. This company is working towards putting Tasmania on the world shipbuilding map.

The Opposition will be moving an amendment to this Bill in relation to the registration criteria. Three new modified registration criteria are contained in the legislation. It is the first of those to which the Opposition amendment refers, that is, that 75 per cent of the activities of the applicants for bounties must be devoted to the construction or modification of vessels for which the applicants are seeking bounty entitlements. The second criterion is that the applicant for the bounty must at all times employ 40 persons in ship modifications or constructions. The third criterion is that applicants must be prepared to submit a business plan. Existing requirements, including those which require applicants to be financially secure, to have access to waterfront premises and to be prepared to employ one apprentice for every eight tradespersons, will apply.

It is clear to the Opposition that the first criterion-that 75 per cent of the activities of applicants for the bounty must be devoted to the construction or modification of vessels-is the one that may result in a significant level of bureaucratic interference. We will have a situation in which it will be the bureaucrats who decide which companies are able to build ships more effectively than others. I would not like to see a successful enterprise such as the one I mentioned earlier, International Catamarans, overregulated and interfered with by too much bureaucratic control. That is one of the main reasons the Opposition will be moving this amendment. We want to ensure that the Bill does not discourage potentially efficient producers, to the cost of the industry. Although the industry is small, it is one that has great potential to produce those very important export dollars that we strive for these days. The bounty legislation we are debating today is designed to assist the shipbuilding industry over the ensuing years. It seems to me that the implementation of those restrictive criteria would have unfortunately the opposite effect to what should be desired by this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1989, the purpose of which is to increase the levy paid per export tonne of uranium concentrates from Australia. The duty initially stood at 11c per kilogram and has applied since the first production and export from the Ranger uranium mine, which is a subsidiary of Energy Resources of Australia. The levy was paid initially in the financial year 1981-82. Since that time, presumably in line with the Government's philosophy of user pays-at least to the extent of 75 per cent-the levy increased to 80c per kilogram in 1986; rose to $1.02 in 1987; rose to $1.15 from July 1988; and is to rise to $1.30 from July 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: This levy, which has been set to pay for the responsibilities of the Office of the Supervising Scientist (OSS), is not uniform amongst all uranium producers. It is paid by the Nabarlek operation, which for the time being has almost ceased production. At the moment it is putting what one would describe loosely as only very low grade gravel through its plant, simply to maintain itself, with the Government's encouragement, as the third mine in the three-mine policy. The levy is paid by the Ranger uranium mine. It is not paid by Western Mining Corporation Ltd's Olympic Dam project; nor by anybody else who is exploring for uranium in the Rudall River area of Western Australia, for example; nor by BHP Gold Mines Ltd, which is exploring in the conservation zone of the Kakadu-Alligator Rivers Region-allegedly for gold, but no doubt other significant minerals have been intersected.

The object of the legislation is primarily to provide funding for the Office of the Supervising Scientist, whose responsibilities until now have been for monitoring of the South Alligator River region. They have now been extended to the Coronation Hill area. The principal responsibilities are found in the Environment Protection (Alligator Rivers Region) Act, under section 5. The functions of the OSS are to develop appropriate research programs relating to mining activities; to coordinate and supervise those research programs; devise and develop standards, practices and procedures in relation to mining operations for the protection of the environment; to devise and develop measures for the protection and restoration of the environment from the effects of mining; to coordinate and supervise implementation of legislative requirements relating to the protection of the environment; to advise the Minister with respect to the duties outlined above; to perform other functions that may be prescribed; and to do anything incidental or conducive to the performance of the foregoing functions.

In tandem with section 5, the Environment Protection (Alligator Rivers Region) Act 1978 also establishes two associated bodies-the Co-ordinating Committee for the Alligator Rivers Region, which the Supervising Scientist chairs, and the Alligator Rivers Region Research Institute, which he manages. The research function is by far the largest activity of the OSS and is centred around the work of the Alligator Rivers Region Research Institute.
The Environment Protection (Alligator Rivers Region) Act defines some of the functions of the Co-ordinating Committee as follows:

(a) to consider programs for research into, and programs for the collection and assessment of information relating to, the effects on the environment in the Alligator Rivers Region of uranium mining operations in the Region;
(b) to keep under review programs, and the carrying out of programs, referred to in paragraph (a);
(c) to make recommendations to the Supervising Scientist with respect to programs referred to in paragraph (a);
(d) to consider, and keep under review-

(i) standards, practices and procedures in relation to uranium mining operations in the Region for the protection of, or in so far as those standards, practices and procedures affect, the environment in the Region; and
(ii) measures for the protection and restoration of the environment in the Region from the effects of uranium mining operations in the Region;

The Office of the Supervising Scientist has been subject to more than one audit of its effectiveness. It has been subject to some criticism by the coalition parties and to severe criticism by the Ranger uranium mine, which made the point that more than $40m of taxpayers' funds has so far been raised by way of levy and spent by the Office of the Supervising Scientist.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very well spent, too.

—I regret that I am unable to share Senator Dunn's enthusiasm because, sadly but accurately, I have a contrary view. The Office of the Supervising Scientist was set up, as a result of Commissioner Fox's Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry, to have more limited terms of reference and scope than those into which inevitably, like all such instrumentalities, it has expanded. The staff numbers reached 75 in 1985 and they have been maintained at around that level. The 1988-89 budget reached a new high of $6,576,000. Energy Resources of Australia says-I cannot be certain that the figures are accurate, but I have no reason to believe they are not because they have not been contradicted by either the Government or the Supervising Scientist-that the average annual cost per employee in the OSS is approximately 50 per cent higher than the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation, 20 per cent higher than the Natural Resource Division of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and 28 per cent higher than the Alligator Rivers region unit-the Northern Territory uranium unit. Ranger tells us that in the 10 years from 1978 to 1988, OSS research work has produced no practical procedures or standards which Ranger can use to help protect the environment. We are also told that, on average, roughly $4m a year is being spent on research but that there is almost nothing of real practical value for protecting the environment from the results of uranium mining.

SPEECH.PARA: If honourable senators turn to table 2 of the document which sets out the cost of operations of the Office of the Supervising Scientist, they will note, for instance, that, in 1986-87-and this is the latest figure I have been able to find-$292,994 was spent on travel. Debate continues in respect of the location of the OSS. The Supervising Scientist has made it quite clear that he has no intention of leaving Sydney, that he is cosy and comfortable in that fine capital and that his skirmishes past the perimeter of the metropolitan area will consist of infrequent flights to Jabiru to monitor the activities of the organisation. It seems to me bizarre, by any measure, that an organisation which is set up essentially to monitor the effects of Ranger's mining is based in Sydney. Only by the most bizarre logic can one conclude that there is some rational reason for that. But, by normal logic, it has no justification. That has caused some concern and anxiety because it means that funds are being wasted.

The other matter which is of concern to us is that the Office of the Supervising Scientist is funded by Energy Resources of Australia and not by the operations at Olympic Dam and, more particularly, not by the Coronation Hill joint venture. While the responsibilities of the Office of the Supervising Scientist have now been extended into the conservation zone in which the Coronation Hill project is situated and which is now attracting 10 per cent of the budget of the Office of the Supervising Scientist, no funding has been received from the joint venture partners in an operation which, if my memory serves me correctly, so far has identifiable resources valued at $500m. It would seem not unreasonable that if that company is to be visited by the Office of the Supervising Scientist, it should suffer uniformly the pain of having to pay for this burgeoning organisation.

One might ask why the Office of the Supervising Scientist would have responsibilities for the South Alligator River region but not Olympic Dam in the north of South Australia. I am sure that Senator Irina Dunn will be able to expound the virtues, the values, and the intrinsic qualities of the environment upon which the Olympic Dam mine has been built. She will, no doubt, tell us how that fragile environment has been damaged and scoured and scarred irreparably. Yet, it has not been found necessary to have the Supervising Scientist and his troop of 75 marchers monitor the environment in that region. The truth of the matter is that that job is done by two officers of the South Australian Department of Public Health at a very modest cost. I have not yet heard any suggestion that the monitoring has been done in an inadequate, unsophisticated or inefficient way.

It begs the question: why do we need 75 people, spending $6.6m a year, to tell us that the muzzles north and south of the Ranger uranium mine have the same levels of radium concentration? However, that is one of the wonders which, no doubt, will be explained to me by Senator Irina Dunn when she rises to give support to this wasteful amount of money. One can conclude that while we, on this side of the chamber, support the ongoing and dedicated surveillance, supervision and monitoring of the effects of uranium mining in the Kakadu region not only upon the environment but also upon man, we believe that it is being done in a very slovenly and inefficient way. I suppose if Senator Button were able to say what he honestly believes, he would find himself subconsciously nodding in agreement.

Before I leave this area of the debate, I refer to the fact that the Office of the Supervising Scientist, notwithstanding the belief of some, does not have a role in terms of physically monitoring, or supervising the monitoring, of the various tests that are done in respect of the Ranger uranium mine. That is done by the Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy. Its surveillance and check monitoring has, to my knowledge, not been subject to criticism. While this work has been subject to very considerable scrutiny by way of unnecessary duplication by the Office of the Supervising Scientist, it has been found to be, without exception, thoroughly effective. It seems to me that there is a great deal of unnecessary duplication taking place which could well be done away with.

I wish to raise the general question of uranium mining in Australia. The tragedy is that we have this bizarre three-mine policy that even members of the loony Left, in their rational moments, understand not to have any basis of logic. That policy establishes a holding position to prevent the exploration and exploitation of any further uranium regions in Australia. That is the perimeter fence for them. The Government, as with coastal shipping and waterfront reform and, notwithstanding the pleadings of Senator Button, micro-economic reform in respect of Qantas Airways Ltd, does nothing. It is thoroughly paralysed. A considerable burden has been placed on every single taxpayer in Australia because this Government is straitjacketed in terms of its decision-making on uranium mining in Australia.

Senator Graham Richardson, as a member of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources which inquired into the resource potential of the Kakadu National Park, initially had the enlightened view that further exploitation, however sensitive the environment, was the appropriate way to go. However, Senator Richardson was confronted with some polls that showed that the Labor vote was haemorrhaging to the Australian Democrats and other funny little groups that attract the fringes of normal logical thinking. So suddenly overnight he converted to a born again greenie-not by logic, not by emotion, not by persuasion, simply by the polls. Notwithstanding that, when it came-as is now the case-to internal internecine debates within the Australian Labor Party in these matters, Senator Richardson is one of those who pragmatically say that the three-mine system is based on absolutely no logic, only political expediency. I quote him:
The real policy of the Labor movement has been one of political expediency, of public disapproval but the private approval of uranium mining.
I understand that he is joined by others in that view. In the meantime he is between a rock and a hard place in being able to persuade those in his Party that uranium mining has some virtue.

I notice that Senator Cook, in answer to a question earlier, told us that we did not need any further production in Australia because spot prices are where they are and that the world's needs would be satisfied by buying spot. For goodness sake! Of course that is totally untrue. We only have to look at our levels of production and how they have grown in recent years compared to those of Canada for instance. Australia has about one-third of the world's low cost uranium reserve and we have one-tenth of the world market. By contrast, Canada has one-tenth of the world supply of low grade uranium and it has 33 per cent of the world market. That is a total reversal of the Australian statistics. That represents about $600m in trade annually. Just on those figures alone, we are losing $600m a year in trade.

Members of the Labor Party are wringing their hands and Bob Hawke is bursting into tears on the radio about the balance of payments in Australia and the effect it is having on the average taxpayer. When there is an opportunity to change that imbalance, what do they do? They retreat into the dens of darkness of their internecine conflicts and hope to struggle through without facing the reality of the light of day.

TALK.START.PARA: —You make it sound terrible.

—Occasionally the truth, when spoken, does sound terrible, because it is. There is no kind way of putting it. The other reason that Australia is falling far behind in its level of production is the sequential development which took place in Australia's resources. We have a Government that thinks it knows better than the market place.

SPEECH.PARA: Between 1975 and 1987 Canada's production rose from 3,500 tonnes to about 12,600 tonnes. In the last year or two our production has gone from about 3,500 tonnes to, I think, 4,000 tonnes. There is virtually no movement. Our production is absolutely static. In part, that is caused by this absurd proposition that we have a floor price. We keep pitching the floor price at a level that makes our uranium unattractive in the free market of the world. So while Canada, for instance, is able to write long term contracts, we are not because we want more for our uranium, but it stays in the ground. What absolutely absurd logic! I have no doubt that in terms of markets that has cost us dearly.

We have Senator Cook telling us that presently there is an oversupply. There was, and there still is, an overhang in the market, as Senator Button would know, but the reasons are historic; they are well known. We know that what happened in the 1970s led to oversupply in the early 1980s. We know that there were those oil price shocks. We know that there was a world recession. We know that, as a result of the oil price shocks, conservation policies were put into place in most Western world countries. So demand was reduced and electricity growth very much dwindled. We then had problems in the United States of America. The Three Mile Island incident was blown out of all proportion by the propagandists of this world. That, in part, led to half the 254 projects for nuclear reactors, which would have come on stream in the United States, being cancelled before they ever got off the ground. So by the 1980s there was an overhang. At that time demand could have been more than satisfied by the supply. As a result of that overhang, there has since been a closing down of high cost production mines-in my view mines that will not start again. We therefore can take them out of the production equation. Yet we now find that demand is running ahead of supply.

As I said earlier, Senator Cook tells us that we ought to look to spot prices. In answer to a question from I think Senator Parer, Senator Cook told us to look at spot prices to get some understanding of the world market. Senator Cook ought to look past his superficial and glib departmental briefings, ought to look behind the scenes and ask himself why spot prices are where they are and how relevant they are. He would learn that in 1988 spot prices accounted for 9.7 million pounds of U308. That was less than 10 per cent of the reactor requirements of that year. The 1988 spot price market volume was 13 per cent less than it was in 1987 and 41 per cent below that of 1985 volume.

As we all know, the vast majority of uranium contracts are long term contracts between the utilities and the producers. They are based on cost plus profit-not on an artificial price for the oversupply of unwanted inventories. So spot prices are not relevant to long term projection of prices; nor are they relevant to long-term contracts. Those spot prices should be considered or judged to be a reflection of neither the prices nor the demand we can expect in the 1990s and up to the year 2000. Until the year 2000 the demand is reasonably predictable because the reactors are either in the planning stage or in the construction state. Their timing of coming on stream is predictable and so is their demand. I do not pretend to know what will happen past the year 2000. In some part, it will be influenced by global attitudes towards the environment. Issues such as the greenhouse effect will play a significant part.

The reality is that in many respects we will be confronted with the use of either coal or uranium for the generation of electricity. Australia must confront those options, as must every nation of the world. It must be confronted by Australian society in terms of our contribution towards cleansing the environment and in terms of our preparedness to produce a less dirty form of material for the production of electricity. Once we start to confront that issue in a responsible and mature way, we will have to start to make value judgments about the level of our development of the resource and decide whether we are prepared to ship it out and allow somebody else to process it and get the downstream development value or whether we have the courage to have it developed in a very safe and responsible way in Australia and, as a result of that, receive the very much added benefits to our balance of trade.

I find it most regrettable that this Government is not prepared or able to confront the very real issues that bear down on all of us in Australia, and perhaps more on those who might fit loosely into the poorer categories than on others. However, because this Government finds itself straitjacketed by the left wing and some left wing trade unions, it is not able to do that which thinking, sensible members of the Government know it ought to do; that is, to abolish this facade of a three-mine policy; stop Nabarlek putting gravel through its plant to maintain that facade; get on with developing Jabiluka, Yeelirrie, Rudall River and the other operations which are able to go ahead; and allow the market forces to decide whether or not those mines are viable. I have no doubt that our contribution to the supply of uranium around the world will increase very significantly. We will be able to roll back the figures we have before us at present which show Canada to be taking our share of world trade and therefore enhancing its standard of living at a price extracted from the people of Australia.

I find it sad that we are confronted today with a piece of legislation which does nothing more than extract a levy from a mining company for the purpose of having that company monitored by the Office of the Supervising Scientist when we should be confronting the very real issues of the uranium industry in Australia generally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating in part the real issues concerning the uranium mining industry. I intend only to address the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1989, which seeks to increase the export duty on uranium mines from the Alligator Rivers Region. I am surprised at Senator Crichton-Browne. He is probably quite out of touch with his own Party, and he is certainly out of touch with those Liberal voters in Tasmania who changed their vote to vote for the green independents. This may be a problem that faces both parties at the next election.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill seeks to increase the duty on exported uranium mined in the Alligator Rivers Region to reflect the Government's position that the costs associated with protecting the environment from the potential adverse effects of uranium mining should be borne, as far as practicable, by the industry carrying out those operations and not by the ordinary taxpayer. It is proposed that the levy be increased from $1.02 per kilo to $1.15 and that this will contribute an additional $0.8m for 1988-89 to the cost of the work of the Office of the Supervising Scientist (OSS), which is presently about 90 per cent funded by Energy Resources of Australia Ltd (ERA). The company claims that the duty is a heavy one which amounts to about 5 per cent of its operating costs. ERA is crying poor in this regard. I will mention something that no speaker before me has mentioned, and that is that its before tax profit last year was $132m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that a sin?
—It is not a sin, but I do not believe that ERA can be crying poor when it has made that profit.
—Have you ever been there and seen the capital investment?

—Yes, I was in Ranger in February of this year. I went in as a guest of the General Manager, so the honourable senator cannot say that I have not been there. ERA says that the levy is discriminating because it is not also paid by the Olympic Dam uranium operation in South Australia. I agree, and I agree with the comments in this regard by senators who have already spoken in this debate. There is, I suggest, an obvious way to readdress this iniquity; that is, to require an equivalent tax from the South Australian company. Perhaps, also, if there had been an inquiry into the environmental effects of the Olympic Dam project before it was undertaken by a company which was originally supposed to mine gold and mine uranium only as a by-product, an OSS would have been established for South Australia or the existing responsibilities of the OSS would have been extended to cover that mine.
—You cannot have an inquiry and a State election at the same time.

—That is right. Similarly, Senator MacGibbon pointed out that BHP Gold Mines Ltd, the operation of which also come under the responsibility of the OSS, is not presently required to pay such an export levy. If the mine at Coronation Hill goes ahead, clearly the company ought to be required to pay the tax, if only to remove the discrimination against ERA.

SPEECH.PARA: We know that the OSS was established in 1978 as a result of a recommendation by Mr Justice Fox, who conducted the extensive inquiry into uranium mining in the Northern Territory called the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry. He recommended the establishment of the OSS to set standards and procedures for environmental protection of the region from the adverse effects of uranium mining, amongst other things. In recent times, relations between the ERA, the company which owns Ranger, and the OSS have become severely strained. The Supervising Scientist, Mr Bob Fry, wrote to the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts on 29 April 1988, to offer the following explanation for the cause of this tension. He said:

Relations with Ranger have deteriorated significantly in recent times due, I believe, to a concerted campaign by Energy Resources of Australia to discredit the Office and have it abolished. The immediate cause of this is the raising of the levy on uranium exports from the Region . . . I am increasingly concerned at the reluctance of Ranger to provide detailed information . . . Ranger's growing reluctance to co-operate and keep OSS informed is making it difficult for me to co-ordinate activities and indeed to avoid the very duplication of effort and inefficiencies ERA and Ranger complain about.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what he says in his annual report. Why don't you read the annual report?

—I have read the annual report. Later in the year, ERA began to press for the abolition of the OSS, saying that its functions could be performed just as well by the Commonwealth Scientific Industrial Research Organisation or the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation. It also claimed that the OSS had not fulfilled its role as outlined in the Environment Protection (Alligator Rivers Region) Act and it charged the OSS with being inefficient and with duplicating the functions of other organisations. An ERA submission claimed that the OSS had expended approximately $40m-as Senator Crichton-Browne pointed out-and had failed to produce any standards, practices and procedures of value to environment protection at Ranger. However, Mr Bob Fry, the Supervising Scientist, has refuted these claims by saying that ERA misunderstood the function of the OSS, which was to research environmental protection rather than to focus on Ranger's mining activity. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The standards we are developing are standards which protect the environment, not standards about the way they should operate their plant, not standards about the way they should lay layers of tailings, not standards even about the way they should apply water to a land application site.
They are all engineering matters which the mining company either knows how to do, or it doesn't know how to do and has got to find some consultant to tell them . . .
ERA's major objection to the OSS is:
. . . the apparent lack of any priority given to collecting information that might be useful to the mining companies.

ERA referred specifically to two activities-the spray irrigation of excess water and a new system of dealing with the tailings which did not involve a permanent cover of water in the tailings dam. ERA claimed that spray irrigation was recognised by the Fox Inquiry as a potentially useful water management technique but that the OSS only recently became involved with such a research program. Mr Fry, in reply, said that the Fox Inquiry referred to the evaporation of water from within a tailings dam through a fountain effect, and he pointed out that the irrigation program at Ranger sprayed water on an area adjacent to the mine.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that in the annual report? Come on, is that in his annual report?

—There is not time to quote from everything in a half-hour speech. Mr Fry also stressed that the OSS research was conducted on the long term environmental effects of such a procedure, whereas ERA seemed to think that the OSS ought to be doing research on short term aspects. The tailings issue illustrates perfectly the different perspectives of ERA and the OSS. Mr Fry asked:

SPEECH.PARA: What research could an environmental organisation like ours do to develop a pretty well-established engineering method of pouring a slurry out of a pipe?

ERA had not been forced by the OSS to conduct a $150,000 trial for tailings management, as ERA claimed. This was in fact required by the Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy. I would like to put on record part of a letter written by the then Research Director of the Alligator Rivers Region Research Institute, Dr Glen Riley, to the Australian Financial Review on 2 December last year. This letter reveals the hypocrisy of ERA's recent complaints. He said:

ERA claims the research carried out by the Office of the Supervising Scientist (the `Commonwealth environmental watch-dog') to be irrelevant and too expensive, anyway. However, the costs of the OSS remain (after inflation) within the band foreshadowed in 1977 and accepted by government and industry at that time.

Ranger, ERA's operating company, assisted in the formulation of the research program of this office and has for years served on the Co-ordinating Committee for the Alligator Rivers Region, one of whose functions is to assess research as it relates to the environmental effects of uranium mining. Never, during this time, has Ranger chosen to recommend a change in this research strategy that is being followed. This continuing implicit endorsement of the OSS research program confirms Ranger's opinion voiced to ASTEC (Australian Science and Technology Council) during an earlier review of the relevance and quality of OSS research programs. On that occasion Ranger said:

`It is vitally important . . . that the Office of the Supervising Scientist is allowed to continue in its present role and that it is afforded sufficient funds to maintain and improve its scientific status so that it can carry out its designated functions effectively.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Designated-put the stress on `designated'.
—That is what we are debating here today. He continued:

SPEECH.PARA: At that time Ranger appeared to recognise that this research role of the OSS was to study potential threats to the environment associated with mining activities and how these risks might be mitigated. It is not, nor should it be, the primary focus of OSS research to develop technical or engineering solutions to operational problems confronting Ranger. The OSS was set up to satisfy community concerns, not the pragmatic needs of the mining industry, although it would be short-sighted of the industry not to see that it too is a beneficiary of such research.

It is quite clear to me that the OSS has a unique function and that that function ought to be preserved and strengthened in view of Australia's international obligations to protect the World Heritage area which completely surrounds the mine. This is a fact that Senator Crichton-Browne does not seem to recognise. After all, Olympic Dam is not surrounded by a World Heritage area. Even with the efforts of the OSS over the last decade to protect the environment, there have been potentially serious accidents. One last year involved the accidental dumping of up to 448,000 tonnes of radioactive low-grade ore onto the waste rock dump, which contains a much lower level of uranium. Water running off from the waste rock dump is generally collected in retention pond 4 (RP4) for release, while water run-off from the low-grade ore dump is collected in retention pond 2. This pond collects water from the entire restricted release zone and it is never to be released except under special conditions such as a one in 10-year rainfall.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you can drink out of both of them.

—If the honourable senator is foolish enough to do that, as the Northern Territory Minister for Mines and Energy did-it was sufficient to provoke a ludicrous cartoon which Senator Tambling distributed in the Senate this morning-he is welcome to it. I cannot guarantee the effects. Perhaps they are already visible. The low-grade ore was dumped onto the waste rock dump when the discriminator equipment failed in May of last year. The fact that it was not discovered until November by the company's own health and safety officers, does not give one confidence in the ability of the company to monitor its own operations adequately. It was fortunate that the mistake occurred during the dry season, for otherwise the radioactive material would certainly have been washed into RP4 for release into the Magela Creek system, which is a major tributary of the East Alligator River. When I visited Ranger earlier this year the Manager told me that a crocodile lived in RP4. That may well be so, but it is not necessarily proof of the safety of the water in that pond. One would need to test the full range of aquatic organisms within the pond, particularly those which are sensitive to radioactive elements, to gauge the deeper and long term effects of the water on aquatic ecosystems.
—Has not the OSS already done that?

—The OSS has done it and found that organisms, and particularly fish, have died. In particular, the reproductive success of sensitive aquatic fauna is an important indicator of the toxicity of the water in the retention ponds. The accident on the waste rock dump was the subject of an internal memo written by Dr Glen Riley to the OSS last year. In relation to this mater he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I regard this situation as the most serious deficiency shown by Ranger in the long series of malfunctions and operational shortcomings since the mine opened.
Rather than achieve better (or more sure) environmental control as they gain more experience, Ranger are moving the operation into a more hazardous situation.

Although a spokesman for the Northern Territory Minister for Mines and Energy, Mr Coulter, confirmed that the Northern Territory Government had considered prosecuting ERA over the incident, it decided against it on the grounds that the breach was accidental. He said that the incident was `very small beer'. I say that it could have been much bigger beer if the incident had taken place during the wet. There is a major disagreement between Ranger and OSS in relation to the release of water into Magela Creek from RP4. Ranger has built a spillway and merely wants the water to spill over, every time the creek reaches a certain level, into the beautiful Jalkmara Billabong which, in turn, flows into Magela Creek. The OSS wants the water to be pumped directly from RP4 to Magela Creek so that the levels of dilution can be more strictly controlled. When I talked to the General Manager of Ranger in February, he said that the spillway allowed the naturally toxic water from RP4 to collect in Jalkmara Billabong in a way which simulated the natural environment of the area. Now it is true that the waters of the area are of higher toxicity than elsewhere as a result of formic acid and other natural processes. However, the Ranger General Manager also said to me that since Jalkmara Billabong is on the site of the second ore body, it did not really matter what happened to it in the interim. I think that is a fairly careless attitude towards the environment.

The reason that the OSS is opposed to the release of water into the Jalkmara Billabong is that it could cause a backflow along the Jalkmara Billabong which would collect for a much longer period than normal. When I put it to Bob Cleary, the General Manager, he said that it would not matter if the toxic water was held there since it simply simulates the natural environment of the billabong and that the vegetation would be able to remove the toxic material by oxidation, sedimentation or osmosis, or one of a number of other natural processes. When I asked him for evidence of the research that had been done on this, the reply was totally unsatisfactory. It was clearly a rule of thumb assessment and no scientific work had been done on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unsatisfactory to you.
—Unsatisfactory by any scientific standards.
—Are you a scientist?
—I remind the honourable senator that I have been the author of an award winning book on Australian ecology, and that award was given by the scientific body, the Royal Australian Zoological Society.
—Does that make you a scientist?

—I do not have a science degree but I have co-authored a book which won a scientific award. Because the OSS lacks the powers to compel the Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy to follow its recommendations, it has bent over backwards to cooperate with the company. One of the examples of such cooperation occurred recently when Ranger proposed to the OSS that it should get what Ranger called an arbitrator to assess two separate analyses that had been done by Ranger and the OSS on what constitutes a one in 10-year rainfall, that is, the conditions under which water from RP2, the restricted release zone, could be released into the surrounding water system through Magela Creek. There is a fundamental difference between the two models proposed by Ranger and by the OSS. Ranger wants to be able to release water from RP2 every time it reaches a certain level in the pond. The OSS wants the release to be made on a measure of local rainfall and claims that Ranger has not allowed for adequate storage in the retention pond. If this fact were recognised, Ranger would be forced to accept the inconvenience and the cost of deepening the pond or preparing another pond, or storing that toxic water at the bottom of the mine pit and facing the inconvenience of not being able to mine the bottom of the pit for the duration of the wet season. Then during the dry season Ranger would have the option of pumping that water back into RP2 or back into the tailings dam, which would then be semi-dry.

SPEECH.PARA: The OSS disputed many of the findings of the report and received recognition from Professor Pilgrim and Associate Professor Corderoy of the University of New South Wales that there were mistakes in it. However, the damaging aspect of this is that an earlier version of the report went out with the word `final' on it. Ranger now claims that that is the final report and that it supports Ranger's analysis.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was it commented on in the annual report-in the OSS report?

—This is a very recent matter; it occurred only in the last couple of months. I am surprised that Senator Tambling is not up to date. There have been a number of minor infringements in relation to the release of water. I have already referred to one and I do not propose to go into it, but it resulted in the ludicrous image of the Northern Territory Minister for Mines and Energy drinking a glass of water from retention pond 4. That was the cause of a long letter from Senator Graham Richardson to the Australian newspaper, which indicated that RP4 contained toxic water. A spokesman for Senator Richardson said of the water:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Coulter might be able to drink it, but that's not to say the rest of Kakadu's little creatures can do the same.

Such breaches illustrate a major difference between the two organisations. Ranger would like to release water and then get the OSS to go down and measure the effects. If the effects are not major it wants to say, `See, there are no effects on the environment'. That is not a very scientific way of approaching the protection of the environment. The OSS, quite properly, wants to conduct the studies in order to be able to have some kind of predictive measure of the effect of releases on the environment, particularly the long-term effects. Unfortunately, the OSS is hampered by a welter of legislation which makes its operations extraordinarily difficult. Dr Wasson of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation stated as much in his evidence as a private citizen to the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts. He said:

. . . somebody has to cut through what I perceive to be a regulatory nightmare that has developed around Ranger. . . I would think that a lot of the problems Ranger has faced has to do with regulations cutting across one another and not knowing who is the final authority. I would think that if the Officer of the Supervising Scientist could, after due consideration, be given that responsibility it would be an excellent way of cutting through a lot of these problems.

I have to support Dr Wasson's statement. In fact, the Committee supported Dr Wasson's statement and said that it seemed to the Committee that the regulatory framework was complex and could lead to confusion. It also led the Committee to recommend increased responsibilities for the OSS and its strengthening, as appropriate, to take account of the issues discussed in the preceding paragraphs of the report.

The biggest problem regarding Ranger in the long run is what happens to the tailings dam. The company has rectified an earlier problem and has added more water to the tailings dam. A few months ago it was practically dry and there was a danger of a lot of radioactive dust blowing off the tailings dam onto the township of Jabiru and getting into the local ecosystems. There are about 350 traditional Aboriginal owners living in the park. If the Government had any consideration for those traditional owners and the inhabitants of the local Jabiru township, it would conduct continuing medical tests on their health. That should be done as a matter of urgency, particularly in view of studies in the United Kingdom.

One of the great difficulties under which the OSS operates is the secrecy provisions of the Environment Protection (Alligator Rivers Region) Act. The Government should look generally at the legislation under which the OSS operates and perhaps even think about changing it so the OSS can do its job properly. One of the ways of strengthening the position of the OSS would be to require the Northern Territory Government to implement the recommendations of the OSS so that the OSS is not put in the invidious position of having to go to an arbitrator that is, in fact, a second scientific body outside itself. After all, the OSS was set up to monitor and research the environment and to look at the effects of uranium mining. The OSS, and in particular Mr Bob Fry, has shown a great amount of reasonableness in the face of such powerlessness.

In the long run I believe that Kakadu National Park will make more money for Australia and the Northern Territory than will uranium mining and that any money put into the park as a tourist facility should be regarded by the Government as an investment. It is a major source of revenue and, properly managed, can be a joy and a delight to not only Australians but the citizens of the world. It is the largest World Heritage area in the tropics and we are all very concerned about it. Senator Richardson and the Government make noises about their concern for the environment and the greenhouse effect, but in my view it is completely inconsistent to have a uranium mine stuck in the middle of a World Heritage area. Natural ecosystems do not recognise human boundaries. Rivers flow across boundaries. In the wet season the whole area is flooded and any radioactive material that is released in one part of the park can be taken miles downstream to another part of the park. Although it may seem to be a very resilient environment facing such extremes of weather conditions each year, it is not. It is quite clear that it has a very delicately balanced ecosystem which must be preserved and protected not only because of the aesthetic pleasures that it offers but also because of its great importance to the world environment.

I do not intend to take up the points raised earlier by Senator Coulter regarding nuclear energy, except to say that I support his comments. However, it still surprises me that many honourable senators continue to ignore the long-term environmental hazards of uranium mining when they propose nuclear fission as an alternative source of energy. I can only conclude that they are content to leave the problem of the disposal of radioactive waste to their grandchildren and great-grandchildren. I note that the Federal coalition would, in government, return control of both Uluru and Kakadu national parks to the Northern Territory Government and further expand the Commonwealth's uranium policy. Clearly, that would be disastrous for the area. It would be a disaster for Kakadu National Park because the Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy has proven that it is not capable of looking after the area. It has consistently undermined the work of the OSS and has shown itself to be an arm of the mining industry. In my opinion, it would be better for the OSS to be given the full powers to enforce its recommendations to ensure that the brief that it was given under the Fox Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry is absolute.

Kakadu is home to one-third of this nation's bird species and a quarter of its fish species. It is also home to many rare and endangered species such as the pig-nosed turtle, the salt-water crocodile and the hooded parrot. Water is a crucial resource for the wildlife of the area. Towards the dry season its billabongs and rivers teem with birds that travel to the region for food. Thus contamination of the water presents a great threat to the wildlife and the ecosystems of the region. We must do all that we can to preserve them. For that reason I support the legislation. I would like to see the export levy go up even higher so that it covers 100 per cent of the costs of the OSS. However, 90 per cent will do for the time being.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will reply briefly on behalf of the Government to honourable senators' speeches on the Bills. I start at some disadvantage in being somewhat breathless after Senator Dunn's speech. I must say that the compilation of all that information must have been a very exhausting task for the honourable senator: certainly, it was exhausting to listen to. Her having so much information puts me at some disadvantage. I suppose the burden of Senator Dunn's speech is that she fulfils a description which was once given to Kingsley Martin, an editor of the New Statesman, in his latter years as a person buoyant with gloom because he was dedicated to catastrophe. It is unfortunate to see Senator Dunn in that category.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not intend to deal in detail with all the contributions to the debate. I had the advantage of hearing Senator MacGibbon's contribution, in which he asked some questions about the amendment to the definitions set out in the explanatory memorandum. The Government decided not to backdate the changes prior to 3 March because to do so would mean forgoing significant revenue. The decision was made quite deliberately. The expanded definitions are expected to cost some $20m a year. Should this Bill be passed the new and clarified eligibility criteria for the rebated diesel duty will commence on 3 March 1989, the date of Government announcement. No rebate will be paid for the period October 1986 to 2 March 1989.

Senator MacGibbon also moved a second reading amendment which relates to the uranium concentrate levy. Honourable senators looked at it from different perspectives. Senator Dunn's solution to the problem was that if it is unfair to the one on which the levy is imposed, the way to level that is to impose it on the other one as well. Senator MacGibbon and other speakers approached the issue from a somewhat different perspective, saying it was unfair to impose it on one and not on the second one. The point about the levy is, first, that the Government does not believe that the export levy will significantly affect the competitive position of companies mining uranium in the Alligator Rivers region. In the Government's view it is a small price to pay to protect a part of Australia's heritage that, as Senator Dunn pointed out, is of international significance. I could give the Senate figures on the likely impact of the levy, but I do not propose to do so at this stage. The simple point is that the mining operations in the Alligator Rivers region not only are more environmentally sensitive but also are situated in a national park. That is not true of the other company's operations in respect of which the alleged discrimination would arise. So the Government does not accept the second reading amendment.

One or two honourable senators spoke on the Bounty (Ships) Bill. I think I can best deal with it in the committee stage of the Bill. Other honourable senators talked about the grain harvester bounty and the cultivation machinery and equipment bounty and there is a second reading amendment in relation to that issue also. The matter has already been discussed in the Senate by way of questions at Question Time and so on. As the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, I certainly regret that the degree of continuity which as a government we have provided in terms of the administration of industry policy was disrupted somewhat by this precipitate termination of the bounty; nonetheless, the Government has since introduced transitional provisions which will be the subject of amendments to this legislation which will assist companies to overcome the transitional period. The reasons for the change to the bounty were expressed at the time of the April statement and thereafter by me and there is no change in the fundamental reasons as to why that was done. In so far as the Opposition amendment expresses regret about that matter, I accept in some ways the spirit of it, although I do not accept second reading amendments to Bills of this kind.

This is at first sight a fairly complex set of Bills, but in reality they are fairly simple. Many of the provisions implement decisions of the Government previously announced. The debate has defined very narrowly the controversial aspects of the legislation and honourable senators have spoken on those controversial items. As far as I intend to at this stage, I have replied to those matters. I commend the Bills to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question is that the amendment moved by Senator MacGibbon in respect of the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1989 be agreed to.
—The question is that the amendment moved by Senator MacGibbon in respect of the Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 2, after clause 4, insert the following new clauses in Part 2:
Claims for payment of subsidy
``4a. Section 17 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting paragraph (3) (d) and substituting the following paragraph:
`(d) be lodged with a Collector for a State or Territory, or with the Comptroller:

(i) unless subparagraph (ii) applies-before the end of the period of 12 months commencing on the day on which the condition referred to in subsection 9 (4) or (6) or 10 (3), as the case requires, was compiled with in respect of the subsidised equipment; or
(ii) if 16 July 1989 occurs before the end of the period of 12 months referred to in subparagraph (i)-before 16 July 1989.'.
Savings

``4b. Where a manufacturer of subsidised equipment has completed or completes the manufacture of such equipment after the end of the subsidy period but before 16 June 1989 to meet a firm order placed with the manufacturer before the end of the subsidy period, the Principal Act as amended by this Act has effect as if:
(a) the manufacture of the subsidised equipment had been completed, and the subsidised equipment had been prepared for sale, by the manufacturer during the subsidy period; and
(b) the subsidised equipment had been, at the end of the subsidy period:
(i) held in the manufacturer's stock; and
(ii) listed in the manufacturer's inventory of stock.''.
(2) Page 3, after clause 7, add the following new clauses:
Claims for payment of subsidy
``8. Section 18 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting paragraph (2) (d) and substituting the following paragraph:
`(d) be lodged with a Collector for a State or Territory, or with the Comptroller:

(i) unless sub paragraph (ii) applies-before the end of the period of 12 months commencing on the day on which the condition referred to in subsection 10 (4) or (6) or 11 (3) or (5), as the case requires, was complied with in respect of the subsidised equipment; or
(ii) if 16 July 1989 occurs before the end of the period of 12 months referred to in subparagraph (i)-before 16 July 1989.'.
Savings

``9. Where a manufacturer of subsidised equipment has completed or completes the manufacture of such equipment after the end of the subsidy period but before 16 June 1989 to meet a firm order placed with the manufacturer before the end of the subsidy period, the Principal Act as amended by this Act has effect as if:
(a) the manufacturer of the subsidised equipment had been completed, and the subsidised equipment had been prepared for sale, by the manufacturer during the subsidy period; and
(b) the subsidised equipment had been, at the end of the subsidy period:
(i) held in the manufacturer's stock; and
(ii) listed in the manufacturer's inventory of stock.''.
(3) Page 1, Title, at the end of title, add ``, and for related purposes''.

On 12 April 1989 the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced the termination of the Subsidy (Grain Harvesters and Equipment) Act and the Subsidy (Cultivation Machines and Equipment) Act as from that date, as part of the savings made by the Government in its April economic statement. The amendments propose transitional arrangements for the phasing out of the grain harvester and cultivation equipment Acts, which will give the industry time to adjust to the new trading environment. The Government considers this is justified because the industry has been able to establish that it had a high enough level of firm orders on 12 April 1989, the termination date for the schemes, to warrant a transitional period to cover such orders.

The amendments provide that, where a manufacturer completes all the steps necessary to claim under the two Acts by 16 July 1989 for the purposes of satisfying a firm order placed with the manufacturer prior to 13 April, bounty will be payable to that manufacturer on the manufacture of that equipment, provided a claim for payment is lodged prior to 16 July.

The proposed amendments, which provide transitional arrangements, will have no financial impact, as the additional bounty payments for eligible grain harvesters and cultivation equipment will all be met from within the respective Acts 1988-89 financial year appropriations. I commend the amendments to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not be opposing these amendments. We simply draw the notice of the Committee to the fact that the Government should have foreseen this action when the Bill was drafted. It is a reflection on this Government's competence, in a sense, that these amendments have had to be moved at this time and in this way.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is no reflection on anybody's competence. Members of the industry made representations to us, as did a lot of Opposition senators-including Senator Chaney-and we changed our view. I thought that would be the sort of conduct which even this Opposition would welcome, because it is the only influence which the Opposition has on events. It did have an influence on these events, and I would have thought the honourable senator would have welcomed it.

—We certainly welcome the fact that the Government reflected upon its position. However, the position arose because an industry had its legs chopped from under it without any fair warning at all. That is why the amendments are before us today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the Government for its amendments, which extend the termination date from 12 April to 12 June. As I read this Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill, this also applies to harvesters. The amendments will have an affect on cultivation equipment, but virtually none on harvesters. This is because no harvesters are being manufactured and certainly none are being sold at this time of the year-except by or to anyone who may have especially tried to take advantage of this small give-away.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to express my concern that this subsidy had only until 30 June 1990 to run-and that date should have been retained because there would have been at least one season for the use of cultivation equipment, and one more for the harvesters. This is because harvesting plant is bought just before harvesting, which is understandable, and seeding plant is bought just before seeding. As far as the harvesters are concerned, this extension until 12 June will bring no benefit because the plant will not have been bought by then. As I said during the second reading debate, I hoped the Government would have considered treating Australian manufacturers in a slightly different way from multinational manufacturers which happen to be operating in Australia for the time being.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
BOUNTY (SHIPS) BILL 1989
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 13, after subparagraph 17 (6) (d) (i), line 43, add ``and''.
(2) Page 14, subparagraph 17 (6) (d) (ii), lines 1-3, leave out the subparagraph.

Under the current scheme which is in operation, to be eligible for bounty, shipbuilders must meet registration criteria as well as orderly development provisions. Today there are about 20 registered shipbuilders compared with over 30 in 1985. Since 1984 and up until April 1989, 45 shipbuilders had received registration, yet only 13 firms have maintained continuous registration during this period. Under the Bounty (Ships) Bill, the registration criteria are even more restrictive. It is argued that this is to offset the advantage of removing the orderly development provisions.

We are told that these requirements are necessary to ensure that bounties are given only to shipbuilders with a long term commitment to the industry. Yet the requirement that 75 per cent of activities be devoted to bountiable construction and modification is quite an arbitrary figure-a figure that apparently the Government has just plucked out of the air. It is a provision that can be readily circumvented with creative management. The Opposition is concerned that there seems to be no basis for the figure of 75 per cent and that is why we have moved an amendment to seek its deletion.

Let us look at what happens when a company is starting up. Initially, it may well be able to get off the ground but it could well have, in its operational activities, something that does not satisfy the requirement in respect of the 75 per cent involvement in bountiable construction and modification. Yet it could have all the shipbuilding skills that it needs to fulfil a task. Is the Government able to say that, because a company has these professional skills, it is not a serious player in the shipbuilding industry? Are all Australian shipyards-few that they are-able to satisfy the condition at present?

I notice that the Industries Assistance Commission is opposed to this present criterion; it actually recommended a reversion to tariff assistance if the more restrictive requirement was not removed. The Opposition will not go that far but we have moved to delete the 75 per cent requirement. In this respect, clause 17 (6) of this Bill provides:
The Minister shall not register an applicant for registration unless:
. . . at least 75% of the applicant's activities will be devoted to the construction or modification of vessels of more than 150 but not more than 10,000 gross construction tons . . .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept the amendments. The current arrangements for the Australian shipbuilding industry, which are further clarified in this legislation, have produced order out of the chaos in the industry. When the previous arrangements were first put in place, in excess of 70 shipyards in Australia-sometimes up to 90-were eligible for the bounty which was then payable. That encouraged fragmentation; ad hoc responses to particular situations; yards building a ship for a particular fisherman in response to a particular demand; and no concentration on technology and skills. The job shop mentality was very apparent in the shipbuilding industry in this country and it is not unkind to say that it was going out backwards.

SPEECH.PARA: By producing some order in the arrangements we have made sure that the subsidy-which, after all, is taxpayers' dollars-is targeted towards those shipbuilders who meet certain criteria and who are prepared to become professional shipbuilders. In 1984-85, when these arrangements were introduced, if it had been said anywhere that Australia was likely to be able to produce ships for export, frankly, people would have laughed. At present, more than half a billion dollars worth of ships are being built in Australian shipyards, more than half of which are for export. Australian shipbuilders, under these orderly arrangements, have been able to gain markets in Europe, the United Kingdom, India, the Middle East and Asia. We have had a concentration of professionalism in the shipbuilding industry. Shipbuilders are the most successful finders of niche markets in export terms-probably of any industry in this country. They are producing vessels which are recognised internationally and our export performance attests to that.

These arrangements are designed to assist those shipbuilders who have the potential to be world competitive. They are there. World competitiveness is not a part time business. People have to decide to be in it as a vocation, if you like and, if they do, they are probably halfway towards making it. The 75 per cent requirement allows firms to have some degree of diversification in their operations, but it ensures that they be substantially involved in shipbuilding if they expect to be world-class players. If honourable senators lived in some international dream world and they wanted to buy a luxury cruise vessel, it is probable that the best vessels in the world are made in Australia by a company in Western Australia, and marketed overseas. If they wanted an international catamaran ferry, it is probable that the best vessels are now made in Australia and marketed overseas.

These successes have been achieved because of these development proposals and because people in the industry have concentrated their minds on becoming shipbuilders of world-class. They have been achieved because of proposals such as the one in this legislation which insists that shipbuilders' activities are at least 75 per cent directed to shipbuilding. Of course, this might not accord with pet theories which some people have. Pet theories have prevailed in Australian industry for many years but performance was never exactly as the theoreticians might have desired. We have in Australia a regime which is demonstrably successful and none of these successful Australian companies would have any difficulty with the 75 per cent rule.

Senator MacGibbon, who always suspects that people will subvert these proposals, said, `Why do shipbuilders not indulge in a bit of creative accounting or whatever? Is it not open to them to say that they will split a business-that part of it will attract a bounty because it will be 75 per cent shipbuilding and they will put their engineering job shop business somewhere else?'. That is quite possible, but it makes them concentrate their minds on what they are about in terms of their shipbuilding activity. I think that is an excellent thing. The Government does not accept these amendments. I commend the legislation, as drafted, to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to those companies which are sitting on the borderlines-and I am sure that Senator Button and Senator MacGibbon have been lobbied very heavily by one company in Western Australia-in that they have contracts which mean that, for the time being, their shipbuilding activity represents more than 75 per cent of their total activity, but, when the contracts fall out some time down the track, they may fall below the 75 per cent level. I am sure those companies would like some assurance that, for the time that they remain above that limit, they will be eligible for the bounty and that, if they temporarily fall below that level, they will remain in a bountiable and registrable state. If they pick up other contracts quickly, they will remain registrable. If they remain below the 75 per cent level, clearly they will fall below the criteria and will not attract the bounty. As the bounty is payable on the completion of the vessels, if the answer to the first question is yes, such a company would be entitled to bounty while it remained above the 75 per cent level. What will happen to those vessels that may be only partly completed at the time the company drops below the 75 per cent level, even though the parts of those vessels that were completed while the company was above the 75 per cent level would have attracted the bounty?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I may be able to satisfy Senator Coulter. The company he is talking about is registered. Registration is an annual process. It has just been successful in a particular overseas contract. Some of the other correspondents from Western Australia are also registered, and there is no reason why they should not be registered again and again, provided they maintain that 75 per cent level.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Coulter asked what will happen if companies are stuck with a ship half-built and fall below the 75 per cent level. It must be remembered that the bounty is paid on completion of the vessel, it is not paid along the track. There is always concern, which in the case of the companies in question is probably not justified, that at some time in the future they may fall below the 75 per cent level and that will be an issue for them. But I must remind Senator Coulter that the bounty is phasing out in any event and that by 1995 there will be no bounty at all under the proposals in the legislation. So what we are looking at is the period between now and then. It is very likely that those companies will continue to obtain registration, as they have recently done. As I said, the bounty is payable at the end of the shipbuild, and not halfway through.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to put on record my praise for the performance of those shipbuilders that have been very successful in the international market. But that success has come not only through their own merchandising and construction skills; it has been aided by the weakness of the Australian dollar on overseas markets and by the payment of the bounty itself. Like Senator Coulter, I am concerned about this. Six years is a long time in the life of a company. While the Bill provides that the bounty will disappear by 1995, there is still a long way to go-in fact, two terms of the parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Hamer in his contribution this morning raised the point that when one has an investment in a shipyard, not only does it build ships but it also has an obligation to maintain its products, which are the ships that are being built. The yards that are involved in the export market, particularly those in the pleasure craft field, are very sensitive to cyclical swings. If there is a change in the economies of overseas countries and people go quietly for a year or two and do not buy 150-foot yachts and that sort of thing, a lot of the yards here will be in difficulty, and they must maintain their existence by doing maintenance work to keep their work force intact. I would argue with Senator Coulter that there is a need for a bit of flexibility and understanding of their position. I come to the question I asked when I first spoke on this amendment: How did the Government arrive at the figure of 75 per cent rather than 74 per cent, 73 per cent or even 65 per cent? What was the decisive factor that led to the 75 per cent figure?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that the 75 per cent figure is an arbitrary one. At some stage one has to arrive at a conclusion about a number of issues relating to shipyards in terms of skilled personnel, technology and a whole range of issues. Inevitably, they are arbitrary decisions, and the figure of 75 per cent is arbitrary in that sense. I remind the Committee that there is not all that much money to go around in terms of this bounty, and it will not be going around forever. The more specific the requirement relating to the registration of yards, the more those yards which are up to world-class manufacturing will benefit. I agree with Senator MacGibbon's point that the value of the Australian dollar is important for this industry. It is going to be more important in the next year or two when we have a 15 per cent bounty or a 10 per cent bounty-or, as it will become, no bounty at all.

SPEECH.PARA: So while I understand the concerns, I think they operate very much at the margin. Although one or two companies out of the 23 or 24 that are recipients of the bounty have lobbied senators and so on, as Senator Coulter put it, it is quite a manageable issue, and I have no personal doubts about the future of those companies as shipbuilders.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek further clarification of the question I asked earlier, because I am still not clear about those vessels that might be under construction at the time a company falls below the 75 per cent level. The Minister has replied that the bounty is paid on completed ships, which is true. But the amount of bounty is calculated on the actual costs borne at the time. It is not calculated on the costs, as they might be inflated, at the time the ship is actually completed. The costs of construction listed in the Bill include design costs, direct labour costs, direct material costs, subcontracting costs, fitting-out costs, costs involved in the trialling and, finally, transportation costs. Let us suppose a company is within the level of bounty for the whole period and has the ship actually completed but has not transported and delivered the ship. In other words, when all the listed costs of construction or modification-and, presumably, they are all-embracing; they are all the costs for which the bounty is payable-have been incurred but the ship is not yet delivered, is that company then entitled to the bounty or not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer to that question is yes, it is. Might I say again, on the question of registration, that registration is for one year. On re-registration, the company is required to satisfy the registration criteria afresh. For a ship in the course of being built, though, the bounty which arises from its registration remains for that ship, and the question of deregistration is a discretionary one; that is, the Minister may cancel registration if the criteria are not met. That decision is appealable to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. In answer to what I might fairly describe as Senator Coulter's hypothetical question about `what happens if', that ship still gets the bounty.
—On those parts that are completed, of course.
—Yes. In so far as Senator Coulter refers to what the bounty embraces, that is a matter of common agreement with the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator MacGibbon's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
