TALK.START.PARA: —I want to go to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1989 and deal with the diesel fuel rebate scheme, which the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) referred to in part in his reply to the second reading debate. I return to my concerns about the gap where no payment is made for rebates. The Minister said that it would have cost too much money to have allowed a rebate through that period. How much money would it have cost? How many companies would have been involved? How many individuals would have been involved? Will the Minister give the Senate an accurate figure on that?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that I can give an accurate figure because my arithmetic is abysmal. The expanded definitions are expected to cost $20m per year. If one backdated this to the missing period one could, I presume, do a calculation. I have not done it but that gives the honourable senator something of the order of the magnitude of the difference.
—Can the Minister tell the Committee whether that figure could be accurately arrived at? Are the records there for the Government to establish what the obligation would be if it were repaid?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have just been advised, from October 1986 to now there is the possibility that some companies could have been eligible. We do not know whether they would have been eligible during that period. But they are now and henceforth the cost of that will be $20m a year. There was a technical difficulty in determining eligibility in the past anyway. But the other factor is that they are now eligible, they get the benefits from now on and there is the cost to revenue.

—I followed that answer with absolute clarity and comprehension. The question which I have been asking Senator Button and which he has been avoiding is: are the Minister's records accurate enough to determine which companies and which individuals would have been entitled to a rebate throughout that period.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just been advised that one company has alleged that it would have been eligible. I do not know whether that allegation can be substantiated at this time; I think probably not. The answer in retrospective terms is that determining eligibility from the records may have been very difficult.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct the attention of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1989. If we can lift ourselves above party politics and launch into the altruism that ought to prevail in these sorts of debates can I ask the Minister: Why is it that Energy Resources of Australia Ltd which owns the Ranger uranium mine is required essentially to carry the full burden of the budget of the Office of the Supervising Scientist to the extent that 75 per cent of its budget is paid for by the industry? I noticed in the second reading speech of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) that the cost associated with protecting the environment and also protecting the environment from potential damage ought to be quite properly borne as far as practicable by the industry and not by what the Minister described as ordinary taxpayers.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a cute definition that I do not understand. I am sure it means something to somebody. Why is it that the ordinary taxpayers who are shareholders in Energy Resources of Australia Ltd carry the full burden of the $4 billion for the Office of the Supervising Scientist whereas the ordinary taxpayers who are shareholders in the Coronation Hill joint venture project, which now comes within the terms of reference by way of amendment to the legislation because it is located within the conservation zone, do not make a contribution? If my memory serves me correctly in a question asked by Senator Puplick at the Estimates committee Mr Fry, in one of his rare visits to Australia, was able to tell him that 10 per cent-I think he was talking about 10 per cent of his budget; his answer was not clear-is now spent on the conservation zone. Why is it that Ranger should have to pay a proportion of the cost of the activity in that area when the object of the activity for the moment at least is designed to monitor the environment of an area which is being disrupted, modest as it might be, by the Coronation Hill joint venture partners and in no way is associated with the activities of the Ranger uranium mine?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crichton-Browne comes in here, if I might say so, calling for high-mindedness in this debate. Broad-mindedness has been defined as being the result of flattening high-mindedness out. If that is Senator Crichton-Browne's point, broad-mindedness is what we often get in the Senate. I made a contribution on this issue when Senator Crichton-Browne was not physically with us, no doubt he was in spirit. There are two or three points which I shall make which I hope are simple in respect of Senator Crichton-Browne's question. It is a sort of cap fits situation. Mining in Kakadu creates certain potential environmental hazards which the levy is designed essentially to address. That was the origins of it. It is not a tax on the uranium industry as such.
—It happens to be for the moment.

—It is not on all of the uranium industry. It is on that section of the industry which produces the greatest risk of environmental damage in a national park. Senator Crichton-Browne then went on to ask, `What about Coronation Hill?'. The matter of a levy on gold mining operations at Coronation Hill or on any operations within the Kakadu conservation zone has to be determined in the context of developing a regulatory regime for the conservation zone and for mining proposals within it.

SPEECH.PARA: In the context of this debate we cannot deal with what is essentially an unreal situation now that mining is not taking place at Coronation Hill. If there is an environmental and mining regime to be put into place in association with the Coronation Hill venture, maybe it will attract a levy for the same sorts of purposes as the current levy in respect of Ranger. That, if I might say so, illustrates the point that it is not a tax on the uranium industry or part of it. It is essentially about mining activities and their environmental implications in national parks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Button made the point that it is not a tax on the uranium industry. I understand that. But it just so happens to be that for the moment the uranium industry, to the extent that Ranger fits within that category, is the only industry that is being taxed. I understand that it is not about the uranium industry. It can be well argued that the effect of uranium mining on the environment is decidedly less than the effect of other extraction industries that are involved in matters such as--
—A great deal less.

—I agree. These include industries that require cyanide solutions and other such processing activities. I understand that. But the truth of the matter is that at the present time the Office of the Supervising Scientist has responsibilities that now go past stages one and two and the original responsibilities given to it under the Act. I assume the Supervising Scientist is collecting base line research data in the Coronation Hill area but I am not certain, having read what I have about his functioning up until now. He is certainly spending somewhere in the range of $650,000 a year in the conservation zone. He is only in the conservation zone because of the existence of the Coronation Hill joint venture project, otherwise he would not be there. The question I am asking is: Why is Ranger required to make a contribution to the funding of his activity which extends past its activity and goes into the conservation zone? In other words, simply put, Ranger is subsidising his environmental considerations in the conservation zone. Senator Button would know better than most that environmental considerations ought always to forerun mining activity. That is exactly why he is in Coronation Hill now. Exploration is taking place. The proven reserves clearly demonstrate that there will be a mine there. So the Office of the Supervising Scientist is now monitoring in advance of mining operations subject to approval from the Government. In fact, the Supervising Scientist is doing work related to a project which is presently taking place to the extent of exploration. I am asking why Coronation Hill is not making a contribution while Ranger is required to carry the difference.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps in the context of this debate Senator Crichton-Browne should have listened to his ideological colleague, Senator Dunn, because she wanted the playing field levelled too. She said that the levy falls on Energy Resources of Australia Ltd at present and if the Opposition wants to even it all up, it should put it on Olympic Dam as well--
—In terms of the playing field, there is some argument for that.

—Yes, but the honourable senator is putting a different argument about the playing field. He is saying that it should apply to Coronation Hill although he concedes in his remarks that environmental work is best done before mining operations start as well as during and after. The burden of the answer that I gave the honourable senator a minute or two ago was that when an environmental and mining regime is put in place for Coronation Hill, then the question of the levy will be dealt with in that context at that time. The honourable senator has to be a little patient.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not pursue it because Senator Button knows that there is a vacuum in terms of logic. There is a simple way of solving the problem; that is, if Ranger is expected to pay 75 per cent of the cost of the Supervising Scientist to the extent that he is required to do work in the Kakadu National Park as a result of Ranger being there, the same thing could easily apply, whether it be by way of levy or any other discretionary determination, to Coronation Hill. If he is spending $650,000 a year in the conservation zone because the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd is there, we simply say that 75 per cent of $650,000 is $540,000 and that amount is extracted from BHP. A levy is not required. There is nothing magical about an export levy, it is simply a mechanism for attracting funding.
—I will tell them of your suggestion.

—I am seeking to pursue the logic of the Government determination so far. Having said that, it is clear to me that nothing further will be elicited from the Minister. I want to take the Minister back to the question of the levy which has raised in the range of $40m. Under clause 4 the levy is being increased to $1.15, from 23 August. As we have just discussed, that is to accommodate 75 per cent of the costs of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. Staff numbers have increased from six to around 75, and have been around that figure for some little time. Senator Button will not be unmindful of the various criticisms made either in wisdom or in ignorance about the direction of the office's research and the location and the cost of the office in Sydney.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that until 1986-87, the last figure I have, the Office of the Supervising Scientist has cost Australian taxpayers $2,650,000 simply in air fares. I do not have the calculations, but if we look at a total budget of $40m and we add on two more extra years, we see that 8 per cent of the total budget of the Office of the Supervising Scientist is spent on employees presumably by and large flying from Sydney to Darwin or Katherine and back to Sydney, or paying for the air fare of Mr Fry to travel around the world and make himself and all of us all the wiser for his experience. That is a very significant part of the budget. The Minister can see why some concern should be expressed by those of us on this side of the chamber about the level of the levy and the discriminatory way in which it has been imposed, perhaps by necessity. But certainly over $2.5m is a very significant part of a budget.

I wonder whether the Government has looked at those sorts of figures and asked itself whether it is getting value for dollars, or whether all the research that is required is being done or in some way is not being fulfilled because of the requirement for air fares which, as I recall, are the result of the Supervising Scientist insisting that if he took the job he had to stay in Sydney and to hell with everybody else.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not familiar with the details of this matter. However, I am able to supply the honourable senator with some information. The first thing I should say is that the size and operating costs of the Office of the Supervising Scientist are very close to those estimated in 1978 by the then Government as being necessary for the organisation to carry out the research and other statutory functions envisaged by the Ranger inquiry.
—They didn't imagine that there would be only three mines.

—I do not know what it imagined. It was the Ranger inquiry, was it not? The Office of the Supervising Scientist currently has a total permanent staff of 67-43 of them are in Jabiru, two are in Darwin and 22 are in Sydney--
—And temporaries? He had 72.3 staff in 1987-88; he has 73.4 staff in 1988-89 Budget figures.

—That may be right; I do not want to dispute that as I am not in a position to do so. In light of the work being done it is considered more cost effective to locate in Sydney those people who do not need to be in the Northern Territory to carry out their functions. With regard to the 8 per cent cost of air fares for the Office of the Supervising Scientist, clearly that arrangement with some of the staff in Sydney and 43 staff in Jabiru does involve travel, but any operation in the Northern Territory of Commonwealth employees involves travel because of the conditions which obtain to working in the Northern Territory or northern parts of Australia in respect of leave and other arrangements which inevitably make the operation more costly. That is a fact in respect of any operation, including private sector operations, which employ staff in the Territory. So the figure is likely to be higher.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not pursue it any more. I will conclude by saying that I noticed that Senator Button made the point that the advantage of having part of the operation located in Sydney is so that those who do not need to be in Jabiru can be in Sydney. It is not without significance to note that in 1985-86 when there were 65 permanent employees in the Office of the Supervising Scientist travel took up $400,460 out of a budget of $5.535m. The Minister is telling me that people are living in Sydney because there is no need for them to be up in the Northern Territory. There is an enormous amount of travel between Sydney and the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose that the Taxation Laws Amendment (Rates and Rebates) Bill 1989 be debated cognately with the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1989, the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1989 and the Income Tax (Arrangements with the States) Repeal Bill 1989.
—There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating cognately four Bills. One of those Bills which was to be debated this evening has now been deferred because of the tragic events in China. I share the Government's view that it is appropriate to defer that legislation for the time being. The four Bills before us are the Taxation Laws Amendment (Rates and Rebates) Bill 1989, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1989, the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1989 and the Income Tax (Arrangements with the States) Repeal Bill 1989. It is obvious that debating four Bills of this kind cognately in the space of 30 minutes does not leave much time to say a great deal about any of them. I propose to consider them in reverse order, so to speak in ascending order of importance. The Opposition does not oppose the Income Tax (Arrangements with the States) Repeal Bill 1989 but shall move an amendment to the motion that this Bill be now read a second time. In relation to that Bill I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add: ``, but the Senate notes that:
(a) the Treasurer is devoid of any policy on Federal/State financial relations;
(b) the Treasurer has been unable to achieve effective restraint in State expenditure;
(c) the Treasurer remains exposed to the effects of increases in State charges on the CPI; and
(d) the global borrowing limits are a fiction given the extent to which they can be circumvented''.

This Bill is nothing more than a political stunt. I put it to the Manager of Government Business (Senator Robert Ray) in particular that it is a waste of valuable parliamentary time when the Senate's legislative load is already so heavy. The Act, passed in 1978, has become moribund. That is not contested. But to be taking up parliamentary time to repeal it seems to me to be ludicrous. It was enacted in 1978 as a measure designed to provide the States with an opportunity to reduce taxation. It provided for up to 10 per cent of the tax revenue collected by the Commonwealth in each State to be allocated to that State explicitly in the form of grants. If a State did not desire the amount of revenue its residents could receive a tax rebate from that 10 per cent-which the State Government did not receive. In that way it was believed that a discipline would be imposed on State governments to encourage them to manage their financial affairs in a most efficient manner. This proposal was not taken up by the States at the time. The chances of tax reduction that it held out were destroyed by the vehement opposition to it by the then Premier of New South Wales, Mr Neville Wran.

It is regrettable that our Treasurer (Mr Keating) should spend time on playing political games in putting up this piece of legislation rather than getting about his assigned duties and, in particular, rather than formulating an effective Commonwealth-State financial relationship. I conclude my comments on that matter and simply pass on. The Opposition does not oppose the repeal of the legislation.

I now refer to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1989. The Opposition does not oppose this Bill, but again we will be moving an amendment to the motion that the Bill be read a second time. I now foreshadow that amendment:
At the end of motion, add: ``, but the Senate notes:

(a) that this Bill arose fundamentally because of the Government's blatant exercise of attempting to manipulate the Consumer Price Index by lowering the excise tax on beer while introducing a sales tax on normal strength beer;
(b) the Government's failure more generally to reform the ramshackle indirect tax system, which is littered with inconsistencies and anomalies; and

(c) that the Commonwealth Ombudsman has criticised the administration of sales tax, in particular on the grounds that it is unfair to expect taxpayers to operate a self-assessment system in an atmosphere of uncertainty and without an efficient advisory service or a regular and timely monitoring system''.

This Bill simply highlights the anomalies and inconsistencies of that ramshackle indirect tax system to which the second reading amendment I have just foreshadowed refers. The Treasurer has used the present wholesale sales tax system as a classic means of taxation by stealth. In the first nine months of this financial year sales tax revenue was up by over 24 per cent. That is well above the 14.4 per cent increase forecast in the Budget.

It is not an isolated development. Last financial year sales tax collections rose by 19 per cent; that followed rises of 10 per cent in 1986-87 and 15 per cent in 1985-86. In the six years of the life of this present Government, sales tax revenue has gone up by about 150 per cent-roughly three times the rate of inflation in that period. However, this particular Bill was not prompted by an endeavour to reduce the tax burden; it is simply a political stunt.

After attempting in the last Budget to fudge the consumer price index (CPI) figures in the short term by reducing excise tax on beer, the Government ran into another one of its manifold unintended consequences. Carlton and United Breweries Ltd claims to have leased beer bottles from the manufacturers of those bottles, Bottle Co. of Victoria Ltd, since 1903. Following the change in the application of sales tax to beer in the August Budget that company, quite legitimately-as has been admitted by the Government-sought to take advantage of a pre-existing exemption in the sales tax law which the Government in its haste had totally overlooked. In doing so the company was not seeking to increase its own profit. It was seeking to pass on the advantages of that exemption to consumers by selling its beer at a slightly lower price than that of its competitors. I do not think reducing prices is a serious crime.

I want to complete my necessarily attenuated comments on this Bill by drawing to attention to the reference to the Commonwealth Ombudsman in the second reading amendment which I earlier foreshadowed. In recent statements the Ombudsman has listed a number of serious problems with the general administration of the sales tax system. In his report in the Administrative Review No. 50 of April of this year the Ombudsman noted:
The most significant problems are:
uncertainty about key provisions of the sales tax legislation giving rise to confusion both within and outside the Taxation Office, and to disputation;

disadvantage to taxpayers because the requirement to assess for themselves which goods are taxable and at what rate, leading to difficulty in the absence of an efficient inquiry system, in establishing correct liability for particular transactions;

absence of regular monitoring of sales tax returns by the Taxation Office so that taxpayers' errors are not detected in time to prevent significant arrears of sales tax, which continue to accrue until detection;
inconsistent advice and decisions from regional offices which may put some manufacturers at a significant competitive disadvantage; and
difficulties in obtaining refunds of overpaid sales tax.

The Ombudsman expressed the view that it is unfair to expect taxpayers to operate in a self-assessment system, in an atmosphere of uncertainty, and without an efficient advisory service or a regular and timely monitoring system. He said:
It is equally unjust, to penalise them for innocent errors resulting from these deficiencies.

It is true that those highly critical remarks were made as recently as only April 1989. I think, therefore, that it is fair to give the Commissioner of Taxation some time to respond to them, not merely in word but, I trust, in deed. Therefore, I say no more about it other than that the Opposition will certainly be monitoring that response.

I turn now to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1989. The Opposition will not oppose the second reading of this Bill, but I foreshadow major amendments at the committee stage which are designed to address one aspect of the Bill which I can describe only as remarkable. Indeed, it has been the subject of some remark by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. That Committee has drawn attention to the provisions of this Bill which would provide the Commissioner of Taxation, at his unfettered discretion, with the authority to provide information regarding taxpayers, whether individuals or corporations, to designated law enforcement agencies and also to the Comptroller-General of Customs. What is so remarkable-and, as I say, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has drawn attention to this very point-is that this extraordinary provision appears in a Bill, the main purpose of which otherwise is to make a number of wholely technical amendments and to repeal a number of provisions that are no longer operative in tax law.

I will deal briefly with those unexceptionable, if you like, aspects of the Bill. What they are really about is clearing up a few of the unintended consequences of the Government's own ill-considered legislation. For example, the Bill moves to exempt from capital gains tax a taxpayer's residence when it consists of habitation in a retirement village and the like. The fact is that in the past the Government has claimed that such residences were exempt from capital gains tax. However, as the Treasurer now says, just to make sure or, more accurately, to fix up an oversight, the Government is putting forward this particular change.

I turn to the coalition's proposed committee stage amendments about which I propose to say something now because I regard the matter to which they relate as significant. As I said earlier, the amendments relate to the intention in this Bill to amend the taxation secrecy provisions in order to allow the Commissioner of Taxation to disclose, at his discretion, tax information to specified law enforcement agencies, namely, the Australian Federal Police, the State and Northern Territory police forces, the Director of Public Prosecutions, the National Crime Authority, State and Territory corporate affairs commissions and the Australian Customs Service. The coalition is not satisfied either with that framework of proposals or with the safeguards, such as they are, contained in the legislation against the misuse of such powers. We are simply not willing to place in the hands of the Taxation Commissioner further powers to relay confidential taxpayer information to other government bodies without much more powerful checks upon that process than the Bill now contains and, in particular, without changing, so to speak, the point of initiation away from the Commissioner and into the law enforcement agencies.

We are particularly concerned about these provisions in light of the Taxation Office's already apparent failure to comply effectively with the tax file number legislation requirements. I note that earlier this year tens of thousands of letters containing highly confidential tax file numbers were posted to dead people and to the old addresses of people who years ago had moved from their abodes. Even more recently, Opposition members and senators have been made aware of further gross breaches of secrecy provisions with people's tax file information being sent to the wrong people. For example, a case was raised only very recently by the honourable member for Warringah, the Hon. Michael MacKellar, in the House of Representatives.

The Opposition wishes to establish a mechanism which will provide a check on the ability of the Commissioner of Taxation to provide information solely at his discretion to various law enforcement agencies. Effectively, what we shall be proposing at the committee stage are procedures very similar to the procedure which exists for information requests by the National Crime Authority. I repeat: We propose to place the initiative for such a request not in the hands of the Commissioner but in the hands of the law enforcement agencies. Where an authorised law enforcement agency officer considers that the Taxation Commissioner may have information that is relevant to the particular inquiry or may have acquired information which is relevant to establishing whether a serious offence has been committed or is being committed, the officer, we propose, may apply to a judge of the Federal Court of Australia for access to that information. That application would be required to be in writing and would need to set out particulars of the information requested. In turn, the Federal Court judge may-I repeat, may-order the Commissioner to disclose the requested information to the law enforcement agency and make further orders prohibiting that agency from communicating that information to unauthorised persons.

I repeat: This is not the Government's proposal; these are the amendments which the Opposition shall, in due course, move in the committee stage to that proposal. We will provide for the Taxation Commissioner to be given the opportunity to bring to the notice of the judge any matter that the Commissioner considers should have been regarded in considering the application. The judge would need to be satisfied that that information was relevant to the investigation. We propose similar conditions to those which we are proposing in the case of the law enforcement agencies to apply to the Comptroller-General of Customs in terms of a request for information which he and his officers may also make in like case.

Finally, we propose that the Privacy Commissioner should monitor the provision of any such requested information and shall report to the Minister if the Privacy Commissioner thinks that the provision of that information is an invasion of privacy. I will have a good deal more to say about those matters when we come to the committee stage.

I conclude my remarks on that legislation by saying that I regard it as astonishing that the Government should bring forward a proposal of that kind tucked away in an otherwise nugatory and inoffensive technical, unassuming Bill, particularly so in light of recent events and the hullabaloo last year in relation to the tax file number and subsequently this year in relation to the administration of that legislation, even as finally enacted.

I come now to the final Bill before the Senate in the series of Bills being debated cognately this evening, that is, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Rates and Rebates) Bill 1989. The Opposition will not oppose this Bill, but I foreshadow the following amendment to the motion that the Bill be read a second time:
At the end of motion, add: ``, but the Senate notes that:
(a) even after the July 1989 tax cuts, the Hawke/Keating Government will remain the highest taxing Government in the post-war history of Australia;
(b) the long overdue tax cuts will substantially be eaten up by the consequences of the Government's high inflation and high interest rate policies; and

(c) it is vital that economic measures be implemented to lower inflation and interest rates if Australia is to see a sustainable reduction in the tax burden and in the enormous net foreign debt of $103 billion''.

This Bill, of course, delivers the personal income tax reductions and other changes which were announced in the 12 April economic statement by the Treasurer. However, the fact is that, as noted in that foreshadowed second reading amendment, even after the tax cuts are delivered on 1 July, this Government will still remain the highest taxing government in our postwar history. The truth is that the tax cuts to be granted at that time will return only part of the taxes that have been ripped off Australian taxpayers over recent years through the insidious processes of bracket creep. According to the very professional economic consultancy firm, Access Economics Pty Ltd, by the end of next year this Government will have plundered around $10 billion from taxpayers through bracket creep since 1985-86-basically, since the tax summit. The tax cuts being given at the beginning of next month are worth only around half of that amount.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the sales tax increase?

—As my colleague Senator Walters reminds the Senate, this says nothing as to the plundering through the sales tax mechanism to which I referred before Senator Walters came into the chamber. The new tax scales announced by the Government offer very little incentive to work harder for anybody earning over the second highest tax threshold of $20,600, which is, of course, about 20 per cent below average weekly earnings. The top rate of tax, 48.25 per cent-that is, 47 per cent plus the 1 1/4 per cent Medicare levy-cuts in at an income of still only $35,000, which is now considerably less than one and a half times average weekly earnings. Thirty years ago, the top rate-which admittedly was then somewhat higher, in the area of 66 per cent-did not become effective until one earned 18 times the average weekly earnings. As bracket creep continues to take its toll, almost two-thirds of Australian taxpayers will be facing the top two marginal tax rates within two years.

SPEECH.PARA: The simple fact is that the Government cannot give sustainable tax cuts without cutting inflation, including wage and salary inflation. The Government cannot cut that inflation because it has abrogated economic leadership for the past two years almost, since the last election, in favour of cheap electoral stunts. One indication of this is the Treasurer's economic statement of 12 April last. It contained barely two sentences-one each-on Australia's two major problems of high foreign debt and high inflation. We all know what has happened since that statement was brought down not quite two months ago. We had figures only a short time ago showing that our foreign debt has increased even further from the figures which the Treasurer was no doubt basing his remarks on at that time, and at the end of March we had net foreign debts of $103 billion.

The Prime Minister has mounted some sort of personal campaign in the media designed to con Australians into the view that somehow that does not matter because, as he says, 61 per cent of these debts are liabilities of private corporations and they are not, therefore, the Government's responsibility. That, of course, is hogwash. Of course they are the Government's responsibility, because it is the policies of the Government which have produced the deficits month by month on the external balance of payments on the current account of this country, which can only be paid for, only be financed on the capital account, either through borrowings or through selling off bits of Australia. Of course, the Government has been presiding over policies which have resulted in both of those things being done at a very fast clip. Not only have we now totted up $103 billion of foreign debt, but at 30 June last, which is the latest date for which we have figures in this area, we also had totted up net foreign other liabilities, in the sense of ownership of land, companies, corporate equities and assets other than debt instruments, of $30 billion. At that time our total net foreign liability position in this country was $121.2 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is `we'?
—Under the policies of this Government, the Government which Senator Maguire is happy to speak up for.
—You mean John Elliott and Rupert Murdoch, do you?

—It is no good either the Prime Minister or Senator Maguire, in his lame brained fashion, going on about people such as Mr John Elliott, Mr Alan Bond or other people like that borrowing overseas-all the scapegoats which this Government would love to lay the responsibility on for the results of its policies. The fact is that if it had not been for the policies of this Government, we would not have the deficits which have had to be borrowed. If Mr Elliott, Mr Bond or somebody else had not borrowed them, governments would have had to borrow them. Somebody would have had to borrow them, as Senator Maguire well knows. It is totally disingenuous, to use a parliamentary expression, for the Prime Minister or Senator Maguire to attempt to persuade the people of this country that it is not the Government's fault.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the matter of high inflation. As we all remember very clearly, the Treasurer, in last August's Budget, told us that by this time inflation would have dropped to no more than 4.5 per cent. He even went so far as to forecast beyond that: that in the financial year on which we are about to embark, it would drop further to between 3 per cent and 4 per cent. What have we got? Even on the new fudged figures we have got a consumer price index running at 6.9 per cent in the 12 months to the March quarter, and almost certainly rising even further in the current quarter. So we will finish the year with an inflation rate of probably over 7 per cent compared to the Treasurer's 4 1/2 per cent. The Commonwealth Treasury, working for this Government, as is its duty, in figures prepared for the recent Premiers Conference and Loan Council meetings in Canberra a few weeks ago, in putting forward information to indicate to the States the amounts of the financial assistance grants which would be likely to be paid to them next financial year, made the point-it had to, because it had to provide these forecasts for that purpose-that in the 12 months to the March quarter of next year inflation would run at 6.9 per cent. So the Government's own agencies are currently forecasting that inflation will continue to run at its present extravagant levels. Because of these two major problems of high foreign debt and high inflation, the Government simply cannot give tax cuts that are sustainable.

The tax cuts which will be given, or which the Government is purporting will be given in a few weeks time, on 1 July, will be eaten up, as our second reading amendment says, by the consequences of the Government's high inflation and high interest rate policies. In the last 12 months alone housing loan mortgage rates have risen by 3 1/2 percentage points, which in itself goes a very long way to eating up the consequences of a tax cut which is broadly estimated to be $20 a week after tax for the average weekly wage earner. In addition, the inflation rate is bowling along merrily at 7 1/2 per cent, and the wage and salary package which has been negotiated between the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions will increase wages and salaries, according to the Government's estimates, by 6 1/2 per cent, although most independent commentators expect the increase to run at 7 1/2 to 8 per cent. Judging by the recent rate of wage drift I would say that even that may turn out to be an underestimate. This will speed up even further the process of bracket creep to which I have referred. The Bill which purports to represent the final fruits, which is meant to bring home the bacon, as the Treasurer promised his Party and ministerial colleagues at the time of the Budget last year, will bring home the usual litany of fraud, deceit and failure of which the Government can now be totally convicted. I move:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate notes that:
(a) even after the July 1989 tax cuts, the Hawke/Keating Government will remain the highest taxing Government in the post-war history of Australia;
(b) the long overdue tax cuts will substantially be eaten up by the consequences of the Government's high inflation and high interest rate policies; and

(c) it is vital that economic measures be implemented to lower inflation and interest rates if Australia is to see a sustainable reduction in the tax burden and in the enormous net foreign debt of $103 billion''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating a range of taxation measures which have been introduced by the Hawke Government. The most important is the Taxation Laws Amendment (Rates and Rebates) Bill 1989 which is the legislation giving effect to the April economic statement tax cuts which will come into effect on 1 July. I support the package. The legislation gives effect to the cuts in personal income tax announced in the April economic statement. The measures will not only provide substantial benefits to millions of Australians but also be crucial to the future growth of the Australian economy.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the Liberals the only real growth industry in the Australian economy was the tax avoidance industry. Labor has not only confronted the tax avoidance industry but also brought record growth to Australia. Our aim has been to reform taxation for all Australians-not to just pander to sectional interests as the Liberals did. Labor is united in purpose, strategy and resolve to cut income taxes for lower income earners in this country. In government, the Liberals showed that they were ideologically, politically and economically incapable of cutting taxes for all Australians. The wages-tax trade-off to which this legislation gives effect is a central element of the Government's strategy to drive Australia's inflation rate down.

We have just heard the greatest exercise in hypocrisy from Senator Stone, the former head of the Australian Department of the Treasury. The chief architect, if you like, in the Public Service of the Liberals' economic policies in the late 1970s and early 1980s lectured us at length this evening about so-called runaway inflation in the Australian economy. The facts are that when Mr Stone, in his previous incarnation, was at the Treasury and in charge of the economic levers in Australia we had double digit inflation. Up to the March quarter of 1983 prices were running at an annual rate of 11 1/2 per cent. Of course we know what happened in March 1983: the Liberal Government of which Senator Stone was the chief economic adviser was swept out of office; it was hurled from power by the Australian people because they said, `No more double digit inflation; no more double digit unemployment'-and that was the Liberal Government's record.

The legislation before us provides increases in household disposable income of around 12 per cent per annum. Effectively, that will be at half the cost to employers and the inflation rate. As a result of the wages-tax trade-off, we estimate that this year gross wages will grow by only around 6 1/2 per cent. That is a very rare occurrence in a buoyant economy. In an economy characterised by strong and rapid economic growth, as is the case at the moment, it is the most usual practice to have rapid wage growth, not wages constrained to the 6 1/2 per cent growth that we face this year. That sort of outcome is in stark contrast to that achieved by conservative policies and philosophies; it is in contrast to the Liberal and National parties' wages outcomes when they were in government. The legislation before us tonight is in marked contrast with the coalition's tax record. Tonight Senator Stone tried to lecture us and said that the Government is a high tax government. The fact is that when the Liberals were in power in 1982 and 1983, the lowest tax bracket in the Australian income tax schedule was 30c in the dollar. That is the reality. As a result of the proposed tax cuts in the legislation we are debating this evening, the bottom tax rate will be cut not to 25c in the dollar, but to 21c in the dollar, a stark comparison with the record of the Liberals and Nationals in government.

The income tax cuts have been funded from this Government's Budget surplus. We are now covering our expenditures by revenues. We have a Budget surplus. That has resulted from stringent fiscal restraint and it has been funded, importantly, by Labor's crackdown on the tax cheats in the Australian community. A lot of the revenue has come from hurtling against the wall the tax avoidance industry in the Australian economy. Our policies are in stark contrast to the Liberals' tax changes of 1982, tax changes which were made on top of the wages explosion when wages grew at 15 per cent and 20 per cent per annum. That wages explosion heralded the worst recession in 50 years in the Australian economy. Labor's tax cuts are the outcome of the unprecedented tax reform undertaken by the Government.

Instead of reform, the Liberals in government let tax avoidance and tax evasion become a national scandal and a disgrace. Under the Liberals, income tax was voluntary for the rich in Australia. Instead of supporting Labor's reforms, they have opposed almost every measure against tax avoidance and tax evasion. I simply refer to the fringe benefits tax which was fought tooth and nail by Opposition senators and to the free lunch crackdown by this Government. The Government stopped the practice of the pin-striped brigade at the big end of town going out and having expensive lunches and charging them to the taxpayer. Working class families could not charge lunches in expensive restaurants against their tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the kid's ice-cream?

—I am pleased that Senator Boswell came into the chamber this evening because I well remember him at the end of 1985 when we were cracking down on the free lunch, when we were consigning it to the garbage bin of history, telling us that the restaurant industry would collapse. That is what he said. He is in the Hansard record time and time again claiming that the restaurant industry would collapse. When we distil that argument to its basics, we see that Senator Boswell and his ilk were really saying that Australians were going to stop eating. That is what it really came down to. Now he is again mouthing off about this Government's tax cuts.

SPEECH.PARA: We also introduced the capital gains tax which is significantly protecting our income tax base against tax avoidance. The introduction of that very important tax indicated that at last Australia's national tax system had arrived in the twentieth century. At last we had come into line with the major countries in the world in having a tax on unearned income through capital gains. Our revenues come from the fringe benefits tax, the free lunch crackdown and the capital gains tax. Opposition members knew when they were in government that the ordinary taxpayers in Australia were bearing the burden of tax avoidance schemes designed by and accessible to only the rich, yet they failed to stop it. We had Liberal Party rhetoric about tax cuts. That contrasts with their broken election promises and their increased taxes. I well recall the fistful of dollars advertisements in the 1977 election and the dollars that were taken back within months of that election early in 1978 by Mr Howard when he was the Treasurer of this country. The Liberals' record in government gives them no credibility at all on taxation.

Tonight Senator Stone, the former head of the Treasury, the former chief public servant in charge of economic policy in this country, tried to lecture members of the Government for being part of some sort of high tax government. I simply refer Senator Stone to the 1968 Budget Papers, which show very clearly that during the life of the Liberal-National Party Government in the 1970s and early 1980s in this country, the share of taxation in our national income, the share of taxation in our gross domestic product, did not fall but rose. Taxation rose faster than Australia's national income, when the Liberal and National parties were in power, by a whopping 1.7 per cent.

Senator Stone should not lecture this Government about how we are a high taxing government and claim that taxes have risen under a Labor government when clearly the record shows that, despite the rhetoric of the Liberals in 1975 and 1977 when they went to the polls saying that they would cut taxes in this country, the share of our national income taken by taxation rose under them. It is against that record that the Labor Government's tax cuts, to take effect from 1 July, are welcomed by Australians. The tax cuts are not piecemeal measures; they are substantial cuts with substantial benefits for the Australian economy. They are central to the accord, the wages-tax trade-off that this Government has developed to keep down the pressures on costs and to ensure that our international competitiveness is enhanced in the world community. The Australian community is well aware of the advantages of these tax cuts. For example, an advertisement from a leading Australian retail chain, K Mart, which is part of Coles-Myer group, advertises: `Tax cuts all round. K Mart makes the good news better'. It is encouraging people to get in and get the bargains, because that store is well aware of the importance of the disposable income of many Australian families. This particularly large retail organisation understands that the tax cuts are real, significant and large. I quote from the Australian Institute of Family Studies, as follows:
Overall the Government's tax package redresses substantially all of the deficiencies in the tax-transfer system affecting families and single individuals (since 1976).

I was stunned and shocked tonight by the utter hypocrisy of Senator Stone in lecturing this Government about so-called bracket creep or fiscal drag, that is, the movement of taxpayers into higher tax brackets as a result of inflationary pressures. The reality is that a Liberal government introduced tax indexation as a means of overcoming bracket creep and fiscal drag, and then scrapped it. Senator Stone was the Government's chief economic adviser at the Treasury for the whole period that the Liberal and National parties were in government, when they played around with tax indexation as a means of overcoming fiscal drag and then threw it out of the window.

Let us look at the record. In 1976 the Liberal Party said, `We have to bring in tax indexation to keep governments honest'. That is on the public record. The Liberal Government introduced the indexation of tax brackets in 1976 to overcome the so-called bracket creep in the Australian tax system. There was indexation of tax brackets in the 1976-77 and 1977-78 financial years. But that was the end of it. The Liberal Government then halved the indexation factor-it adjusted for only half the inflation rate for the 1978-79 financial year-and then suspended it totally. That Government threw indexation out of the window in 1979-80. Tonight we have heard Senator Stone telling this Government that it is somehow syphoning off revenue from the Australian taxpayers through fiscal drag and bracket creep, when the reality is that, despite a Liberal government being elected on the promise of keeping governments honest in Australia, it threw out this measure in 1979-80. The Liberal Government experimented with it again in the financial years 1980-81 and 1981-82. Even then, it was adjusted for only half the increase in the inflation rate in the Australian community. Then it was thrown out of the window again, finally, in 1981-82. That is the record of the Liberal Party on bracket creep.

I might add that, when using the data I have used this evening, I have quoted extensively from Mr Andrew Peacock, MHR. When he went onto the back bench in the early 1980s he documented the Fraser Government's move away from both tax index- ation and its commitment to adjust tax brackets for inflation. Let us not have any more lectures from Senator Stone and the like because the Liberal policy on tax indexation in practice is just like its policies on economic management when it was in government-stop-go, stop-go and grind the economy into the ground. The reality is that the Liberals have done as much for tax indexation in Australia as King Herod did for baby-sitting. That is what they did in office. Let us have no more Liberal nonsense on tax indexation. The Liberals promised it and they threw it out the window.
In this connection I would like to quote again from the comments of the Institute of Family Studies on the tax package. In its April statement this year the Institute said:
Nearly all income groups will pay less tax under the new scale than they would have paid if the 1983-84 tax scale had been fully indexed.

So the Institute of Family Studies is saying that, for nearly all income groups, the Hawke Labor Government has effectively given tax cuts which are larger than would have been given had the tax scales in Australia been fully indexed for inflation from the time that Government came to office. Let us have no more nonsense from those opposite about bracket creep and fiscal drag. Clearly, they are uninformed on the subject. Clearly, they are hypocritical in coming in here and trying to tell us about how we should run the tax scales in this country. I am pleased to say that the tax cuts announced in the April statement focus on low to middle income earners. They bring substantial increases in the take-home pay of ordinary Australians. The tax package concentrates on criteria such as fairness and equity and social justice. Recently, while campaigning in the Mount Gambier area of South Australia, I addressed the workers at two large timber mills-the Woods and Forests mill and the Softwood Holdings Ltd mill, both of which have thousands of employees--

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't tell Richardson or he will close it down.

—It is based on pinus radiata which has been planted by men and women. We harvest the native trees in South Australia for timber production. So, clearly, a man-made resource is being harvested. I point out that the response of the workers in those two mills to the tax cuts was overwhelmingly good. They were very positive towards the increases in their disposable incomes through income tax cuts and, in particular, to increases in the family allowance and the family allowance supplement. Last Friday I also had the same feedback when I was campaigning in Adelaide with Mr Bob Catley, the Federal candidate for Adelaide. We went to the Tubemakers Ltd plant in Adelaide-a very large industrial enterprise-and we had an enormously positive response to the income tax cuts. The Liberals try to belittle these tax cuts. They try to claim-as Senator Stone has tried to do-that somehow they will be eaten up by interest rate rises. But they know that people out in the electorates have been looking for reductions in personal income tax and increases in the family allowances.

SPEECH.PARA: The impact on individual households is significant indeed. For example, a single income family with a dependent spouse and two dependent children and on $290 a week gross or $15,000 a year, in effect, will get a $24 a week wage rise as a result of the increase in the family allowance and the reductions in personal income tax. A single income family on $20,000 a year will get a large percentage reduction in its tax burden. In fact, the number of dollars it will pay in tax in the next financial year compared with this financial year will be reduced by a massive 17 per cent. In dollar terms, that family's tax burden will be reduced by more than one-sixth and it will get the biggest reduction in average tax rates-its average rate of income tax will fall by 3.4 percentage points.

I think the most important part of this package is that, from 1 July onwards, many thousands of Australian families will no longer face personal income tax. From 1 July the net tax for many Australian families will be zero. The reason for that is that family assistance payments, through both the family allowance supplement, for single income families with gross incomes up to about $20,000 a year will exceed their total tax liabilities. One of the great achievements of this Hawke Government will be to free many lower and middle income families totally from the burden of income tax. They will be getting back more in family payments than they will be paying out in tax. For example, a single income family with two teenage children on a gross income of $20,000 a year will pay a total in tax next financial year, after allowing for the increase in the dependent spouse rebate, of $2,117. Their family assistance-that is, the family allowance and the family allowance supplement-will total $2,594. So they will be getting back from the Federal Government through family assistance $477 more than they will be paying in personal income tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quote someone more appropriate to average weekly earnings.

—Senator Tambling has to get out into the community and have a look at the concept of average weekly earnings, because it does not really apply in my State of South Australia. For example, many of the employees at the timber mills in the Mount Gambier district are still earning a gross wage of less than $300 a week. Many of the people at the mill I visited in Adelaide last week are earning more like $400 a week. We have to get back to reality and focus our thoughts and considerations on those people who are earning those sorts of incomes in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Conceptually, we now have in Australia a negative income tax. We have now moved under this Hawke Labor Government to a negative income tax for many tens of thousands of families. Over the 1960s and 1970s in the United States, Canada, Western Europe and Great Britain, the concept of a negative income tax was talked about as a way of alleviating poverty by focusing government resources more on the neediest people in the community. Instead of their paying tax to the government, it was to pay to them. Single income families in this country on incomes up to about $20,000 gross next financial year will be receiving more from the Australian Government, the Hawke Labor Government, in family assistance payments through the family allowance and the family allowance supplement than they will be paying in personal income tax. That is a terrific step forward. As I have pointed out, the average effective tax rate, allowing for family assistance increases, will be zero or negative for many low income families.

I have pointed out that family allowance increases form part of this package. There seems to be a misconception in the community that it is only the family allowance supplement that is being increased as part of this package, but essentially every family that has been receiving the family allowance payment this financial year will get an increase in the family allowance next financial year. That is a very important point that we in the Government must communicate immediately and directly to the Australian community. The family payments in the package are central to Labor's concept of improving the social wage. That is a broad measure of the welfare of Australian households. It is not a monetary wage concept, which, of course, is the focus of the Liberal and National parties concerning the treatment of families. They talk about cash wages and cash incomes, but they do not look at the range of services that governments provide in the health, education, welfare and housing areas, which all add to family welfare and standards of living. This tax package is moving down the road towards a broader concept of the social wage by focusing even more resources on lower income families with children. Under the Liberals and the Nationals, the concept of the social wage was non-existent. All increases in income, if any, came through wage rises. At the end of the coalition government we saw the massive wages explosion of 1981 with money wages growing by 15 to 20 per cent per annum and double digit inflation.

Despite the lecture here tonight from Senator Stone about the evils of inflation and his claim that Labor has failed to deliver on inflation, the reality is that when he was over the road down in the Treasury Building at the beginning of 1983, inflation under the Liberal-National Party Government was at double digit levels. It was 11 1/2 per cent per annum. He has the cheek to come in here tonight and lecture us on inflation, telling us that somehow we are not meeting our targets on inflation. The reality is that we do not have 11 per cent inflation or even 10 per cent inflation at present; we have got the rate of increase in prices as measured by the consumer price index down to below 7 per cent.

It is fascinating to look at the international comparisons that the Liberals and the Nationals make about inflation. Up until about three months ago every time they talked about price rises in the Australian community they compared us with Margaret Thatcher's England. They talked about how our inflation rate was higher than that in the United Kingdom. It is fascinating how, all of a sudden, comparisons about inflation by Liberal and National spokespersons have forgotten to focus on the United Kingdom. I checked the international papers and found the reason why. Mrs Thatcher, that messiah who the Liberals trek to London to meet and ask how she has governed her country for 10 years, that competent economic manager, they believe, has now got inflation running at over 8 per cent. In Australia it is less than 7 per cent. Is it not incredible? Interest rates are on the way up in Britain and there is a record balance of payments deficit. This is the person Opposition members trek to London to see, to grovel at her feet and say, `Mrs Thatcher, how do you run your wonderful economy? It is terrible in Australia'. When they come back they forget about it and forget to make a comparison, because in Australia we do not have double digit inflation or even 8 per cent inflation, as they have in Britain; we have an inflation rate of less than 7 per cent under this Hawke Labor Government.

That is the record under this Government. As a result of our economic and tax policies, we have got away from double digit unemployment and double digit inflation, which was a horrific legacy of the Liberals at the beginning of the 1980s. The coalition Government's record on taxation was one of farce, fiasco and failure. A decade ago the Liberals claimed they would cut taxes. They have failed. Today this Labor Government is delivering real tax cuts for the Australian people. In reforming taxation Labor has shown real energy, initiative and enterprise. The beneficiaries will be the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I came into the chamber tonight to address one Bill only, the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1989, and to foreshadow an amendment to that Bill which will call for the abolition of the 20 per cent tax on recycled paper. But having listened to Senator Maguire, I cannot help but comment more broadly than that. What he was talking about seems to indicate yet again the poverty of both the Government's economic policies and those of the Opposition. Both indicate a clear subjugation of social and political policy to economic ends rather than the other way around.

SPEECH.PARA: I was interested to hear what Senator Maguire said in the latter moments of his address when he was talking about the social wage and negative income tax. We have a very large number of people in Australia at present on various forms of benefits-pensions, family supports and supplemented family supports. All those things are subject to means tests, and a means test necessarily involves an enormous bureaucracy to supervise it-to snoop on single mums and see whether they do not have a de facto lover who might be living with them, et cetera. I wonder why the Government does not understand the good sense of going all the way and creating a national support income so that everybody will get an income from the Government. Money that one earned beyond that income which one got from the government would simply be income on top and one would pay tax on the total amount. If one were very wealthy most of that national support income would go back to the Government by way of tax. At one stroke it removes all of the problems of means tests. It removes all the costs of bureaucracy and also would elevate the standing of those people who, in their own eyes, are now dealt with as second class citizens. For instance this includes pensioners who must travel on public transport between 10 o'clock in the morning and 3 o'clock in the afternoon to get reduced fares and who must line up in public hospitals for benefits that only those with a particular pension card are entitled to get.

The development of a national support income which was paid to everybody irrespective of means test would at one stroke remove many of the anomalies to which Senator Maguire was referring and with which he was attempting to make a totally artificial distinction between policies of the Government and the Opposition. The facts of the matter are that inequity in Australia has increased during the time of the Hawke Government as it has in Great Britain under Margaret Thatcher. There is much greater difference now between the income and the wealth of the wealthy in both countries and the increasing number of poor and disadvantaged.

What one clearly needs to do is to develop a radically different approach to wages, to prices and to tax. As I indicated in a speech the other day, if one removes from centre stage the economic consideration, puts people centre stage and then works an economic policy to serve the interests of the people, one would come up with a totally different pattern. That not only would include something like a national support income but also would mean attempting to take the tax out of wages altogether and shift that tax onto non-renewable resources. That bears very much on the amendment to which I will refer in a moment, namely, the removal of the 20 per cent tax on recycled paper. There are clear indications that the way in which we have levied a large part of the tax burden on wages in a situation involving those who can demand increased wages, simply moves to increase the demand for wages. The higher price for labour leads to attempts to reduce the number of people employed and shifts investment away from labour into capital investment. It therefore increases the demand on resources. The move should go the other way. We should be putting the tax onto material consumption, lowering wages and lowering the tax on wages.

One of the other things to which I have referred on several previous occasions is the establishment of a national capital account to put alongside the gross domestic product. This, of course, bears directly on the use of trees for the manufacture of paper. We do not put any value on trees in situ. It appears to be cheaper to take new trees out of the forest and turn them into paper than it is to collect paper which has already been used and recycle it. If we introduce a differential tax on paper which is manufactured de novo and paper which comes from pulp that has already been used, we are in a sense getting to a situation which recognises the value of the forests in situ.

It is a rather indirect way of doing it, but it works in much the same direction. There are substantially good reasons for doing this. I point to the 1.6 times 10 to the fifteenth grams of carbon that go into the atmosphere each year from the cutting down of forests, principally the tropical rainforest, but not inconsiderably forests elsewhere that are chopped down to manufacture paper, the further consumption of resources which go into the paper mills by way of the energy demands of those paper mills, the pollution of water supplies in the manufacture of paper and the pollution of lakes, rivers and oceans in the effluent stream. All these things are ultimately a further cost to the community.

As I understand it at present Australia does not recycle any paper back into paper. The 30 per cent of paper which is recycled goes into cardboard. It is essentially a one-trip recycling because at the next stage it is merely burned. If we are to place less burden on the forests and on the atmosphere and less pollutional burden on water supplies in effluent discharges, then it is clearly desirable to achieve a much higher level of recycling. That could be achieved by removing this tax burden on paper manufactured from recycled pulp. At the moment I understand that if one wants to use recycled paper in Australia, one has to import that paper from overseas. The removal of the 20 per cent sales tax on recycled paper would in the short run advantage, relative to Australia, those manufacturers overseas who are already manufacturing that paper.

As Senator Richardson has pointed out, he is in favour of the Australian Federal Government using recycled paper and I understand that he is moving in that direction. I also understand from his press releases that he is attempting to encourage other governments in Australia to move to the use of recycled paper for many purposes because the manufacturers in Australia indicated that the amount of paper coming through the Federal Parliament and through Federal Government departments would not be sufficient to maintain a viable recycling industry. But if one adds other governments in other States, and if one can encourage private industry also to use recycled paper, then the volumes become large enough to establish a viable industry.

If we have a society which is predicated on economic signals and economic indicators-decisions are largely predicated on economic considerations-it is absolutely appropriate to use the price signal to move this industry in this direction. Back in 1967, in a very important essay called The Tragedy of the Commons, I think it was Garrett Hardin who pointed out that if one wanted to move a society in a certain direction, one could not rely on so-called education and conscience to get the job done because unless the economic indicators were changed those people who developed a conscience with respect to a particular activity would simply put themselves at a disadvantage. Of course, that is exactly the situation that we are in at present-those who choose to use recycled paper pay a slightly higher cost for doing so. The removal of the sales tax from paper made from recycled pulp would get the price signals working in exactly the same direction as conscience. Those who had a conscience would get an advantage from using that recycled paper.

Senator Walsh has just come into the chamber. If this amendment is successful, and if the prediction I make is correct-that is, that this measure would encourage a much larger percentage of Australia's pulp to be used three or possibly four times before being turned into cardboard and discarded-the contribution which the forest industries would make to gross domestic product would fall. The industries would say that that was a bad thing. But even if their contribution to gross domestic product were to fall, the country as a whole may well be much better off. I make the point, as I have done in the past, that the size of the gross domestic product is not necessarily an indication of the social benefit which a country derives from the throughput of its resources. So I foreshadow an amendment I will move in the committee stage to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1989, namely, to exempt paper made from recycled pulp from sales tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will move an amendment in relation to the second reading of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1989 and has moved an amendment to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Rates and Rebates) Bill 1989. Paragraphs (a) and (b) of our amendment to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill state:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) that this Bill arose fundamentally because of the Government's blatant exercise of attempting to manipulate the Consumer Price Index by lowering the excise tax on beer while introducing a sales tax on normal strength beer;
(b) the Government's failure more generally to reform the ramshackle indirect tax system, which is littered with inconsistencies and anomalies;

The phrase `inconsistencies and anomalies' is an example of the marvellous words the Treasurer (Mr Keating) continually uses. They are seen continually in tax measures. One finds under that sort of heading the sneaky introduction of a wide range of consumer taxes by a government which swore, with the same sort of integrity it has shown in regard to every other promise it has broken, not to move in the direction of consumer taxes which it claimed were disgraceful when it was alleged that the Opposition was pursuing that course. Under the heading `inconsistencies and anomalies' this Government has introduced a sales tax on orange juice, flavoured milk, ice-cream and a whole range of consumer items-in other words, a consumption tax on items used particularly by the families and children of this nation. Whenever I see the words `inconsistencies and anomalies' I reach for my cast iron knickers. It is the classic way this Government hits the ordinary families of Australia. Our amendment in relation to the second reading of the Taxation Laws Amendment (Rates and Rebates) Bill notes that:
(a) even after the July 1989 tax cuts, the Hawke/Keating Government will remain the highest taxing Government in the post-war history of Australia;
(b) the long overdue tax cuts will substantially be eaten up by the consequences of the Government's high inflation and high interest rate policies; and

(c) it is vital that economic measures be implemented to lower inflation and interest rates if Australia is to see a sustainable reduction in the tax burden and in the enormous net foreign debt of $103 billion'.

Those amendments basically sum up the disaster that this nation is now facing under the economic mismanagement of Mr Keating. It is extraordinary, for example, that the Prime Minister and Mr Keating are going around pretending that, because the foreign debt is not owed by the Government itself-that 60 per cent of it is owed by the private sector-therefore somehow the Government is not responsible. Actually, the appropriate word is `irresponsible'. The Government is irresponsible to claim that it has no responsibility for the size of that foreign debt. Clearly, if this Government's economic policies meant that Australia could pay its way in the world we would not have to beg $1.5 billion worth of cash each month to settle our overseas bills in the way we have to at the moment. It was a vital part of the last Budget that that monthly bill would be reduced to something like $750m a month instead of the $1.4 billion that we have been running at.

The Government's forecast for the current account deficit was about $9.5 billion, whereas it now looks like being $15 billion. The reason for this is simple: this Government's economic management has been absolutely hopeless. It has depended almost entirely on monetary policy. There is no doubt that monetary policy simply has not worked. It is not good enough to rely on interest rates to regulate this economy. One of the disastrous consequences of this Government's reliance on interest rates, and how they do not work in controlling the economy, can be seen by looking at the housing sector. I do not want to go into this area too much tonight because I hope to have an opportunity to discuss it on another occasion.

The simple reality is that the banks and the building societies have not felt capable, in a competitive environment, of passing on to Australians the real cash flow impact of higher interest rates. That means that the banks have chosen to extend people's mortgage loans for many years-in fact, for some people to infinity. This means they will never pay off their homes. That decision has been taken by the banks so that Australians will not suffer a massive withdrawal of money from their pockets as a result of huge interest rates-but their debt will become greater. In other words, they are not suffering the pain now but they will suffer it in the future. The reality is that sooner or later that pain will be suffered for a variety of reasons. One of the reasons is that the Government wants people to suffer. It is vital for the Government's economic policy for the people to suffer.

The banks and building societies have softened the blow on Australians with these huge interest rate rises by not increasing the amount that most Australians have to pay each month on their mortgage. This has had one extraordinary consequence. It has reduced the effectiveness of the Government's monetary policy. One of the reasons the Government's monetary policy has failed is that it has not had an enormous impact on consumption. In the area of housing, one of the major debts Australians face, there has been no increase relative to the size of the increase in interest rates and no increase in the size of the money being drawn out of circulation to reduce the level of consumption capacity that people have.

The consequences of that are very simple: if the Government increases interest rates but the amount of money that people pay each month is not increased, then monetary policy is not working. If the Government's strategy is to reduce demand by increasing interest rates, then clearly that objective is being frustrated if the banks do not charge people more per month. That is exactly what has happened. That is one of the reasons why these high interest rates, and rising interest rates, simply have not held down demand in the way this Government wanted. That is why these huge interest rates have not stopped the big rises in imports that the Government wanted to stop. This demonstrates the Government's total failure to understand what really happens in a free market economy. It, its economic planners and its apparatchiks are only competent, apparently, in an area where there is control. But those controls have all gone. There is now a free market and, as a result, the Government's reliance on monetary policy has been shown to be a cruel fraud because it does not work. The Government has to screw that policy tighter and tighter to have the same sort of impact that it had hoped to achieve with much lower interest rates. Of course, those more modest interest rate rises were reflected immediately in higher mortgage repayments.

One thing that the Government can be cheerful about is that every time it puts up interest rates-and so far this financial year they have gone up from 13 1/2 per cent to 17 per cent-it gets a higher tax revenue which effectively is paid for by the home seekers of Australia. They are helping to supply Mr Keating's tax revenue. At a later opportunity, I hope to go into that matter in some detail. Let us recognise that one of the greatest beneficiaries of the Government's high interest rate policy is the Government's tax revenue. People should not forget that.

On the question of revenue, it is relevant to look closely at the April 1989 statement of Commonwealth Government financial transactions, which was released only last week. That statement shows, for example, that in the area of outlays, the public debt interest burden on the Government, which one would have thought would have gone up in view of higher interest rates, has, in fact, declined. That is due to the lower than expected volume of notes issued which has been partly offset by the impact of higher yields. Also, as the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) tried to interject, the Government is making fewer claims through the public sector borrowing requirement. But the fact is that public debt interest rates have not gone up.
