It is quite clear at the moment that this Government's policy of higher interest rates brings it a net benefit rather than a net loss, and that net benefit is largely being met by the mortgage payers of Australia. In other words, the last people one would think this Government would want to punish are on the top of the list. This Government seeks to punish them by concentrating its policies on high interest rates and doing nothing else.

Some other interesting matters arise out of this statement of Commonwealth Government financial transactions. The statement reveals that the outlays for the year as a whole are expected to be close to the original Budget estimate even though by April they were running a little behind. It is interesting to note that while there were shortfalls in some areas, these are being offset by higher than estimated outlays in other areas, particularly in defence where running costs and outlays on defence industries have been higher than estimated. Assistance to other governments, which is linked to the consumer price index (CPI), has increased more than expected. Assistance for natural disasters has also increased.

Let us concentrate briefly on the question of the CPI-linked increased payments. This Government's inflation policy has collapsed. Not even Government Ministers like Senator Walsh would pretend that the inflation result for this year will be at all satisfactory. That collapse is one of the major problems this nation is now facing in its relationship with the rest of the world and its capacity to protect itself from the inevitable disaster when our commodity prices fall and when the Australian economy ceases getting the benefit of the once-off kick that it has had in the last few years when the terms of trade fortunately stopped falling and temporarily moved to our advantage. The disaster is that we are now in serious economic crisis despite the fact that our terms of trade have been temporarily advantageous to us.

TALK.START.PARA: —The best since 1976.

—As Senator Stone says, they are the best since 1976. But one wonders how long that situation will remain. In fact, already there are clear indications of significant falls. I think a $1 billion drop in the total returns from wool is expected next financial year. We have already seen some of the metals commodities coming well and truly off the top. The instability generated by the current problems with China would certainly raise some questions about what will happen with world trade. This is apart from serious concerns about the economic future of the United States of America.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the other side of this equation. In our amendments we noted that, even after the July 1989 tax cuts, the Hawke-Keating Government will remain Australia's highest taxing government in our postwar history. Let us just test that. In the 10 months to April this year we have seen exactly what is happening to revenue collections. It seems to me that the key point to look at is what pay as you earn (PAYE) taxpayers-the great bulk of Australians; people who work for a living and get paid a salary-are paying. PAYE collections from this extraordinary, grasping, high taxing Government have so far this year gone up by 17.5 per cent compared to the same period last year. The Budget forecast that net PAYE collections would go up by 13.8 per cent. At the time we said, `Hey, that's a bit rough. You are supposed to be holding down taxes and here is yet again another attack on the taxpayer'. But we find that collections are not going up by 13.8 per cent; they are going up by 17.5 per cent. That is an extra $1.2 billion a year in taxes more than the forecast rise of $4.3 billion for this year. No wonder this Government can pretend that it is handing out some great benefits by way of tax cuts. When one adds the $4.3 billion that the Government budgeted and for the $1.2 billion extra it will get, that magically adds up to $5.5 billion. What is the volume of the tax cut? It is $5 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is 4.9.

—Yes. So on these figures alone the reality is that so far this year this Government has collected about $600m more than the tax cut it will hand back. What monumental hypocrisy from this Government! It has tried to pretend that somehow it is doing something absolutely wonderful when in fact it is still ripping off more than it is giving back by way of tax cuts. That is apart from the enormous expense facing people who are trying to pay off their homes. For example, people with average mortgages have to face enormous interest bills. I hope to have the opportunity to deal with that at greater length at another time. We also see, among these extraordinary rises in income tax collections, the prescribed payments system. There has been an increase of 36.6 per cent in the amount collected under the prescribed payments system, to over $1 billion-an increase of over one-third compared to the 22 per cent increase that was forecast. In fact, the Government has collected almost as much in 10 months as it was supposed to collect in the full year. Company tax collections have gone up by 15 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting, though, that non-PAYE taxpayers have paid a substantial amount less. In other words, all these big increases in tax revenue have taken place despite a drop of almost 20 per cent in non-PAYE tax collections. This is fascinating. The excuse for this is that it reflects delays in processing returns of provisional taxpayers at the Australian Taxation Office (ATO). It also involves higher than expected levels of refunds, the incorporation of provisional taxpayers and an apparent shift in the composition of investment portfolios away from interest income towards insurance company and friendly society bonds.

However, the key element is delays in processing returns of provisional taxpayers at the ATO. If that delay is not caught up with within the next two months-and I doubt that it will be-we will see next year a massive, hidden in-built dam wall; a wall of water, or a tax flow, will come rushing in. In other words, the figures for the huge tax collections we will see by the end of this year will not fully reflect the real level of tax debt which is to be collected when the delays in processing returns are eventually overcome. The figures I have given today show that this enormous and continuing rise in Government tax revenues will not fully reflect what this Government is ripping off the taxpayers of Australia.

Let us now look at another area-sales tax, the area where the Government said it would not have any consumption tax. We have had a 23.8 per cent increase in sales tax collections this year. The Budget forecast was 14.4 per cent. That means, on an annual basis, an increase of approximately $700m. According to the statement of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) this increase is supposed to reflect the strength of sales of motor vehicles, and non-retail and investment goods and the impact of the 1988-89 budget measure on beer. Of course, one of the amendments to be considered tonight is to deal with that matter, which was a fiddle aimed at cheating on the CPI. That cheating on the CPI had some unintended consequences which now must be fixed.

Here we have a huge increase in consumption taxes, even above its Budget forecast, from a government which said it was not going to go into consumption taxes because they were somehow obscene. The fact is that in the six years of the Hawke Government there has been a 150 per cent rise in consumption taxes. That is three times the rate of inflation. It hits hardest on lower income earners, particularly families with young children, who are consumers of food such as orange juice, ice-cream and flavoured milk-items on which the Government has, for the first time ever, put a consumption tax. It is a hidden attack on the pockets of Australians, particularly Australian families.

One of the matters that confuse me slightly is the customs duty collections in the period to April, which were only very slightly higher, 1.9 per cent higher, than the collections for the same period last year. I would have thought that the massive increase in import volumes and import values-I regret I have not got the figures in front of me-should surely have brought a significant increase in customs duty. This statement indicates that there has in fact been a compositional shift towards goods dutiable at higher rates, and I presume that means a big increase in the number of motor vehicle imports. Despite that, there has been only a 1.9 per cent increase in collections. The Finance Minister's statement says that this is because there has been a reduction in tariff rates and import prices resulting from a higher value for the Australian dollar in 1988-89. That really surprises me. I cannot imagine that will end up being correct, although I notice that in the Budget Papers the Government was expecting a 2.5 per cent fall in customs duty on imports. That is not because of a higher Australian dollar; it is because it expected its economic policies to work, and of course they have not worked.

It is interesting to see the sorts of things that Mr Keating was saying on 19 July 1988 and how he was stressing that we could not have tax cuts. I wonder what has happened since July 1988 that has so improved our economic position.

TALK.START.PARA: —Things have got worse.

—Exactly. Yet in July 1988 Mr Keating was saying the strongest possible things, jawboning about how it was not appropriate to have tax cuts and how it was vital to maintain a tough fiscal stance, a tough wages stance and a tough monetary stance. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: If the unions think we're just mouthing some empty rhetoric about a tax-wage trade-off and the quality needing to be there before we produce the goods, then they're mistaken . . .
We will hang on to the surplus if they don't play the game.

They were certainly playing some sort of game, because they played the game well enough for Mr Keating to give them the surplus, $5 billion of it, by way of tax cuts, to give them a wage rise as well, and a promise of more to come, and no requirement on productivity whatsoever at this stage. It sounded impressive to the foreign investors, but it was meaningless nonsense. He said:

If Australia doesn't make provision now when there's a bit of sunshine around in terms of commodity prices, if we don't pay a bit of debt off and restructure the economy now, if the terms of trade ever turn down on us again we'll cop it right in the neck.
He is right; we are going to cop it right in the neck. This is what he was saying less than a year ago. He said that the country could not rely on improved commodity prices, and:

The terms of trade have been declining since 1950 in a trend away, and it's reasonable to assume that decline may resume. The lift in the terms of trade we are seeing now of high rates of world growth may not be around forever.

TALK.START.PARA: —When did he say all this?
—In July last year. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Now is the time to restructure the economy, and this is why it's very important to keep policy tight-fiscal, wage, and at this time, monetary policy.

What has he done to keep wages policy tight? He has given major rises because he could not do the deal he thought he was going to do with the unions. Has he kept fiscal policy tight? Yes, by reducing taxes by $5 billion. What about monetary policy? That is the only thing he is screwing. He is screwing monetary policy; he is screwing interest rates. If all this was true when Mr Keating said it last July, what intrigues me is why it is suddenly true no longer.

TALK.START.PARA: —The balance of payments is worse.

—The balance of payments, the inflation rate-all those things are worse. In February this year Dr Hewson, the shadow Treasurer, said, and he has been proved so right, that there were real dangers in what Mr Keating was doing. He said that there was a danger of interest rate overkill. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: It will be very difficult for them to engineer a `soft landing'; it has not been characteristic of the Australian economy. It looks like we will again see economic activity go from `too fast' to `flat'.
Dr Hewson stated that there was a danger of an exchange rate crisis. He stated:

It could happen if `jawboning' is carried too far. It will certainly happen if world commodity prices suddenly fall quite markedly. (i.e. over and above the downward drift that is already evident in commodity prices).

There is no doubt that the Opposition has been correct in continually stressing the need for structural change which the Government, as we realised when we debated the statement yesterday, has only started to nibble at, not to bite on. Until the Government takes notice of the Opposition and follows the strong advice we have been giving it for years about what it should do, the economy will be a disaster.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator WALSH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to speak for very long. I did not hear Senator Stone's speech, but I understand that he was critical of bracket creep, fiscal drag, or whatever one wants to call it. It is worth noting that on 17 February 1982, the present Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, when he was not a Minister in the coalition Government, said in Parliament:

SPEECH.PARA: In the last six years the Government has made certain reforms in the taxation field. These have been spelt out by the Treasurer and important among them was the introduction for a time of tax indexation, one of the fundamental elements of Liberal Party policy in recent years. Yet full indexation applied only in 1976-77 and 1977-78 and half indexation of the standard rate scale applied in 1978-79 and 1980-81. Now it has been abandoned altogether.
I do not know whether Mr Peacock was aware of Senator Stone's views, but it is worth putting on the record what Mr Peacock said about the coalition Government at that time.

There are three second reading amendments in relation to this package and I will comment briefly on each. The first second reading amendment, which has been moved in relation to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Rates and Rebates) Bill, asserts in the first paragraph that this Government is the highest taxing government ever. I have two comments to make on that. Firstly, the level of tax as a proportion of gross domestic product (GDP) compared with what it was in some previous period should be adjusted for the fact that health expenditure via Medicare is now on the Commonwealth Budget to a much larger extent than it is on the household budget. Secondly and more importantly, it is easy to run a low tax policy if one is willing to run an irresponsible Commonwealth Budget deficit of the order of 5 per cent of GDP, as the previous coalition Government was doing when it was booted out of office.
The second amendment, which is in relation to the Sales Tax (Exemption and Classification) Amendment Bill, contains a paragraph stating:
the Government's failure more generally to reform the ramshackle indirect tax system, which is littered with inconsistencies and anomalies . . .

That clearly signals an intention to introduce a broad-based consumption tax. Cheekiest of all is the amendment to the Income Tax (Arrangements with the States) Repeal Bill. The second reading amendment states:
the Treasurer is devoid of any policy on Federal State financial relations;

The 1978 Act which this Bill seeks to repeal was the foundation stone of the Fraser Government's much vaunted new federalism policy of 1975. That policy was to return to the States the power to levy their own income taxes, thereby reducing their demand on the Commonwealth Budget for financial assistance and other grants. It was enacted by the Fraser Government in 1978, but it was never enforced. I would have thought that the survivors of that Government, most of whom are still in the Parliament, would be the last people who should be censorious about any government failing to pursue a meaningful policy on Federal-State financial relations. This was the jewel in the crown of Fraserism-new federalism. The Act was passed and nothing happened afterwards, nothing at all. The people who were responsible for that are the last ones who should be censorious about what any government does in that area.

I do not intend to say any more, other than to point out what would be fairly obvious by now; that is, the Government will not accept any of the second reading amendments. A number of amendments to two of the Bills will be moved at the committee stage. Some of them will concern privacy matters and will be handled by Senator Tate. The others will be handled by me.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Stone's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I foreshadowed during the second reading debate when dealing with the three Bills cognately, the Opposition has proposed seven pages of amendments to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), which have been circulated to the Committee. All those amendments are in respect of clause 28 of this Bill. As I said in my earlier remarks, these amendments relate to a provision in clause 28 for a major increase in the discretion available to the Commissioner of Taxation to make taxation information in his possession, whether in respect of individuals or corporations, available to certain specified law enforcement agencies, including the Australian Customs Service.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the view of the Opposition that this Bill represents yet another erosion of the safeguards against the privacy of taxpayers' affairs. While we would support any reasonable measure-I repeat, any reasonable measure-to assist law enforcement agencies in the pursuit of their duties, we believe that the Government has gone much further in these Bills than can possibly be justified. In saying that, the Opposition is in part influenced by a whole series of events in the history of the current Government. For example, we have had the notorious Australia Card-the so-called ID card-legislation, which was withdrawn ignominiously by the Government because of a major technical defect that we discovered within it. It was finally defeated in this place shortly after I came into the Senate.

We then had the extremely unhappy experience with the tax file number legislation in its original form-the arrogant proposals put forward by the Treasurer, Mr Keating, which required in the end to be very significantly amended by the Opposition with, I am glad to say, the support of the Australian Democrats. Associated with that, there was a major extension of the privacy legislation designed to provide some additional protection other than that which was finally contained in that legislation as a result of the Opposition's amendments to provide an additional degree of protection to the privacy of taxpayers. As I say, those are two major pieces of history which, to say the least, do not argue well for the bona fides of the Government in this area.

Since the tax file number legislation was eventually passed here late last year, we have had a whole series of very unfortunate incidents, to use no harsher a term, arising out of the administration of that legislation by the Australian Taxation Office. I do not want to appear to be blackguarding the Australian Taxation Office. In my previous career I worked with the people in that Office for many years and I put it on the record that I always found them good colleagues with a proper sense of their duty to the public. But I am bound to say that in the last few years I, too, have had to concede, to those who are more critical in that area than I have been previously wont to be, that some worrying signs are developing in that area.

It is against that background that the Opposition has considered these provisions in the legislation that is now before the Committee. Clause 28 of the legislation contains, as I said, very wide-ranging provisions which provide for taxation information to be made available by the Commissioner of Taxation to law enforcement agencies, including such bodies as the State and Federal police forces, the State corporate affairs commissions-which, although in one sense law enforcement agencies, are not normally thought of as being in that category; they have much wider-ranging duties and responsibilities-the Comptroller-General of Customs, and the Director of Public Prosecutions. The list goes on.

Those of us who speak for the Opposition have a rooted objection to what is proposed here. As I said before, we fully accept that if one of these law enforcement agencies has a legitimate reason to believe, as a result of its investigations into a particular matter, that information in or thought to be in the possession of the Commissioner of Taxation would be material to the pursuit of its investigations, we have no objection to an application being made by that agency for access to that information. But we believe it proper-indeed, vital-that any such application should go through a proper process and that it should be made to a judge of the Federal Court of Australia. The judge in question should have the powers to seek further information on the matter, including information from the Commissioner of Taxation, and satisfy himself or herself that the request is a legitimate one and not simply some sort of grand fishing expedition, for example.

I understand-and I suppose it is conceivable I could be corrected-that the Government is likely to oppose the Opposition's amendment in this area. I find that very disappointing. Indeed, I go so far as to use a stronger term than that: I find it astonishing. First of all, this provision which I am now addressing finds its place in a Bill, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1989, which is otherwise totally devoted to a whole series of quite minor, non-contentious, technical, unassuming-one might almost say `boring'-amendments, the sole purpose of which is to repair the usual string of deficiencies in the Government's previous drafting.

Yet tucked away at clause 28 of the Bill we find three pages of the most enormous import, matters certainly not capable of being described as in any way consisting solely of technical amendments or fixing up previous deficiencies in the law. We also find that there are some safeguards put into those passages of the clause, but, in our opinion, they are totally inadequate. The fact is that there is presently a crisis of confidence in the Australian community about the security of personal information provided to bureaucracies generally but particularly to this Government's bureaucracy and I have to say again-it gives me no pleasure to do so-particularly the Taxation Office. It is not any part of our purpose in being here simply to stand by and let the Labor Party give the Commissioner of Taxation unfettered discretion in releasing strictly confidential tax data relating to the private affairs of individuals or corporations-even to law enforcement agencies.

This year has already produced a litany of disasters from the Taxation Office. Back in February or March we had tens of thousands of letters containing tax file number information which were simply posted to the wrong addresses. Even in more recent weeks reports have been coming in to the offices of coalition senators and members and perhaps, for all I know, to Government members and senators and to Australian Democrats, of confidential taxation information being given to people unauthorised to receive it. Quite recently in one case information on over 30 people was reported to have been wrongly supplied to a person in South Australia. As I said in my earlier remarks, we had a case which was made public in the other chamber a week or two ago by Mr Michael MacKellar.

In the light of all of that, we will move these amendments which have been circulated, with three objectives in mind. Firstly, we believe that the responsibility for initiating action for the release of such information should not be within the discretion of the Commissioner. Responsibility for initiating action should rest with the law enforcement agencies concerned and should be based upon some reasonable belief on their part that in the light of investigations that they are carrying out the Commissioner is reasonably believed to have information which would assist them materially with those investigations. Secondly, we also believe that any approach by a law enforcement agency for the release of otherwise confidential tax information should require approval, as I said earlier, from a Federal Court judge and that the judge must be satisfied that the information is relevant to the particular investigation. Finally, the third purpose of our amendment is to ensure that the Privacy Commissioner should monitor the provision of any request for information of this kind and should report to the Minister if he considers the provision of the information constitutes an invasion of privacy. I should say, for the information of the Committee, that these proposals in the Opposition's amendment are closely modelled upon those of a very similar kind in the legislation governing access by the National Crime Authority to taxation information.

We on this side of politics are well accustomed to the Australian Labor Party posturing as a party having a deep concern for civil liberties. What in fact these changes that are now being proposed by Mr Keating reveal is a total disregard for such concerns. It is a totally hypocritical regard for such concerns. I wager-I have no basis for saying this but I would not be surprised; perhaps I should be more cautious rather than offering to wager-that very few members or senators on the Labor Party side of either this chamber or the other are aware that these sorts of provisions are in this Bill. I think that, if they had been aware, we would have heard of it before this time by some leak to the press or someone beginning to jump up and down within the Labor Party itself. I should go out of my way to say that there are people within that Party who are genuinely concerned about civil liberties, invasion of privacy and all the things which are infringed by this Bill and the restoration of which our amendment is directed to. I seek leave to move the amendments together.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1). Pages 10 and 11, clause 28, proposed subsection 3e (1), line 39 (page 10) to line 6 (page 11), leave out the proposed subsection, insert the following subsections:

`` `(1) Subject to this section, the Commissioner may disclose to an authorised law enforcement agency officer information that the Commissioner may have acquired under the provisions of a tax law (in this section referred to as the ``requested information''), notwithstanding any taxation secrecy provision.
`` `(1a) Where an authorised law enforcement agency officer considers that the Commissioner may have acquired requested information that is relevant to:
(a) establishing whether a serious offence has been, or is being, committed; or
(b) the making, or proposed or possible making, of a proceeds of crime order;
the authorised law enforcement agency officer may apply to a Judge of the Federal Court of Australia.
`(1b) An application under subsection (1a) shall be in writing and shall be accompanied by an affidavit made by the applicant that:
(a) sets out the details of:
(i) the investigation into establishing whether a serious offence has been or is being committed; or
(ii) the making, or proposed or possible making, of a proceeds of crime order; and
(b) specifies particulars of the requested information.

`` `(1c) An authorised law enforcement agency officer who makes an application under subsection (1a) shall give notice in writing to the Commissioner of the making of the application and of the particulars of the requested information.
`` `(1d) Where an application is made to a Judge under subsection (1a):

(a) the Judge may order the Commissioner to disclose to the authorised law enforcement agency officer all of the requested information, or such of the requested information as is specified in the order, that the Commissioner has acquired under the provisions of a taxation law or of a previous law of the Commonwealth of which the Commissioner had the general administration; and

(b) if the Judge makes an order under paragraph (a)-the Judge may make a further order prohibiting the authorised law enforcement agency officer from communicating the information except in such manner as is, and to such persons (being persons to whom the authorised law enforcement agency officer is otherwise entitled to communicate the information) as are specified in the order, and a Judge may at any time, on application by an authorised law enforcement agency officer or by the Commissioner, notice of which shall be given to the Commissioner or to the authorised law enforcement agency officer, as the case requires, vary or revoke such a further order.
`` `(1e) A Judge shall not make an order under subsection (1d) in relation to an application unless:
(a) the Commissioner has been given the opportunity to bring to the notice of the Judge any matter to which the Commissioner considers the Judge should have regard in considering the application;

(b) the applicant has given to the Judge, on oath or by affidavit, such further information (if any) as the Judge requires concerning the investigation in relation to which the application is made; and
(c) the Judge is satisfied that:
(i) there are reasonable grounds for believing that the information to be specified in the order is relevant to the investigation in relation to which the application is made; and
(ii) the information to be specified in the order is not readily obtainable by the authorised law enforcement agency officer from a source other than the Commissioner.

`` `(1f) A Judge, in considering for the purposes of paragraph (1e) (c) whether or not particular information that may be relevant is readily obtainable by the authorised law enforcement agency officer from a source other than the Commissioner, shall have regard to any prejudice to the conduct of the investigation that may result if the authorised law enforcement agency officer is required to obtain the information from such a source.'.''.

(2) Page 11, clause 28, proposed subsections 3e (2), (3) and (4), lines 7, 20, and 26, leave out ``Where information'' (thrice occurring), insert ``Without prejudice to paragraph (1d) (b), where information''.
(3) Page 13, clause 28, proposed subsection 3f (1), lines 26 to 29, leave out the proposed subsection, insert the following subsections:

`` `(1) Subject to this section, the Commissioner may disclose to the Comptroller-General of customs information that the Commissioner may have acquired under the provisions of a tax law (in this section referred to as the ``requested information'') notwithstanding any taxation secrecy provision.
`` `(1a) Where the Comptroller-General of Customs considers that the Commissioner may have acquired requested information that is relevant to:
(a) establishing whether a serious offence has been, or is being committed; or
(b) the making, or proposed or possible making, of a proceeds of crime order;
the Comptroller-General of Customs may apply to a Judge of the Federal Court of Australia.
`` `(1b) An application under subsection (1a) shall be in writing and shall be accompanied by an affidavit made by the applicant that:
(a) sets out the details of:
(i) the investigation into establishing whether a serious offence has been or is being committed; or
(ii) the making, or proposed or possible making, of a proceeds of crime order; and
(b) specifies particulars of the requested information.

`` `(1c) The Comptroller-General of Customs who makes an application under subsection (1a) shall give notice in writing to the Commissioner of the making of the application and of the particulars of the requested information.
`` `(1d) Where an application is made to a Judge under subsection (1a):

(a) the Judge may order the Commissioner to disclose to the Comptroller-General of Customs all of the requested information, or such of the requested information as is specified in the order, that the Commissioner has acquired under the provisions of a taxation law or of a previous law of the Commonwealth of which the Commissioner had the general administration; and

(b) if the Judge makes an order under paragraph (a)-the Judge may make a further order prohibiting the Comptroller-General of Customs from communicating the information except in such manner as is, and to such persons (being persons to whom the Comptroller-General of Customs is otherwise entitled to communicate the information) as are, specified in the order, and a Judge may at any time, on application by the Comptroller-General of Customs or by the Commissioner, notice of which shall be given to the Commissioner or to the Comptroller-General of Customs, as the case requires, vary or revoke such a further order.
`` `(1e) A Judge shall not make an order under subsection (1d) in relation to an application unless:
(a) the Commissioner has been given the opportunity to bring to the notice of the Judge any matter to which the Commissioner considers the Judge should have regard in considering the application;

(b) the applicant has given to the Judge, on oath or by affidavit, such further information (if any) as the Judge requires concerning the investigation in relation to which the application is made; and
(c) the Judge is satisfied that:
(i) there are reasonable grounds for believing that the information to be specified in the order is relevant to the investigation in relation to which the application is made; and
(ii) the information to be specified in the order is not readily obtainable by the Comptroller-General of Customs from a source other than the Commissioner.

`` `(1f) A Judge, in considering for the purposes of paragraph (1e) (c) whether or not particular information that may be relevant is readily obtainable by the Comptroller-General of Customs from a source other than the Commissioner, shall have regard to any prejudice to the conduct of the investigation that may result if the Comptroller-General of Customs is required to obtain the information from such a source.'.''.
(4) Page 13, clause 28, after proposed section 3f, insert the following new section in Part 5:
Privacy Commissioner to monitor provision of requested information

``3g. (1) The Commissioner shall provide to the Privacy Commissioner all requests for information made under sections 3e and 3f and details of all such requested information provided to an authorised law enforcement agency officer or to the Comptroller-General of Customs.
`` `(2) The Privacy Commissioner shall report to the Minister if the Privacy Commissioner thinks that the provision of the requested information is an interference with the privacy of an individual.
`` `(3) In this section:
`Minister' and `Privacy Commissioner' have the same meanings as in the Privacy Act 1988; and
`requested information' has the same meaning as in sections 3f and 3g.'.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —One matter which has bedevilled the combating of serious crime in Australia is the protection of turf, the undue jealousy that somehow builds up within an organisation such that it holds on to information for itself which may be of use to another law enforcement agency, and we are contemplating several of them in this Bill, in a way which does not allow the pursuit of the person who is responsible for a serious crime either against a person within our community or against some institution, for example the Government itself, in the fact that a major fraud is being practised against it. What has been a pleasing feature of the maturity of the Australian community over the last four or five years has been the gradual realisation that those barriers, those hurdles, that exist between agencies and departments of the national Government, ought to be, by permission of this Parliament of course, lowered or dismantled, or a way should be found by which the hurdle can be circumvented in a reasonable way in order to achieve the aim of combating criminal activity in our community.

SPEECH.PARA: The clause of the Bill that is being debated at the moment is one more step in that attempt by our community to enable the Commissioner of Taxation to provide information to law enforcement agencies where it is relevant to the pursuit of some trail which will lead to the conviction of a person for a serious offence or in relation to the profits of crime which are generated by engaging in nefarious and illegal activity. I think that is probably the first answer to one of Senator Stone's concerns; in fact, this does not confer an unfettered discretion on the Commissioner of Taxation. It is quite wrong to say that an unfettered discretion is conferred on the Commissioner of Taxation; in fact, the discretion is fettered in the sense that it may be exercised only in order to release information which is relevant to establishing whether a serious offence has been committed or where it is relevant to the proposed making of an order relating to proceeds of crime-the confiscation of the assets and profits of those engaged in criminal activity. So indeed it is a fettered discretion, I would submit, in the sense that it has to be for defined purposes.

Of course, a serious crime is an indictable offence which, generally speaking, is a more serious offence carrying a consequence perhaps of 12 months or more imprisonment. That would be a general way of describing indictable offences, or we would point to them in the various Australian criminal codes or common law schedules of crimes. So it is fettered in the sense that it has to be for a specific purpose. Indeed, if the Commissioner of Taxation releases information otherwise than for those purposes, then he is guilty of an offence against section 16 of the taxation Act, the secrecy provision, and is subject to a very severe and stringent penalty. So I think we have to see this as a fettered discretion in that sense; it has to be for a specific purpose which, if not adhered to, exposes the Commissioner of Taxation not only to a very severe penalty but also to the very danger which I think Senator Stone is speaking of-that is, the ethos, the understanding, that, if information is provided to the Taxation Commissioner, then on the whole one may expect that it be held very confidentially within his organisation. To have that sort of confidence undermined by a case which pointed to a lax implementing of the will of the Parliament in relation to this matter, and the imposition of the penalty under section 16, would bring such discredit on the Taxation Commissioner that I am sure that he would always be most prudent in ensuring that any release of information under this proposal was for the fettered purposes outlined by the proposal.

It is also important to note that the information can be used only for intelligence purposes. It cannot be either voluntarily disclosed in a court or required, coerced or compelled to be disclosed in a court of law, except where the offence relates, I think, to a revenue offence or to a matter under the proceeds of crime legislation where a conviction has already been recorded. Once again there is an attempt by the Parliament to say that we believe that it is important that this information be passed from the Taxation Commissioner to one of the nominated law enforcement agencies. But part of the privacy aspect is that the information not be revealed in court, even under coercion, or, as I say, compelled from a person appearing in a particular case of litigation.

Nevertheless, it is true to say that Senator Stone has indicated quite rightly that this measure represents something of-I think he called it-enormous import. He was using it to contrast with the more technical provisions surrounding this clause, or series of clauses. It is of import. There is no doubt about that. It should raise questions in the mind of anybody who is concerned with protecting the privacy of material that is made available to any government agency-in this case, the Taxation Office. For that reason, it is important that one recalls the role of the Privacy Commissioner in relation to the disclosure of this sort of information to a law enforcement agency. Senator Stone may well ask in relation to my first point: how would anyone know that the Taxation Commissioner was putting out information that was not within the fettered confines of the objectives set by the Parliament? That is a fair question. The answer is that every disclosure of such information must be notated on the file. When we passed the privacy legislation last year we ensured--

TALK.START.PARA: —When you passed our privacy legislation.

—It had the benefit of consideration and input by all sides. That part of the legislation was always in our drafts, right from the beginning-that any disclosure of information to aid a law enforcement agency has to be notated on the file. When I say `on the file' it does not simply mean a red flag on a manila folder. In electronic data processing terms, no doubt there is some equivalent terminology. That notation is there to be audited by the Privacy Commissioner, who has access to and can call upon those files and find out for himself whether there has been any abuse of the power, the discretion, which this Parliament would be residing in the Taxation Commissioner.
—Why does it have to be discretion?

—I do not know exactly what Senator Crichton-Browne means. He would not want it to be mandatory-or does he? Is he saying that perhaps it should be mandatory, that the provision should read `shall'-`the Commissioner shall make information available.'? We believe that there are matters of balance, matters of consideration, which it might be proper for the Taxation Commissioner to take into account. Therefore, we are enabling him to do it without compelling him to do it.
—At his discretion.

—I have already answered that. It is not exactly a discretion. It has to be according to objectives set by this Parliament. If the Commissioner goes outside those objectives, he is guilty of a serious offence against the secrecy provisions.
—Your explanatory memorandum itself uses the word `discretion'.
—Yes, and I am trying to explain what it means in this context.
—You said it does not mean discretion.

—I said that it did not mean an unfettered discretion. I know what I have said, even though I may be more preoccupied with the test match that is going on at the moment. But I am concentrating on this Bill and on the committee stage at the moment. The Privacy Commissioner has a very real role. Information privacy principle 11, which was contained in the privacy legislation passed by this Parliament, provides:

SPEECH.PARA: Where personal information is disclosed for the purposes of enforcement of the criminal law or of a law imposing a pecuniary penalty, or for the purpose of the protection of the public revenue, the record-keeper shall include in the record containing that information a note of the disclosure.

As I said, this enables the Privacy Commissioner to audit the Tax Office database to ensure that it is complying with the information privacy principles and to take such steps, whether by way of indicating that a prosecution should be launched or by way of report to this Parliament, if he considers that that particular power is being abused.

I believe I have indicated the real nature of the discretion, not unfettered, that is being placed in the hands of the Taxation Commissioner in this particular instance. I have indicated that, if he wanders outside the particular objectives for the disclosure of information, he will be guilty of an offence, and the Privacy Commissioner will pick that up by auditing the notations on the files. The information can be used by law enforcement agencies only for the purpose of carrying out their investigations as part of the intelligence and information which they sift through in order to gather admissible evidence, but it cannot be admitted in court as evidence and cannot be either voluntarily given or compelled in some judicial proceeding. I believe in that situation the Parliament is able to prudently carry out this reform, this innovation, this change, to the usual way in which matters are held tight and secret within the Taxation Office.

Whilst it is true that the Opposition has modelled its proposed amendment on a provision dealing with the way in which the National Crime Authority may gain access to taxation information, that particular provision, that methodology, that way of going about things, has never been used, implemented or been the way in which the National Crime Authority has obtained information from the Tax Office. Rather, section 3d (1) of the Taxation Administration Act 1953 has been used. It states:
Notwithstanding anything in a taxation secrecy provision, the Commissioner may communicate information to the Authority for the purposes of a tax related investigation.
I believe that indicates a model which is more akin to that which the Government has adopted in relation to this particular legislation.

The crisis of confidence-the term which Senator Stone adopted in relation to the Tax Office-is probably too strong a term. The legitimate misgivings which are aroused in the public when they read of the unwarranted and negligent, to say the least, disclosure of information about the taxation affairs of citizens that is not authorised and should not be made available can be satisfied by the sort of regime which is put in place and the sorts of safeguards which I have outlined. I ask the Committee to support the Government's proposals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition's amendment is comprehensive and deals with an area which I think has exercised our minds in this chamber quite often. I refer to the problem of secrecy on the one hand and the ability to fight crime on the other, or privacy versus the ability of the community to protect itself. It is not an easy judgment to make. As the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) has said, this legislation follows a fairly open provision that has always been in the Act-a provision that enabled the Commissioner of Taxation to use his discretion in regard to a number of matters concerning crime.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has drawn up an amendment which uses the route of a Federal Court judge. It is a time honoured route. Quite a number of Acts interpose a judge between members of the bureaucracy seeking to take an action and the person they are seeking to proceed against.
Consideration interrupted.
