SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Preselections in New South Wales always generate some interest and enthusiasm, particularly in the Australian Labor Party (ALP). I would like to draw the Senate's attention not simply to the whimsical behaviour of the Labor Party in its recent Liverpool State preselection but also to a preselection coming up this weekend for the Senate. We have heard quite often the Labor Party discussing Liberal Party Senate preselections and, perhaps, the same sort of enthusiasm should be exercised in looking at the Labor Party's preselection over the coming weekend.

SPEECH.PARA: Among others, Senator John Morris will be seeking preselection to face the electors at the next election. I know this will surprise the Senate, but not all members of the Labor Party actually favour the re-endorsement of Senator John Morris. I know it sounds strange. I have been on the receiving end of extraordinarily large amounts of information which seem to be critical of Senator John Morris. I can assume only that the intention involved in providing me with this information is to ensure that Senator John Morris is not preselected. We all remember how that original preselection took place. It was part of a deal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was it as good as Paul Keating's?

—It was very interesting. It was part of a deal between two factions which merged in New South Wales. As I recall, one was called the Rank and File Committee. I think some of the activities were pretty rank. The agreement to merge these two factions meant that Mr John Morris, as he was then, won a place on the ALP Senate ticket. In other words, this faction was bought by the right wing of the Labor Party in New South Wales at the cost-some may say a very considerable cost-of giving Mr Morris, as he was then, a seat in the Senate.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. I think a couple of days ago at Question Time you ruled out of order the suggestion that somebody bought their position. In that case I think it was a claim that a Liberal Party senator had bought her place on the front bench by doing a political deal. I believe it is quite out of order and grossly offensive to an honourable senator to indicate that in some way he had bought his seat in the Senate by a dastardly political deal.

—On the point of order, Mr President: I listened very carefully to what Senator Michael Baume was saying. He made no such allegation. The allegation was against a faction; it was not against Senator Morris. On that basis, there was no accusation against a senator to which a standing order could apply.
—Order! Senator Baume, were you making an imputation that Senator Morris had bought his seat in the Senate?

—No. I was extracting information from 1984 press clippings outlining that the right wing splinter group, the Rank and File Committee, had agreed to merge with the Right of the Labor Party in New South Wales, the price of which was giving Senator Morris a seat in the Senate. As I said, I think-and obviously my informants are of the same view-that it was a very high price to pay. The fact that it was such a high price to pay is evident from an examination, which has kindly been done for me, of Senator Morris's--

SPEECH.PARA: Government senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am letting him continue. I have warned him about the imputation.
—In very simple terms the high price is--

SPEECH.PARA: Government senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —If Government senators will restrain their enthusiasm they will see what I mean by the term `the high price'. When one pays people's salaries one assumes there will be some return on those salaries. There are those who take the view that the return on Senator Morris's salary is not as large as it may be for every other honourable senator in the chamber.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The honourable senator is obviously trying to tread a very fine line. He just unequivocally suggested that Senator Morris does not deliver the same degree of value for money in this House as do other honourable senators. It is a personal reflection. I do not see how the Senate can regard it in any other way. Standing order 418 is quite specific about that. It is not only disorderly; it is highly disorderly.
—Senator Baume, I ask you to withdraw the imputation.
—I withdraw the imputation, Mr President. I will simply stick to the facts. Since Senator Morris has come into this chamber he has made two speeches. One was his maiden speech--
—Only two?

—Only two. One was his maiden speech and the other was when he spoke during a matter of public interest debate on 7 November 1985. There have been no speeches since. These two speeches involved a total of 4,200 words. These two speeches, when related to his income over four years, amount to $72 a word. I know of no member of the Senate apart from Senator Morris who is worth $72 a word. I regret if I offended anyone by talking about price but I thought it important. That price would obviously rate highly in the consciousness of those people who have referred these matters to me in the run up to the preselection on Saturday.

SPEECH.PARA: That is not to say that Senator Morris has not participated in other ways in this chamber. In that period he has asked 80 questions. I think that at times the word `Dorothy' has been used in this context. There were two notices of motion. Senator Puplick well remembers one of them. I think that after that one Senator Morris may have lost his enthusiasm for notices of motion. The Senate will remember that that notice of motion involved a congratulatory message to Mr Wran and an expression of regret at his departure as Premier of New South Wales. Senator Puplick very sensibly moved that the matter be dealt with forthwith so that we could all participate with some comment on Mr Wran's record as Premier of New South Wales. I well recall that, as a result of that, the Labor Party voted against Senator Morris's motion coming before this chamber. Of the two notices of motion of Senator Morris, there was certainly a 50 per cent failure rate. Once again, I submit that if people wish to talk about the cost or the price of Senator Morris, it could be looked at as being fairly high.
Government senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to hear that there are some interjections from the other side.
—They are much better at handing it out than at taking it.

—Absolutely. I agree with Senator Stone. The continual smart-aleckery from the other side about preselections on our side is apparently quite acceptable. But if we seek to raise some very proper matters relating to the interesting preselection coming up on Saturday, it is somehow disgraceful and merits a voluminous number of interjections. While we are on the subject of interjections, let us examine Senator Morris's performance in that area. In four years, he is recorded in Hansard as having made no interjections whatsoever. I commend him for it.
—He has not been here to make any interjections.

—I take Senator Patterson's point. I am glad she raised it because, while some people might say that it is highly commendable that he made no interjections, there are others who would say that it would have been nicer had he been here to do so. I examined, on request, the honourable senator's attendance at Senate divisions between July 1985, when he became a member of this place, and the present. In that period there were 408 divisions. For 163 of them, the honourable senator was absent. In other words, that was a 40 per cent failure rate. I do not know whether any other senators have managed a 40 per cent failure rate on divisions.
—He was paired.

—Exactly. Senator Morris was, in fact, paired. In other words, his absence was de facto authorised by the Labor Party. It was quite happy for him not to be here, and I can understand why. But the reality is that with the connivance of his colleagues he was absent for 40 per cent of the votes taken in this place since his election. What was he doing? Why was he not here? We in the Opposition were not given the credit or the benefit of any advice on that score. All we knew when we looked at the figures was that he appeared to have been absent without leave for 40 per cent of the decisions taken by this Senate. It may well be that, had the good senator been here, those decisions would have been different. His contribution, had he made one, may have changed our minds. His attendance, had he been here, may have influenced a vote. But I regret to say that his 40 per cent absence rate made it very difficult.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously, one can put one's face in the door, get one's travel allowance and then depart from this place without actually participating in any divisions, so I had a look at the number of sitting days for which Senator Morris was in fact marked present. I found that, of the 331 sitting days so far, he was absent for 54. That, of course, does not equal 40 per cent; it equals only 15 per cent or so. In other words, although he was marked present for many days, he simply did not turn up to the great bulk of the divisions or, in fact, any of the divisions which took place on the days he was marked present. I simply say to the good senator that these sorts of matters are ones that no doubt have interested those people who have drawn them to my attention, who clearly do not wish the good senator to be there--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who are they?
—It would be a good idea if you disclosed yours.
—Order! It would be a good idea if there were no interjections from either side.

—I thank the Senate for its quiet, reasonable and rational attention to the points I am making. Senator Morris is also Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare. That is an exciting and interesting committee. I do not know of any chairman of any committee, particularly involved as that one was in some serious inquiries, that managed to miss 24 per cent, roughly a quarter, of the meetings of his own committee. Normally committee meetings are held at the convenience of the chairman. I do not know which convenience this Chairman was at at the time. But it is most unusual that a senator should miss so many. I will not go into the details of all the other committees. I must say, though, that the honourable senator attends the House Committee quite often, and that is natural, because I have often been interested to see that he attends them, in view of his clear conflict of interest as the President, or an official, of the Liquor and Allied Trades Union of Australia, when he was dealing in what seemed to me to be matters affecting the interests of both the Senate and his labour constituency in a way which certainly had the potential for a conflict of interest.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I hate to disturb Senator Michael Baume, because he really is making a very good case on a very good political basis and the exchange across the chamber is all very good. But on this occasion I think Senator Baume transgressed in saying that there was a conflict of interest. Because a committee has a particular label and because Senator Morris is a member of a union with a particular label, the honourable senator is comparing the labels and saying that there is a conflict of interest. I do not think he has taken it far enough to draw that conclusion and I do not think it is necessary for me to ask the Chair to ask him to withdraw that, because I am sure he will, I having pointed out where on this one occasion the honourable senator seems to have transgressed.

—On all matters I defer to the wisdom and decency of Senator Cooney. If he in any way feels that I have transgressed, I would happily withdraw and simply leave the facts on the table, which are that the President of the Liquor and Allied Trades Union is on the House Committee, which is theoretically, as I understand it, the employer of people who are members of his union. If that does not create any potential for conflict, I am quite prepared to accept that proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer the Senate also to an article written in the Sunday Telegraph on 5 March 1989 entitled `Comrades turn on the silent Senator'. It says:
A bitter row has erupted over a campaign to dump the $111,000-a-year union leader who is said to hold the cushiest job in the Australian Labor movement.

It says that on top of his parliamentary expenses he has the use of an imported top of the range Mazda as honorary New South Wales President of the Liquor Trades Union, and apart from politics and unions, he also has an interest in land development.

TALK.START.PARA: —Top of the range Mazda?

—I am told that the Mazda 929 is a very comfortable and expensive motor car. Obviously my Holden does not rate compared to the stylish motor vehicles possessed by the former trade union officers opposite who can afford top of the range Mazdas and regard that as simply an El Cheapo. Maybe relative to the Volvos and other things they drive, it is. That article stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Some of his former friends and colleagues in the LTU-
the Liquor Trades Union-
have launched a campaign to unseat him in the branch election later this year, claiming that he has spent no more than 20 days in his office in the past 2 1/2 years.
That is why I said I wondered where he was when he was not in the Senate because apparently, according to that report, he was not in his trade union office either.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where was he?
—Indeed.
—He must have been in his electoral office.
—That is quite right, Senator; he must have been in his electoral office. I have a consuming interest, as they say, in this matter. The report stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Coming on top of the Liverpool preselection row, the battle for the LTU looms as another potential embarrassment for the ALP head office, which offered Senator Morris the Senate seat about five years ago.
This all developed out of an innocent, simple question I asked Senator Walsh which was referred to by the Sunday Telegraph. The newspaper noted:
Senator Morris has never responded to an attack on him-
I would not call it an attack on him-

in the Senate in November 1986 by Senator Michael Baume . . . asked Finance Minister Peter Walsh if the fringe benefits tax was payable by non-profit making organisations (such as unions) where non-wage benefits were granted for services rendered by non-employees.

He cited the case of Senator Morris, whom he said was receiving a monthly tax-free expense allowance of $450, totalling $5400 a year, and a honorarium of $200 per working day when not engaged in other official capacities, probably totalling a minimum of $30,000 a year.
In those days he only had the use of a Holden Statesman rather than a top of the line Mazda.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is he a socialist?
—Of course he is a socialist. It was then stated:

SPEECH.PARA: It is understood the union's committee of management voted unanimously a month ago to continue Senator Morris's honorarium and expenses, which have been increased with National Wage case increases since 1986.
One of the members of the committee was Mr Reeves, who votes `yes' to avoid tipping his hand that a challenge was on the way.
The committee has since decided that the union should pay Senator Morris's legal fees in the action against Mr Reeves.

Apparently that legal action has been settled. What I wonder-perhaps this is a question which the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) could answer-is whether, when the union pays legal fees such as this, fringe benefits tax is payable? Perhaps I can give notice of that and in Question Time tomorrow we will see whether the Minister has a coherent response to that question.

I have been advised by those who are trying to ensure that Senator Morris is not re-elected that in the legal case that was settled a whole range of accusations were made. I do not know the merit of them and I do not seek to argue the case for or against them, but I will inform the Senate what was put to the court. No doubt it will be of great interest to those who will be making pre-selection decisions on Saturday or Sunday. It relates to the fact that Senator Morris became secretary of the union after the June 1970 union elections when, together with a team of candidates, including Mr Patrick Reeves, he was successful in ousting the communists from the union at that election. I congratulate him on that result. However, in about 1972 the candidates who ousted the communists commenced contributing sums of money from their union wages to a fund to assist candidates nominated by their group in future union elections. From time to time other persons who were employees of the union and members of that faction would contribute to that fund.

Both the honourable senator and the union secretary, Ken Jeffreys, were signatories of that fund. The fund was supposed to be used only for the purpose of paying for election expenses for their faction. The members of their faction met regularly and trusted the honourable senator, only inquiring of him as to the balance of the fund from time to time. In court it was asserted that he never gave them an account of the funds. At the end of last year the honourable senator's alleged refusal to provide information in respect of the fund and further, by reason of the honourable senator drawing both the senatorial salary and his salary as president of the union, Mr Reeves and others advised him that, as a result, they would be standing against him at the union elections in June this year. They then requested their contributions from the fund and allegedly the honourable senator refused to pay them their share of their union election fund.

Finally, it was alleged in the court that Mr Reeves was forced to commence action in the Supreme Court to receive his funds and, further, to get some form of account as to how those funds had been disbursed. It was alleged in the court that the honourable senator initially refused to give any form of account, but after many court appearances, he provided a copy of a receipt for funds paid into the trust account of his solicitors, who are the solicitors for the union, for an amount of approximately $103,000. His Honour Mr Justice Waddell, ordered particulars of the fund to be provided. In the affidavit that the honourable senator filed in those proceedings, he advised that accounts had never been kept, notwithstanding the fact that the fund had been in existence for over 15 years. He did not even have any of the invoices that had been presented to the fund to pay the costs of the election. No-one should be surprised by that. Anyone who knows anything about the right wing of the Labor Party in New South Wales will know how to handle donations from Harris-Daishowa and where the Treasurer (Mr Keating) learnt his particular form of accounting which enables him to come up with all sorts of extraordinary results. In any event, the solicitors for Mr Reeves issued a notice to produce upon the honourable senator requiring all records relating to the fund. According to the court records, the honourable senator was able to provide only two passbooks in answer to that request.

The solicitors for Mr Reeves at the time attempted to serve a subpoena upon the other signatory of the fund, the Secretary of the union, Mr Jeffreys. I understand that Mr Jeffreys has suffered from ill health and there may be a simple answer for the fact that the process server made seven attempts to serve Mr Jeffreys at his home and at the offices of the union. When counsel for Mr Reeves advised Acting Master McLachlan of the Supreme Court of these matters, apparently for the first time in many years he ordered substituted service of the subpoena and found he was satisfied that Mr Jeffreys was attempting to avoid service. I will not go on with the other great detail I have here, beyond saying that counsel for the plaintiff advised the court that on the day--

TALK.START.PARA: —You have not made a mark yet.
—Order!

—With that exciting interjection, perhaps I should just mention this. On 24 May 1989 the honourable senator's solicitors refused to allow Mr Reeves access, it is alleged, to a file subpoenaed by his solicitors in respect of a file on a transfer of property owned by Senator Morris, being all that land contained in volume 14080, folio 47, at Coffs Harbour transferred from the honourable senator to Mr Jeffreys. I have no knowledge of the merits or otherwise of this, except that they were statements made in court following which a settlement, the details of which I do not know, took place.
—What are you alleging? If you are going to smear, at least tell us what it is.
—The Minister has asked me to detail it and I will.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Baume, in a brilliant and very clever speech, has created an atmosphere which certainly casts imputations on the motives of Senator Morris and reflects on him in a very subtle way. He has built up a case by quoting documents tendered in a court. The fact that they are privileged in court and the fact that his statement is privileged here does not thereby convert those statements into statements which are not personal reflections on a senator. In fact, they are personal reflections on a senator. That is the whole tone of the speech and it seems to me that he has gone too far in that respect.
—Order! In reply to the point of order, I have been listening for any direct imputation. I think Senator Baume has rather cleverly avoided a direct imputation. I will allow him to continue.

—All I want to say on that matter, quite frankly, is that the subpoenaed documents revealed that an amount of $20,000 had been removed from the funds account held at the Commonwealth Banking Corporation. That is the funds account held on behalf of the group which had contributed money for union elections. The sum of $20,000 had been removed from the funds account held at the Commonwealth Banking Corporation on the authority of both Mr Jeffreys and the honourable senator. In light of the fact that there was no election for the union during that year, why was the money withdrawn? That is obviously a question that, no doubt, many people would be asking. As I said, the matter has been settled. It is simply part of a considerable volume of transactions. I just wish that I was able to afford the level of mortgages that Senator Morris has-$716,000, according to the documents I have here, which sum seems to emerge from very considerable property transactions which I certainly could not afford. Since 1971 Senator Morris has bought seven properties, and his wife has bought nine.

—Mr President, I have a point of order. There is an imputation being made that Senator Morris has come by money in order to indulge in these property speculations by means which are not on the public record. In that instance, Senator Baume is certainly casting a reflection on the integrity of the honourable senator.
—I do not think Senator Michael Baume has actually drawn that conclusion, and I will allow him to continue.
—I do not wish to detain the--
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —What we have seen Senator Michael Baume indulge in tonight is nothing new in this chamber. It is nothing unusual for one political party, just before a pre-selection, to attack a member of another in order to embarrass him at his pre-selection. Unfortunately, while it is a method often used in this chamber, it is rarely successful; and I do not think Senator Michael Baume has been very successful tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the case against my friend and colleague Senator Morris. It is only a year and a half ago that we in this chamber were lauding one of the greats of the Liberal Party. We said what a wonderful bloke he was-experienced, sharp, and so on. Yet from 1981, when I took my place here, until 1987 he made two speeches. His name was Reg Withers. There was hardly an interjection, hardly a question and hardly a speech from him. When the sad day comes that Senator Morris leaves this chamber we will probably make the same speeches and say that Senator Morris is the Senator Withers of the Labor Party, because that is the point Senator Baume made. It must be a fact that Senator Michael Baume was congratulating Senator Morris because, if he was not, he was putting the boot into the great Reg Withers, who made only two speeches in more time in this chamber-while I have been here-than Senator Morris has been here. The second point that Senator Baume insinuates, in his sneaky and grovelling style--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Ray, you will have to withdraw that remark.

—I withdraw that, Mr President. Senator Baume insinuates that there is something wrong with Senator Morris being on the House Committee. I do not attack the farmers on the Opposition benches who sit on rural affairs committees as having a conflict of interest. I do not attack the lawyers who sit on the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee. `So what!', is all I can say. The first of Senator Baume's two great points is that Senator Morris has made two speeches. In doing that, Senator Baume is either praising Senator Morris or condemning Senator Withers. His second point concerning conflict of interest, as I say, is total rubbish.

SPEECH.PARA: Then he criticises Senator Morris because Senator Morris may derive some income from outside this chamber, with Senator Stone, who has admitted in this chamber that he has been paid for his newspaper articles, chortling away in the background. There was another journalist, I remember, without the courage to put his own name to articles. He used to put the name of Steve Martin to his articles. I wonder who that could be. He did not have the courage to put his own name, but I bet he got paid for the articles-didn't you, Senator Baume? Three times now Senator Baume has made attacks. Firstly, he indirectly attacked Withers. Secondly, in an attack on conflict of interest he attacked half his colleagues on his side of the chamber. Thirdly, we then had the hypocritical cant of accusing other people of earning outside income when he has had his own snout in the trough. I wonder how we judge an individual like that. I wonder what he will go and say to Neil Brown who is a Queen's Counsel. Did he not collect any of his fees? Did he fly around the country when he was on the nose and not on the Opposition's front bench and not collect any money, or is this a snide attack on a well-known Peacock supporter? I wonder.

I will tell honourable senators of a pretty crude and low attack to which we have never responded in this chamber since the court case. Senator Baume says, `That is typical of a right wing machine; look at Harris-Daishowa'. Why does the honourable senator not look at the decision? The individual concerned was not charged with the serious offence but with the minor one. Why does the honourable senator not look at what the magistrate said in declaring Mr Loosley's honesty and character? That is more than the honourable senator could say for Community Polling and the rest of the skulduggery, as exposed by Starr and others in the New South Wales branch of the Liberal Party. That was much worse. But the honourable senator came into this chamber and tried to have Mr Loosley convicted. He accused us of a cover up when our behaviour was exemplary. That matter was investigated, referred to the Director of Public Prosecutions and taken to the magistrates court, where the lowest possible fine was applied and Mr Loosley's character was cleared.

But no, Senator Baume, with his nose in the gutter, wants to dredge that up again. He is just lucky that his Party is in government in New South Wales. It is a pity that the honourable senator does not investigate the various malpractices there. The honourable senator has only to come honest once in New South Wales. We had allegations about 400 of the dead voting. We set up an inquiry into Senator Bishop's allegations, amongst other things, and found that there was no basis whatsoever for those accusations. And so it goes on.

I do not object to the honourable senator coming in here and attacking a colleague just before his preselection; that is part of politics. If Senator Morris cannot stand that heat he will get out of the kitchen; but I know that he will not. It is part of the process. It has rarely worked. It worked with Senator Fred Chaney when John Dawkins endorsed him just before his preselection. That is the only kiss of death I have ever seen work, which does not really say much for Mr Dawkins; it just shows how pathetic the preselection voters were in Western Australia that they fell for the red Fred line. But on the subject of preselection we all have skeletons in the closet; we all have a lot to hide.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not everyone.

—Not everyone. The honourable senator opposite made it up through the ranks. Let me start with honourable senators opposite. Senator McGauran may go to the toilet if he wants to, but I would rather he stayed here and listened to this. Senator McGauran got endorsed for the National Party of Australia. Senator McGauran paid for an expensive campaign. Senator McGauran got elected here as a National Party member. However, the crunch came. Three sitting Liberal senators plus Senator McGauran wanted to be on the Opposition ticket. As the Opposition can win only three seats, someone had to drop off. They negotiated for weeks and months and, finally, poor old Senator McGauran was asked to ride off into the sunset to protect three sitting Liberal members. Then, as a result of Liberal preselection, Senator David Hamer was dumped and Senator McGauran is left looking like the greatest mug ever. These things happen. We feel a bit sorry for Senator McGauran with his preselection problems. I am sure that he would have some sympathy for Senator Morris.

SPEECH.PARA: We have Senator Stone's preselection. What a wonderful event that was. Senator Stone was hired by Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen-I do not know for how much money-as a consultant. Then what happened? Joh was looking for candidates. He said, `Great, we will have you. We will get rid of your trusted friend and colleague, Stan Collard, as he is expendable. Even though he is Leader of the National Party in this chamber, we will give him the flick and we will put in Senator Stone'. And on it goes.

It is interesting tonight to see just how many failed House of Representatives members have come in here for a vicarious thrill. Senator Short, my Victorian colleague-Carlton supporter though he may be-failed in Ballarat; Senator Baume failed in Macarthur; and Senator Tambling failed in the Northern Territory. Everyone who has been thrown out of the House of Representatives has trotted in here tonight, having secured a preselection for the Senate. The Senate is almost becoming a retired House for the has-beens of the House of Representatives; which is a pity. At least I never succeeded in getting into the House of Representatives. I am in a slightly different category. What we had tonight was all the poor old failures looking for a vicarious thrill and trying to stop someone else's preselection when they have failed in House of Representatives seats.

We have had some good preselection battles this year. Looking back on it, Liverpool made the semi-finals. There is no doubt about that. There was the fight between Senator Teague, Senator Chapman and Senator Hill, who made the quarter-finals of preselection. But as to the grand final, the all-time champion preselection-there it is, sitting dressed like a canary in the front row. That was the big one, the grandaddy of all preselections. I must say that we on this side had divided loyalties in that preselection.

TALK.START.PARA: —Divided disloyalties.

—Actually, Gough Whitlam once said that the only trouble with Sam Cohen was that he had a conflict of disloyalty. We thought we would actually prefer Senator Chris Puplick as an individual, but then again he is more talented than the other one. It is always better to have the talent put to No. 3 so that, hopefully, he will disappear out of the chamber. Then we looked at the alternative and we had no doubts at all. We all got in behind Senator Puplick, but there was not much we could do.
—A fat lot of good you did.

—A fat lot of good we did, but we tried hard. Anything we could have done to help we would have done. But this is a fairly impotent chamber in helping party preselections, as Senator Baume will find out when the preselection is held at the weekend.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been other interesting preselections. Does the Senate remember the preselection of the honourable member for Berowra, Dr Harry Edwards? What a top one! Forty-eight people turned up, but when the ballot box was opened up there were 49 votes in it. People are still looking for the forty-ninth voter, the invisible man that voted in the Berowra preselection. The most pathetic preselection of all occurred last week. The Opposition knew that there was a preselection on because Senator Calvert, Senator Watson and Senator Newman were jumping on every item so that they could impress everyone back home. That was the wooden spoon preselection of the year. It was really a terrible choice.

We had the great Victorian preselection. Victoria has always had the reputation of being the maddest State politically. We had that screaming in the headlines week after week: `Will Macphee win Goldstein?'; `Won't he win Goldstein?'. It went backwards and forwards-Kroger v. Macphee-week in, week out in the media. What happened after the leadership spill? The candidates all buzzed off down to a Richmond restaurant, drank wine with each other, said what good blokes they were and headed off into Deakin to try to win the preselection there. We had Mr Ken Aldred, the failed member for Henty-who got preselection for Bruce in 1983 because his name started with A and for no other reason-finally dumped out of Bruce. Then there was poor old Shippo, Mr Roger Shipton, who was dumped out of Higgins at last, not for Elliott but for an acolyte of Elliott's. We have had a good preselection season and we have seen a lot of victims.

Next Saturday we are to have another big preselection in Deakin, between Mr Aldred and Mr Macphee. The whole party machine in Victoria is trying to get behind Mr Macphee. They were behind him last preselection, but they had knives in their hands. This time they are behind Mr Macphee. I must correct the record. I saw in the newspapers this morning that Mr Aldred had denied that he tried to join the Australian Labor Party in 1971. He was right on that. Mr Aldred tried to join the Labor Party in 1973. He tried to join the Murrumbeena branch. I personally held up his application because I thought he was a Liberal Party stooge. But a year later he got Liberal Party preselection for the seat of Henty. He is reported in the newspapers this morning as denying that. I say to the preselectors of Deakin: bear that in mind. In 1973 he was almost Comrade Aldred; in 1975 he was MHR for Henty-Liberal Party, if you don't mind.

We can go back over a lot of preselection history. We will not get particularly far. The Opposition can raise some of our classic preselections. There was the one in Shortland in 1971. Do honourable senators remember Peter Solomon? Was that not a bobby-dazzler? All this comes to tonight is that Senator Michael Baume has put together a motley set of allegations against Senator Morris, none of which has held much water. If that is the best that Senator Baume can do, I hope he does a job on me before my next preselection.

TALK.START.PARA: —You haven't faced a preselection.

—In 1979 I faced a preselection. I then faced, I think-and Senator Zakharov was at them all-four State conferences where they tried to roll me. They tried to rewrite the branch rules to write my name into it. They have never been game to have a go since. My day will come when I will turn up and not have the numbers, and I will not whinge.
—I remember what Don Grimes said about you when you first came in.

—Senator Puplick has misquoted what Don Grimes said when I first came in. In any event, I do not hold it against Don because he is doing an excellent job in The Hague. I do not hold it against any of the other people who are serving the interests of this country at our suggestion-not at all. What we have heard from Senator Michael Baume is what people generally call a bucket job. It is not a good one, not a competent one, not even a humorous one; it is a pointless one. The reality is that Senator Morris will romp in at his preselection whenever it is held because he has got the support on the ground. No amount of Opposition senators' rather turgid style here tonight will change that. I interrupted listening to honourable senators to listen to the cricket. We were 1 for 47. Fair dinkum, that is the only wicket that has gone down tonight. Honourable senators opposite have really struck right out. We could be very cruel and start picking off the Opposition side. What about the new senator who put foam rubber up around the division bell because it was too noisy and missed five divisions in a row? We do not want to pick on him tonight, do we? He will not be here much longer so we will not pick on him tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: I say in summary-we have probably delayed the Senate long enough-that Senator Michael Baume was trying to do a bucket job. It has been a second-rate bucket job, not even a professional one. I close on this note because I had to mention it the other day: Senator Michael Baume is a friend of the Australian Labor Party. I hope that Senator Morris, deep in his heart, can forgive him and find him a friend, because, in our hour of need, when we were struggling in the 1987 election, who came to our aid? Who got on to Tasmanian talkback and who delivered the bacon from the Labor Party? `Mr Steve Martin', alias Senator Michael Baume. Thank you very much, Senator Baume. Then when we thought we were in a bit of trouble-the economy may not be going as well as we would like-the Liberal Party has a leadership spill. And the honeymoon period starts. Who does the coup de grace again? Steve Martin, alias Senator Michael Baume, comes to our aid again. He said, `If I was running a Labor Party campaign, that's the way I'd do it'. Thank you very much.

I have only this point in conclusion: Senator Michael Baume is not Secret Agent 143 5/8, member of the New South Wales branch of the Labor Party. I have to deny that scurrilous allegation. I hope that Senator Morris, in his heart, will learn to forgive him. He is a friend of the Labor Party. Over time we will find that he has probably increased Senator Morris's votes at the preselection rather than reduced them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say a few words with regard to the allegations and statements made by Senator Michael Baume tonight. It is amazing the lengths to which some people will go. We have just heard from Senator Michael Baume an attempt to place on record allegations-all untrue-that opponents of mine in the current election for the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union of Australia have been trying to peddle for some time. I make that clear because Senator Michael Baume talked about a court case which took place some three to four weeks ago. That court case was settled. Pat Reeves, the person who is leading the unity ticket, who Senator Michael Baume is supporting, asked his solicitor, through his barrister, on four occasions to settle the case. It was settled. Unfortunately, it was settled before a judge of the Supreme Court on the basis that the contents of the settlement could not be divulged. Senator Michael Baume knows that because I spoke to him, through my research assistant, this morning. Senator Michael Baume was told about it but he still had the audacity to come into this House tonight and raise it. But let us see what Senator Michael Baume is all about. He is all about supporting the Pat Reeves unity team in the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union of Australia. Why is he all about supporting Pat Reeves in that union?
—A good question.

—I will answer that question for the honourable senator. It is because Senator Michael Baume told my research assistant this morning that he was vitally opposed to penalty rates in the hospitality industry. Let us have a look at where Mr Baume fits. It is important for all honourable senators to understand where he sits.
—Senator Morris, you should call Senator Baume by his correct title.

—I ask Senator Baume: Who asked that it be kept secret? Who asked that the document that was before the Supreme Court be kept secret? I would like Senator Baume, through you, Mr President, to tell the Senate tonight who asked him to keep the document secret. The reason it was kept secret was that Senator Baume knew that I could not. I have the document from my solicitor who faxed it through to me today. It is a statement signed by all the people whom he has named tonight and who settled that case before the Supreme Court.
—I said it had been settled.

—Senator Baume said that it had been settled but at the same time he made the innuendo that there were certain amounts of money missing and that there were properties bought. Senator Baume raised the name of Mr Ken Jeffreys, who is the secretary of the union, to try to suggest by innuendo that he was a dishonest person. That is what Senator Baume was trying to do tonight. We were waiting for my election material because the election started yesterday. I have that material. It shows a photo of Senator Baume and Pat Reeves who is leading the unity ticket in the liquor industries ballot which started yesterday. They want to abolish penalty rates. I seek leave to table the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —By attacking me Senator Michael Baume has shown quite clearly how far my opponent, Mr Pat Reeves, is prepared to go to try to sell out the liquor industry members in New South Wales by abolishing their penalty rates.
—I spoke to people in the administrative committee of the Labor Party.
—Did you speak to people?
—Name them.
—Do you want me to?
—Yes. I am on that committee. I want to be free of the allegation-name them.
—Order! Senator Michael Baume, you were heard in relative silence. I think that you should cease interjecting.

—Mr President, I have a point of order. On several occasions the honourable senator has referred to you as Mr Chairman and to Senator Baume as Mr Baume. Could you tell him to correct his language? He has not spoken in the Senate much but he should learn the protocols of the Senate.

—Order! Senator Walters, I told Senator Morris to call Senator Baume `Senator Baume'. I am called Chairman, Deputy President, whatever, during the day. I am aware that the honourable senator has been attacked tonight. I ask him to call me `Mr President' and I am sure he will.

—I certainly will, Mr President, and I am only too proud to do that. Mr Reeves should be ashamed to seek support from a man who is well known for his opposition to penalty rates. Senator Michael Baume should be ashamed at giving support to a dangerous gang which has already indicated that it wants to call national stoppages in regard to certain issues. At the same time our members are disgusted at the Reeves attempt, with friends like Senator Michael Baume, to take over the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union. They are anti-penalty rate campaigners and they want to ensure that penalty rates are eliminated throughout the industry for members of the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union. I have a letter from my barristers on instruction from my solicitor today. I seek leave to have the letter incorporated in Hansard.
—Not until it has been seen.
—Senator Morris, you can show it to the shadow Minister on duty on the other side. He might agree for it to be tabled.
—The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: I have been asked by my instructing solicitors to record certain events which ultimately led to the settlement of the abovementioned matter.
That is Reeves v. Morris. I continue:
To the best of my recollection the following occurred:

(i) The initial and original suggestions for settlement of the matter came from Mr Evatt of Counsel. He invited me, on a number of occasions, to seek instructions to pay his clients various sums of money in settlement of the proceedings.
Having sought those instructions, I then indicated to him that we were not prepared to settle the matter as we were confident of our prospects of success;

(ii) Nearer the time of actual settlement, I had a number of general conversations with Mr Haffenden of the Counsel, who by that stage had replaced Mr Evatt, regarding the hearing of the matter. The general prospects of settlement were discussed and I indicated to Mr Haffenden that, as my client was still confident of his prospects of success in the action, I was not instructed to put any offer of settlement. However, I indicated to Mr Haffenden that, if he had instructions to settle the matter, he should put an offer to me.
Subsequently, Mr Haffenden put an offer of settlement to my instructing solicitor, Mr Ludemann, and me. On instructions, that particular offer was rejected.

(iii) With regard to any allegation of fraud against Senator Morris, at one of the earlier Notices of Motion to strike out the Plaintiff's second or third Statement of Claim (which was successful) I invited Mr Evatt, in open Court, to plead any allegation of fraud that was to be alleged and maintained against Senator Morris.
Mr Evatt indicated in open Court, based upon his instructions no doubt, that there was no allegation of fraud being raised against Senator Morris.

From the evidence led by the Plaintiffs, there was never any evidence of fraud. Further, I note that the full amount that Mr Reeves alleged should have been in the Fund was accounted for. In fact, on uncontradicted evidence, there was a greater amount in the Fund.

The letter is signed by G. S. Charny, QC. Senator Michael Baume has tried to sling mud in this chamber tonight. He has stepped into the gutter and has tried to implicate me in a situation. He knows that I have preselection coming up on Sunday this week. I am pleased to tell the Senate that I have the full support of my Party in New South Wales-left, right and centre. I can assure Senator Baume that he has done the Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union in New South Wales the greatest favour of all time by raising this matter tonight because for the last five months we have tried to prove beyond any doubt that he has been involved with the Pat Reeves gang to try to take control of the Liquor Industries Union in conjunction with a person who is running on that ticket by the name of Heggie. Everyone knows who Heggie is. Heggie works for Qantas Airways Ltd at the airport and is the husband of Mrs Heggie, who is the Liberal mayoress of Fairfield Council. She stood unsuccessfully for the Liberal Party in the seat of Cabramatta against a colleague of ours, Mr Newman.

So let us be clear on where all this stems from. Senator Baume is supporting a person by the name of Bill Wood. Bill Wood was sacked by the union in 1969-not by the union leadership but by the union membership-at the Sydney Town Hall. He was sacked again in 1975 by the Federal Council of the union for the misappropriation of money. That is the sort of person Senator Baume is supporting here tonight. These are the sorts of people whom Senator Baume has put on the record he has been supporting over the last six months. It goes back to 18 months ago when I led him into a trap, when he asked that question and I did not answer it. Senator Graham Richardson would know that because I spoke to the honourable senator about the matter then and told him what it was leading to. He fully agreed that I should not reply to those allegations at that point of time.

We have exposed Senator Baume tonight for what he is. We have exposed the Pat Reeves unity ticket for what it is-a combination of extreme right wing Liberal Party people trying to take over the liquor industries union. The ballot started yesterday. When my members throughout New South Wales read this transcript tomorrow-now that Senator Baume has delivered his seal of approval and come out of the cupboard-I am quite convinced that the John Morris team will be elected by a substantial majority. I am pleased to say that I am quite confident that on Sunday I will be selected as the No. 1 person from the Labor Party to represent New South Wales.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I wish to make a personal explanation. I am not trying to take over the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union of Australia. I have been off the grog for 18 months because of a medical problem. I have no interest in the matter. I have never had any discussions with any member of the liquor industries union, to my recollection. I have had no association, according to my recollection, with any member of the Liquor Industries Union. I have never met Mr Reeves. I have never had anything to do with him. I do not drive a top of the line Mazda. I am not in concert with any gang.

SPEECH.PARA: I am bemused at any suggestion that I have any motive in regard to a liquor industries union election. I can assure you, Mr President, that the issue I raised related to preselection for the Australian Labor Party. I have no interest in the liquor industries union elections. Whether I have any views on the matter of penalty rates is totally immaterial to what I have had to say. To bring that up in some endeavour to associate me with the liquor industries union is absolute nonsense. I am not party to any of the matters that Senator Morris spent most of his time discussing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Monday evening this week, Senator Zakharov tabled a document prepared by an anthropologist entitled On Shaky Ground. She spoke about the Kakadu National Park and the Coronation Hill project in the Northern Territory. Senator Zakharov herself was, I believe, most certainly on shaky ground. Senator Zakharov's assertions about the role of the Northern Territory Minister for Mines and Energy, the Hon. Barry Coulter, in circumstances surrounding the Coronation Hill site are plainly ludicrous. She said that Mr Coulter had put pressure on Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd to put pressure, in turn, on the Jawoyn people for an agreement on sacred sites protection. I have checked this claim with Mr Coulter, who reports that it is merely a rerun of a line promoted by the former director of the Northern Territory Aboriginal Sacred Sites Protection Authority, Mr Bob Ellis, a person who subscribes heavily to conspiracy theories. It is simply not true. Barry Coulter, in the face of apparent conflicting interest about the location of a key Aboriginal site, commissioned an anthropologist, Mr Steven Davis, to report to the Northern Territory Government on the facts of the matter. That report did not sit comfortably with Mr Ellis, who sought in many ways to denigrate it and its author with a series of unpleasant personal attacks. Mr Ellis mounted a year-long campaign on this issue against the Northern Territory Government and others, in particular Mr Coulter. Mr David Cooper, the author of the document tabled by Senator Zakharov, is closely identified with Mr Ellis. Senator Zakharov's comments about Mr Davis should be seen in that light.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable senator also accused Mr Coulter of claiming that a non-Aboriginal person, mining engineer Joe Fisher, had been the custodian of sites in the area for 40 years. It would be a nonsense to suggest such a thing, just as it is a nonsense for Senator Zakharov to suggest that that is what Mr Coulter said. What he said was that Mr Fisher had brought to the attention of the Northern Territory Administration in the early 1950s the fact that a number of sites significant to Aboriginal people were located in the South Alligator Valley, and that most of the information about sacred sites being promoted today by various organisations actually emanated from Mr Fisher's studies. In other words, it was thanks to Joe Fisher that such sites were identified and the first steps taken for protection. As the Aboriginal Land Commissioner has noted, the Jawoyn people had not had any connections with the region for many years before Mr Fisher's research. Senator Zakharov has sought to make mischief out of this undoubted fact. She is acting as a mouthpiece for white activists in this matter, and not on behalf of the Aboriginal people themselves.

Senator Zakharov points out that she has drawn upon the report which she has tabled, titled On Shaky Ground, authored by Mr David Cooper of the Aboriginal Sacred Sites Protection Authority. Senator Zakharov makes it clear that Mr Cooper's report has made use of the original video material compiled by Mr Davis in the course of his inquiry. The document which Senator Zakharov tabled states on page 4 that the video `is currently the subject of the legal action'. The Aboriginal Sacred Sites Protection Authority gave an undertaking to honour restrictions on the usage and availability of this material, which is the subject of legal proceedings before the Supreme Court of the Northern Territory. That undertaking does not appear to have been honoured. Mr Cooper's paper, tabled by Senator Zakharov, and the honourable senator's subsequent use of that material, is a breach of those undertakings. Senator Zakharov clearly abused her parliamentary privilege and has put herself above the law in ignoring the restrictions placed on this material in the process of Supreme Court proceedings. Mr Davis has at all times complied with the undertakings not to disclose any such material which is subject to the present proceedings in the Supreme Court of the Northern Territory.

Senator Zakharov also states that a photograph of a restricted Bula painting which recently appeared in the Australian newspaper she believed to have originated from Mr Davis. This is absolutely false. Mr Davis did not take that photograph, nor did he send that photograph to the Australian or any other publication. Senator Zakharov states that she was disturbed to discover material in the video shown to women. Senator Zakharov may recall that Mr Davis pointed out to the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts that the video tape was, in terms of Aboriginal tradition, restricted and should not be seen by Aboriginal women or uninitiated men and that it was left to Senator Zakharov to make her own decision as to whether she should see it or not. Senator Zakharov will also recall that she stated that it was her standing as a senator which she felt would exempt her from the traditional Aboriginal restrictions which apply to women. She made her own decision to see the video tape material. However, Senator Zakharov's conversation with Mr Davis on this point was not recorded in the Hansard as Senator Zakharov had failed to direct the recorders to proceed with recording the conversation at the outset of the in camera evidence. It was only when Senator Zakharov was reminded by Senator Townley of this lapse in recording of the in camera material that she then directed the recording to continue. However, it would seem that Senator Zakharov now conveniently has used her ineptitude in the management as a chairperson of the Committee to absolve herself from having breached traditional Aboriginal restrictions. Let me remind Senator Zakharov that within Aboriginal tradition the traditional penalty for the breach of such traditional restrictions by a woman would normally be death by spearing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not serious enough.

—Maybe not. I expect that Senator Zakharov hopes that her position as a senator still exempts her from Aboriginal restrictions. Senator Zakharov also uses the same argument when she states that the Aboriginal custodians have been denied natural justice in that the video transcript, as presented by Mr Davis, was not made available to the Aboriginal custodians to check the integrity of the transcript.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Zakharov should also be reminded that Mr Davis pointed out in that same initial in camera conversation, which she failed to have recorded, that it was only the viewing of the video material which was restricted in Aboriginal material as it shows paintings and elements which were restricted within Aboriginal tradition. Mr Davis clearly pointed out that he did not wish the transcripts of the video conversations to be restricted but, rather, a public document. It was Senator Zakharov who asked for the transcript material to be incorporated into the Hansard as in camera evidence.

When the in camera proceedings before the Senate Committee on Wednesday, 29 October 1986, were forwarded to Mr Davis for his perusal, he contacted the Secretary to the Committee and again pointed out that it was not his wish that the transcript of the video tape be held in camera but, rather, that it be a public document. He was advised that it was best for the time being to leave the material in the in camera evidence and that the option would be available in the future to have the restrictions lifted and the material subsequently be made publicly available.

Senator Zakharov states that Mr Davis's report resulted in an inquiry into the Aboriginal Sacred Sites Authority. Senator Zakharov further points out that the Sacred Sites Review Committee, which conducted the inquiry into the Authority, did not include the issue of Coronation Hill in its final report. If Senator Zakharov had researched her information adequately, she would have found that the Review Committee decided that it would not address the matter of Coronation Hill in its report as the Review Committee simply did not want to prejudice the outcome of proceedings before the Supreme Court of the Northern Territory, and Senator Zakharov would have done well to have followed the same lines.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tambling has made a number of allegations. I do not have the material before me to refute them. I will certainly read what he has had to say and probably will reply at a later time. I say categorically that on no occasion have I ever knowingly viewed material which was restricted to men only. To my memory, the conversation which Senator Tambling claims took place with Mr Steven Davis is not fact.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the Senate's attention tonight to the parlous condition of the Cain Government's WorkCare scheme in Victoria and to give the Senate some details of just one of the huge number of rorts that are making a major contribution to this situation. WorkCare in Victoria is but a step away from bankruptcy. The scheme has been in existence for only some five years, but already its unfunded liabilities have climbed to around $4 billion. These are the liabilities of the taxpayers of Victoria. In the last 24 hours, Premier Cain has put Victorians on notice for a horror State Budget in August. He is reported in today's press as having said:

SPEECH.PARA: Whatever way you look at it the numbers just don't add up. We're going to be spending less this year than last year because we haven't got it to spend.

That would have to be the understatement of the year. When we take into account WorkCare's $4 billion of unfunded liabilities, we realise that not only WorkCare but the Government of Victoria is bankrupt. The Victorian Government has shown a cynical disregard for the interests of the State by refusing to take action on WorkCare. The Treasurer, Mr Jolly, has had a report by an all-party parliamentary committee inquiry into WorkCare since July 1988. He has taken no action on it whatsoever. The reason is that the Victorian unions, now led by John Halfpenny in his capacity as Secretary of the Victorian Trades Hall Council, have refused to give their agreement to cutting out the scandalous waste, inefficiency and fraud that is occurring. I use the word `fraud' advisedly. There is mounting evidence to show the extent of that fraud. Tonight I want to reveal just one example of it, but that example can be multiplied one thousand fold.

Much of the work which has led to these disclosures has been done by Victorian Liberal State shadow Ministers and, in particular, Mr Phil Gude and Mr Alan Stockdale. They deserve the thanks of every Victorian for their efforts. So serious is the situation that Mr Gude has today called for the indemnification of all people employed by doctors, health professionals, lawyers, claims agents and private investigation firms who come forward with information to assist in stopping the multimillion dollar rip-offs that are occurring. This call by Mr Gude follows a similar one last week by the Victorian Allied Health Professionals Association. Two members of that association, who were employees of a private rehabilitation provider, were sacked last month for providing information to the Victorian Accident Rehabilitation Council, known as VARC. Despite repeated requests, Victorian Accident Rehabilitation Council has not been prepared to provide any form of indemnity to the two persons.

It is quite intolerable that the only casualties where rorts and abuses by employing private rehabilitation providers are exposed are the employees who had the courage and the integrity to expose the rorts and abuses. According to advice I have received, there is strong evidence to indicate that VARC is engaged in a conspiracy designed to cover up a multimillion dollar Workcare rehabilitation scandal. The Victorian Treasurer has not even been prepared to hold a full public inquiry into what may well be the biggest public scandal ever in Victoria's history. The Premier, Mr Cain, should sack Mr Jolly immediately if he has any sense of propriety or integrity and any concern at all for the interests of Victoria, because the Treasurer is guilty of gross negligence. So too is the Premier.

I want now to provide the Senate with details to support the grave allegations I am making tonight. I will do this by reference to the case involving the two dismissed employees of a private rehabilitation provider, to which I have already referred. The two dismissed employees are Mr Nigel Reece and Mr Brendan O'Kane. The firm which employed them until their dismissal last month is CPS Rehabilitation Service, a firm of occupational health consultants. The firm has offices in Victoria, Sydney and Adelaide. Mr Reece was the firm's manager for the Ford Motor Co. account. Mr O'Kane was a rehabilitation consultant at the Ford Motor Co. of Australia in Geelong. In March of this year, and again in May, Mr Reece advised the General Manager (Rehabilitation Management) of VARC, and VARC's legal advisers, Sly and Weigall, in writing that many hundreds of CPS invoices were billed to the WorkCare rehabilitation payments agency for services provided by specific CPS consultants when, apparently, no such service was in fact provided by the specified consultant. Mr Reece also advised VARC that all such non-commencement billings to the WorkCare rehabilitation payments agency, and other authorised payment agencies, were stored in the CPS computer database, and that this was readily accessible.

On 30 March 1989 Mr Reece wrote to VARC advising that between November 1987 and mid-1988 CPS received overpayments for WorkCare billed services totalling $97,550. This sum comprised duplicated payments, overpayments and payments for non-CPS cases. Mr Reece said that CPS isolated these overpayments from general revenue and held them in a `suspense account'. At the end of the 1987-88 financial year, the $97,550 was transferred out of the suspense account, written into profit, then transferred back into the suspense account. In November 1988, on the decision of a full CPS board meeting, the total was transferred into general revenue, and hence into profit. Mr Reece also provided this and related information to Sly and Weigall in a conference. I am advised that he has not been given access to the transcript of that conference. On 18 January 1989, in conference with Sly and Weigall, Mr Bernard O'Kane provided additional evidence of fraudulent billing by CPS.

Mr President, it is a very detailed and involved case and I seek leave to table the following documents, having sought the Government's permission: the record of the conference held on 18 January 1989 between Mr O'Kane and Sly and Weigall; a file note by Mr Reece dated 18 January 1989; a memorandum dated 14 March 89 from Mr Reece to VARC and to Sly and Weigall outlining details of the CPS overpayments; a letter from Mr Reece to VARC dated 30 March 1989 giving further details of the overpayments; a letter dated 4 May 1989 plus attachments from Mr Reece to VARC giving details of specific CPS overpayment invoices billed to WorkCare Rehabilitation Payments Agency; and a letter dated 31 May 1989 from the principal of CPS to Mr Reece offering a settlement on condition that Mr Reece dropped his legal action against CPS for unfair dismissal. Part of the CPS offer was that, `No further statements whatsoever regarding CPS to be made to any third party by you', and that, `The terms of this agreement be kept confidential'.

Mr Reece, needless to say, has rejected this brazen bribery attempt out of hand. If the evidence I have provided to the Senate tonight is typical of the fraud that is occurring within the WorkCare system in Victoria--

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you want to table those documents?
—Yes, I seek leave to table the documents.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President. If it is typical of the fraud that is occurring within the WorkCare system in Victoria-as I said at the outset, there is mounting evidence to suggest that it is just the tip of the iceberg-no wonder the scheme has unfunded liabilities of around $4 billion. This is a scandal of monumental proportions. It will bankrupt WorkCare and it could bankrupt Victoria. It is unbelievable that the Victorian Government has refused to take action on WorkCare. That it has not raises another fundamental question, and that is: What is the Victorian Government trying to hide?

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.53 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 28 February 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: How many complaints has the Government received regarding the $1 and $2 coins.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has received 435 pieces of correspondence conveying complaints over the $2 coin. Some of this correspondence reflected the views of more than one person. On the basis of the records available, there were at least 206 written complaints about the $1 coin. The bulk of the complaints about both $1 and $2 coins were received in the period immediately following their issues to the public.

The experience in Australia and elsewhere is that it takes some time for people to become accustomed to a change in the currency, something which affects everyone's daily life. While it is common for there to be complaints immediately following any change to the coinage, these usually decline as people adjust to the change.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 3 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With regard to an article in the Australian Financial Review entitled `Plastic power ready to take over shopping', will every major bank, building society and credit union in Australia be linked by a cashless, plastic network before the end of the month of March 1989.
(2) What measures are available to the Australian Government to regulate such potential initiatives from Australian or overseas banks, building societies and credit unions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The electronic funds processing at point of sale (EFTPOS) systems, which allow customers to use plastic cards to transfer funds from their accounts with financial institutions directly to retailers' accounts, are becoming more widespread in Australia although the volume of transactions carried on EFTPOS systems is still not large. A key feature of EFTPOS developments in Australia has been the increasing number of linkages between the systems of different financial institutions. Most of the EFTPOS systems of the major and state banks have now been linked. Most other banks and most building societies and credit unions are able to offer their customers access to the terminals of at least one of the major or state banks.

(2) The development of EFTPOS system has been closely monitored by the Australian Payments System Council. The Council, established by the Treasurer in 1984 and chaired by a senior officer of the Reserve Bank, is required to foster interconnection between payments systems and to ensure that competition amongst all financial institutions benefits consumers. In September 1986 Commonwealth and State Ministers endorsed a code of conduct on electronic funds transfer systems drawn up by a Working Group comprising representatives of Commonwealth and State Governments. The code carefully defines the rights and obligations of users and providers of electronic funds transfer systems (including EFTPOS). The code requires institutions which issue plastic cards for customer use in electronic terminals to, inter alia:

(i) establish in their electronic banking contracts certain rights and obligations, particularly in the important areas of liability for unauthorised electronic transactions and liability for technical malfunctions;
(ii) follow certain minimum information disclosure requirements in providing these services; and
(iii) establish procedures to ensure that disputed electronic transactions are centrally recorded.

The code is not statutory but the conditions of use documents issued by institutions to cover users of plastic cards in electronic terminals are legally binding. The Working Group which drew up the code has been liaising with financial institutions since 1986 to ensure that card issuing institutions publish conditions of use documents which conform with the requirements of the code.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 6 April 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Minister provide details of any studies, published or unpublished, which describe radiological hazards to workers from mineral sands concentrates of ilmenite, leucoxene, rutile, zircon, monazite, xenotime, garnet, kyanite, upgraded ilmenite (synthetic rutile), and any other notifiable concentrates as produced by the mineral sands industry; if not, can the Minister confirm that these materials are harmless in terms of radiological effects and chemical toxicity; if not, why not.

(2) Can the Minister provide a list of epidemological studies which have been carried out in the workplace of industries involved in the production of substances listed in part (1), concerned with radiological or chemical hazards to workers or the public; if not, why not.
(3) Can the materials listed in (1) above interact synergistically with other carcinogens and thus increase the possible carcinogenic effects over those induced by either carcinogen alone.
(4) Which of the materials listed in (1) above are initiators and which are promoters of cancers in workers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I have provided Senator Vallentine with a listing of studies known to the Australian Radiation Laboratory.

I am advised that the available studies show that there are two major pathways for exposure of mineral sands workers to radiation: external gamma radiation for some of the concentrates, particularly monazite and xenotime, and internal radiation from radioactivity in dust inhaled during the secondary separation process. The radiation arises from the natural thorium and uranium series radionuclides present in the ore.

The Australian studies show that, in general, radiation doses received by workers are likely to be below the limits recommended by the National Health and Medical Research Council. However, in some areas of the secondary separation process, there are high concentrations of airborne dust containing radioactivity. Continuous occupation of these areas without respiratory protection equipment could lead to unacceptably high intake of radioactivity by inhalation. Consequently, dust masks should be worn by workers in these areas and occupancy should be restricted by designating them `controlled areas'. I am advised that the industry is investigating strategies for inhibiting dust generation at source.
(2) No epidemological studies of mineral sands workers are available to my Department.

(3) I am advised that no evidence is available on possible synergistic effects of the materials listed in (1) with known carcinogens. The subject has been studied in a related area, namely that of lung cancer risk from inhalation of radon daughters. There is evidence to suggest a synergistic effect between radon daughter exposure and cigarette smoking. (See `Lung cancer risk from indoor exposures to radon daughters'. Publication 50 of the International Commission on Radiological Protection, Pergamon Press, Oxford, 1987).

(4) A detailed understanding of the mechanism of cancer induction by radiation is not yet available. Radiation induced cancers could be associated with the materials listed in (1) through their various contents of thorium series and uranium series radionuclides. The extent to which radiation is an initiator or promoter of cancer is not clear, although there is some evidence to suggest that the available data is best described by models which attribute an initiating role to radiation. (See `Health effects models developed from the 1988 UNSCEAR report', publication NRPB-R226, National Radiological Protection Board, Chilton, UK, 1989, and `Sources, effects and risks of ionizing radiation', UNSCEAR 1988 Report to the General Assembly, United Nations, New York, 1988).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 4 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Department have a 008 number which may be used by Gold Coast residents who wish to contact officers of the Department in Brisbane; if so, is this number listed in the Gold Coast telephone directory; if not, will the number be listed in future editions of the Gold Coast telephone directory and what is the number.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: While the Department of the Treasury does not have an office in Brisbane, it does have a 008 number which may be used by Gold Coast residents. The number (008-020-008) is listed in telephone directories Australia-wide, with the exception of Canberra.
